headline: Vance Tells Rogan: Teens Become Trans to Get Into Ivy League
abstract: Appearing on Joe Rogan’s podcast, Senator JD Vance also said that liberal women celebrate their abortions and that Donald Trump would win the “normal gay guy vote.”
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio criticized what he called “gender transition craziness,” spoke dismissively of women he claimed were “celebrating” their abortions and said that studies “connect testosterone levels in young men with conservative politics” during a three-hour episode of “The Joe Rogan Experience” that was released on Thursday.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 1, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An obituary on Sunday about Phil Lesh, the longtime bassist of the Grateful Dead, referred incorrectly to hepatitis C, which he contracted at one point. It is a viral infection; it is not caused by alcohol abuse.

headline: Man Who Killed Hundreds of Eagles and Hawks Gets Nearly 4 Years in Prison
abstract: Travis John Branson was part of a conspiracy that killed 3,600 birds, prosecutors said. He also trafficked and sold bird parts on the black market.
lead_paragraph: A Washington man who killed hundreds of eagles and hawks in Montana that he later helped traffic and sell on the black market was sentenced to nearly four years in prison on Thursday, prosecutors said.

headline: Packed Like Sardines
abstract: Spencer Leach opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: How Heidi Klum Transformed Into E.T. for Halloween
abstract: The model and television host dressed as the alien from Steven Spielberg’s 1982 film for her annual New York City costume party.
lead_paragraph: This Halloween, Heidi Klum is wearing an adult diaper.

headline: Elite School Will Provide Counselors for Students Distressed by Election
abstract: Attendance on Wednesday, or whatever day the results are announced, is optional for high school students at the Ethical Culture Fieldston School in New York City, families were told.
lead_paragraph: One of New York City’s elite private schools told families on Thursday that “students who feel too emotionally distressed” the day after Election Day will be excused from classes, and that psychologists will be available during the week to provide counseling.

headline: Why Germany’s Resistance to an Italian Bank Takeover Is Raising Eyebrows
abstract: Despite an openness to cross-border mergers, Germany has pushed back against talk of the Italian lender UniCredit’s acquiring Commerzbank.
lead_paragraph: Germans are eager to sell hundreds of billions of euros’ worth of goods in Italy, while drinking its wines, skiing its Alps and sunning on its beaches.

headline: A Relationship Built on Music and Laughter
abstract: “We make each other laugh every day,” Jeffrey Grossman said of his bond with Karl Hinze, whom he met in 2009.
lead_paragraph: When Jeffrey Adam Grossman and Karl Joseph Hinze messaged each other on the dating site OkCupid in May 2009, Mr. Grossman had reservations about Mr. Hinze’s age. “I was 26, and he was 20, which seemed slightly scandalous,” Mr. Grossman said. “I decided to keep talking to him because we had both answered what seemed like hundreds of questions, and the site promised that we would be a great romantic match.”

headline: Can Quake-Prone Japan Ever Embrace Nuclear Energy Again?
abstract: The government, its makeup in flux after the governing party lost seats this week, will soon need to make decisions that will shape Japan’s future nuclear policy.
lead_paragraph: A decade after one of the most devastating atomic-energy disasters in history, Japan was finally getting closer to reviving nuclear power.

headline: They Realized They Were Singing the Same Tune
abstract: When the opera singers Nicholas Martorano and Elizabeth Novella first met, they knew something was meant to be.
lead_paragraph: In Nicholas Vincent Martorano’s eyes, he and Elizabeth Wheatley Novella were destined to meet each other.

headline: Did He ‘Put Something in My Shrimp Fried Rice’? Maybe a Love Potion.
abstract: Darian Aaron wasn’t looking for anything serious when he downloaded Tinder four years ago. Then he met Marcus Gresham.
lead_paragraph: Months before he met Marcus Rafeal Donte Gresham on Tinder in November 2020, Darian Lamon Aaron got behind the wheel of his Toyota Camry and cried from Miami to Atlanta.

headline: When Eve and Eve Bit the Apple
abstract: In this essay from 2016, a writer struggles to reconcile her love for a woman with being “a good Christian girl.”
lead_paragraph: In celebration of Modern Love’s 20th anniversary last month, we published a special package of articles about the column’s history and impact. To learn about the origin of Modern Love, read about seven ways to love better, see how the longtime illustrator creates his images, and much more, go to nytimes.com/modernlove. In this space, as each week’s Modern Love column, we are republishing four “classic” essays from earlier years that especially moved us.

headline: They Love John Fluevog Shoes So Much They Married at One of His Stores
abstract: Amber Walker and Ron Dutt held a surprise wedding during the “Flummunity Fest,” a fan-driven gathering for admirers of the designer.
lead_paragraph: The day before her wedding, Amber Dawne Walker perched on the teal velvet couch upstairs at the flagship John Fluevog shoe store in Vancouver, British Columbia, clutching the hand of her fiancé, Ron Amar Dutt. “This is just like my dream,” she said.

headline: Quote of the Day: Billionaires Make Bets on Control
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “If you want to protect your business interests, cowardice is a rational thing.”

headline: Mexico’s New President Faces Her First Major Crisis
abstract: A confrontation between the judiciary and the governing party will test Claudia Sheinbaum’s leadership and offer a window into how she will wield power.
lead_paragraph: Presidents are often defined by their first crisis, and Mexico’s new leader is facing a big one: a clash of democratic institutions that could fundamentally upend the country.

headline: In Spanish Town Devastated by Flood, a Grim Search for Bodies
abstract: Rescuers in Paiporta, where more than 60 people died, were still pulling bodies from the mud. “We are alive,” a resident said. “But we have lost everything.”
lead_paragraph: Plates with half-eaten dinners were still sitting on the white tablecloths in the nursing home’s dining hall on Thursday, amid muddy and overturned wheelchairs and walkers. Six people died in the facility on Tuesday, as a raging river exploded out of its banks and swept through villages and towns around the Spanish city of Valencia, on the country’s east-central coast.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Devastating floods in Spain.
lead_paragraph: Some of the worst floods in decades in eastern Spain trapped thousands of people in vehicles and homes, killed at least 158 people and left others missing. See photos and videos.

headline: Word of the Day: retaliation
abstract: This word has appeared in 967 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word retaliation has appeared in 967 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 23 in “Why Is Israel Poised to Attack Iran?” by Matthew Mpoke Bigg:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Trashes Trump’s ‘Cosplay Garbage Man’
abstract: Kimmel said that when Trump delivered a speech while wearing an orange safety vest, it was “like a 4-year-old who wants to wear his costume to school.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Botswana Voters Hand Governing Party a Stunning Rebuke
abstract: After 58 years, the Botswana Democratic Party lost its majority in Parliament, becoming the latest long-dominant party in southern Africa to fall from power.
lead_paragraph: The party that has governed Botswana since it became independent in 1966 received a stunning rebuke in national elections this week, losing its majority in Parliament for the first time, according to results announced on Friday morning.

headline: Trump Assails Liz Cheney and Imagines Guns ‘Shooting at Her’
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris said that anyone who uses “that kind of violent rhetoric is clearly disqualified, and unqualified, to be president.”
lead_paragraph: Election 2024 live updates: Follow our coverage of Trump and Harris on Election Day.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: These Are the Best Places to Cheer for the New York City Marathon
abstract: Here’s our guide to picking a good cheering location, whether you are following one runner’s progress or looking for a good spot to park yourself for the day.
lead_paragraph: For runners of the New York City Marathon, support from the crowds gathered along the course is a highlight, from the first cheers coming off the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge to the last as the race concludes along Central Park South.

headline: Why There’s a Fierce Pushback Against 5 N.Y.C. Ballot Proposals
abstract: A broad coalition opposes the citywide questions placed on the ballot by Mayor Eric Adams’s charter revision commission, saying they weaken City Council power.
lead_paragraph: Amid the festive sounds and alluring scents of food drifting through the Latin Night Market in Upper Manhattan, Ana María Archila, co-director of the New York Working Families Party, was engaged on a different agenda.

headline: Sprinting to Election Day, in Spanish
abstract: A team of editors and translators help communicate election coverage to Spanish-speaking readers, which comes with its own set of unique challenges.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is four days away. Every day of the countdown, Inside The Times will share an article about how our election coverage works. Today, a journalist shares how The Times translates its political coverage into Spanish.

headline: Ripped Test
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Breeders’ Cup Arrives in California, Where Horse Racing Is Struggling
abstract: The state looms large in the sport’s history, and its tracks are stunning. But horse racing in California is going broke.
lead_paragraph: Bing Crosby built the Del Mar racetrack in the 1930s, when horse racing’s popularity in the American sporting landscape was second only to baseball. His pals W.C. Fields, Ava Gardner, Desi Arnaz and Lucille Ball roamed its clubhouse. Crosby insisted on a late first post time — 2 p.m. — so they could golf (wink, wink) beforehand or recover from the night before.

headline: In Subway Chokehold Trial, Lawyers Spar Over Daniel Penny’s Chokehold
abstract: Mr. Penny is charged with manslaughter in the May 2023 killing of Jordan Neely, a homeless man menacing passengers in a subway car.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors and defense lawyers agreed on a couple of points as they opened a closely watched trial in Manhattan on Friday: Jordan Neely, a 30-year-old homeless man, had been menacing passengers in a subway car. And Daniel Penny, a former Marine, put him in a chokehold to subdue him.

headline: más y más y más flores
abstract: During the Day of the Dead, the cempasúchil, or marigold, is believed to guide spirits back home. In Mexico City, people who lost a loved one to Covid use the flower to honor their dead.
lead_paragraph: During the Day of the Dead, the cempasúchil, or marigold, is believed to guide spirits back home. In Mexico City, people who lost a loved one to Covid use the flower to honor their dead.

headline: For Day of the Dead, a Burst of Flowers to Honor the Departed
abstract: During the Day of the Dead, the cempasúchil, or marigold, is believed to guide spirits back home. In Mexico City, people who lost a loved one to Covid use the flower to honor their dead.
lead_paragraph: The life of the marigold, known as the cempasúchil in Mexico, reflects our own: the plant sprouts, grows, flowers and dies. The flowers’ yellow and orange glow is ubiquitous across Mexico every year in the first few days of November, during Day of the Dead, as families place cempasúchil flowers on altars and at cemeteries to create a path to guide their loved ones back home.

headline: Can Axions Save the Universe?
abstract: The hunt for dark matter is shifting from particles to waves named after a laundry detergent.
lead_paragraph: The search is on for some of the flimsiest lumps of matter and energy ever dreamed up by physicists. They are darker than night, barely more substantial than a thought, and named after a laundry detergent. But axions, as they are called, could constitute most of the matter in our universe, forming the unseen skeletons of galaxies and chains of light that adorn the skies of astronomers. Confirmation of their existence would upset some of the deepest theories of nature.

headline: She Was the First Nicaraguan to Be Crowned Miss Universe. Can She Ever Go Home?
abstract: After Sheynnis Palacios won the Miss Universe title, her country’s government arrested the family members of the Miss Nicaragua contest director, and she hasn’t returned home since.
lead_paragraph: At a custom clothing shop in Manhattan earlier this year, Sheynnis Palacios was getting measured for new clothes. Miss Universe, after all, always needs fresh outfits.

headline: Xenophobia and Hate Speech Are Spiking Heading Into the Election
abstract: Leading Republican politicians and lax social media controls have contributed to a proliferation of hate rhetoric and anti-immigrant sentiment.
lead_paragraph: The last time there was a presidential election, the country was coming off a summer of protests in favor of greater racial equality. Support for increased immigration was at the highest level ever polled.

headline: What to Know About ‘The Apprentice,’ the Controversial Donald Trump Biopic
abstract: The film, now available on demand, followed a thorny path to distribution — including the threat of a lawsuit by its subject.
lead_paragraph: If you know one thing about the new Donald Trump biopic “The Apprentice,” it’s likely this: The former president doesn’t want you to see it.

headline: The Anti-D.E.I. Agitator That Big Companies Fear Most
abstract: From his home in Tennessee, the social media rabble-rouser Robby Starbuck is waging war on “woke” policies at places like Lowe’s and Ford. His timing is impeccable.
lead_paragraph: In early June, Robby Starbuck sat on the screened-in patio of his home in suburban Tennessee and recorded an eight-minute monologue on his mobile phone — a no-frills, TikTok-style video entitled “Exposed: Tractor Supply Went Woke.”

headline: When the Price of Your Burrito Clashes With Your ‘Reference Price’
abstract: The term refers to what we have internalized as the fair price for a product or service. It’s often out of sync with what things now actually cost.
lead_paragraph: After two years of the highest inflation since the 1980s, the problem of rapid price increases appears largely under control, according to most indicators. But that’s not how consumers experience it.

headline: ‘It’s Time!’ Mariah Carey Reflects on 30 Years as Queen of Christmas
abstract: Getting her usual early start on the holiday, the powerhouse vocalist and songwriter looks back on the phenomenon she created.
lead_paragraph: When the record company came knocking, Mariah Carey wasn’t sure about making a Christmas album.

headline: Repression Intensifies in the Country Hosting a Major Climate Meeting
abstract: Human rights watchdogs say Azerbaijan is in the midst of a vicious campaign of repression. But in global geopolitics, this energy-rich Caucasus country now has a lot of leverage.
lead_paragraph: In the months leading up to a high-profile global climate summit in November, the government of Azerbaijan has been intensely preparing for its role as host, renovating building facades, training volunteers and retrofitting a stadium for tens of thousands of delegates.

headline: Inside a Deadly Southern California Jail System: 5 Takeaways
abstract: Troubling patterns across the Riverside County jail system put detainees at risk.
lead_paragraph: She was 21. She had crossed America on a road trip and was excited about staying in California. But over months, she was living on the streets and struggling. After she trespassed on private property and had a confrontation with the landowner, she was jailed on misdemeanor charges.

headline: Her Stomach Pain Was Unbearable. What Was Causing It?
abstract: The terrible pain started a week earlier, and she had already been to the emergency room twice.
lead_paragraph: “You need to go back to the hospital,” the visiting nurse declared shortly after entering the 68-year-old woman’s bedroom. The patient’s hair was matted, her face pale and dotted with sweat. She moaned softly as she shifted in the bed, the tangled sheets a testament to her search for a comfortable position.

headline: How Wagner’s Ruthless Image Crumbled in Mali
abstract: The Russian mercenary group operated with little pushback in the West African nation — until it launched one of its most ambitious missions.
lead_paragraph: For years, Russia has promoted the Wagner mercenary group to authoritarian leaders in Africa as a force of fearsome warriors who could protect leaders’ grip on power and help their armies reclaim territories from armed groups.

headline: The Deadliest Year Inside One of America’s Deadliest Jail Systems
abstract: Riverside County, Calif., reported its highest detainee death count in decades, including multiple suicides that reveal deep institutional problems.
lead_paragraph: Alicia Upton paced the concrete floor of her jail cell. She looked around the cramped quarters. Then she pressed the alert button on an intercom attached to the wall.

headline: A Prickly Martha Stewart Makes for a Bracing Netflix Portrait
abstract: “Martha,” from R.J. Cutler, argues that she was ahead of her time. But though she sits for a lengthy interview, this isn’t hagiography.
lead_paragraph: The re-evaluation of maligned celebrities — especially women who reached the height of fame in the 1990s — has become its own mini-genre of pop culture. Often the story tells a bigger tale: a culture bent on taking down successful women, or beautiful ones, or just ones who accidentally strayed into the spotlight.

headline: The Deep Roots of 4 of Donald Trump’s Nativist Remarks
abstract: In the former president’s pitch to voters, historians hear echoes of the nation’s inescapable xenophobic history.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s third run for the White House has neared its end the same way his first one started: with relentless dehumanizing portrayals of immigrants.

headline: As Famine Stalks Gaza, Farmers Lament Their Many Losses
abstract: After more than a year of war, farmers have lost land, equipment and sometimes their lives.
lead_paragraph: Farmers in the Gaza Strip once tended eggplants, peppers and tomatoes in modest plots squeezed between the territory’s urban sprawl and the watchtowers of the Israeli border wall.

headline: Working-Class Voters Are Pivotal. Both Candidates Are Vying for Their Support.
abstract: Kamala Harris’s plans offer a bigger boost for the working class, but Donald Trump seems to be convincing voters.
lead_paragraph: Bernadette Daywalt had yet to decide whom to vote for in the presidential election. But the 69-year-old retiree said her decision would probably come down to economics.

headline: Justice Dept. Sues Rocket Mortgage for Appraisal Discrimination
abstract: After a white appraiser slashed the value of a Black woman’s duplex, the Justice Department sued all involved in the assessment, including the nation’s largest lender.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, Francesca Cheroutes decided to make some improvements to her six-bedroom duplex in Denver. She installed new gutters and added new countertops and bathroom lighting.

headline: Why There’s Hope for U.S. Factory Towns Laid Low by the ‘China Shock’
abstract: Communities that suffered the worst of plant closings in recent decades are now gaining an outsize share of fresh investment and new jobs.
lead_paragraph: For much of the last half century, economic life in the heart of North Carolina has been dominated by factory closings, joblessness and downgraded expectations. Textile mills and furniture plants have been undercut by low-priced imports from Mexico and China. Tobacco processing jobs have disappeared.

headline: How Teens Are Handling a Flood of Election Misinformation
abstract: Teens share their best advice for spotting misinformation and staying sharp during a turbulent election season.
lead_paragraph: This presidential election year, young Americans are navigating a chaotic world of information, often with limited tools to distinguish what’s credible, what’s questionable and what’s downright false.

headline: There Is a Silver Lining in This Tense Election Year
abstract: Widespread dissatisfaction with American politics can lead to major political reform.
lead_paragraph: As we move closer to Election Day, most Americans are angry, exhausted and dissatisfied with the current state of our politics. Only 4 percent of survey respondents said the political system was working extremely well or even very well. Sixteen percent said they trusted the federal government always or most of the time, a historical low going back nearly 70 years. Trust in Congress is near record lows.

headline: This 300-Square-Foot Cabin Can Stretch to 500, Solarium Included
abstract: Post-pandemic, a lawyer decided she wanted a new life raising sheep. She bought land in Vermont and hired a Dutch designer to build her a shape-shifting home.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic caused many people to reconsider what they wanted out of life. And for some, like Yvette Lanneaux, that introspective moment inspired dramatic change.

headline: 4 Surprising Things We Learned From the John Williams Documentary
abstract: A new Disney+ film about the prolific film composer chronicles his life and career, with a focus on his famous music for movies including “Jaws” and “Star Wars.”
lead_paragraph: The composer John Williams is responsible for some of the most recognizable music in film history: the epic fanfares in “Star Wars,” the two-note dread of “Jaws” and too many other examples to name without sounding like an IMDb tour of popular American cinema.

headline: On Marathon Sunday, Go to Carnegie Hall. Or See a Dog Movie.
abstract: Nov. 3 is the date for the big race, but there are other things going on. It’ll just be a little harder to get to them.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at what else will be going on as thousands of runners pound their way from Staten Island to Central Park in the New York City Marathon on Sunday. We’ll also look at an audit that found management problems in an important rental assistance program.

headline: Kwame Onwuachi Is a Whole New Kind of Celebrity Chef
abstract: With a raft of endorsement deals, star appearances and a new restaurant in Washington, he’s won fame and clout that stretch far beyond the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: For a chef who had opened a new restaurant an hour ago, Kwame Onwuachi looked very calm. The place is called Sirius, and it is a four-seat tasting counter inside another restaurant, Dogon. Mr. Onwuachi opened Dogon itself a month earlier, on Sept. 9, inside the Salamander Washington DC hotel.

headline: How a Tiny Vineyard Along an Interstate May Reshape the Wine Industry
abstract: With eight rows of vines in San Francisco and a vision of inclusivity, Christopher Renfro and the Two Eighty Project are training the next generation of winemakers.
lead_paragraph: Alemany Farm ripples with life on a steep hillside in San Francisco. Rows of broccoli and collards, tomatillos, chiles and herbs, stands of cherry and plum trees — all this bounty is available free to the public. There’s even a tiny vineyard, a scruffy eight rows, the only one in the city.

headline: Luther Vandross and the Sound That Could Fill Hearts, or Break Them
abstract: He was hounded by a fat-phobic press, but as Dawn Porter’s new documentary shows, he was a transformational presence from the start.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in the late 1970s, while making the transition from background singer to phenomenal solo act, Luther Vandross shaped the sound of commercialism as much as he shaped the sound of modern American music. He recorded lucrative jingles for Juicy Fruit, Miller beer and even Gino’s pizza. During the Gino’s session, he was asked to personify a sizzling hot pie coming from the oven, and he improvised by quickly dropping his tenor into the hadal zone of his body and retrieving it, like a free diver collecting pearls.

headline: What Trump’s Environmental Record Says About a Second Term
abstract: Mr. Trump and his allies envision a second term that would try to permanently eliminate protections for air, water and climate.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, Donald J. Trump has repeatedly said that he wants “the cleanest air and the cleanest water.”

headline: Are We on the Cusp of a New Political Order?
abstract: The historian Gary Gerstle discusses how America’s political consensus has shifted over the decades.
lead_paragraph: In 2020 — this is January of 2020, way before the election took place, before Covid, for that matter — I published a whole book about political polarization. It was called “Why We’re Polarized.” And I’ve been thinking a lot about how the polarization of this year is different from what I was tracking when I was writing that book.

headline: This Election Is the Tiebreaker Over Trumpism
abstract: The hosts dig into what they got right, and what they got so wrong, about this campaign season.
lead_paragraph: Is this really the most consequential election of our lifetimes?

headline: What if A.I. Is Actually Good for Hollywood?
abstract: It’s already powering remarkable visual innovations, like in the new movie “Here.” But boosters think that’s just the beginning.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles headquarters of Metaphysic, a Hollywood visual-effects start-up that uses artificial intelligence to create digital renderings of the human face, were much cooler in my imagination, if I’m being honest. I came here to get my mind blown by A.I., and this dim three-room warren overlooking Sunset Boulevard felt more like the slouchy offices of a middling law firm. Ed Ulbrich, Metaphysic’s chief content officer, steered me into a room that looked set to host a deposition, then sat me down in a leather desk chair with a camera pointed at it. I stared at myself on a large flat-screen TV, waiting to be sworn in.

headline: KAWS, the Collector, Says, ‘I Don’t Feel Like Anything Is Mine.’
abstract: Some collectors treat artworks like poker chips and flip work by young artists. That’s not Brian Donnelly. Now his finds star in a show.
lead_paragraph: As a young street artist, Brian Donnelly (now known as KAWS) would visit PPOW in downtown Manhattan to see work by the painter Martin Wong. A tall Chinese American who loved rodeo clothes, Wong mixed with graffiti writers in ’80s New York — he once kept the influential train tagger Lee Quinones as his personal chef — and painted shuttered storefronts with psychedelic intensity.

headline: 8 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: This dramedy follows cousins David (Jesse Eisenberg, who also directed) and Benji (Kieran Culkin) as they travel across Poland to honor their late grandmother, a Holocaust survivor.

headline: Donald Trump Is Done With Checks and Balances
abstract: You aren’t just choosing a candidate. You’re choosing a theory of power.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to say that “democracy is on the ballot” on Election Day?

headline: What I Truly Expect if an Unconstrained Trump Retakes Power
abstract: The transition from democracy to autocracy is a process, not an on-off switch.
lead_paragraph: Lately, I’ve seen conservatives taunting liberals online by asking why, if we really think America could be on the verge of fascism, our bags aren’t packed. “It’s tempting to begin trolling my anti-Trump friends by asking if they are liquefying assets, getting passports in order, etc.?” Scott McConnell, a founding editor of The American Conservative, posted on X. National Review’s Michael Brendan Dougherty said something similarly snarky: “So fascism is here and you’re not doing what people did when fascism showed up, which is contemplating emigration in terror or joining armed resistance.”

headline: ‘There Is No “Just Moving On”’: The Trials of a Grieving Father
abstract: In an upstate New York courtroom, Thomas Rath faced down the man accused of orchestrating his son’s murder.
lead_paragraph: The father of the victim was first to testify. He wore a gray quilted vest, a blue-gray shirt and an expression trying but failing to show nothing. He refused for now even to look at the thickset man charged in the torture and murder of his son.

headline: Why Trump Has a More Plausible Path to the Presidency, in 19 Maps
abstract: A Democratic strategist explains how a deadlocked presidential race may play out in the Electoral College.
lead_paragraph: A Democratic strategist explains how a deadlocked presidential race may play out in the Electoral College.

headline: Oil Interests Gave More Than $75 Million to Trump PACs, New Analysis Shows
abstract: Oil moguls are big donors to Donald Trump. But so are engineering firms, hedge fund managers, shipbuilders and others that profit from fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: Oil and gas interests have given an estimated $75 million to Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, the Republican National Committee and affiliated committees, far more than has been previously known, according to a new analysis of federal campaign data.

headline: Can You Identify These Regional Election Stickers?
abstract: From student-drawn designs to state emblems, the stickers handed out at election polling sites are getting more creative. Election officials hope it will boost voter turnout.
lead_paragraph: From student-drawn designs to state emblems, the stickers handed out at election polling sites are getting more creative. Election officials hope it will boost voter turnout.

headline: Should Tourists Return to Asheville?
abstract: The Biltmore, a popular destination in the area of western North Carolina ravaged by Hurricane Helene, will reopen Saturday. Local travel operators nervously hope it will mark the return of tourists.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a month after the remnants of Hurricane Helene killed residents, destroyed homes and businesses, and felled thousands of trees in western North Carolina, workers at the Biltmore Estate in Asheville, N.C., got a round of applause Wednesday when they stood a tree up — a 28-foot Fraser fir that will be one of 57 Christmas trees displayed this holiday season in the estate’s 19th-century mansion.

headline: How Robert Smith of the Cure Became Rock’s Most Dogged Activist
abstract: With his band’s first new album in 16 years out Friday, post-punk’s dark prince discusses enduring on his own terms and clashing with the most powerful company in live music.
lead_paragraph: At Brighton Electric, a warren of rock rehearsal spaces in an old brick tram depot in this English seaside town, young guitar luggers stream in and out while the thudding jams of baby bands reverberate throughout the building.

headline: Did Trump Just Lose His Crucial Latino Support?
abstract: Latino voters could determine who will be the next president. Donald Trump might have jeopardized his chances with them.
lead_paragraph: Republicans’ growing support among Latinos is no longer guaranteed after a comedian made a racist joke at Donald Trump’s Madison Square Garden rally. But could it cost Trump the election? Isvett Verde, a Times Opinion editor, speaks with Mike Madrid, a Republican and an expert on Latino voting trends and behaviors, about why the election may hinge on each candidate’s ability to sway Latino voters.

headline: How Do You Turn a Bad Day Around?
abstract: We all have them. What are your strategies?
lead_paragraph: Your alarm didn’t go off, and then you missed the school bus. You had an argument with your best friend, and forgot there was a math quiz for second period. Then you spilled coffee on your favorite shirt. And it’s not even lunchtime! Ugh!

headline: You Might Consider Praying
abstract: It’s what we can do when we don’t know what to do.
lead_paragraph: This year keeps breaking our hearts. A partial list: a divisive presidential election seeding anger and anxiety and resentment by the day; violence in Gaza and Israel; devastating floods and hurricanes and climbing sea levels.

headline: $1.6 Million Homes in Sardinia, Italy
abstract: Homes in the island region of Italy include a three-bedroom villa in the Costa Smeralda, a traditional stone house in Muzzeddu, and a nine-bedroom estate on 62 acres.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, three-bathroom villa is perched on a hill in the hamlet of Pantogia, overlooking the Tyrrhenian Sea on the northeast coast of Sardinia.

headline: In Other News, Who Will Control Congress?
abstract: It could come down to the fate of Democrats in Trump-leaning territory.
lead_paragraph: For most of this year, we’ve been focused on the race for president, the messages coming from both parties’ nominees and their reception among voters.

headline: Let’s Not Blow It Again
abstract: Don’t let the monarch of Mar-a-Lago take back his throne.
lead_paragraph: So, about the woman thing.

headline: The New York Times Election Week News Quiz, Nov. 1, 2024
abstract: This week we’ve got a special edition of the news quiz, focused entirely on the upcoming election.
lead_paragraph: This week we’ve got a special edition of the news quiz, focused entirely on the upcoming election.

headline: Do I Have to Speak Up if Someone Fails to Cash My Check?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the duty one has to rectify accounting errors and other billing mistakes.
lead_paragraph: Three times in the last month I have been the beneficiary of administrative errors that, if they stand, will save me thousands of dollars. I’m a bit pinched financially at the moment and would like to think it’s the gods smiling on me, but I wonder about my ethical obligations.

headline: How to Accomplish a Huge Goal (One Step at a Time)
abstract: Focus on the incremental steps that are in your control.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, I’m running my 10th New York City Marathon. I’m ready and the weather looks perfect. It should be a good day, in part because I learned a real lesson last year.

headline: When to Expect Results in Each State on Election Night, and Beyond
abstract: The Times surveyed election officials in all 50 states to learn how they will count the votes, and when we might know the outcome in the battleground states.
lead_paragraph: The Times surveyed election officials in all 50 states to learn how they will count the votes, and when we might know the outcome in the battleground states.

headline: Election Uncertainty Looms Over Hiring
abstract: Some employers say they have been wary to expand until the outcome of the presidential election is known.
lead_paragraph: Storms and strikes are likely to muddle the October jobs report, but so is another complicating factor: uncertainty about the presidential election, which some executives suggest has put a damper on hiring, too.

headline: Storms and Strikes Take a Toll on Pre-election Jobs Report
abstract: U.S. payrolls grew by only 12,000 in October, a figure that left markets placid but fueled political contention. Unemployment remained 4.1 percent.
lead_paragraph: Job creation stalled in October, a month battered by strikes and hurricanes, presenting an unclear picture of where the labor market was headed even as overall economic growth remained impressive.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 510
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Nov. 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,232
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Day of Week, Date, Year.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: JD Vance Goes on Joe Rogan, and Young Thug Pleads Guilty
abstract: Plus, the jobs report, with a twist.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Army of Election Officials Ready to Reject the Vote
abstract: An investigation in four battleground states found that Republicans have taken control of election boards with the aim of challenging and overturning results that don’t go their way.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, as the voting ends and the counting begins, the election system itself will be on trial.

headline: Billionaire Game Theory + We Are Not Ready for A.G.I. + Election Betting Markets Get Weird
abstract: “If I had $1 billion, how would I try to influence the results of this election?”
lead_paragraph: Last week, Jeff Bezos canceled the Washington Post editorial board’s plan to endorse Kamala Harris. Are tech billionaires hedging their bets in case Donald Trump wins? Then, Miles Brundage, a former OpenAI senior adviser on artificial general intelligence readiness, stops by to tell us how his old company is doing when it comes to being ready for superintelligence, and whether we should all keep saving for retirement. And finally, David Yaffe-Bellany, a Times technology reporter, joins us to explore the rise of Polymarket, a crypto-powered betting platform, and discuss whether prediction markets can tell us who is going to win the election.

headline: Destructive Israeli Raid in West Bank Kills 5, Palestinians Say
abstract: The Israeli military said its soldiers had engaged in close combat in the Nur Shams area of the occupied territory.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Friday that it had concluded a raid in the occupied West Bank overnight after killing several militants, in an operation that residents and humanitarian groups said caused significant damage to roads and other civilian infrastructure.

headline: Jobs Data Come as the Fed Stares Down a Complex Moment
abstract: Growth has been resilient, but inflation is cooling. The combination makes it hard to guess how much policymakers will lower rates.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials cut interest rates in September for the first time in four years, but now investors are beginning to ask the natural next question: How much will they lower them in the months and years to come?

headline: The Races for Congress
abstract: We preview next week’s elections and what a divided or united government might mean for each party.
lead_paragraph: Every president of the past 30 years has taken office with his party in control of both the Senate and the House. That combination has allowed presidents to pass major legislation early in their terms — including deficit reduction by Bill Clinton, tax cuts by George W. Bush and Donald Trump, an expansion of health insurance by Barack Obama, and a major climate law by Joe Biden.

headline: Death Toll Rises to 205 as More Rain Batters Spain
abstract: The authorities said dozens of people were still missing, as forecasters warned of new flooding in the southwest of the country.
lead_paragraph: As the death toll passed 200 from floods this week that triggered the deadliest natural disaster in Spain’s recent history, southern regions were battered by more heavy downpours on Friday, complicating an already strained rescue effort.

headline: ‘Phantom of the Opera’ Closed on Broadway. Next Year It Will Hit the Road.
abstract: The enduring Andrew Lloyd Webber musical will begin a multiyear tour in Baltimore in November 2025.
lead_paragraph: When “The Phantom of the Opera” ended its record-setting run on Broadway last year, even its producer suggested it would only be a matter of time before musical theater’s most famous masked man once again haunted these shores.

headline: Books by Jodi Picoult, John Green and Stephen King Among the Most Banned in Schools
abstract: A record number of books were banned in districts across the country during the 2023-2024 school year, according to a free speech organization.
lead_paragraph: Jodi Picoult’s “Nineteen Minutes,” a novel about the aftermath of a school shooting, was banned in 98 school districts across the country in the last school year, making it the most frequently removed book in a period that saw a record number of book bans across the country, according to PEN America.

headline: Why Businesses Worry About R.F.K. Jr.
abstract: The Kennedy scion has long been a skeptic of vaccines, pesticides and more. Corporate leaders worry he may gain policy power if Donald Trump wins.
lead_paragraph: As corporate America increasingly reckons with the possibility of Donald Trump returning to the White House, it’s grappling with the policies that key advisers might push for.

headline: The First Big-City Mayor to Face a Recall in Years Is Fighting for Her Job
abstract: Frustrated voters will decide on Tuesday whether to oust Sheng Thao, the mayor of Oakland, Calif., because of high crime and other problems.
lead_paragraph: After the Covid-19 pandemic, San Francisco drew national attention for how property crimes, fentanyl deaths and store closures had reversed the fortunes of a gleaming tech capital.

headline: The Market Is Fairly Upbeat. Is It the Calm Before a Storm?
abstract: Stocks have risen this year despite uncertainties and outright hostilities in U.S. politics and around the world. But bonds and other markets show signs of concern, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. election is a nail-biter, and the world is anything but calm. Yet the stock market has been remarkably tranquil.

headline: Expect Higher Costs for Your Health Care Benefits Next Year
abstract: Employers are predicting an increase of as much as 9 percent, on average, but are generally avoiding passing along much of that to their employees, industry groups say.
lead_paragraph: Weight-loss drugs. Cutting-edge gene therapies. In vitro fertilization. All are life-changing, but expensive, medical options that are helping to drive up health care costs next year for employers and their employees.

headline: Muddled Jobs Data May Do Little to Alter Immediate Fed Rate Path
abstract: Officials at the Federal Reserve are widely expected to cut rates by a quarter point next week.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials cut interest rates in September for the first time in four years, but now investors are beginning to ask the natural next question: How much will they lower them in the months and years to come?

headline: Diwali Reminds Me of Who I Am (but It Took Awhile to Get There)
abstract: The writer Raj Tawney shares how celebrating Diwali eventually taught him to feel more rooted in his Indian culture — and in himself.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Rúben Amorim and the Unhelpful Burden of History
abstract: Winning at Manchester United will be tough enough for the club’s new manager. Unfair comparisons with the past won’t help.
lead_paragraph: Rio Ferdinand’s endorsement was immediate. Manchester United had only fired Erik ten Hag a few minutes earlier — an eventuality as delayed as it was predictable — and already Ferdinand had weighed the claims of the dozens of candidates to succeed him and come to his conclusion.

headline: Weak Jobs Report Provides Political Fodder Ahead of Election Day
abstract: Republicans and Democrats used the latest jobs numbers to bolster their arguments about who would be better at managing the economy.
lead_paragraph: A weak jobs report that was depressed by storms and labor strikes quickly became political fodder on Friday as Republicans and Democrats injected the numbers into their arguments over whether former President Donald J. Trump or Vice President Kamala Harris would be better at managing the economy.

headline: Providing Care for the Mentally Ill and Homeless
abstract: Readers praise an outreach program on the streets of California. Also: Election panic; the climate stakes; election fraud; questions for Trump and Vance.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Inside Heidi Klum’s Halloween Party
abstract: The model’s annual bash in New York City drew stars including Nicole Scherzinger, Charli D’Amelio and Bethenny Frankel.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, Nicole Scherzinger slipped off a pair of black foam slides and padded barefoot down West 48th Street. Fake blood the shade of maraschino cherries was smeared down her collarbones and the neck of her dress.

headline: Yeat’s Chart Topper and Rage Rap’s New Wave
abstract: A conversation about the mysterious rapper’s rise and the impact of hip-hop’s splintering.
lead_paragraph: “Lyfestyle,” the latest album from the 24-year-old rapper Yeat, recently debuted at the top of the Billboard album chart. It was the biggest success yet for an artist who’s been gaining popularity while studiously avoiding the spotlight, and whose music is legible to his most devoted fans and students, but maybe not far outside that tent.

headline: Hit Play About U.S. Constitution Debuts in Canada. Amended, of Course.
abstract: How do you retool “What the Constitution Means to Me” for those unfamiliar with the U.S. Constitution? Consult Canada’s Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
lead_paragraph: “What the Constitution Means to Me,” Heidi Schreck’s Tony-nominated exploration of the document’s gender and racial biases, will be the most performed work in the United States for the second year in a row. And this week, just days before the U.S. presidential election, it will have its Canadian premiere.

headline: Tom Hanks and Robin Wright Open a New Box
abstract: The “Forrest Gump” stars were game to reunite with Robert Zemeckis for the technical experiment of “Here.” De-aging? A static camera? They weren’t fazed.
lead_paragraph: It’s not exactly a “Forrest Gump” sequel, but the new movie “Here” does reunite the stars Tom Hanks and Robin Wright, and the filmmakers — the director Robert Zemeckis, screenwriter Eric Roth, composer Alan Silvestri — of that 1994 Oscar-winning favorite. Like the earlier film, the new one also travels across decades, with an unheard-of perspective.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include female assassins, a quirky French thief and crooked cops.
lead_paragraph: The jaded assassin Dominique (Oksana Orlan) is interrupted from her trip when her plane is shot down in Colombia by a cartel. She is given shelter by a local cop, Julio (Sebastián Carvajal), who is working as an informant against the cartel’s hired help, the crooked Chief Santiago (Maurice Compte). When Julio is murdered by Santiago, it’s up to Dominique to pull out her guns one last time to defend Julio’s pregnant sister Paulina (Maria del Rosario Barreto) and her children from Santiago’s wrath.

headline: Let’s Eat Like Marathoners
abstract: Not everyone can conquer 26.2 miles. But we can all enjoy Melissa Clark’s sustaining pasta with kale pesto and butternut squash.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There are whales breaching in 20 feet of water off the cabanas near Breezy Point in Queens, feeding on acres of peanut bunker amid swarms of striped bass. Out by the pilot boat at the mouth of the Ambrose Channel, bluefin tuna crash bait on the water’s surface. Dolphins cruise between them, over the sand sharks known as dogfish, while tautog eat crabs on the ocean floor. Everywhere are birds — terns, gulls, gannets — and, amid them, fishermen in little boats observing the show, seeing it against a backdrop of urban majesty.

headline: 1 in 4 Child Deaths After E.R. Visits Are Preventable, Study Finds
abstract: If every emergency room in the United States were fully prepared to treat children, thousands of lives would be saved and the cost would be $11.84 or less per child, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: The morning after Phyllis Rabinowitz brought her newborn daughter home from the hospital, she knew something was terribly wrong. The baby, Rebecca, had thick mucus, trouble breathing and lethargy unlike anything Ms. Rabinowitz had seen in her first child.

headline: ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’ Book Club Conversation Space: Chat About Gabriel García Márquez’s Other Books
abstract: Looking to discuss García Márquez’s other books? Chat about them here.
lead_paragraph: This month, the Book Review Book Club is reading “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” by Gabriel García Márquez. Do you also want to talk about other titles from García Márquez’s robust catalog of novels, novellas, short stories and nonfiction? You can discuss them here. Click the chat bubble above to leave a comment.

headline: ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’ Book Club Conversation Space: Spoiler Chat
abstract: Want to discuss spoilers related to our November book club selection, “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” by Gabriel García Márquez? Post them here.
lead_paragraph: Want to talk about something that happens later in “One Hundred Years of Solitude”? Dying to dig into a particular plot point or react to a big reveal? Post your spoiler-filled thoughts, questions and observations in the comments here. (Click the chat bubble above to comment.)

headline: ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’ Book Club Conversation Space: Main Discussion
abstract: Discuss our November book club selection, “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” by Gabriel García Márquez, with the Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Share your thoughts about “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” by Gabriel García Márquez, in the comments here by clicking the chat bubble above to comment. This will be our main conversation space.

headline: ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’ Book Club Conversation Space: García Márquez Memories
abstract: Share your memories of reading García Márquez’s books here.
lead_paragraph: One of the great things about revisiting a classic is hearing from readers about how they first stumbled upon a beloved author and the notable encounters they’ve had with that author’s seminal work. Do you have a fond memory of reading “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” or another one of Gabriel García Márquez’s books? Share them here.

headline: Diving to Drink a 19th-Century Shipwreck’s Treasure
abstract: A team recently dived deep beneath Lake Huron hoping to harvest grain that may one day be distilled into whiskey with a flavor forgotten to history.
lead_paragraph: The wreck of the James R. Bentley, a 170-foot-long schooner, has sat 165 feet beneath the surface of Lake Huron since 1878. Within its hold was an unlikely treasure.

headline: They Barter and Trade to Survive. How Will They Vote?
abstract: Many rural Americans engage in cashless barter systems to get food and firewood for heating and cooking. They value self-sufficiency, making them wary of government intervention.
lead_paragraph: When Miki Shiverick needs firewood to heat her home, or help clearing the rusted appliances and vehicles from her property, she doesn’t go to a store or pay for services. Instead, she trades for it.

headline: Play: Election-Night Bingo
abstract: Listen up for these terms as the votes roll in. Find them on the board to be the night’s big winner.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of A Kid’s Guide to the Election, a collection of stories about the 2024 presidential election for readers ages 8 to 14, written and produced by The New York Times for Kids. This section is published in The Times’s print edition on the last Sunday of every month.

headline: So … How Does the Electoral College Work, Again?
abstract: It’s weird. It’s confusing. It’s how we elect the president.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of A Kid’s Guide to the Election, a collection of stories about the 2024 presidential election for readers ages 8 to 14, written and produced by The New York Times for Kids. This section is published in The Times’s print edition on the last Sunday of every month.

headline: From A.I. to Musk’s Brain Chips, the F.D.A.’s Device Unit Faces Rapid Change
abstract: The new director overseeing medical devices will confront criticisms about hasty approvals as she ushers in revolutionary technology.
lead_paragraph: There are now artificial intelligence programs that scan M.R.I.s for signs of cancer, Apple AirPods that work as hearing aids and devices that decode the electrical blips of the brain to restore speech to those who have lost it.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Disney+, Amazon, Apple TV+ and More in November
abstract: “Cruel Intentions,” “Music by John Williams” and “Dune: The Prophecy” arrive, along with “Bad Sisters” Season 2.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Too Young to Vote? Here’s How Kids Are Getting Involved.
abstract: Teens around the country are volunteering, canvassing and registering voters.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of A Kid’s Guide to the Election, a collection of stories about the 2024 presidential election for readers ages 8 to 14, written and produced by The New York Times for Kids. This section is published in The Times’s print edition on the last Sunday of every month.

headline: A Brief History of Messy Elections
abstract: Three times the results were disputed after the votes were in.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of A Kid’s Guide to the Election, a collection of stories about the 2024 presidential election for readers ages 8 to 14, written and produced by The New York Times for Kids. This section is published in The Times’s print edition on the last Sunday of every month.

headline: Help! My Family Can’t Stop Fighting About Politics.
abstract: When families disagree on candidates, kids can get caught in the middle.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of A Kid’s Guide to the Election, a collection of stories about the 2024 presidential election for readers ages 8 to 14, written and produced by The New York Times for Kids. This section is published in The Times’s print edition on the last Sunday of every month.

headline: Inside Five of America’s Strangest Polling Places
abstract: Grab a snack, do your laundry and cast a ballot.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of A Kid’s Guide to the Election, a collection of stories about the 2024 presidential election for readers ages 8 to 14, written and produced by The New York Times for Kids. This section is published in The Times’s print edition on the last Sunday of every month.

headline: When Will We Know Who Won?
abstract: It may take a while. Here’s what could happen next.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of A Kid’s Guide to the Election, a collection of stories about the 2024 presidential election for readers ages 8 to 14, written and produced by The New York Times for Kids. This section is published in The Times’s print edition on the last Sunday of every month.

headline: What the Weak Jobs Report Tells Us
abstract: It doesn’t mean we’re on the edge of a recession.
lead_paragraph: The great Biden employment boom (16 million jobs added since he took office) took a breather last month, according to Friday morning’s report, with a gain of only 12,000 jobs and downward revisions to some earlier numbers. Much of the slowdown reflected special factors — Hurricane Helene and the Boeing strike. But job gains still fell short of most forecasts, even though the forecasters knew about these factors.

headline: So, Can We Trust the Polls?
abstract: Recent changes add up to a case for cautious optimism on better accuracy, but that’s far from a guarantee.
lead_paragraph: The polls underestimated Donald J. Trump in 2016.

headline: This 3-Course Vegetarian Dinner Is Ready to Party
abstract: This gorgeous David Tanis spread stars a sweet-tart radicchio salad, and a cheesy polenta bake with herby mushrooms.
lead_paragraph: Seasons change. The sun sets early, and the evening temperatures are cool, even if afternoons are sunny. It’s nice to settle into autumn menus.

headline: As Russia Advances, U.S. Fears Ukraine Has Entered a Grim Phase
abstract: Weapons supplies are no longer Ukraine’s main disadvantage, American military officials say.
lead_paragraph: American military and intelligence officials have concluded that the war in Ukraine is no longer a stalemate as Russia makes steady gains, and the sense of pessimism in Kyiv and Washington is deepening.

headline: Trump Is Courting Apolitical Young Men. Will It Pay Off?
abstract: Gen Z men are increasingly turning away from the Democratic Party, swayed by the former president’s bravado and irreverence. But they also do not usually vote in high numbers.
lead_paragraph: Back in June, former President Donald J. Trump appeared on a podcast interview with Logan Paul, the wrestler and social media star. They chatted about immigration and the economy, but also about boxing and the existence of aliens — which Mr. Trump described as “very possible.”

headline: How Trump Is Trying to Win Gen Z Men
abstract: Young men in recent years have become more politically conservative. But will they vote? Kellen Browning, a New York Times reporter covering the 2024 election with a focus on Nevada and Arizona, discusses the Trump campaign’s efforts to court the group.
lead_paragraph: Young men in recent years have become more politically conservative. But will they vote? Kellen Browning, a New York Times reporter covering the 2024 election with a focus on Nevada and Arizona, discusses the Trump campaign’s efforts to court the group.

headline: Disinformation Watchdogs Are Under Pressure. This Group Refuses to Stop.
abstract: Though a larger coalition of fact checkers has disbanded, a team of students and researchers at the University of Washington in Seattle is still working to document how lies online threaten to undermine this year’s presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Inside two small, windowless conference rooms on the campus of the University of Washington in Seattle, a group of students and researchers is prowling the internet to track the rumors and conspiracy theories eroding faith in this year’s presidential election.

headline: How Election Deniers Sank a Security Conference in Georgia
abstract: The gathering had nothing to do with the election. That didn’t stop conspiracy theorists from spreading falsehoods.
lead_paragraph: Since 2021, a security conference in Atlanta had played host to a simple tabletop exercise in which attendees talked about how they would respond to fictional disasters like plane crashes or water treatment issues.

headline: The Path to Control of Congress May Swerve Through Alabama
abstract: A House district in Alabama was redrawn to empower Black voters, changing what had been a safe Republican seat into a highly competitive and potentially consequential battleground.
lead_paragraph: Away from the presidential battleground states that are claiming most of both parties’ attention, a redrawn House district in ruby-red Alabama could prove crucial to their ambitions in Washington.

headline: Tsunehisa Katsumata, Top Executive in Power Plant Meltdown, Dies at 84
abstract: He was sued and prosecuted for his actions as chairman of the Japanese power company that ran the Fukushima nuclear facility when it failed in a 2011 earthquake and tsunami.
lead_paragraph: Tsunehisa Katsumata, the former chairman of Tokyo Electric Power Company, who had been embroiled in legal proceedings after the catastrophic meltdown at the company’s Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in 2011, has died. He was 84.

headline: The Fight for the House Is on a Knife’s Edge
abstract: Public and private polling this cycle, as well as strategists in both parties, point to one of the tightest contests yet for the House majority, in races that stretch from California to Nebraska to Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Control of the House is on a knife’s edge, with Democrats and Republicans from the liberal coasts to the nation’s heartland running neck-and-neck in the key races that will decide which party will hold the majority in the next Congress.

headline: Veto Power in the Balance, Nevada’s G.O.P. Governor Keeps Trump at Arm’s Length
abstract: Republicans believe a strong Donald Trump victory would ensure that Gov. Joe Lombardo could keep overriding Democratic priorities. But Mr. Lombardo is operating outside the state party, and largely away from Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Joe Lombardo, Nevada’s Republican governor, is doing just about everything he can to stop Democrats from gaining the ability to sharply curtail his power this November.

headline: Israel Strikes Near Beirut as Diplomatic Push Shows No Sign of Success
abstract: The Biden administration sent envoys including the C.I.A. director to the Middle East this week, but Israel, Hezbollah and Hamas all appeared far from a deal to end the fighting.
lead_paragraph: Israeli warplanes struck near Beirut for the first time in several days and airstrikes killed at least 52 people in central Lebanon on Friday, according to the Lebanese authorities, as diplomatic efforts to reduce the fighting between Israel and Hezbollah showed no sign of success.

headline: U.S. Spy Agencies Issue New Warning on Russia’s Election Misinformation Campaign
abstract: Three recent videos have sought to undermine confidence in the security of the vote.
lead_paragraph: U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that Russia is behind two new fabricated videos that appeared on social media this week falsely claiming that Haitians illegally voted in Georgia and that Vice President Kamala Harris and her husband received a $500,000 bribe from the performer Sean Combs.

headline: How to Keep Traffic Moving? An Airport Puts Hugs on a Timer.
abstract: The new rule at a New Zealand airport limits curbside embraces to three minutes, drawing worldwide commentary, from the indignant to the amused.
lead_paragraph: Airports have tried an array of methods to combat traffic jams outside terminals, like dedicated taxi lanes, ride-share bans and police officers telling drivers to move along, or else.

headline: Is It Healthy to Eat Just Once a Day?
abstract: Bruce Springsteen said he does. We asked experts about the science behind the OMAD diet.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen is still going hard at 75. He played more than 100 shows in 2023 and 2024 combined. His sets routinely top three hours. And he has shows booked through next July.

headline: ‘Blitz’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The writer and director Steve McQueen narrates a sequence from his film set in London during World War II.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Steve McQueen narrates a sequence from his film set in London during World War II.

headline: Watch a Nightclub Scene in ‘Blitz’
abstract: The writer and director Steve McQueen discusses a sequence set in the Café de Paris in London.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Anitta Mesmerizes the Weeknd, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks from Ethel Cain, the Black Keys featuring Beck, Ilham and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Who Abandoned Liberalism First, the Populists or the Establishment?
abstract: The uncertain future of ‘whole of society’ politics.
lead_paragraph: While American liberalism debates, round and round, whether Trumpism is a form of fascism, conservatives and conservatism’s fellow travelers have their own running debate about what exactly is happening to liberalism these days.

headline: White House Altered Official Transcript of Biden’s Remarks on Trump and ‘Garbage’
abstract: The debate over the meaning of President Biden’s words comes down to an apostrophe, which the White House press office inserted into the transcript without the approval of official stenographers.
lead_paragraph: The White House altered the official transcript of President Biden’s remarks this week about the Trump campaign and “garbage” as it rushed to clarify that the president’s words had been taken out of context, people familiar with the matter said on Friday.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Nov. 2, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Stream These 9 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
abstract: A slew of great movies and TV shows are leaving Netflix for U.S. subscribers in November. Here’s a roundup of the best.
lead_paragraph: Three inventive and engaging biopics are leaving Netflix in the United States this month, along with a scorching stage adaptation, a thrilling Tom Cruise vehicle and an animated comedy that is decidedly not for the kiddies. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

headline: Israeli Military Carries Out Raid in the Occupied West Bank
abstract: The Israeli military said they killed several militants during a raid in the West Bank, in an operation that residents and humanitarian groups said caused significant damage to infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said they killed several militants during a raid in the West Bank, in an operation that residents and humanitarian groups said caused significant damage to infrastructure.

headline: The Best Chore Coats, From $40 to $1,850
abstract: A roundup of versatile work wear-inspired jackets.
lead_paragraph: “This jacket is made partly from recycled cotton, the shape is as classic as it comes and the price is right.”

headline: All Trick, No Treat: Dublin Crowds Turn Up for Halloween Parade That Wasn’t
abstract: The scariest thing this Halloween? In one city, it was the power of a phony online event listing.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Dubliners made their way to the city center on Thursday night, excited for a Halloween parade to take place on a mild October evening as they lined up along O’Connell Street, a major thoroughfare.

headline: How a Year of Rain Fell on Parts of Spain in Eight Hours
abstract: The region is no stranger to storms like those that caused this week’s deluges. But global warming helps them pack a bigger punch, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: The flooding in eastern Spain, already the deadliest disaster in the country’s recent history, is a foretaste of the extreme storms that the region can expect to see more of as humans continue heating up the planet, scientists said this week.

headline: Volunteers Clean Up Debris After Unprecedented Flooding in Spain
abstract: Cars and homes were destroyed and streets were left clogged with mud in the wake of severe flooding in the Valencia region.
lead_paragraph: Cars and homes were destroyed and streets were left clogged with mud in the wake of severe flooding in the Valencia region.

headline: McDonald’s Ice Cream Machines May Get Quicker Fix After Copyright Ruling
abstract: An exemption to a longstanding copyright act allows industrial equipment to be fixed by people not affiliated with the manufacturer.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s ice cream machines, frequently the subject of memes and ridicule from frustrated customers who say their quest for a cold treat is often thwarted by broken equipment, may get fixed more quickly.

headline: This Sorority Is Going All in to Get Out the Vote
abstract: Alpha Kappa Alpha’s forceful push to increase voter turnout could help boost critical support for Democrats from Black voters.
lead_paragraph: In the days after early voting started in Georgia last month, sorority parties broke out around Atlanta.

headline: Biden Won’t Attend This Year’s Climate Summit, White House Officials Say
abstract: The president’s senior climate adviser is expected to lead the American delegation at the U.N. talks in Azerbaijan.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will not attend an annual international climate summit this year, which is being held in Azerbaijan less than one week after the U.S. presidential elections, the White House confirmed on Friday.

headline: A Poem About Waiting, and Wishing You Had a Drink
abstract: Our critic A.O. Scott walks you through a poem that speaks to his mood right now. It’s called “Party Politics,” but it’s not about those parties, or those politics.
lead_paragraph: Our critic A.O. Scott walks you through a poem that speaks to his mood right now. It’s called “Party Politics,” but it’s not about those parties, or those politics.

headline: Chipmaker GlobalFoundries Faces $500,000 Fine for Banned Shipments to China
abstract: The Biden administration said it had reached a settlement after the U.S. chipmaker voluntarily disclosed that it had shipped products to a firm linked with China’s military industrial complex.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Friday that it would impose a fine of $500,000 on the U.S. chipmaker GlobalFoundries, after the company shipped more than $17 million of products to a Chinese company on a restricted trade list.

headline: Hugh Hewitt, Conservative Columnist, Quits The Washington Post
abstract: His decision came hours after he abruptly stormed off a broadcast of a live online Post talk show.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Hewitt, the conservative pundit, said on Friday that he would no longer write columns for The Washington Post, where he had been a regular contributor to the paper’s opinion pages.

headline: Eric Adams to Stand Trial on Corruption Charges in April, Judge Says
abstract: Accused of conspiring to funnel illegal contributions from Turkey into his campaign coffers, Mr. Adams has pleaded not guilty.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City is scheduled to stand trial on corruption charges on April 21, a federal judge said at a hearing on Friday.

headline: Trump’s Economic Vision Has a Lot of Flaws. Here’s Another.
abstract: A new paper undermines the historical narrative at the heart of his love of tariffs.
lead_paragraph: Tariffs made America great, Donald Trump likes to argue. Is it true?

headline: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘Intermezzo’
abstract: Sally Rooney’s new novel explores the relationship between two brothers grieving the death of their father, and follows their complicated love lives with Rooney’s usual panache.
lead_paragraph: Sally Rooney is a writer people talk about. Since her first novel, “Conversations With Friends,” was published in 2017, Rooney has been hailed as a defining voice of the millennial generation because of her ability to capture the particular angst and confusion of young love, friendship and coming-of-age in our fraught digital era.

headline: Maryland Republican Fighting Uphill Battle Pitches Voters on Splitting Their Tickets
abstract: A spot for former Gov. Larry Hogan aims to give Democrats permission to back him over Angela Alsobrooks and still vote for Kamala Harris — or against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Larry Hogan, the Republican candidate for Senate in Maryland, is running this 30-second advertisement in the Baltimore and Washington markets as part of his decidedly uphill battle against Angela Alsobrooks, the Democratic Prince George’s County Executive. His campaign has spent $664,400 on the ad since it went up on Oct. 24, according to AdImpact.

headline: Ed Sheeran Prevails in Copyright Appeal Over ‘Let’s Get It On’
abstract: A three-judge panel affirmed that Sheeran’s “Thinking Out Loud” did not illegally borrow from Marvin Gaye’s song.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Friday ruled that Ed Sheeran’s 2014 song “Thinking Out Loud” did not infringe on the copyright of Marvin Gaye’s classic “Let’s Get It On,” tying up one loose end after Sheeran’s victory in court last year.

headline: Latino Civil Rights Group Pushes Back on the Myth of Noncitizen Voters
abstract: The League of United Latin American Citizens, which was targeted in Texas’ election fraud case, is teaming up with a pro-democracy group to counter Republican-led election challenges.
lead_paragraph: The League of United Latin American Citizens, whose volunteers were the target of raids in a voter fraud inquiry in Texas over the summer, on Friday said it had teamed up with a pro-democracy group led by Democratic strategists to push back on Republican-led efforts to limit their activities and those of voting rights activists across the country.

headline: With Days to Go, Trump Courts Apolitical Young Men
abstract: Also, the U.S. fears Ukraine has entered a grim phase. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and Kamala Harris headed into the final weekend of what appears to be an extremely tight race by holding events across the Midwestern battleground states. They also waged national media campaigns to try to win over small but crucial groups of voters who have yet to make up their minds.

headline: 2024 Holiday Gift Guide
abstract: Wondering what to get for all the beloved people in your life, whether they be quirky, picky, fancy or frugal? Our experts have curated the best gifts to help you check everyone off your list.
lead_paragraph: Wondering what to get for all the beloved people in your life, whether they be quirky, picky, fancy or frugal? Our experts have curated the best gifts to help you check everyone off your list.

headline: Halloween Parade Float in Pennsylvania Denounced as Racist
abstract: Daylon A. Davis, the president of the N.A.A.C.P.’s Pittsburgh branch, said he was deeply disturbed by the way Vice President Kamala Harris was depicted.
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh branch of the N.A.A.C.P. and the speaker of the Pennsylvania House have denounced a local Halloween parade float that featured a woman apparently dressed as Vice President Kamala Harris who was tethered to a small vehicle that was ferrying a person dressed as former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Richard A. Fineberg, Relentless Skeptic of Alaska Pipeline, Dies at 83
abstract: A journalist and an analyst, he was driven to hold oil companies accountable. Earlier, he was on the storied boat Greenpeace when he and others tried to halt a nuclear test.
lead_paragraph: When Richard A. Fineberg lived in a small cabin in central Alaska, overlooking a valley near Fairbanks, it was packed with documents.

headline: Chicago School Board President Resigns Over Social Media Posts
abstract: One week into the job, the Rev. Mitchell Ikenna Johnson resigned amid criticism by elected leaders that his past posts were anti-Semitic and misogynistic.
lead_paragraph: A week after he was sworn into office, the president of the Board of Education in Chicago resigned on Thursday over social media posts from the past year that elected officials criticized as anti-Semitic and misogynistic and that espoused a conspiracy theory about the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline: How Long Does It Take to Boil an Egg?
abstract: It depends. Here’s a guide to getting the eggs you’re craving.
lead_paragraph: A boiled egg is a little delight, whether it’s soft enough to scoop with a tiny spoon or set enough to slice. But rubbery whites and gray-green yolks that emit a sulfurous smell are far less delightful. To avoid those pitfalls, try this basic method for boiling eggs. But before you begin, know that “boiling” isn’t quite the right word. Instead, simmering is what you’re after, a steady, low bubble that yields egg whites as soft as slips, but offer a little resistance to a bite. Keeping the water at a lighter gurgle prevents overcooking and ensures the eggs don’t jostle against one another or the saucepan and crack while cooking.

headline: Harris and Trump Rally in Milwaukee as They Make Final Wisconsin Push
abstract: The presidential rivals campaigned in the battleground state’s largest city after Donald Trump tried to slightly soften his violent remarks about Liz Cheney, which Kamala Harris called “disqualifying.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump converged on Milwaukee on Friday night during their final scheduled visits to Wisconsin, a battleground state where neither of them has a lead and which is considered particularly essential to a Harris victory.

headline: I Took a ‘Decision Holiday’ and Put A.I. in Charge of My Life
abstract: I thought it would make me put glue on pizza, but instead it entertained my children and got me to finally paint my office. How could it transform our daily lives?
lead_paragraph: I thought it would make me put glue on pizza, but instead it entertained my children and got me to finally paint my office. How could it transform our daily lives?

headline: Canadian Police Say They Dismantled Country’s Largest Drug Lab
abstract: Federal officers in British Columbia seized drugs and chemical precursors that could produce about 96 million opioid doses, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Canadian authorities have dismantled what they described as the country’s largest drug laboratory, hidden in a rural part of British Columbia, seizing enough chemicals and other material to produce roughly 96 million doses of fentanyl, the country’s leading cause of overdose deaths.

headline: Trump Still Can’t Stop Talking About Women
abstract: The countdown to the election feels like an Advent calendar with a dubious remark behind each door.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris almost never talks about what it would mean to elect a female president, nor does she speculate about why women disproportionately support her candidacy.

headline: Montana Camper Offered His Killer a Beer Before He Was Murdered, Police Say
abstract: DNA from a beer can helped lead the authorities to an arrest in the killing of Dustin Kjersem, whose death was originally reported as a possible bear attack, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A Montana camper whose mutilated body was found in a forest last month was brutally killed by a stranger he welcomed to his campsite and offered a beer, the authorities said this week, a gesture they say ultimately led to the killer’s arrest.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Bid to Block Count of Some Pennsylvania Provisional Ballots
