Trump told supporters at a Pennsylvania rally on Sunday that he “shouldn’t have left” the White House at the end of his term, escalated his unfounded claims of voter fraud and said “I don’t mind” if reporters are shot at.

headline: James O’Keefe Recruits Election Workers to Secretly Record at the Polls
abstract: Mr. O’Keefe has sought volunteers willing to wear hidden cameras and hunt for voting problems. Dozens of election judges and poll monitors responded, records show.
lead_paragraph: James O’Keefe, the conservative influencer who founded and formerly led Project Veritas, has assembled a corps of election workers and poll monitors planning to secretly film voting and ballot counting in states across the country.

headline: He’s Running the N.Y.C. Marathon as Part of His Recovery From Addiction
abstract: Travis Friese is running on a team organized by Odyssey House, a residential treatment program.
lead_paragraph: His first time in rehab, Travis Friese thought he could just learn to use drugs less frequently, and in that way avoid the negative effects of addiction.

headline: With Oil Prices Weak, OPEC Plus Postpones Increases Again
abstract: Saudi Arabia, which leads the group, appears wary of unsettling markets just before the U.S. presidential election on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia and seven other oil-producing countries said on Sunday that they would postpone plans to gradually increase oil output until the end of December, according to a news release posted on the website of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

headline: Weary, Troubled and Nervous: Americans Flood the Early Vote
abstract: Nearly 75 million people have cast early ballots, making their voices heard amid worry about the process, the outcome and democracy itself.
lead_paragraph: An anxious America, weary from a vitriolic campaign season and worried about the state of the nation’s democracy, is voting with determination, with roughly 75 million people having cast ballots in the early voting period.

headline: Georgia Judge Rejects Republican Lawsuit to Block Hand-Returned Mail Ballots
abstract: The lawsuit targeted Fulton County, a Democratic stronghold, seeking to stop it from opening election offices over the weekend to receive absentee ballots in person.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia judge on Saturday rejected a Republican lawsuit aimed at blocking counties from opening election offices over the weekend to let voters return their absentee ballots in person.

headline: What One Tossup District Says About the Trump-Harris Battle for the Suburbs
abstract: Representative David Schweikert, a vulnerable Republican, is fighting for his political life in suburban Arizona, where the sprint to win over a crucial bloc of voters is coming down to the wire.
lead_paragraph: Knocking on doors in Phoenix and Scottsdale in the election’s frantic final days, canvassers working on behalf of the Democratic candidate for the U.S. House were greeted by reactions from across the political spectrum.

headline: Joey Jay, First Little Leaguer to Get to the Majors, Dies at 89
abstract: A pitcher who won 99 games in 13 seasons, he played for the Braves and the Reds. But when he retired, he never looked back.
lead_paragraph: Joey Jay, who in 1953 became the first former Little Leaguer to reach the major leagues and went on to win 99 games in 13 seasons pitching for the Milwaukee (later Atlanta) Braves and the Cincinnati Reds, died on Sept. 27 in Lutz, Fla. He was 89 and had lived in the Tampa Bay area in his later years.

headline: U.S. Confirms Reports That Iran Arrested an Iranian-American Citizen
abstract: Rights groups said that Reza Valizadeh, an Iranian-American journalist, was recently arrested in Iran, although the State Department did not confirm that he was the person detained.
lead_paragraph: The State Department confirmed that it was looking into reports that an Iranian-American citizen had been arrested in Iran. The news comes amid renewed tensions between Iran, which has long used Western detainees for leverage, and the United States, Israel’s biggest ally, following Israeli airstrikes on Iran last month.

headline: 9 Memorable Looks at the New York City Marathon
abstract: Form versus function can be debated another time as these marathoners made sure they looked good while they were running hard.
lead_paragraph: As the sun rose on Sunday, thousands of runners packed into Fort Wadsworth, a 226-acre park on the eastern shore of Staten Island, where the New York City Marathon was set to kick off.

headline: Entire City Police Force in Oklahoma Quits as 2 Council Members Also Resign
abstract: The reasons for the abrupt mass departures in the city of Geary, Okla., which has a population of just under 1,000, were unclear.
lead_paragraph: Three officers and the chief of a four-person police department in a small city in Oklahoma abruptly resigned on Thursday, as did two of its three City Council members, all with little explanation.

headline: Biden Wanted to Fix Immigration, but Leaves Behind a System That Is Still Broken
abstract: President Biden’s legacy will largely be limited to his success in lowering border crossings. But his approach has drawn criticism, and some of his actions have moved the problem deeper into the country.
lead_paragraph: President Biden had big ambitions for remaking America’s immigration system.

headline: Abdi Nageeye and Sheila Chepkirui Win New York City Marathon
abstract: A riveting competition ended with one-on-one clashes in both the men’s and women’s races, and with three Kenyans on the women’s podium.
lead_paragraph: Sheila Chepkirui of Kenya was well aware of the esteemed company that she was keeping in the late stages of the New York City Marathon on Sunday morning.

headline: Crime Has Been a Big Talking Point. How Does It Look in Battleground States?
abstract: Even as violence crime rates fall, Republicans have sought to tie murders and drug overdoses to migrants. Here’s a rundown of crime rates in swing states.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump routinely raises the issue of crime on the campaign trail, saying that it is “through the roof” and that cities like Philadelphia are “ravaged by bloodshed.”

headline: The New York City Marathon, in Photos
abstract: New York Times photographers captured scenes of today’s race across the city. Here are some of their photos.
lead_paragraph: More than 50,000 runners were taking part in the New York City Marathon on Sunday, making the 26.2 mile journey from Staten Island to Central Park. The weather was cooler than in recent years, allowing for perfect conditions.

headline: Fiery Michigan Crash Kills 4 After Semi Truck Slams Into Stopped Traffic
abstract: Seventeen other people were injured in the crash, which happened Saturday night on a highway east of Lansing after traffic had been halted to allow for utility work.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed and 17 others, including children, were seriously injured after a semi truck crashed into vehicles stopped on a highway in Michigan on Saturday night, the authorities said.

headline: Monday Briefing: The Final Set of Times/Siena Election Polls
abstract: Plus, using generative A.I. to take a “decision holiday.”
lead_paragraph: There’s one more day until Election Day, and the final set of Times/Siena polls are in.

headline: An ‘S.N.L.’ Sketch Gives Harvey Epstein His 15 Minutes of Fame
abstract: Mr. Epstein, a state assemblyman who is running for New York City Council, had no idea he would be the subject of a skit watched by millions.
lead_paragraph: When Harvey Epstein went to sleep on Saturday night, he was a low-profile New York State assemblyman. When he woke up on Sunday morning, he was something of an internet celebrity.

headline: Trump Says He Thinks Julia Roberts Will Regret Ad Supporting Harris
abstract: Ms. Roberts narrated an ad suggesting that women could privately vote for Vice President Kamala Harris without letting their husbands know.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said Saturday morning that he thought the actress Julia Roberts would come to regret narrating an ad suggesting that women could privately vote for Vice President Kamala Harris while telling their husbands otherwise.

headline: Trump Says He May Move Against Some Vaccinations and Fluoride in Water
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump expressed openness to proposals set forth by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the vaccine skeptic he has said would be allowed to “go wild on health.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he expected Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to have a “big role” in a second administration, and acknowledged the possibility that he could take action against two major public health successes — vaccines and the fluoridation of water — if he won the presidency.

headline: New Yorkers Celebrate the 53rd New York City Marathon
abstract: Hundreds of thousands turned out across New York City to cheer on marathon participants.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands turned out across New York City to cheer on marathon participants.

headline: What Polls Can Tell Us, Beyond the Horse Race
abstract: As the election dust prepares to settle, patterns are emerging that might provide valuable context in the weeks to come.
lead_paragraph: Put your phone down, and back slowly away from those election forecasts. In a presidential race that has remained stubbornly close for weeks, nothing short of a campaign-shattering seismic event is likely to budge the polls much in the next few days.

headline: Alan Rachins, ‘L.A. Law’ and ‘Dharma & Greg’ Actor, Dies at 82
abstract: He became recognizable as a performer whose specialty was difficult men, in both absurd comedies and tense dramas.
lead_paragraph: Alan Rachins, who delighted TV watchers by playing two very different kinds of histrionic middle-aged men in two hit shows, “L.A. Law” and “Dharma & Greg,” died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 82.

headline: Obama Gives Tailored Pitch to Voters Wavering on Harris
abstract: Barack Obama’s laundry list for different constituencies hinted at what groups Democrats were focusing on in the final hours before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama, in a long and impassioned speech on the final day of early voting in Wisconsin, made a plea to voters to back Vice President Kamala Harris even if they disagree with her on a particular policy issue or have lost trust in Democratic politicians.

headline: Rainy-Day Reserves
abstract: Get into solving mode for this puzzle by Colin Adams.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Gretchen Whitmer Rallies Michigan Democrats as Election Day Nears
abstract: Ms. Whitmer won re-election as Michigan’s governor by 11 percentage points two years ago. Polls show a much closer race for president.
lead_paragraph: A campaign bus adorned with “BIG GRETCH SAYS GO VOTE” signage pulled into a labor union parking lot on Saturday as dozens of bundled-up Democrats prepared to knock on doors in East Lansing, Mich., a liberal stronghold in a closely divided state.

headline: Review: Seven Dancers, a Mosaic of Movement
abstract: Netta Yerushalmy’s “Movement” at N.Y.U. Skirball comes from a patchwork of sources: TikTok, television, marching band practice and more.
lead_paragraph: When a group of dancers gets together, they arrive with years of information stored in their bodies: layers upon layers of formal training and, like anyone else, of everyday experience just moving through the world.

headline: Pro-West Leader Wins High-Stakes Vote in Former Soviet Republic
abstract: The president of Moldova, Maia Sandu, won re-election on Sunday against a rival candidate she had denounced as “Moscow’s man.”
lead_paragraph: The pro-Western president of Moldova, Maia Sandu, won re-election on Sunday in a high-stakes runoff vote in the former Soviet republic against a rival candidate she had denounced as “Moscow’s man.”

headline: California County to Pay $300,000 Over Butchering of Girl’s Goat
abstract: The girl and her family reached a settlement after accusing the Shasta County Sheriff’s Office of unlawfully seizing a pet goat that was sold and slaughtered.
lead_paragraph: A California county’s sheriff’s office agreed to pay $300,000 after it seized a 9-year-old girl’s pet goat, which was later slaughtered, according to court documents made public Friday.

headline: A Vivid Trump-Harris Contrast in the Campaign’s Grueling Final Days
abstract: As Kamala Harris visited a church in Detroit on the last Sunday of the campaign, Donald J. Trump told supporters that he “shouldn’t have left” the White House after the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: It was the final Sunday of the campaign for president, and Vice President Kamala Harris and Donald J. Trump were continuing to race across battleground states in their search for support. But in message and demeanor, Ms. Harris, the Democrat, and Mr. Trump, the Republican, could not have been more different.

headline: 1 Dead and 4 Are Missing After Boat Capsizes Off California
abstract: On Sunday, the U.S. Coast Guard called off its search, which began after reports of six overdue boaters the day before. Officials said a child was rescued and a teenager’s body was recovered.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Coast Guard discontinued its extensive search for four boaters missing after their vessel capsized on Saturday off California, after recovering the body of a teenager and rescuing an 11-year-old boy who were on board, the authorities said.

headline: Charli XCX, Leonardo DiCaprio and Colman Domingo Turn Out for the LACMA Gala
abstract: Hollywood stars mingled with artists for a benefit honoring the artist Simone Leigh and the filmmaker Baz Luhrmann.
lead_paragraph: Blake Lively, Kaia Gerber and Kim Kardashian took pictures under the lights, posing against a backdrop of more than 200 restored street lamps from “Urban Light,” an installation by the artist Chris Burden that served as a stand-in for a red carpet.

headline: Judge Allows Iowa to Challenge Voters It Suspects of Being Noncitizens
abstract: A federal judge appointed by President Biden allowed the challenge to continue, but voiced concerns at some of the measures taken by Iowa’s secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled on Sunday that Iowa may continue challenging hundreds of potential ballots cast in the election on the basis that the voters might be noncitizens, a move that critics say could disenfranchise legitimate voters.

headline: These Uncommitted Voters Finally Made Their Choice for President
abstract: Over the last four months, these voters have struggled with their decision. Now, with time short, they explain who’s getting, or not getting, their vote.
lead_paragraph: Over the last four months, The New York Times has been speaking with undecided voters after some of the most dramatic moments of the presidential campaign, to learn how those events were shaping their choice.

headline: In Nebraska, Separate Referendums on Abortion Create Confusion for Voters
abstract: Referendum 434 would enshrine the state’s current ban after 12 weeks. Referendum 439 would create a right to abortion “until fetal viability.”
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, voters in Nebraska will be presented with dueling measures on abortion. While abortion is on the ballot in nearly a dozen states, and recent polling data appears to show support for measures that protect abortion rights, in Nebraska having two measures to choose from means many voters are simply confused.

headline: Harris, at Final Michigan Rally, Offers Forward-Looking Vision
abstract: “Our campaign has not been about being against something, it is about being for something,” Vice President Kamala Harris said, avoiding any mention of her rival by name.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris made her final appeal to Michigan voters at an energetic rally on a college campus on Sunday, sounding notes of unity while drawing implicit contrasts with her opponent.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 4, 2024
abstract: No Corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Spain’s King and Officials Pelted With Mud
abstract: A crowd hurled mud and insults at King Felipe VI and other officials on Sunday during a visit to the flood-ravaged town of Paiporta in Valencia.
lead_paragraph: A crowd hurled mud and insults at King Felipe VI and other officials on Sunday during a visit to the flood-ravaged town of Paiporta in Valencia.

headline: Jon Stewart Looks Back With Sanity and/or Fear
abstract: The comedian and co-host of “The Daily Show” reflects on how American politics has changed over the last two decades.
lead_paragraph: The comedian and co-host of “The Daily Show” reflects on how American politics has changed over the last two decades.

headline: Quote of the Day: New Life for Factory Towns Hobbled by ‘China Shock’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We’re transforming the Rust Belt into the Battery Belt.”

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: A day before Election Day, an anxious America, weary from the campaign and worried about the state of the nation’s democracy, is voting with determination, with roughly 75 million people having cast ballots in the early voting period. In nine states, more than 50 percent of eligible voters have already voted.

headline: An Indonesian Tribe’s Language Gets an Alphabet: Korea’s
abstract: The Cia-Cia language has been passed down orally for centuries. Now the tribe’s children are learning to write it in Hangul, the Korean script.
lead_paragraph: Excited chatter filled the classroom as the lesson began. Every desk had a paper nameplate on it with the occupant’s name written in the Korean alphabet, called Hangul. Soon, the students were following their instructor’s lead and etching the distinctive circles and lines of the script in their notebooks.

headline: James Van Der Beek, Star of ‘Dawson’s Creek,’ Says He Has Cancer
abstract: Mr. Van Der Beek, who played Dawson Leery in the ’90s drama, told People Magazine that he was being treated for colorectal cancer.
lead_paragraph: James Van Der Beek, who starred in the 1990s teen television drama “Dawson’s Creek,” said on Sunday that he had been diagnosed with colorectal cancer.

headline: Every Vote in Every State Matters
abstract: Races for Congress in California, New York and every other state are crucial to putting a check on Donald Trump if he is re-elected.
lead_paragraph: In the years in which Americans choose a president, that race usually monopolizes the nation’s attention. There are, however, 469 other races this year to choose the people who represent us in Washington, D.C.

headline: Election Night, Plus Five Things to Watch on TV This Week
abstract: Tune into the major networks’ election coverage, catch up on the teen drama “The Outer Banks” and dive into a bunch of true-crime docuseries.
lead_paragraph: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are available to watch live or stream this week, Nov. 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Where There’s Joy in a Terror Bird
abstract: In Colombia, a fossil-collecting rancher has found a giant, flightless killer from 13 million years ago — and a missing link to the region’s evolutionary history.
lead_paragraph: César Perdomo’s small paleontological museum, La Tormenta, is a work in progress. A bare cement structure built on a windswept platform in the Tatacoa Desert, it offers a panoramic view of shallow, craggy canyons carved from soft mudstone.

headline: Word of the Day: paradoxical
abstract: This word has appeared in 100 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word paradoxical has appeared in 100 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 25 in “Can the Row Keep Its Cool?” by Misty White Sidell:

headline: Indonesia Volcano Eruption Covers Village in Ash
abstract: Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki erupted on Sunday, killing several people and forcing others to flee their villages.
lead_paragraph: Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki erupted on Sunday, killing several people and forcing others to flee their villages.

headline: At Least 10 Killed in Indonesia After Volcano Erupts
abstract: The authorities warned of more volcanic activity at Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki, which has erupted dozens of times in the past few weeks.
lead_paragraph: At least 10 people were killed when a volcano in eastern Indonesia erupted, officials said on Monday, warning that there would be a greater risk of earthquakes in the coming days.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Quincy Jones, Giant of American Music, Dies at 91
abstract: As a producer, he made the best-selling album of all time, Michael Jackson’s “Thriller.” He was also a prolific arranger and composer of film music.
lead_paragraph: Quincy Jones, one of the most powerful forces in American popular music for more than half a century, died on Sunday night in his home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: A Small Thing That Gives Me a Tiny Shred of Hope
abstract: A wee flame flickering in the dark.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Second Trial in Teacher’s Killing Begins in France
abstract: Eight more people are facing charges over the 2020 murder of the teacher, Samuel Paty, who had displayed caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad as an illustration of free speech.
lead_paragraph: Eight people went on trial in Paris on Monday in connection with the murder of Samuel Paty, a history teacher whose beheading by an Islamist terrorist in 2020 shocked France and put the nation on edge.

headline: This Retired General Settled the 9/11 Case. Then the Defense Secretary Took Charge.
abstract: Susan Escallier’s approval of a plea deal, one of the most important decisions in the history of Guantánamo Bay’s war court, has drawn attention to her role and the dysfunctional military commissions.
lead_paragraph: Susan Escallier excelled at being an Army lawyer. During her 32 years in uniform, she had jumped out of airplanes, deployed to Iraq three times and was a devoted, competitive runner. Then she suffered a stroke and had to retire in 2021.

headline: Kareem Rahma’s American Dream
abstract: The creator and host of “Subway Takes” and “Keep the Meter Running” makes New Yorkers — and the Democratic presidential ticket — explain themselves.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, the comedian and media personality Kareem Rahma decided to double the output of his internet talk show, “Subway Takes,” from two episodes per week to four. What he couldn’t remember was why.

headline: Doctors Should Have to Report Medically Impaired Drivers
abstract: We are perhaps uniquely qualified to address this issue.
lead_paragraph: When my father was declining from Alzheimer’s disease, my family often talked about when we should make him stop driving.

headline: He Lived in the Same Apartment for 30 Years. Then Came a Knock on the Door.
abstract: After an emergency evacuation put them into limbo, tenants of a New York building are still awaiting a court decision that might help them recover their past lives.

headline: Foreclosures in China Soar, Threatening to Choke Off Bank Profits
abstract: When the housing market was flying high, mortgage defaults were almost nonexistent. But now the legal system is struggling to keep up with evictions.
lead_paragraph: Banks in China are foreclosing on a growing number of apartments after homeowners could not pay their mortgages, as the country’s housing crash threatens the financial system.

headline: Child Care Costs Are Swallowing Their Paychecks, and These Voters Want Solutions
abstract: Talk of inflation, immigration and abortion have taken center stage in the campaign, but women in battlegrounds like Wisconsin say that the cost and quality of child care have become a major concern.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Randolph, the owner of a child care center on Milwaukee’s North Side, pinned a button to her chest that reads “I’m a Care Voter.” She laid out a spread of pizza and snacks outside, a draw for mothers and children in the neighborhood who were milling around the yard on a warm recent evening.

headline: The Art of Not Belonging: Ralph Lemon Takes Over MoMA PS1
abstract: In certain circles, the name Ralph — like Merce or Madonna — lights up a room. The choreographer and visual artist is the subject of a major exhibition of his art and performances.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Lemon, the kind of artist for whom deterrents are provocations, isn’t easily pinned down. He’s a choreographer and a visual artist. He’s written books. He’s received a MacArthur “genius” award. In certain circles, the name Ralph — no Lemon necessary, like Merce or Madonna — is all that’s needed to light up a room. For others, he’s an unknown. You get the feeling Lemon doesn’t mind. He once told Philip Bither, the senior curator of performing arts at the Walker Art Center, that he aspired to be only a rumor.

headline: Sorry, Mom. I’m Skipping Your Turkey Dinner for a Solo Vacation.
abstract: Seeking self-care and a respite from the pressures of the season, more Americans are viewing the holidays as a perfect time to take a trip on their own.
lead_paragraph: Last Thanksgiving, Dennis Friedrichsen, a 43-year-old tech worker from Minnesota, found himself dining on the banks of the Nile, sharing a feast of kebabs and chickpea stew with 11 strangers from three continents. Then he spent Christmas in Tanzania. Like a growing number of travelers, Mr. Friedrichsen saw the holidays as the perfect time for a solo adventure.

headline: Sun Belt, Rust Belt, Barbecue Belt: America’s Debatable Regions
abstract: The United States it may be, but America is a patchwork of regions whose boundaries can be confusing — and up for debate. Especially around Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Rust Belt. Sun Belt. Bible Belt. Grain Belt. Barbecue Belt. Beltway.

headline: A Librarian From Louisiana Fights Book Bans and ‘the Haters’
abstract: Amanda Jones, who will attend a gala on Monday at the New York Public Library, lobbied against restrictions on libraries — and faced a backlash.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll find out why a school librarian from Louisiana is coming to the New York Public Library’s $5,000-a-person gala tonight. We’ll also hear what a City Council candidate has to say about a “Saturday Night Live” sketch that has made him an internet celebrity.

headline: How Peruvian Food Became a Global Star
abstract: Ceviche, quinoa, sushi — the nation’s kaleidoscopic culinary traditions are earning popularity and prestige around the world.
lead_paragraph: When the Peruvian-born restaurateur Humberto Leon was growing up in Los Angeles in the 1980s, his high-school classmates had barely heard of Peru, much less its cuisine.

headline: From Museum Guard to Memoirist, and Now the Play’s His Thing
abstract: With Patrick Bringley’s “All the Beauty in the World” now in its 10th printing, he’s debuting in two new roles: playwright and actor.
lead_paragraph: Looking up, stage left.

headline: Jon Stewart Looks Back With Sanity and/or Fear
abstract: The comedian and co-host of “The Daily Show” reflects on how American politics has changed over the last two decades.
lead_paragraph: If you go back to the Tea Party moment in 2010, Tucker Carlson had only just been hired by Fox News. He was two years out from being employed by MSNBC. Elon Musk was stanning for Barack Obama. You got Jon Stewart then into his second decade as a host of “The Daily Show.” And he and Stephen Colbert hosted the satirical Rally to Restore Sanity and/or Fear at the National Mall in Washington, D.C. And Stewart gave this speech.

headline: The County That Got Every President Right (Since 1980)
abstract: One county in Washington State has picked the winner in every presidential election since 1980. Astead W. Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” visited the county last year. Now, he returns in the last days before Election Day to see if voters’ views have changed.
lead_paragraph: One county in Washington State has picked the winner in every presidential election since 1980. Astead W. Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” visited the county last year. Now, he returns in the last days before Election Day to see if voters’ views have changed.

headline: These Fantasy Books Will Transport You to Other Worlds
abstract: Immersive novels by Leigh Bardugo, Madeline Miller, Brian Jacques and more offer thrilling adventures in richly imagined realms.
lead_paragraph: There are few pleasures as delicious as losing yourself in a great fantasy book. By day, you may be going through the humdrum motions of a realistic life: buying groceries, washing towels, waiting for the subway. But a well-crafted tale can transport you to a richly imagined world, swapping your shoes for those of a powerful sorcerer, a vampire bride or an anthropomorphic mouse defending your abbey from a one-eyed rat and his minions.

headline: On Telegram, a Violent Preview of What May Unfold on Election Day and After
abstract: Right-wing groups, which use Telegram to organize real-world actions, are urging followers to watch the polls and stand up for their rights, in a harbinger of potential chaos.
lead_paragraph: Groups backing former President Donald J. Trump recently sent messages to organize poll watchers to be ready to dispute votes in Democratic areas. Some posted images of armed men standing up for their rights to recruit for their cause. Others spread conspiracy theories that anything less than a Trump victory on Tuesday would be a miscarriage of justice worthy of revolt.

headline: Win or Lose, Trump Has Already Won
abstract: On trade and immigration, he can claim a remarkable degree of vindication.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not Donald Trump wins this election, he has already won a broader debate about whom our political system is supposed to serve.

headline: $3.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury A-frame house in Palm Springs, a three-bedroom home overlooking Lake Arrowhead, and a hilltop six-bedroom estate in Santa Rosa.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath house was designed in 1958 by the architect Charles Du Bois for the Alexander Construction Company, with an oversized A-frame facade and Polynesian-inspired flourishes. The house, which includes a casita with its own wet bar and bathroom, is a popular stop on architecture tours of Palm Springs. The tract it sits in, known as Vista Las Palmas, is adjacent to the bustling Indian Canyon Drive and about a mile from the Palm Springs Art Museum.

headline: Dancing? Bible Verses? Booze? A Tense D.C. Tries to Calm Its Nerves.
abstract: Few have a more direct stake in the outcome of the election than residents of the capital, where countless people work in government or politics.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Capitol Hill, young and old, tried to keep Election Day at arm’s length on Halloween, hitting the red brick sidewalks in defiantly carefree costumes: Batman, Taylor Swift, aliens, orange traffic cones, farm animals — anything but politicians or presidents.

headline: Harris’s and Trump’s Closing Messages, as Seen Through Their Ads
abstract: Kamala Harris and her allies have concentrated their spending on addressing the economy. For Donald Trump, one theme dominates: fear.
lead_paragraph: The closing arguments have been delivered by former President Donald J. Trump in New York’s Madison Square Garden and by Vice President Kamala Harris on the Ellipse in Washington, with the White House as her backdrop.

headline: Is the ‘50-50-ish Race’ Driving You Crazy? You Are Not Alone.
abstract: Frank Bruni, Kristen Soltis Anderson and Nate Silver take stock of where the race is as Election Day looms.
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted a written online conversation on Friday, Nov. 1, with Kristen Soltis Anderson, a contributing Opinion writer and Republican pollster, and Nate Silver, the author of “On the Edge: The Art of Risking Everything” and the newsletter Silver Bulletin, to discuss polling and politics in the final days of the race between Kamala Harris and Donald Trump. Their conversation has been edited for length and clarity.

headline: Trump’s Big Immigration Raid Snared Them. They’re Still in Mississippi.
abstract: Five years ago, the raids upended life for immigrant families in poultry towns, but the industry still runs on their work.
lead_paragraph: Baldomero Orozco-Juarez was slicing chicken meat into tenders at a poultry processing plant in Carthage, Miss., when immigration agents stormed in with guns drawn. Some workers tried to flee. There was nowhere to run.

headline: Why Isn’t Trump Running Away With This?
abstract: Voters hate inflation — Democrats should be breathing a sigh of relief to be heading into a coin-flip election.
lead_paragraph: “Why is this even close?” That question consistently rings out as an accusation in the left precincts of American political life. The suggestion is that Donald Trump’s continued viability as a presidential candidate reveals something dark and damning about either the country as a whole or the Democratic Party specifically.

headline: The Early Loves of Oliver Sacks: Medicine, Muscles and Motorbikes
abstract: A new collection of personal letters tracks the neurologist’s raucous self-discovery and venerable career.
lead_paragraph: The first 200 pages of Oliver Sacks’s letters are among the best things I’ve read all year. He was new in America, not long out of Oxford University, writing to family and friends back home, and his observations were electric — wild and funny and befuddled and frank.

headline: The Future of the Planet Hangs on This Vote
abstract: If you care about the future of this planet and the future of the human race, you cannot afford to sit out this election.
lead_paragraph: In thinking about climate change, I often feel desperate, but in talking with others I try not to lead with despair. Like all human emotions, despair is contagious. Worse, it leads to immobility, and we have run out of time for hand-wringing. If ever we must resist the temptation to fall into despair, surely it is now, with the election polls so close and the future of the planet hanging on what happens Tuesday.

headline: In Ballot Issues, Voting and Democracy Are Having a Moment
abstract: Residents in almost 20 states will decide on issues about gerrymanders, election rules and other voting issues.
lead_paragraph: In a campaign season where the health of American democracy is hotly debated, voters in almost 20 states will get a chance to decide whether to change some of the basic rules of elections.

headline: Reading the Auras of Democrats and Republicans on the Eve of the Election
abstract: There was one moment in this election where the vibes actually shifted, and you probably can guess what it was.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day upon us, how is everyone feeling about the presidential race? Angry? Hopeful? Anxious? Exhausted? Perfectly Zen? If we could take an aura photograph of the American electorate — a portrait filled with blobs of color by electromagnetic sensors, intended to reveal the subject’s character and state of mind — what would it look like?

headline: Does Everyone Have a Responsibility to Vote?
abstract: Is it OK not to vote, or is voting a civic duty?
lead_paragraph: A healthy representative democracy depends on citizens exercising their right to vote. More than 75 million Americans have cast an early ballot so far this election cycle, but many tens of millions of Americans will still probably sit this election out.

headline: Herzog & de Meuron to Renovate Breuer Building for Sotheby’s
abstract: The Pritzker-winning architectural firm is known for its transformation of existing structures like the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: The Pritzker-winning architects Herzog & de Meuron will renovate the modernist Breuer building into Sotheby’s new global headquarters, the auction house announced on Monday, adding that it has completed the purchase of the Madison Avenue building from the Whitney Museum.

headline: Why Are People Still Buying Ripped Jeans?
abstract: A reader wonders if ripped jeans will ever go out of style. Our fashion critic offers insight into the future of distressed denim.
lead_paragraph: Forget 10 years. Pre-ripped jeans, because that is what we are talking about, really — the kind of wear and tear that is artfully, or not so artfully, designed into denim, as opposed to the kind of wear and tear that happens over time — have been with us for more than three decades.

headline: Some Late Shifts, but Polls Remain Closest They’ve Ever Been
abstract: The polls tend to err as a group in one direction or the other, so a fairly decisive win by either candidate is still possible.
lead_paragraph: With one day left in the 2024 campaign, the polls show one of the closest presidential elections in the history of American politics.

headline: In Pennsylvania, Republicans Stress Optimism While Democrats Just Stress
abstract: The biggest battleground of the presidential campaign remains tied on the eve of Election Day, with both the Trump and Harris campaigns saying they have the advantage.
lead_paragraph: In a park in northern York County, Pa., where rural farmland bangs into new suburban construction, busloads of Democratic canvassers on Saturday were preparing to knock on doors in a region where not long ago, their voters scarcely existed.

headline: Is Something Worrying You?
abstract: Election Day anxiety can’t get much worse than this.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Well, Bret, tomorrow’s the day. Have you voted yet?

headline: Fleeing Northern Gaza Risked His Life. Staying Destroyed His Family.
abstract: For Gazans facing Israel’s latest offensive against Hamas in the north, every option is fraught with peril.
lead_paragraph: One brother chose to flee. His siblings chose to stay. None of them escaped the horrors of one of the deadliest Israeli campaigns in northern Gaza since the yearlong war began.

headline: Why the New York Times Editorial Board Endorsed Kamala Harris
abstract: Kathleen Kingsbury, the editor of Times Opinion, explains why the editorial board concluded that “Kamala Harris is the only patriotic choice for president” and shares more about its approach to endorsements.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Kingsbury, the editor of Times Opinion, explains why the editorial board concluded that “Kamala Harris is the only patriotic choice for president” and shares more about its approach to endorsements.

headline: How Red and Blue America Shop, Eat and Live
abstract: Politics map onto our everyday life in surprising ways, a data set of millions of places shows.
lead_paragraph: Politics map onto our everyday life in surprising ways, a data set of millions of places shows.

headline: Quincy Jones’s Legacy in 14 Essential Songs
abstract: As a producer, arranger, composer, bandleader and recording artist, he made a powerful mark on nearly every genre he touched. He died Sunday, at 91.
lead_paragraph: Quincy Jones, who died at 91 on Sunday, was a colossus of American music, leaving a profound influence on nearly every genre he touched, from the 1950s on — jazz, funk, soundtracks, syrupy R&B and chart-topping pop.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 513
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Nov. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,235
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Ad Campaign
abstract: Advertising is the biggest expense in a race expected to cost $3.5 billion. These are the stories the candidates are using it to tell.
lead_paragraph: By the time it’s over, this year’s race for president will have cost at least $3.5 billion. The single biggest expense will be campaign ads.

headline: What the Final Polls Tell Us, and the Music Great Quincy Jones Dies
abstract: Plus, right-wing groups prepare to dispute the election.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Case of Document Leaks Roils Israel
abstract: An individual with connections to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office is being investigated. Here’s what to know about how the furor began and what might happen next.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli authorities are investigating a civilian who has been working over the past year in the office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and is suspected of illegally obtaining and leaking classified documents to the news media.

headline: New York Times Tech Workers Go on Strike
abstract: The Times Tech Guild represents more than 600 software developers and others who run the back-end systems behind The Times’s digital operation.
lead_paragraph: The Times Tech Guild, which represents workers like software developers and data analysts at The New York Times, went on strike early Monday, just ahead of the busy Election Day news period.

headline: A Guide to Election Night
abstract: What to expect.
lead_paragraph: Today’s newsletter offers a guide to election night, and we’ll start with a point that many people don’t seem to realize: The process of counting votes may happen more quickly this year than it did four years ago.

headline: Heavy Smog Will Close Schools in Pakistan’s 2nd-Largest City for a Week
abstract: The city of Lahore reported hazardous levels of air pollution on Sunday. Pakistani officials have blamed India for some of it.
lead_paragraph: Classes will be suspended this week at primary schools across Pakistan’s second-largest city, Lahore, after it reported record levels of pollution over the weekend.

headline: Mario & Luigi Energize an Island-Hopping Quest
abstract: Rhythm is a crucial resource in the role-playing game Mario & Luigi: Brothership.
lead_paragraph: Mario, Nintendo’s famously high-voiced plumber, is known to most fans for his action platformers. Less celebrated are the Mario & Luigi role-playing games, which inspire imagination but require a precise sense of rhythm, at least for your right thumb.

headline: New York Times Passes 11 Million Subscribers
abstract: The Times reported steady growth in digital subscriptions in the third quarter and a profit for The Athletic for the first time since it acquired the sports site in 2022.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times added roughly 260,000 paid digital subscribers in the third quarter of the year, the company said on Monday, crossing the threshold of 11 million total subscribers for the first time.

headline: Physical Intelligence, a Robot A.I. Specialist, Raises Millions From Bezos
abstract: The start-up raised $400 million in a funding round with investments from the likes of Jeff Bezos, Thrive Capital and OpenAI.
lead_paragraph: Physical Intelligence, an artificial intelligence start-up seeking to create brains for a wide variety of robots, plans to announce on Monday that it had raised $400 million in financing from major investors.

headline: A November Surprise Is Jostling the Markets
abstract: The dollar, Treasury yields and crypto currencies have fallen, reversing some elements of the so-called Trump trade after an unexpected poll result.
lead_paragraph: Investors on Monday appear to be unwinding bets on the so-called Trump trade. In a major reversal, bonds have rallied and the dollar and crypto currencies have dipped in the race’s final hours.

headline: Do You Know These Space Books That Were Adapted Into Hit Movies?
abstract: This short trivia quiz tests your knowledge of fiction and nonfiction works that were made into popular films about space exploration and the quest to connect with other worlds.
lead_paragraph: This short trivia quiz tests your knowledge of fiction and nonfiction works that were made into popular films about space exploration and the quest to connect with other worlds.

headline: San Franciscans Are ‘Fighting for Their Lives’ Over One Great Highway
abstract: Residents are feuding over whether to turn a two-mile stretch of road along the Pacific Ocean into a bikeway and walking path.
lead_paragraph: Forget the mayor’s race. Forget ballot measures about crime and schools. For many San Franciscans, short of the presidency, the most important contest on Tuesday will determine the future of one short road.

headline: What It Means to Come of Age in Climate Chaos
abstract: Today’s teenagers were born into the global-warming crisis, but already it’s upending their adolescence — and will define their future.
lead_paragraph: Today’s teenagers were born into the global-warming crisis, but already it’s upending their adolescence — and will define their future.

headline: Quincy Jones: A Life in Photos
abstract: Mr. Jones’s extraordinary musical talent was perhaps matched only by his work ethic, making him one of the most prolific people in music.
lead_paragraph: A musician, bandleader, composer, producer and much more, Quincy Jones, who died at 91 on Sunday in California, led many musical lives. Only supreme talent can explain his accomplishments, but there was another factor, too: a ferocious work ethic.

headline: U.S. Farmers Brace for New Trump Trade Wars Amid Tariff Threats
abstract: Despite their concerns, some farm operators still support the former president and prefer his overall economic plan.
lead_paragraph: To former President Donald J. Trump, “tariff” is the most beautiful word in the dictionary.

headline: How Uvalde’s Newspaper Kept Going, Despite Unimaginable Loss
abstract: Craig Garnett, the publisher of The Uvalde Leader-News, opens up about covering a tragedy that was — and is — too close to home.
lead_paragraph: Craig Garnett played many roles as he drove around Uvalde, Texas, in his white pickup truck.

headline: Cost of Mpox Shot Deters Americans at Risk, Critics Say
abstract: The epidemic in Africa continues to grow, prompting fears of another outbreak in the U.S. But the vaccine is no longer free, and vulnerable people are going without.
lead_paragraph: A particularly deadly form of mpox, formerly called monkeypox, has led to more than 48,000 cases and more than 1,100 deaths in Africa this year. The Biden administration has donated one million doses of the vaccine to affected countries.

headline: Who Wins Wisconsin May Depend on This Crumbling G.O.P. Stronghold
abstract: Waukesha County, a suburban area that was long the heart of Wisconsin Republican politics, has moved left. Kamala Harris is trying to accelerate that shift, and Donald Trump needs it to slow.
lead_paragraph: Pat Ruttum lived in her Milwaukee suburb for 25 years before she felt comfortable revealing to her neighbors that she was a Democrat.

headline: Elon Musk and His Super PAC Face Their Crucible Moment
abstract: Donald Trump’s presidential campaign is relying heavily on Mr. Musk’s organization to get Republican voters to the polls.
lead_paragraph: For Elon Musk, it all comes down to this.

headline: For This Rising Conductor, Classical Music Was Never Elitist
abstract: Robert Treviño, who has drawn acclaim for recent recordings, learned music in public school and wants to break down barriers for others.
lead_paragraph: Classical music’s recording industry may be a shadow of its former self, but sometimes, a bit of light shines through. One of the brightest of late has been Robert Treviño, a Mexican American conductor who has been the music director of the Basque National Orchestra in San Sebastián, Spain, since 2017.

headline: Nashville Needs an Infrastructure Fix. Will Voters Agree to Pay for It?
abstract: Desperate to compete with other growing cities, Nashville’s leaders are trying once again to convince voters that a sales tax increase is worth the price.
lead_paragraph: Asked in 2018 to pay for a transportation overhaul that would include a new light rail system and a downtown tunnel, Nashville voters bluntly said no.

headline: An Angry Spain, Still Reeling From Floods, Faces More Rain
abstract: Emergency workers continued the search for victims of last week’s flash floods, while a national debate raged over who was to blame for the catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: As families along Spain’s Mediterranean coast took to the country’s airwaves to plead for help finding lost loved ones in the aftermath of last week’s devastating floods, the government on Monday deployed hundreds more troops to help with the search for victims, according to the emergency authorities.

headline: Five-Star, Reader-Favorite Lemony Chicken-Feta Meatball Soup
abstract: “This is the best soup I’ve ever had in my entire life.”
lead_paragraph: In the New York area, fall has been interrupting itself with summer weather, but that doesn’t mean winter won’t come in the end. I wish there were a way to store all this warmth in my bones for when the freeze finally arrives. But I know I can always put it on my table via zingy, sun-zapped herbs, fruits and vegetables that recall the blue skies they grew under.

headline: When Chronic Diseases Come With Chronic Financial Pressure
abstract: For millions of Americans, paying for the treatment needed to manage their diseases can become its own lifelong problem.
lead_paragraph: Karen Mancera ended the phone call in a panic. In July, she was informed that she was being dropped from a program that allowed her to get free infusions of a medication she needed to keep her chronic inflammatory bowel disease at bay.

headline: How Cannabis Use is Changing Across the U.S.
abstract: As voters weigh in on measures that would broaden marijuana access, recent data reveals unexpected trends in who uses it, and how.
lead_paragraph: Voters in four states will weigh in this week on ballot initiatives that would legalize the recreational or medical use of marijuana.

headline: How Americans Feel About the Election: Anxious and Scared
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump have framed the presidential race as an existential battle. Voters are heeding their warnings.
lead_paragraph: In the American ideal, elections are moments of patriotism, a time for citizens to settle their differences at the ballot box, no matter how fiery the disagreements.

headline: 5 Reasons Early Voting Is Overwhelmed With Falsehoods
abstract: Misleading anecdotes and rumors are spreading faster, and with more ferocity, than in the run-ups to past presidential contests.
lead_paragraph: This year’s early voting period appears to be far more polluted with election misinformation than those in previous presidential races, according to researchers who track disinformation.

headline: A Taylor Dancer for the Ages, ‘Unmannered and Wondrous’
abstract: Carolyn Adams, the Paul Taylor dancer turned educator, is being honored at the company’s gala with a new solo by Robert Battle, her former student.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor loved his dancers, but Carolyn Adams must have been in another league. In his autobiography, Taylor recalled his reaction to her audition for his company: She was “a sure bet, a gold mine.”

headline: A New Boon for Georgia Democrats: Winners of Big Georgia Races
abstract: Elected less than four years ago, Senators Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock have become a Southern battleground’s star campaigners.
lead_paragraph: Almost as soon as Senator Jon Ossoff strode onto College Avenue last week, just up the block from the University of Georgia, a few women giggled and pointed their phones toward him.

headline: How ‘Blitz’ Recreates War-Torn London
abstract: Steve McQueen’s latest film, set in 1940 during Germany’s bombardment of the British capital, draws extensively from wartime photos, and much of it was shot outside London.
lead_paragraph: In a London train station, a young Black child clutches a suitcase with both hands. Drowning in his coat, he wears a flat cap and a stoic expression, striding toward his future as an evacuee. The photograph, taken during the eight-month-long bombardment of British cities by German forces during World War II, was one of the images that inspired Steve McQueen’s new film “Blitz,” currently in select theaters.

headline: Trump keeps decrying rampant crime. Here’s how his misleading claim has shifted.
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump insists that the United States under a Democratic administration is lawless and violent. The facts show otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump insists that the United States under a Democratic administration is lawless and violent. The facts show otherwise.

headline: Trump’s Crowds Are Dwindling as His Campaign Winds Down
abstract: The former president likes to talk about the attendance at his rallies, but empty seats and early exits have grown more common.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has spent parts of the last week of his campaign speaking in self-aggrandizing reverence about the arenas he has filled and the size of his enthusiastic audiences. Never again, he has said, will there be crowds like the ones he has attracted this year.

headline: The Core of Kennedy’s Pitch for Trump? Kennedy.
abstract: Even as the former independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has endorsed Donald J. Trump and campaigned for him, his message to voters is clear: Vote Trump to get me.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s endorsement of former President Donald J. Trump over the summer yoked together two men with large egos and dedicated followings, with an eye toward political expediency and mutual interest.

headline: Vance Describes Election Day Nerves, and an Agenda for His Vice Presidency
abstract: With the close, tense campaign nearing its end, Senator JD Vance projected optimism, but added: “I just want to know.”
lead_paragraph: Since joining the Republican presidential ticket in July, Senator JD Vance has projected unrelenting confidence that he and Donald J. Trump will win the White House. But in the final days of the race, he acknowledged that they had not spoken much about what kind of role he might play after an election victory.

headline: 2 Police Officers Charged With Reckless Manslaughter in Ohio Man’s Death
abstract: The two police officers, who are white, held down the man, who was Black, for seven minutes as he told them he could not breathe.
lead_paragraph: Two white police officers in Canton, Ohio, appeared in court Monday after they were charged with reckless manslaughter in the death of a Black man who was pinned and handcuffed face down.

headline: Iranians Wonder if Trump Wins, Would Things Be Different This Time?
abstract: While Donald J. Trump is seen by many in Tehran as having been disastrous for their country, some hope he might be more open to negotiation in a second term as U.S. president.
lead_paragraph: The last time Donald J. Trump was in office, the consequences for the Islamic Republic of Iran were disastrous.

headline: Long After Sunset, the Final Two Runners Cross the Marathon Finish Line
abstract: Two runners with injuries ended the New York City Marathon on their own two feet — and a pair of crutches.
lead_paragraph: More than 13 hours after the first racers crossed the starting line of the New York City Marathon on Sunday morning, the final two hobbled across the finish line long after the sun had set.

headline: Reaching Rural Voters in North Carolina After Hurricane Helene
abstract: Ahead of Election Day, canvassers knocked on voters’ doors in Ashe County in storm-ravaged Western North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of Election Day, canvassers knocked on voters’ doors in Ashe County in storm-ravaged Western North Carolina.

headline: 12 Treats to Bake While You Wait for Election Results
abstract: Take a break from your screen and make something delicious. It’s a win-win.
lead_paragraph: Scraping chocolate sauce out of a bowl with a spatula. Rolling cookie dough into balls with your hands. Frosting cinnamon rolls while they’re still hot from the oven. For many, baking is a great way to pass the time. It’s hands-on, methodical and requires your full attention. (You can’t doomscroll and whisk at the same time.) Best of all, there’s a delicious reward at the end.

headline: Israeli Strikes Damage a Major Hospital in Northern Gaza, Officials Say
abstract: Patients and medical staff were wounded at Kamal Adwan Hospital, one of the few in northern Gaza still providing limited medical care, the health ministry and the hospital’s chief said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli bombardment damaged an already crippled major hospital in the northern Gaza Strip on Monday, injuring medical staff and patients, local officials said, a week after Israeli forces withdrew from the complex and detained dozens of people, including medical workers.

headline: No, voting machines are not intentionally ‘flipping’ votes between candidates.
abstract: Voters sometimes make mistakes when they use digital voting machines. But the issues are quickly remedied.
lead_paragraph: Social media users have falsely claimed that digital voting machines have been programmed to switch votes from Republicans to Democrats, or vice versa.

headline: Preppers Await the End. But First, the Election.
abstract: In Arizona, groups like the Dewey preppers are ready for the apocalypse and for whatever might come after Nov. 5.
lead_paragraph: The meeting of 19 or so Arizonans in a squat Baptist church to discuss their preparedness for society’s possible collapse was just one event in Mike Fendt’s weekly schedule.

headline: A Grim Trump and an Upbeat Harris End the Race Hitting Opposite Notes
abstract: The moods and messages were more different than ever as the presidential rivals made one last scramble through battleground states, their ambitions riding heavily on Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris closed out their campaigns in the final hours before Election Day in starkly different moods: The former president, often appearing drained at arenas that were not filled, claimed that the country was on the brink of ruin, while the vice president promised a more united future as energized supporters chanted alongside her, “We’re not going back.”

headline: Energized but Uneasy, the Campaigns Make Frantic Final Pushes
abstract: Democrats in battleground states have built a tightly structured get-out-the-vote operation, while Republicans have relied more on outside groups for canvassing.
lead_paragraph: Michael Magnanti listened in his church in Oxford, N.C., on Sunday morning as the pastor asked whether anyone had an announcement for the congregation.

headline: Tracking Typhoon Yinxing
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Yinxing.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Yinxing.

headline: ‘Coach Walz’ Delivers a Last Round of Fiery Pep Talks
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, is making a last-minute appeal to white working-class men. But for all his talk of football, that bloc is far from a safe bet for his ticket.
lead_paragraph: In a packed music venue in Savannah, with polls showing Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump in a dead heat in Georgia and beyond, the lights were dim and the room was focused.

headline: A Pendulous Overcoat for a Swing State
abstract: Temperatures fell this weekend, and Donald Trump reached for a familiar sartorial security blanket on the last leg of his campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: During his final rally-packed sprint toward Election Day, former President Donald J. Trump expanded his typical wardrobe of blue suits and red ties to include some new uniforms. In Pennsylvania, he wore a gray McDonald’s apron for one photo op, and days later, in Wisconsin, he layered a white dress shirt with a fluorescent-orange trash collector’s vest.

headline: ‘A Good Closer’: How Harris’s First Race Shaped Her 2024 Bid
abstract: In 2003, Kamala Harris ran a fast-paced underdog campaign for San Francisco district attorney against a political brawler. Her relentless focus, former aides say, helped carry her to victory.
lead_paragraph: It was the week before Labor Day in 2003 when Rebecca Prozan got a call from a tenacious 38-year-old lawyer making her first run for elected office. The lawyer had a challenge: She wanted Ms. Prozan to manage the final stretch of her campaign to defeat the sitting San Francisco district attorney. She was unknown to the public, polling in single digits. And she had just 70 days to turn it around.

headline: Sydney to Become Seventh World Major Marathon in 2025
abstract: The Sydney Marathon has joined the ranks of New York, Boston, Chicago, London, Berlin and Tokyo, receiving a designation reserved for the most elite races in the world.
lead_paragraph: Just as runners crossed the finish line at the New York City Marathon on Sunday, completing a 26.2-mile trek across all five boroughs, some were already setting their sights on a new major race.

headline: Murray McCory, 80, Dies; JanSport Founder Created the School Backpack
abstract: He brought lightweight packs to millions of students and transformed the way they carried their textbooks to school.
lead_paragraph: Murray McCory, who founded the outdoor equipment company JanSport while still in college and whose signature innovation, a lightweight backpack, revolutionized school life for millions of students, died on Oct. 7 in Seattle. He was 80.

headline: Top N.Y.P.D. Officials Have Tense Public Argument at Marathon
abstract: Commissioner Thomas Donlon and his acting chief of staff, Tarik Sheppard, had to be separated by another official, said people familiar with the dispute.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s interim top police official and his acting chief of staff got into a verbal dispute at the New York City Marathon on Sunday morning that became so heated that it was broken up by another high-ranking officer.

headline: Elon Musk Steps Up Pro-Trump Posts on X
abstract: The billionaire owner of the social media platform has used his account, with more than 202 million followers, to herald his support for Donald J. Trump and declare the election an existential crisis.
lead_paragraph: The day before the election, Elon Musk was promoting his support of former President Donald J. Trump on X.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Louisiana Voting Map Dispute
abstract: The case, which will not affect this election cycle, involves a legal fight over how the state draws its voting maps and could determine the political power of Black voters there.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear a long-running dispute over a congressional map in Louisiana that includes a second district with a majority of Black voters.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Americans brace for Election Day
abstract: Plus, remembering Quincy Jones.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. is on edge as it enters Election Day.

headline: Strong Winds Have California Bracing for Wildfire Weather
abstract: The state will see multiple wind events through the middle of the week, and its biggest cities may face quickly growing wildfires.
lead_paragraph: A series of wind events will result in dangerous conditions throughout California that will have parts of the state on edge anticipating the potential for wildfires.

headline: We’ve Been Underestimating the Scale of Women’s Fury
abstract: If Trump loses on Tuesday, we’ll know why.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening I was watching a movie with my family when a text message made me gasp so hard that it scared them. “What happened?” my husband asked, worried. “Nothing bad,” I said, slightly overcome. “It’s just … Ann Selzer has Harris up three in Iowa!”

headline: No Train to Rockaways for 4 Months? Cuomo, Eyeing Mayor’s Race, Objects.
abstract: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who is eyeing a potential run for New York City mayor next year, criticized plans to close part of the A train in the Rockaways for months.
lead_paragraph: When the Metropolitan Transportation Authority recently announced its decision to shut down part of the A subway line for extensive repairs, the decision upset many of the 9,000 riders who take the route each day.

headline: Tracking Tropical Storm Rafael
abstract: Hurricane Rafael Tracker Map: the Latest on Storm's Path
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Rafael Tracker Map: the Latest on Storm's Path

headline: In a Record, All but Two U.S. States Are in Drought
abstract: Little rain has fallen since Hurricane Helene dropped huge amounts across the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: Almost the entire United States faced drought conditions during the last week of October.

headline: A Surprising Poll for Harris Took Iowa Democrats by Surprise, Too
abstract: The Des Moines Register’s unexpected result showing Kamala Harris ahead by three percentage points in the reliably red state fueled optimism in her party.
lead_paragraph: When The Des Moines Register published its shocking poll this weekend, showing Vice President Kamala Harris with a lead of three percentage points over former President Donald J. Trump in reliably red Iowa, the state’s Democrats were among the most surprised people.

headline: Canada Moves to Limit Oil and Gas Industry Carbon Emissions
abstract: The Trudeau government has focused on the oil and gas production industries because the large amounts of energy they use make them the country’s largest source of greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: Canada announced regulations on Monday to cap carbon emissions from its oil and gas industry and reduce the release of greenhouse gases, a move bitterly opposed by the energy industry and met with lukewarm support from some environmentalists who say the rules are not strict enough.

headline: Behind the Election Anger May Be Something Else: Lingering Covid Grief
abstract: In the first election after the pandemic, Americans are heading to the polls full of emotions.
lead_paragraph: When Americans voted in the last presidential election, people were profoundly isolated from their friends and loved ones. Tens of millions of schoolchildren were still learning virtually, and office workers were hunkered down at home, experiencing the world through their smartphones and laptops.

headline: Where Hurricane Rafael Goes Next
abstract: The storm is turning left, moving across the Gulf of Mexico. Forecasters are still uncertain of exactly where the hurricane will go later this weekend.
lead_paragraph: After cutting across the Caribbean Sea this week, sideswiping Jamaica and passing through the Cayman Islands as a rapidly intensifying hurricane, Rafael made landfall in Cuba on Wednesday afternoon as a Category 3 hurricane. Rafael emerged into the Gulf of Mexico, as a Category 2 hurricane.

headline: More Than 78 Million Americans Voted Early, in a Relatively Smooth Process
abstract: But the flood of early voting does little to offer a clear picture of who is likely to win the election.
lead_paragraph: More than 78 million voters cast an early ballot — either by mail or in person — in a weekslong early voting season that was defined by a relatively seamless process.

headline: Police Officer Found Guilty of Murder in Shooting of a Columbus Man
abstract: An Ohio jury found the officer, Adam Coy, guilty on three charges, including murder and reckless homicide, after he shot Andre Hill, a Black man. The killing led to police reforms.
lead_paragraph: A former Columbus, Ohio, police officer was found guilty of murder on Monday in the 2020 shooting of Andre Hill, a Black man whose death spurred protests against police brutality and led to police reforms in the city.

headline: Russia Escalates Effort to Subvert Election and ‘Instill Fear in Voters,’ U.S. Says
abstract: Groups from Russia and other countries could continue to stoke political discord until the election is certified in January, intelligence agencies say.
lead_paragraph: Russian groups and other foreign adversaries have unleashed an extensive disinformation campaign to undermine confidence in the election, and senior U.S. officials are worried that Moscow’s efforts could continue to stoke political discord until the election is certified in January.

headline: If Trump Wins, Here’s Why
abstract: Donald J. Trump came into the race with extraordinary baggage. If he wins, here’s what analysts will say about how he overcame it.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump came into Election Day with a fervent base of supporters and the experience of having already run for president twice. He also came with felony convictions and large numbers of voters who viewed him unfavorably.

headline: If Harris Wins, Here’s Why
abstract: We don’t yet know the result, but we do know Kamala Harris’s strategy. Here’s what analysts will say if she pulls off a victory this week.
lead_paragraph: This was always a challenging race for Vice President Kamala Harris. She started late, and ran against a tough opponent in a bleak environment. She faced an electorate hungry for change, upset with the direction of the country and the economy.

headline: Trump Vows to ‘Fix It,’ Whether It’s Still Broken or Not
abstract: In his final days on the campaign trail, former President Donald J. Trump has portrayed himself as the repairman for a country awash in inflation, crime and immigration — even though all three are down.
lead_paragraph: At rallies in the campaign’s final days, former President Donald J. Trump’s team has posted “Trump Will Fix It” banners. Online, ads flash the same slogan. “I’ll fix it,” Mr. Trump said in an election-eve ad posted on Monday. Inflation, immigration and crime, he says, are all sky-high, and only he can bring them down.

headline: What That Surprising Iowa Poll Might Be Telling Us
abstract: Sometimes outliers are early indicators, capturing something other polls just haven’t measured yet. Other times, they’re a fluke.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, people who pay close attention to political polls received a November surprise: a well-respected poll showing Vice President Kamala Harris leading in Iowa by three percentage points.

headline: Quincy Jones Orchestrated the Sound of America
abstract: Jones, who died at 91, erased boundaries, connected worlds and embraced delight. As a producer, he coaxed ingenuity from his players and singers.
lead_paragraph: I have this book called “The Complete Quincy Jones,” from 2008. It’s the sort of grand coffee table experience so ephemera loaded that it all but spills out photos and reproductions of letters and sheet music and newspaper clippings and report cards. It’s a book that requires a plan to transport it from a store to your house. Some of this stuff is affixed to the pages, as if Jones, who died on Sunday, had assembled it just for me, even though my name’s nowhere near Oprah Winfrey’s effusive “thank you” note. One of the unglued news items, from a 1989 edition of The International Herald Tribune, has now become a bookmark that reads, inartfully: “Quincy Jones: Black Music’s Bernstein.”

headline: Judge Refuses to Stop Musk’s $1 Million Giveaway
abstract: Elon Musk’s super PAC has been giving away $1 million daily to registered voters who signed a petition supporting the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania judge handed Elon Musk a legal victory on Monday, refusing to halt Mr. Musk’s election sweepstakes, in which registered voters who signed a petition to support the Constitution were entered into a drawing to win $1 million.

headline: Trump and Harris Battle for Pennsylvania
abstract: Also, remembering Quincy Jones. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: With Election Day just hours away, Kamala Harris, Donald Trump and their running mates spent today blitzing across battleground states. Trump held two rallies this afternoon in Pennsylvania before a late-night event in Michigan. Harris is spending her entire day in Pennsylvania.

headline: Fluoride, Vaccines, Obamacare: What to Know About Trump’s Health Statements
abstract: Donald Trump’s pledge to let Robert F. Kennedy Jr. “go wild on health” has put three issues on the agenda in the final days of the 2024 campaign.
lead_paragraph: With candidates and voters focused on the economy, immigration and abortion, the 2024 presidential election has been unusually light on health policy. But former President Donald J. Trump’s recent pledge to let Robert F. Kennedy Jr. “go wild on health” has put the issue front and center in the final days of the campaign.

headline: Philharmonic Dismisses 2 Players Over Sexual Misconduct Accusations
abstract: The orchestra said an inquiry found credible claims against the musicians of sexual assault and harassment. They denied the charges.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic said on Monday that it had dismissed two players after an inquiry uncovered what it described as credible claims against them of sexual assault and harassment.

headline: At Daniel Penny’s Trial, Passengers Describe Harrowing F Train Ride
abstract: Witnesses from the subway train said they feared Jordan Neely but also described the horror of watching him die in a chokehold.
lead_paragraph: Several passengers on the F train became frightened as the desperate man threw down his jacket and screamed that he was hungry and did not care if he lived or died.

headline: Why Trump’s Supporters Should Also Be Wary if He Returns to Power
abstract: If autocracy comes to America, don’t assume it’ll be soft.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know who will win the presidential election. Nobody does. But there’s obviously a substantial chance that Donald Trump will return to power. I’m worried for our country and I’m concerned about what my own life would be like under a second Trump term. And you should be, too.

headline: How the Death of a Celebrity Squirrel Became a Republican Rallying Cry
abstract: After P’Nut and a raccoon named Fred were taken by wildlife agents and euthanized, Donald Trump and local candidates accused New York Democrats of “state overreach.”
lead_paragraph: “I know Don is fired up about P’Nut the squirrel,” JD Vance, the vice-presidential candidate, said at a rally in Sanford, N.C., on Sunday.

headline: Tucker Carlson Says Abortions Cause Hurricanes in Election Eve Broadcast
abstract: In a podcast appearance, Tucker Carlson dismissed scientific research that links global warming to more potent and frequent hurricanes, saying instead that “it’s probably abortion, actually.”
lead_paragraph: Tucker Carlson, a top surrogate for former President Donald J. Trump who spoke at the Republican National Convention this summer and made racist claims at a Trump rally last week at Madison Square Garden, said on Monday that the increased occurrence of hurricanes in the United States was a consequence of abortion — which he characterized as “human sacrifice.”

headline: Latest Rallying Cry From Trump’s Allies: ‘Men Must Vote!’
abstract: The plea, delivered by figures including Elon Musk, reflects a growing concern from Donald J. Trump’s team that heavy turnout among women could spell trouble on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: In the wee hours of Monday morning, Elon Musk, the billionaire who has put nearly $120 million behind an effort to get Donald J. Trump elected, issued a simple warning on the social media platform he owns. “Men must vote!” he wrote at 2:43 a.m.

headline: Man Planned to Use Drone With Explosive to Attack Substation, U.S. Says
abstract: The man, Skyler Philippi, 24, of Columbia, Tenn., targeted the energy facility to try to push his white supremacist ideology, according to prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: A 24-year-old Tennessee man was arrested on Saturday moments before he planned to use a drone carrying an explosive to destroy a Nashville power substation to further his “violent white supremacist ideology,” federal prosecutors said Monday.

headline: Meta Permits Its A.I. Models to Be Used for U.S. Military Purposes
abstract: The shift in policy, covering government agencies and contractors working on national security, is intended to promote “responsible and ethical” innovations, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Meta will allow U.S. government agencies and contractors working on national security to use its artificial intelligence models for military purposes, the company said on Monday, in a shift from its policy that prohibited the use of its technology for such efforts.

headline: The Candidates Keep Talking About Electric Cars in Michigan. Here’s Why.
abstract: Electric vehicles are a top-tier issue in Michigan, where both candidates have framed a vote for their opponent as a threat to the state’s auto industry.
lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump made a September campaign stop in Flint, Mich., he warned that the shift toward electric vehicles could allow China to dominate the automotive industry that built that city and others in Michigan.

headline: The Science That Makes Baseball Mud ‘Magical’
abstract: Scientists dug up the real dirt on the substance applied to all the baseballs used in the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: If you looked closely at the baseballs used in the World Series last month, you would notice that they were covered in a mysterious brown substance.

headline: Into the Abyss
abstract: The uncertainty is getting to us.
lead_paragraph: I spent my weekend driving around southeastern Pennsylvania in a rented minivan. And if the interviews I did there are any indication, there is one thing everyone in this divided nation can agree on: The uncertainty is getting to us.

headline: Army Veteran Is Convicted of Assaulting Police Officer at Capitol Riot
abstract: Brian Glenn Bingham, of New Jersey, hit an officer in the face as the police tried to clear rioters from the building on Jan. 6, 2021, a jury found.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the eve of this year’s presidential election, a New Jersey man was convicted of assaulting a law enforcement officer as part of the mob of Donald J. Trump supporters who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: ​Despite Trump’s Claim, No Ballots Have Been Found Fraudulent in Lancaster County
abstract: The county and three others are investigating voter registration forms, not ballots, that were flagged as suspicious. Some were delivered to election offices by an Arizona-based company.
lead_paragraph: Details about a continuing investigation revealed by a Republican county commissioner at an election board meeting on Monday undercut claims made by former President Donald J. Trump and others about widespread voter fraud in Lancaster County, Pa.

headline: Activists File ‘Bad-Faith’ Ballot Challenges, Pennsylvania Officials Say
abstract: Right-wing activists and G.O.P. state lawmakers have questioned the eligibility of some 4,000 people who requested ballots.
