lead_paragraph: One by one, they testified under oath: a military spouse who moves every three years. A man just back from six months of traveling around the country. A graduate student temporarily away for school.

headline: 10-Minute Challenge: Edward Hopper’s ‘Manhattan Bridge Loop’
abstract: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.
lead_paragraph: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about the first day of Daniel Penny’s trial in the May 2023 killing of Jordan Neely misidentified the county on Long Island where Mr. Penny grew up. It is Suffolk County, not Nassau.

headline: Why the U.S. Election Matters in These Countries
abstract: The world doesn’t pick the U.S. president, but it will face the consequences of whether Americans elect Vice President Kamala Harris or former President Donald J. Trump. New York Times foreign correspondents discuss the top issues in the countries they cover.
lead_paragraph: The world doesn’t pick the U.S. president, but it will face the consequences of whether Americans elect Vice President Kamala Harris or former President Donald J. Trump. New York Times foreign correspondents discuss the top issues in the countries they cover.

headline: The Stakes of the Election
abstract: The Morning newsletter looked at how Kamala Harris and Donald Trump view some of the biggest issues facing the country.
lead_paragraph: Presidential campaigns are often scripted spectacles. They can overshadow policy ideas. So editors of The Morning asked reporters at The Times — who dig through tax records, travel to the southern border and study the science of climate change — to explain what Donald Trump’s and Kamala Harris’s positions on several important issues might mean for the country.

headline: The Polls Are Close. The Results Might Not Be.
abstract: We are just a very normal polling error away from either candidate landing a decisive victory on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: These two things are true about the presidential race: The polls currently show Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump effectively tied. And close polls do not necessarily mean there will be a close result.

headline: Speck in the Sea
abstract: Evan Kalish displays his raw talent.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: What Time Do the Polls Close?
abstract: This guide offers a state-by-state breakdown, with some tips on what results to watch for at each hour of the night.
lead_paragraph: This guide offers a state-by-state breakdown, with some tips on what results to watch for at each hour of the night.

headline: Joe Rogan Endorses Trump, and Trump Calls Him ‘the Biggest There Is’
abstract: Mr. Rogan has hosted Donald J. Trump, JD Vance and Elon Musk for lengthy and friendly interviews in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: Joe Rogan, the enormously popular podcast host who brought Donald J. Trump onto his show for a three-hour episode last month, endorsed the former president in a post on social media on Monday.

headline: 3 U.S. Intelligence Agencies Warn of Election Interference Efforts by Russia and Iran
abstract: Russia, and to a lesser extent Iran, will most likely flood social media with misinformation on Election Day and for weeks afterward, the agencies said.
lead_paragraph: U.S. intelligence and law enforcement officials are warning that Russia is intensifying its already robust effort to subvert confidence in the presidential election on Tuesday by manufacturing false videos and promoting phony allegations of fraud in swing states to stoke division and sow fear.

headline: Arizona Official Releases Voter List Sought by Activists After Court Order
abstract: The secretary of state had objected to turning over names of people without a record of proof of citizenship to lawyers for a right-wing group, fearing the potential consequences.
lead_paragraph: Adrian Fontes, Arizona’s secretary of state, said Monday that his office had handed over the names of hundreds of thousands of voters to lawyers for a right-wing activist group as ordered by a court, adding that he regretted having to do so and worried about the potential consequences.

headline: What You Need to Know About Election Night Results and The New York Times Needle
abstract: Here’s how we will bring you the latest vote totals and estimates of the outcome on the presidential race and other contests around the country.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 Needle is live. Get the latest presidential election forecast here.

headline: Quote of the Day: Fears of Violence and a Sense of Uncertainty
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 5, 2024
lead_paragraph: “I’ll be so glad when it’s over — I think.”

headline: Boeing Union Approves New Contract, Ending Costly Strike
abstract: About 33,000 workers at the aerospace manufacturer had been on strike for nearly two months, having rejected two earlier contract offers.
lead_paragraph: Members of Boeing’s largest union approved a new contract on Monday, ending a weekslong strike that was one of the country’s most financially damaging work stoppages in decades.

headline: Clues to a Trump or Harris Victory Could Emerge Early. Here’s What to Look For.
abstract: It has been a race unlike any other, and declaring a winner could take a while. Here are some potential harbingers.
lead_paragraph: You might be excited about Election Day, dreading it, or desperate for it to be over.

headline: Tiny Homes Face the Ax in Hong Kong, Leaving Many Families Worried
abstract: The government says the city’s smallest apartments need more regulation. For some of Hong Kong’s poorest, that could mean higher rents or even eviction.
lead_paragraph: As she surveyed her home in Hong Kong, Liu Lanhua tried not to be bothered that her narrow kitchen doubled as the family’s only bathroom.

headline: Whether Trump or Harris, Pessimism Reigns in Russia Over U.S. Election Winner
abstract: Russian officials feel disrespected by the Democrats and betrayed by Donald J. Trump, who lavished praise on President Vladimir V. Putin but made decisions the Kremlin saw as benefiting Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin may quietly prefer that Donald J. Trump beat Vice President Kamala Harris in the U.S. presidential election on Tuesday. But among hard-liners and ordinary Russians, hopes that either candidate could help bring a swift end to the war in Ukraine — by stopping military aid and effectively forcing Kyiv to accept Russia’s occupation of its territory — are low.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The wait is over. Americans will vote today after a presidential campaign season that many say has been darker than any in recent memory. In the final hours, candidates, staff members and tens of thousands of volunteers were in an all-out sprint, with the race deadlocked and the country on edge. Here’s the latest.

headline: Fire Destroys Century-Old Building at Knoxville College
abstract: In-person classes haven’t been held at the historically Black college in Tennessee since 2015. A fire official said that no injuries had been reported in the blaze.
lead_paragraph: A fire destroyed a century-old building on the unused campus of a historically Black college in Knoxville, Tennessee, on Monday evening. Images released by the local fire department showed smoke and flames billowing from a gutted structure whose roof was almost entirely gone.

headline: These 15 Voters Swung Between Trump and Harris for Months. Here’s What Decided Things.
abstract: The group discussed Kamala Harris and Donald Trump on the edge of the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: The group discussed Kamala Harris and Donald Trump on the edge of the 2024 election.

headline: Vance Mocks Harris as ‘Trash’ in One of His Final Rallies
abstract: Speaking on the campaign trail in Atlanta, Mr. Vance told supporters that “in our movement, we love every citizen of this country.” Seconds later, he called Vice President Kamala Harris “trash.”
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio said in a campaign rally on Monday afternoon that “in two days, we’re going to take out the trash, and the trash’s name is Kamala Harris,” moments after asserting that Ms. Harris had “disrespect” and “even hatred” for some Americans.

headline: Word of the Day: indolence
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word indolence has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 23 in “‘The Garfield Movie’ Review: This Feels Like Too Much Effort” by Brandon Yu:

headline: Late Night Addresses Your Election Eve Anxiety
abstract: “It feels like the whole country is waiting to get the results of a biopsy,” Jimmy Kimmel said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Standard Time Begins
abstract: Sunday marked the end of Daylight Saving Time — and of 6 p.m. sunsets. How does this time of year make you feel?
lead_paragraph: Goodbye, 6 p.m. sunsets. On Sunday, Daylight Saving Time ended and people in many parts of the world, including in the United States, set their clocks back one hour.

headline: Who Says You Can’t Live Off the Grid in Manhattan?
abstract: It takes dedication, solar panels and lots of vegetables. And it probably means putting dating on hold.
lead_paragraph: How long would you go without your refrigerator? How about your stove, lights, coffee maker, microwave, television? In May 2022, Joshua Spodek disconnected his Greenwich Village apartment from the electrical grid to see if he could live unplugged for a year.

headline: First U.S. Election Result Is In, and It’s a Trump-Harris Tie
abstract: It took just 12 minutes to tally the six votes in Dixville Notch, New Hampshire. ‘I didn’t see that coming,’ one resident said of the split result.
lead_paragraph: The chocolate chip cookies were baked, the room was overheated, and one of America’s weirder election traditions was about to start: All six residents of a former hotel in Dixville Notch, New Hampshire, gathering at midnight to cast their votes for president.

headline: When Kentucky Bans Homeless Camps, Where Do People Go?
abstract: Angel Sivado tries to move people from the streets to permanent housing. A new law makes helping her clients more of a challenge.
lead_paragraph: There are many ways to know a city — its front porches, its restaurants, its tourist traps — but Angel Sivado knows Louisville, Ky., by way of its homeless camps.

headline: Eliminating Kitchen Clutter Has Never Looked More Stylish
abstract: Some of the biggest offenders tend to be small appliances like coffee makers and toasters. Designers are creating new ways to maximize space.
lead_paragraph: One of the joys of undertaking a home renovation is getting to build the kitchen of your dreams. Once that kitchen is in use, though, clutter often finds a way of spoiling the look of prized counters. Some of the biggest offenders tend to be small appliances — coffee makers, toasters, microwaves.

headline: A Journey Into 5,000 Years of History at Canyon de Chelly
abstract: Going on a Navajo-led tour of this national monument in northeastern Arizona takes you to ancient ruins and sacred places that most tourists never see.
lead_paragraph: There is an often used, traditional Navajo prayer that begins, “In beauty, I walk.”

headline: These Are the Latino Voters Who Could Sway This Election
abstract: This multiracial and multiethnic demographic could transform American politics.
lead_paragraph: As photographers we often capture the physical act of migration — people in vulnerable situations crossing the U.S. border illegally. But I wanted to understand how movement between countries shapes families in the long term — how children who are first- or second-generation Americans reconfigured their identity.

headline: Retailers Jump at the Chance to Invest in Fifth Avenue
abstract: IKEA and Uniqlo join luxury fashion houses in owning, rather than leasing, huge retail spaces on the strip. Developers are cashing in.
lead_paragraph: On the bustling shopping strip of Fifth Avenue in New York City sits something you might not expect to find: an empty lot.

headline: What’s the Best Way to Get Rid of Plantar Warts?
abstract: These common growths are stubborn, but doctors say there are several options to try.
lead_paragraph: Q: I get warts on the bottom of my feet. How can I treat and prevent them?

headline: From California to the Caribbean: 5 Sunny New Getaways
abstract: Sea, desert, gardens and sun: If you’re looking to escape chilly weather, we have some suggestions.
lead_paragraph: If the thought of winter has you itching to book a sunny escape, here are five new getaways to consider, from California to the Caribbean. Check into a restored Bahamian retreat where Greta Garbo once stayed, or splurge on a luxury villa overlooking the turquoise waters of Turks and Caicos. Soak up the sun on your balcony at a sleek resort north of the hubbub in Cancún, Mexico. Try reiki at a wellness resort on a private island in the Dominican Republic. Or flee to the desert where you can delight in views of the San Jacinto mountains from a rooftop pool in Palm Springs, Calif. Whatever you choose, warm waters and barefoot adventures await.

headline: Fifth Avenue: The ‘Street of Dreams’ for Over a Century
abstract: The reputation of the iconic New York City thoroughfare began with a competition to build lavish mansions that came crashing down with the advent of luxury apartment buildings.
lead_paragraph: In 1916, Marjorie Merriweather Post, heir to the Postum  cereal fortune, moved into her new home, a five-story, 54-room mansion at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 92nd Street.

headline: Should Single-Use Vapes Be Banned Everywhere?
abstract: In an effort to protect young people’s health, England plans to ban disposable vapes next year. Do you think this measure will curb vaping among teens?
lead_paragraph: Is vaping a problem at your school or in your community? Do you see discarded vapes littering sidewalks, parks or other public spaces? Do you or your friends vape?

headline: Pants That Show You’re in the Know
abstract: Wearing these pants, to some fashion enthusiasts, is akin to carrying “it” bags.
lead_paragraph: For many people, pants are just something to wear. But for some fashion enthusiasts, pants are a way to flex their taste and show they are in the know.

headline: It’s Election Day. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: If you’re voting today, expect long lines. Don’t forget to turn over your ballot to see the questions on the back.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at Election Day in New York, from the logistics to the races to watch after the polls close.

headline: I’m a Presidential Historian. This Is My Biggest Regret About Trump.
abstract: I used to think of Trump as a dangerous but recognizable demagogue. Now I see him as a genuine aberration in our history — and a unique threat to the nation.
lead_paragraph: I thought I knew what we were dealing with. When Donald Trump began his rise to power in 2015, he struck me as a dangerous but recognizable demagogue. As a biographer of presidents, I tend to think historically and seek analogies from the past to shed light on the present. And so, for years Mr. Trump’s marshaling of fear, prejudice, resentment, xenophobia and extremism put me in mind of grievance-driven figures ranging from Huey Long to Joseph McCarthy to George Wallace. To me, Mr. Trump was a difference not of kind (we had long contended with illiberalism in America) but of degree (since the Civil War, no figure with such illiberal views had ever actually won the White House).

headline: Contraband Whiskey and a Secret Royal Dinner: Wall Street Goes to Riyadh
abstract: Are you an international business titan on the hunt for billions of dollars of Saudi oil cash? Prepare for “a mind game.”
lead_paragraph: At exactly 6:19 p.m. last Tuesday, in a gold-trimmed hallway snaking off the lobby of the Ritz-Carlton, Riyadh, a lesson emerged in money, power and what Arabs call wasta, or influence.

headline: Could This Presidential Election Be Decided by the Supreme Court?
abstract: It is unlikely that the court ends up playing a major role in the outcome, according to elections experts, but it is possible. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: As the polls open on Election Day, the race between Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump appears to be a dead heat, leading some to fear that the election will be dragged out and the U.S. Supreme Court could determine the outcome.

headline: The Musician Building the Great Native American Songbook
abstract: Tim Long, a pianist, conductor and teacher, conceived his project to fill a cultural need: “There is no repertoire like this in existence.”
lead_paragraph: The musician Tim Long was sitting at his dining room table on a September morning, looking at old family photos and talking about how good can sometimes emerge from suffering.

headline: Advice From a Psychotherapist on How to Cope Today
abstract: The unknown is the most difficult thing for the brain to navigate.
lead_paragraph: If there’s anything that keeps me and my psychotherapist colleagues in business, it’s uncertainty. You can dance on the horns of a dilemma for only so long before obsession, anxiety, depression — the staples of mental unease — set in.

headline: Where Dinner Starts With a Show
abstract: At Crazy Pizza, the tableside theatrics start with the dough, new bistros arrive on the Upper East Side and more food news.
lead_paragraph: The showmanship that can involve pizza is on full display at the first New York outpost of the international chain, now comprising 15 locations, that started in Italy. It occupies the former Osteria Morini space with Altamarea Group, the owner of that restaurant, as a partner with Majestas, the founder. As at the other locations, chefs enter the dining room spinning the dough to the sounds of another spinner, a D.J. stationed at the bar. A broad Italian menu offers typical appetizers and pastas plus 23 pizzas, including focaccia con stracchino, a take on the famous focaccia col formaggio of Recco, Italy. (Wednesday)

headline: Israeli or Palestinian, U.S. Voters in the West Bank Say Biden Let Them Down
abstract: Tens of thousands of U.S. citizens live in the Israeli-occupied territory, on opposing sides of an entrenched conflict, where neither Palestinians nor Israelis have much enthusiasm for Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Like many Israelis, Bronx-born Eli Knoller, who has dual citizenship and lives in an Israeli settlement in the West Bank, hopes the next American president allows Israel to “finish the job” against Hamas in Gaza, where his son was killed in battle.

headline: Have Election Anxiety? These Five Minutes Can Help.
abstract: A short meditation to get you through Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Today, many of us are ruminating on an unknowable future. Eliza Barclay, a climate editor for New York Times Opinion and a certified mindfulness instructor, is here to help with that. In this five-minute mindfulness meditation, she aims to help listeners ease their fears and anxieties about the election by drawing their attention to the present moment.

headline: To Help His TV Show, He Became a Meme
abstract: Brian Jordan Alvarez’s career started on social media. His mastery of the form, and a ridiculous dance trend, have drawn viewers to his show, “English Teacher.”
lead_paragraph: The start of a new TV show is a fraught time for its creators and stars. Years of work have gone into its debut, yet the window of time in which to attract viewers is brief. Add a splintered media environment and an oxygen-sucking presidential election, and the chances for cultural relevancy slip further.

headline: A Final Dispatch From America’s Bellwether
abstract: These Washington State voters have picked winners since 1980. This year, what everyone agrees on is anxiety.
lead_paragraph: For months now, “The Run-Up” has been traveling around the country talking with people, trying to ensure that when today came, whatever happened wouldn’t feel like a surprise.

headline: The Anti-Anxiety Election Day Menu
abstract: Is the uncertainty of the election making your stomach growl? Try these quick, mildly comforting recipes!
lead_paragraph: It took forever, but today is finally here. As the election results start to pour in, you may not be able to ever totally turn off your anxieties. Maybe you could try feeding them instead with these simple recipes.

headline: The Best Laid Plans to Enjoy (or Ignore) Election Day
abstract: Watching the news, attending election parties, singing with friends and getting Botox are among the activities some people have planned.
lead_paragraph: Madeline Walker, 27, was talking to a close friend about how chaotic Election Day can be, especially in Atlanta, where they both live.

headline: How the Election Could Unfold: Four Scenarios
abstract: A look at plausible outcomes that might wind up seeming obvious in hindsight.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 election is close and deeply uncertain.

headline: Don’t Let Trump Make America Into an Image of Himself
abstract: We cannot become what he wants us to be.
lead_paragraph: There have been several American Republics.

headline: What We’ll Know and When We’ll Know It: A Guide to Election Night
abstract: The vote count will still feature “blue mirages” and “red mirages,” but they won’t be as extreme as in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, it took days for news organizations to project Joe Biden as the winner of the election.

headline: Election Day Is Long. Give Us Five Minutes to Get You Through It.
abstract: Sick of doomscrolling? Try this guided meditation instead.
lead_paragraph: Sick of doomscrolling? Try this guided meditation instead.

headline: For ‘Dinner in America,’ a Surprise Theatrical Run Is Dessert
abstract: The film became popular on TikTok two years after its quiet initial release. Now, it’s getting a second chance in movie theaters.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weeknight at the IFC Center in Manhattan’s West Village, staff members corralled a 400-person crowd in and out of the doors while swarms circled the lead actors of the sold-out feature playing that night: “Dinner in America.” The film — an angsty rom-com that debuted at the Sundance Film Festival in 2020 but struggled to find distribution before being self-released in 2022 — has catapulted from crickets to cult status since going viral on TikTok in the past couple of months. Seizing on a rare encore, the filmmakers have rallied fans to support a shot at the theatrical run they never had.

headline: I Voted for Harris, but Gaza’s Horrors Weigh on My Conscience
abstract: The Biden administration bears responsibility for the mass murder and starvation of Palestinian civilians.
lead_paragraph: I voted for Kamala Harris, even though I think that places me on the wrong side of history.

headline: How to Follow The Times’s Election Results and Coverage
abstract: We will have live coverage and analysis from journalists on the ground in about 20 states, along with all of the results.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is here. Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump have been deadlocked in the polls, teeing up what is likely to be a nail-biter of a race to keep tabs on once the polls start closing.

headline: ‘I Will Be Thrilled to Be Wrong’: Four Columnists Brace for Election Night
abstract: Who will win the presidency, House and Senate? What is the election about? And what happens next for America?
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists David Brooks, Ross Douthat, Michelle Goldberg and Tressie McMillan Cottom about election night and what will follow.

headline: Born in London, Raised in Nigeria, She’s Now Leading Britain’s Conservatives
abstract: Kemi Badenoch’s ascent is partly the result of a deliberate diversifying of the party under David Cameron in the 2000s. In her politics, she exemplifies its more recent rightward turn.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Conservative Party made history last weekend, becoming the country’s first major party to elect a Black woman as leader.

headline: ‘The Curious Case of Benjamin Button’ Gets a Folk-Musical Makeover
abstract: The decade-spanning story of a man aging in reverse comes to the West End, transformed into a thoughtful fable opening on the English coast.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Button is born onto the West End stage with a hunch, a walking stick and venerable observations more suitable to a wizened man than a newborn.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,236
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: At Din Tai Fung, the Hunt for Delicate Dumplings Is Hit or Miss
abstract: The worldwide chain is famed for precision-engineered xiao long bao, but the ones in New York are less than reliable.
lead_paragraph: There was much excitement in the New York dumpling community when Din Tai Fung announced it would open an outpost in Manhattan — the Taiwanese restaurant chain’s 182nd opening worldwide and its 16th location in the United States, but the first one east of Las Vegas. In July, thousands of hopefuls kept vigil at their laptops to score reservations as they were released, only to watch them vanish in minutes.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 514
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Nov. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Election Day Decisions, and Why the Count Could Take Awhile
abstract: Plus, how astronauts vote from space.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: A Guide to Election Night 2024
abstract: It’s Election Day. Here’s how to understand the results.
lead_paragraph: After two years of campaigning, more than a billion of dollars of advertising and a last-minute change to one of the nominees, the 2024 race for president is now in the hands of the American voters.

headline: How Markets Could Respond to the Election
abstract: Investors are considering the candidates’ policies and historical trends to bet on where stocks, bonds and currencies are headed.
lead_paragraph: Investors on Wall Street have a playbook for trading the markets around Election Day.

headline: Cryptocurrency Markets, Promoted by Trump, Brace for Election Volatility
abstract: Many crypto investors hope that a victory for Donald Trump could propel the price of Bitcoin to new heights, though a loss could cause a fall.
lead_paragraph: For months, cryptocurrency investors have been eagerly awaiting the presidential election, convinced that a victory for former President Donald J. Trump would be good for Bitcoin.

headline: Truth Social May Be the Company With the Most at Stake This Election
abstract: No stock is more directly linked to the outcome than Trump Media & Technology Group, the parent company of Truth Social.
lead_paragraph: The stock price of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company has swung up and down over the past few weeks, but it may be in for an even wilder ride.

headline: It’s Election Day
abstract: Today is likely to change the trajectory of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Today is the rare day that’s likely to change the trajectory of the United States.

headline: What to Expect on Election Day
abstract: A guide to what could happen, the stakes for companies and the economy, and how business leaders are preparing for the result — including potential unrest.
lead_paragraph: It’s Election Day. A third of voters have already cast their ballots in one of the most unconventional, expensive and tightest presidential campaigns in history.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Election Day, World Series, Floods
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: These 8 Counties Could Hint at Where the Election Is Headed
abstract: While the nation awaits statewide results after the polls close on Election Day, a number of counties could offer insight into whether different demographic groups are voting for Kamala Harris or Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: When the polls close on Tuesday, we will be watching, of course, for statewide outcomes in the presidential battlegrounds. But as we wait for calls, there will be individual counties you can look to for clues — though not definitive ones — to the contours of the vote.

headline: Japanese Scientists Bet on an Ancient Material for Their New Satellite: Wood
abstract: Scientists in Japan constructed the first satellite made of wood by blending age-old woodworking techniques with rocket science.
lead_paragraph: Since Sputnik 1 was launched in 1957, satellites have been made with metals. A group of Japanese scientists thinks it has a viable alternative: wood.

headline: Israeli Strikes Target Syria for a Second Day in a Row
abstract: The military said the attacks were meant to reduce the transfer of weapons and intelligence from Iran through Syria to Hezbollah, the armed group in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military on Tuesday said its Air Force had struck targets in Syria for the second day in a row, attacks it said were aimed at cutting off the flow of weapons and intelligence between Hezbollah, the armed Lebanese group, and its sponsor, Iran.

headline: Gazans Fear Neither Candidate in U.S. Election Will Help Them
abstract: American politics have not been topmost in the minds of Gazans. “We only need one thing: for this war to come to an end,” one man said.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s support for Israel in the war in Gaza has been divisive for left-leaning voters in the United States, including many Arab Americans, and some say it has soured them on Vice President Kamala Harris’s candidacy.

headline: Here’s When Polls Open Across the United States
abstract: While millions of Americans have already voted early, millions more will head to polling places on Tuesday to cast their ballots in person.
lead_paragraph: Americans headed to the polls on Tuesday to cast their ballots in an extraordinarily close presidential election.

headline: How Lina Khan Became an Election Hot Topic
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission chair drew increasing political vitriol as the presidential vote neared. Her political future hangs in the balance.
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the election, Lina Khan, chair of the Federal Trade Commission, was called a dope, partisan and unhelpful by Democrats and Republicans. Democratic donors including the billionaires Reid Hoffman, Barry Diller and Mark Cuban called for her ouster from the agency. Last week, a report from the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee accused her of having a far-left agenda and weaponizing the agency.

headline: For Biden Officials, Lebanon May Be a Problem Too Big to Solve
abstract: Despite hopes that political shifts in Beirut could bring lasting peace to the Israel-Lebanon border, the United States may have to settle for a quicker fix.
lead_paragraph: With faint hopes for ending the war in Gaza before President Biden leaves office, U.S. officials have turned their focus to Lebanon, where they are scrambling to strike a cease-fire deal to end Israel’s invasion of the country.

headline: Politics, Power and Campus Culture
abstract: Readers discuss university governance and identity politics. Also: An election absence from school; feeling “despairalyzed”; a Marathon memory; a wedding dress.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Britain’s Queen Camilla Cancels Royal Engagements Because of Illness
abstract: Buckingham Palace said Camilla, 77, was unwell with a chest infection and had been advised to rest.
lead_paragraph: Queen Camilla, the wife of Britain’s King Charles III, has withdrawn from two scheduled engagements this week after contracting a chest infection, Buckingham Palace said on Tuesday.

headline: Can Donald Trump Still Vote as a Convicted Felon? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Prohibitions on voting will not apply to the former president, who was convicted of 34 felony counts in New York State this year.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s home state of Florida has historically made it difficult for those convicted of felonies to vote, but Mr. Trump will face no such hurdles casting a ballot for himself this Election Day.

headline: Elon Musk Pushes ‘Ballot Curing’ in Pennsylvania, Eyeing Tight Margin
abstract: The emphasis on the painstaking work of fixing mistakes on individual ballots signals that the billionaire’s pro-Trump group expects the contest to be extremely close.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s super PAC has been emphasizing “ballot curing” in the final days of the presidential campaign, a highly expensive strategy meant to pick up a few additional votes in a razor-thin election.

headline: Quincy Jones, the Maestro of the Recording Studio
abstract: For decades, he had many of the pop world’s best players on call — and knew how to coax out their sharpest performances.
lead_paragraph: “Quincy called me.”

headline: Search for the Missing in Spain Grows Desperate Amid Mud and Confusion
abstract: A week after catastrophic floods, some families are unsure if their relatives are alive. Late on Tuesday, the government said that 89 people were missing in a provisional count.
lead_paragraph: Some families in Spain were planning funerals on Tuesday, days after their relatives’ bodies were found in the aftermath of floods that killed at least 217 people. Others were still waiting for news, caught between grief and the hope that a missing relative could still be alive somewhere in the muck.

headline: North Carolina Breaks Democrats’ Hearts
abstract: After several furious months of action, Harris came up short, and Trump came out on top.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect new developments.

headline: The Hyper-Close House Race That Could Make All the Difference
abstract: If Democrats have any hope of taking control of the House, they need to win races like this one.
lead_paragraph: On the final Friday before Election Day, in what may be the tightest House race in the country, Josh Riley, the Democratic candidate for New York’s 19th Congressional District, was making the case to me that this contest would turn not on voters’ partisan leanings but on which candidate people believe shares their “upstate values.” Not that he was terribly illuminating about what those are.

headline: Four Weeknight Dishes and Baked Alfredo Pasta
abstract: Ali Slagle’s baked Alfredo pasta with broccoli rabe and lemon isn’t exactly quick, but it does make for some quality time in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: It’s Election Day here in the United States, and I’ve been asking everyone I see what they’ll be doing tonight as the results start to roll in.

headline: A Hollywood Drought and a Game Show Dream
abstract: It’s tough to get work in film and television these days. So one unemployed writer decided to study up on “The Price Is Right.”
lead_paragraph: There is very little work to go around in Hollywood these days. So to stay inspired over the past several months, Emily Winter has met with a writing group on Zoom each weekday morning at 10 a.m.

headline: Harris’s Plans for Black Men Aim to Avoid the Setbacks Biden Faced
abstract: In the fine print, Vice President Kamala Harris’s agenda for Black men “and others” is an effort to avoid political and legal obstacles if she is elected.
lead_paragraph: In the final stretch of the presidential campaign, Vice President Kamala Harris has been promoting her “Opportunity Agenda for Black Men” to help boost turnout among a vital constituency whose support for her has been slipping.

headline: Irish Leader Plans to Call Election Later This Week
abstract: Simon Harris, Ireland’s prime minister, said Tuesday that he would dissolve Parliament later this week, setting the stage for a general election by the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: Simon Harris, the prime minister of Ireland, on Tuesday announced plans to call a general election by the end of the week, ending months of speculation over its timing.

headline: More Than 80 Million Americans Cast Early Ballots
abstract: Despite sporadic mishaps, the early voting season went relatively smoothly, both in person and by mail.
lead_paragraph: More than 80 million voters cast an early ballot either by mail or in person in a weekslong early voting season that was defined by a relatively seamless process.

headline: Bernie Marcus, Home Depot Co-Founder, Is Dead at 95
abstract: In 1978, he came up with the idea of a warehouse-style store that would appeal to the do-it-yourself homeowner. With a partner’s help, it became the world’s largest home-improvement retailer.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Marcus, who came up with a revolutionary business idea in the late 1970s — create a do-it-yourself, big-box suburban outlet that would seem more warehouse than store — and, with a partner, turned it into the Home Depot, the world’s largest home-improvement retailer, died on Monday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 95.

headline: U.S. Expects Foreign Adversaries to Stoke Anger Over Election Results
abstract: Officials anticipate a rise in false narratives in the days and weeks after the vote.
lead_paragraph: Russia continued to push out disinformation to undermine faith in the U.S. election on Tuesday, but American officials said they were bracing for an even bigger assault of false narratives in the days and weeks after the vote.

headline: Here are the governor’s races to watch.
abstract: Election Day includes 11 governor’s races. Eight have no incumbent candidate.
lead_paragraph: Voters are poised to elect governors on Tuesday in 11 states, including eight that are wide open, with no incumbent running. But only a handful of races are expected to be competitive. Indeed, neither party is expected to gain an edge from the current configuration of eight Republicans and three Democrats in those states — except in maybe one state.

headline: Britain Confirms Two Cases of Newer Type of Mpox
abstract: The authorities said the risk of a rapid spread remained low because the new cases had had household contact with the first infected person.
lead_paragraph: Two new cases of the version of mpox that has fueled a deadly outbreak in central Africa have been detected in Britain, according to the country’s health authorities. But the authorities say that the overall risk of a rapid spread in the country remains low.

headline: Where Can You Register to Vote on Election Day?
abstract: Vote.gov provides state-specific instructions on how and where to register and what kind of identification is needed.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of U.S. states and Washington, D.C., allow voters to register and cast ballots on Election Day. Vote.gov provides state-specific instructions on how and where to register and what kind of identification is needed. Voters can also check their registration status there.

headline: Flo Wants to Reinvent the Girl Group for a New Generation
abstract: On the British R&B trio’s awaited debut album, “Access All Areas,” nostalgia meets ambition.
lead_paragraph: Flo’s singles kept on coming, but where was a full-fledged album? When all its pop machinery was already in motion, the group dared to put its debut on pause.

headline: China Confronts Europe Over Climate-Based Trade Restrictions
abstract: Days ahead of the U.N.’s global negotiations on climate change, China and other developing countries said trade restrictions should be part of the talks.
lead_paragraph: Before they even started, next week’s talks over the world’s collective response to climate change got even more complicated with an 11th-hour move by China on Tuesday.

headline: Israel Presses On With Military Operations in Gaza and West Bank
abstract: Israel’s military continued to target armed fighters in the northern part of the West Bank even as it conducts major operations in Gaza and Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military continued to target armed fighters in the northern part of the West Bank even as it conducts major operations in Gaza and Lebanon.

headline: Trump, Vance and Allies Hurl Insults at Women as Race Ends
abstract: Donald J. Trump has used misogynistic language to refer to Kamala Harris, fostering an environment among his allies and at his rallies that revels in gendered insults.
lead_paragraph: Standing at his final rally of the 2024 campaign, former President Donald J. Trump in the first minutes after midnight on Election Day used a crude sexist remark to attack Representative Nancy Pelosi, the former House speaker who is one of his longstanding political rivals.

headline: Russia Plotted to Put Incendiary Devices on Cargo Planes, Officials Say
abstract: Western officials are investigating whether devices planted at shipping hubs in Europe may have been a test run by Russian operatives for placing them on planes bound for the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Russia has been plotting to place incendiary devices on cargo planes in Europe and even performed a test run this summer, setting off fires at shipping hubs in Britain and Germany, according to four Western officials briefed on intelligence about the operation.

headline: Growing Food Instead of Lawns in California Front Yards
abstract: Front yards transformed to tiny crop farms in Los Angeles provide vegetables to dozens of families and use a fraction of the water needed by grass.
lead_paragraph: On a corner lot in Leimert Park in dusty South Los Angeles, not far from Obama and Crenshaw Boulevards, sits a curiosity that’s wildly different from all the neighboring grassy yards. Abundant and lush, it looks like a mash-up between a country idyll and something dreamed up by Dr. Seuss.

headline: Israel’s Netanyahu Fires Defense Minister, Citing ‘Gaps’ in Approach to War
abstract: The minister, Yoav Gallant, differed with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the conduct of the war in Gaza and domestic political issues.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu fired his defense minister, Yoav Gallant, on Tuesday over differences on the prosecution of the war in Gaza — a risky step at a moment when Israel is fighting on two fronts. The move sparked protests across the country, including a large gathering near the prime minister’s residence in Jerusalem.

headline: Musk to Spend Election Night With Trump
abstract: Elon Musk has spent $119 million on a super PAC supporting Donald Trump and held events on his behalf. But his ownership of X is especially valuable.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk plans to spend election night with former President Donald J. Trump, giving Mr. Trump direct access to the person controlling one of key information platforms on what could be a chaotic evening.

headline: Trump Votes and Says This Will Be His Last Campaign
abstract: The former president cast his ballot at a recreation center turned polling station in Florida and spoke to reporters.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump cast his ballot for himself in Palm Beach, Fla., on Tuesday and said this was likely to be his last campaign, no matter the outcome.

headline: What to Know About the 10 Ballot Measures in California
abstract: The state has 10 proposals on Tuesday’s ballot, ranging from an increase in the minimum wage to tougher penalties for theft and drug crimes.
lead_paragraph: California is known for its love of direct democracy, and voters in the nation’s most populous state are once again wading through a mix of ballot proposals that could confuse even the most sophisticated of voters.

headline: What Are Your Reactions to the Results of Election 2024?
abstract: We invite teenagers to post their reactions and have conversations here. What does this election mean for our nation, and for you?
lead_paragraph: Please keep in mind that this forum is for teenagers only. While there are many places on NYTimes.com for adults to comment, this is the only dedicated spot for the voices of young people.

headline: ‘Moo Deng? Who Deng?’ Meet Haggis the Baby Pygmy Hippo.
abstract: Edinburgh Zoo playfully started (and then quickly ended) a rivalry with Moo Deng, Thailand’s viral sensation.
lead_paragraph: Haggis is a Scottish pudding prepared by cooking sheep organs inside the animal’s stomach, in which it is also served.

headline: A Climate-Focused Guide to Election Day
abstract: As the nation heads to the polls, here’s a guide to understanding the biggest climate and environmental issues at stake.
lead_paragraph: It’s Election Day in the United States, and the outcome of the presidential race will have a huge impact on the world’s efforts to deal with climate change.

headline: 9 Great Songs That Mention Baseball Stars
abstract: The playlist to get you through Major League Baseball’s long offseason.
lead_paragraph: I’m back! A big thank you to Jon Caramanica, Marc Tracy and Dave Renard, the three guest playlisters who filled in for me while I took a few weeks off. The Amplifier returns to its regular schedule today, though, just in time for … I don’t know, anything important going on this week?

headline: Influencer Flanked by E-Bike Riders at N.Y.C. Marathon Is Banned, Organizers Say
abstract: Matt Choi, who ran the course in under three hours, was followed by two cameramen on electric bikes, who were said to have obstructed other runners.
lead_paragraph: A running influencer with nearly half a million followers who ran the New York City Marathon on Sunday while flanked by two electric bikes has been banned for life from the marathon and other events held by the organizers.

headline: Election Night at The Times, Through the Decades
abstract: The first presidential election The Times covered was in 1852. Things have changed a lot since the days of typewriters and motographs — see how, in archival images from decades past.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is one of the most important nights of the year for the United States. The same can be said for The New York Times.

headline: Giuliani Moved Possessions From N.Y. Apartment as Creditors Closed In
abstract: Lawyers for the two election workers seeking to collect on a $148 million defamation judgment against Rudolph W. Giuliani found that he had largely cleared out his Upper East Side home.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Halloween last week, lawyers for two former Georgia election workers walked into Rudolph W. Giuliani’s Upper East Side apartment. They were there to get an estimate on what it would cost to move the former mayor’s belongings. Not much, it turned out.

headline: Bomb Threats Hit Several States, but None Are Found Credible
abstract: Officials reported election-related threats in Georgia, Maine, Arizona Michigan, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Ohio. The F.B.I. said many of the threats “appear to originate from Russian email domains.”
lead_paragraph: Polling places in several states were targeted by bomb threats on Tuesday, officials said, leading to evacuations and some disruptions in voting, although none of the threats were immediately found to be credible.

headline: Facing Outrage, Nigeria Drops Capital Charges Against Minors
abstract: Dozens of teenagers had been accused of treason and faced possible death sentences, but indignation over their treatment, including lack of food, has the government backpedaling.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of teenagers, some as young as 14, had been held for nearly three months in a squalid detention center that houses murder suspects. They faced treason charges and possible death sentences for alleged participation in protests against Nigeria’s government.

headline: Lightning Strikes Soccer Team in Peru, Killing Player
abstract: A video of the incident shows a flash of light and then several players instantly dropping to the ground.
lead_paragraph: A soccer player in Peru died after he was struck by lightning this week, according to local news reports, an incident captured on video in an arresting reminder of the dangers of being outdoors in a storm with lightning.

headline: ‘Love Is Blind’ Resets, ‘Survivor’ Stalls: A Reality TV Check-in
abstract: A palate-cleanse conversation about the state of legacy reality franchises, and what might come next for them.
lead_paragraph: Long-running reality-television franchises — with their familiar rhythms, tensions and resolutions — can provide a wonderful way to pass the time while, say, waiting for votes to be counted.

headline: How to Hand-Wash All Your Clothes
abstract: Even the most delicate fabrics can often be treated at home, rather than dry-cleaned, and it doesn’t have to be a hassle.
lead_paragraph: If laundry is a chore, hand washing might feel like punishment. Who has the time, let alone the space, to soak and lay out to dry large, delicate garments? Running to the dry cleaner can seem like the best option. But the fabric-conscious experts below argue that hand washing the clothes you love is almost always better: It’s easier on fabrics, helping garments last longer, and it can be surprisingly low fuss. Here’s how they do it.

headline: Nebraska U.S. Senate Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Nebraska general election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Nebraska general election.

headline: Boeing’s Strike Is Over. Its Problems Are Not.
abstract: The aerospace manufacturer and its new chief executive face a daunting to-do list, including improving quality and increasing production of its commercial planes.
lead_paragraph: After nearly two months on strike, some 33,000 Boeing employees will return to work over the next week. But getting the troubled manufacturer back on track will take a lot longer.

abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Idaho elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Idaho elections.

headline: State Ballot Measures to Watch: Abortion, Elections, Minimum Wage
abstract: Voters in 41 states are considering ballot measures that also include legalizing marijuana and public funding for private schools.
lead_paragraph: Voters in 41 states on Tuesday are considering a daunting list of ballot measures. They include guarantees of abortion rights, changes in election rules, increases in minimum wages, marijuana legalization and public funding for private schools.

headline: How We Model Election Results With the Needle
abstract: Our live election night forecast is known as “the Needle.” Nate Cohn, chief political analyst for The New York Times, explains how it works.
lead_paragraph: Our live election night forecast is known as “the Needle.” Nate Cohn, chief political analyst for The New York Times, explains how it works.

headline: What Democracy Looks Like in Rural Wisconsin: One Woman Counting Her Neighbors’ Votes
abstract: Graceann Toberman has been counting the votes in her Wisconsin town of 734 people for decades. “I try not to be in a mad dash,” she says.
lead_paragraph: Graceann Toberman climbed out of bed at 3:50 a.m. on Tuesday, when the sky over her 120-acre farm in southern Wisconsin was inky black, the animals outside were sleeping and the only sound was the flapping of the American flag in the wind. Her to-do list was beckoning.

headline: How Should History Books Remember the 2024 Election?
abstract: Now that the votes are almost in, the Headway Election Challenge asks teenagers for the lessons they are taking away from this election year.
lead_paragraph: The voting is almost over, and now the United States presidential election of 2024 is about to enter an uncertain new phase. This will be the last week to respond to the surveys we’ve posted in the Headway Election Challenge, but now that the nation is beginning to look ahead to Inauguration Day, we’d like to invite participants in the challenge to help us with one last project.

headline: Special Edition: America Votes
abstract: An anxious wait begins.
lead_paragraph: After a grueling and polarizing campaign, American voters are choosing their next president. It’s hours before the last polls close in Alaska, and it may be days until one of the closest presidential elections in U.S. history is decided.

headline: How Many Swing State Voters Are Turning Out for Election Day?
abstract: Margins are expected to be slim, and in-person votes could be the key to a victory. Some polling places had long lines, while others moved voters quickly.
lead_paragraph: In an election that could come down to a photo finish, the answer to a crucial question will determine the next president: How many Americans would vote on Election Day?

headline: When Quincy Jones Worked With Michael Jackson, ‘We Had No Limitations’
abstract: Their work on “Off the Wall,” “Thriller,” and “Bad” set records for commercial success and defined the sound of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Quincy Jones first met Michael Jackson in the early 1970s at Sammy Davis Jr.’s house in Los Angeles, when the 12-year-old was still a bubble-gum soul singer leading his brothers in the Jackson 5.

headline: Despite Bomb Threats and Disinformation, a Fairly Smooth Election
abstract: A barrage of threats, widespread disinformation and a security lapse in Milwaukee marred Election Day in some places. But officials say the voting stayed on track.
lead_paragraph: Americans navigated a fraught voting landscape on Election Day as a largely smooth voting process early in the day went on to be buffeted by bomb threats, widespread disinformation and unabated anxiety over the election system.

headline: An Idaho Health Department Is Barred From Offering Covid Shots
abstract: Experts worry the unusual move, driven by vaccine misinformation, could fuel further efforts to interfere with immunizations.
lead_paragraph: An Idaho health department is no longer offering Covid-19 shots after its board voted last month to restrict the department from doing so, an unusual step driven largely by misinformation about the side effects and safety of the shots.

headline: What Elon Musk Told His 203 Million X Followers on Election Day
abstract: The world’s richest man continued stumping for former President Donald J. Trump and pushing conspiracy theories about voting fraud.
lead_paragraph: On Election Day, Elon Musk used his X account to encourage his 203 million followers to vote for Donald J. Trump. He also used it to stoke fears about election interference.

headline: ‘Butchered’ Dolphin Found on Jersey Shore Is Subject of Federal Inquiry
abstract: The animal’s flesh “had been completely removed with clean cuts from a sharp instrument,” a marine mammal rescue group said.
lead_paragraph: Federal wildlife authorities have opened an investigation into a grisly discovery on a Jersey Shore beach: the partial remains of a dolphin that, according to a marine animal rescue group, “appeared to have been butchered.”

headline: Trump Says This Will Be His Last Campaign
abstract: The former president cast his ballot in Florida, and said that if he loses the election and it’s a fair election, he’d “be the first one to acknowledge it.”
lead_paragraph: The former president cast his ballot in Florida, and said that if he loses the election and it’s a fair election, he’d “be the first one to acknowledge it.”

headline: Los Angeles Faces a ‘Particularly Dangerous Situation’ for Wildfire Weather
abstract: Forecasters in California are using some of their strongest language to warn that windy conditions may help fires spread this week.
lead_paragraph: An intense Santa Ana wind event, California’s second this week, is expected to bring “extremely critical” fire weather and put much of Los Angeles and Ventura Counties in a “particularly dangerous situation” for risky wildfire weather from late Tuesday through Friday, forecasters said.

headline: Who Is Israel Katz, Israel’s New Defense Minister?
abstract: The prime minister has replaced an experienced former general with Mr. Katz, who had been foreign minister and who has staunchly supported Israel’s right-wing government.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel named Israel Katz as the country’s new defense minister after firing Yoav Gallant on Tuesday over policy differences amid wars in Gaza and Lebanon.

headline: A Polarized Nation Votes
abstract: Turnout looked strong. Voting ends in key swing states by 10 p.m. Eastern. Here’s the latest on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of Americans went to the polls today to elect the next president. Some voters, particularly in the West, have a few more hours to cast their ballots. But soon, the dizzying and contentious race between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris will become an exercise in patience as votes are being counted.

headline: A History of Clashes Between Netanyahu and the Defense Minister He Fired
abstract: Yoav Gallant, the ousted cabinet minister, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, had sharp public disagreements over Israel’s war against Hamas and what will follow it.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday dismissed his defense minister, Yoav Gallant, as the country fights a two-front war and waits for the results of a pivotal U.S. presidential election.

headline: The Election Eve Library Party With Spike Lee and Martha Stewart
abstract: The New York Public Library’s annual benefit was a who’s who of literary stars and creative luminaries.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Election Day, crowds of writers, artists and politicians stepped past the stone lions outside the New York Public Library’s regal main branch on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan to attend the Library Lions gala, an autumn tradition that raises funds for the city’s largest library system.

headline: Who Is Chase Oliver, the Libertarian Candidate for President?
abstract: Mr. Oliver is polling in the low single digits. It remains to be seen whether his small share of the vote will affect the outcome of the race.
lead_paragraph: If you search Google for “election results,” as millions of people are doing on Tuesday evening, four names come up in a chart at the top of the page. Kamala Harris and Donald J. Trump, of course. Jill Stein, the Green Party candidate who is fairly well known for her 2016 run. And Chase Oliver — or, as many Americans are likely to say, who?

headline: Your Guide to Our Election Coverage
abstract: We’re watching the polls closely, and will tell you what we know as quickly as possible.
lead_paragraph: It’s here. It’s time. The first battleground state polls are going to close in an hour.

headline: An ‘Old Reliable Friend’: Readers Share Their JanSport Memories
abstract: After the death of Murray McCory, a founder of the outdoors equipment company JanSport, readers recalled how their backpacks served them on life’s journeys.
lead_paragraph: Murray McCory revolutionized school life with a lightweight backpack that he created through JanSport, the outdoors equipment company he founded in 1967. By the mid-1980s, JanSport bags were ubiquitous in colleges and high schools.

headline: Judge Denies Request to Extend Hours Despite 6-Hour Wait to Vote Near Lehigh University
abstract: The lines to cast a ballot at the Banana Factory, an art center in Bethlehem, Pa., stretched for blocks, voters said.
lead_paragraph: Young people were turning out in droves at a polling site near Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa, on Tuesday afternoon, with students waiting for several hours, in lines extending for blocks, to cast their votes.

headline: North Korea Enters Ukraine Fight for First Time, Officials Say
abstract: Western and Ukrainian officials have called the appearance of North Korean forces on the battlefield a major escalation.
lead_paragraph: North Korean troops have entered the fight in Russia’s war against Ukraine, clashing for the first time with Ukrainian forces who are occupying a large chunk of Russia’s Kursk region, according to a senior Ukrainian official and a senior U.S. official.

headline: California Might Have to Wait Weeks for House Battleground Results
abstract: Some battleground contests may not be called for weeks because of the state’s voter-friendly laws and reliance on mail-in ballots.
lead_paragraph: California likes to think of itself as a fast-moving state, but its pace can be downright plodding when it comes to counting votes.

headline: Voters Wait in Line for Hours to Cast Ballot in Pennsylvania
abstract: Young people stood in line at a polling site near Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., for several hours on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Young people stood in line at a polling site near Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., for several hours on Tuesday.

headline: To Whom It May Concern
abstract: Some tips for whoever ends up winning.
lead_paragraph: Dear President-elect ­­­­­__________,

headline: You May Not Be Able to Outrun a Vampire Bat
abstract: Scientists put the bloodsucking mammals on a treadmill to understand how they get the energy to chase down their next meal.
lead_paragraph: With gargoyle-like faces, razor-sharp fangs and an insatiable thirst for blood, vampire bats are nightmare fuel. And that’s before they start running.

headline: What to Know About Yoav Gallant
abstract: The Israeli defense minister was fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after the two clashed over the course of Israel’s war in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel fired Yoav Gallant, his powerful and popular defense minister, on Tuesday, after the two clashed over the course of Israel’s war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Justice Wins Election in West Virginia, Giving Republicans a Senate Edge
abstract: The G.O.P. governor easily won the seat being vacated by Senator Joe Manchin III, an independent who caucused with Democrats, giving Republicans an expected win as they push to take the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Jim Justice, the popular Republican governor of West Virginia, has easily won election to the Senate, according to The Associated Press, in a widely predicted victory that helped shift control of the chamber closer to the G.O.P.

headline: Mexico’s Top Court Dismisses Proposal to Invalidate Contentious Judicial Overhaul
abstract: The move spares the country’s new president from having to choose between recognizing a court decision to strike down the overhaul or aligning with her party’s leaders and ignoring it.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s Supreme Court on Tuesday dismissed a proposal that would have struck down core parts of a recent overhaul of the country’s courts system, effectively ending any contest against a redesign of the judiciary in which nearly all judges must now be elected instead of appointed.

headline: Tyka Nelson, Sister of Prince Who Carved Her Own Path, Dies at 64
abstract: Out from under an imposing shadow, she recorded four albums as a singer and had two R&B hits before turning her focus to her brother’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: Tyka Nelson, who was once called “the most famous unknown singer” as she followed her brother, Prince, into a four-album recording career, and who helped promote his legacy after his death in 2016, died on Monday in Robbinsdale, Minn. She was 64.

headline: Black Voters Weigh Character, Policies and Politics at the Polls
abstract: Polling last month suggested that while the vast majority of Black voters supported Kamala Harris, she was on track to receive less support from Black men than President Biden did four years ago.
lead_paragraph: Rudy Cash, a 19-year-old food server, voted in a presidential election for the first time on Tuesday.

headline: Andy Kim Wins in New Jersey to Become the First Korean American Senator
abstract: Mr. Kim, a Democrat, will take the seat previously held by Robert Menendez, who resigned after being convicted of taking bribes.
lead_paragraph: Representative Andy Kim was elected on Tuesday to the U.S. Senate by a decisive margin, according to The Associated Press, after a tumultuous campaign that grew out of a corruption scandal that engulfed New Jersey’s former senator, Robert Menendez, a once-powerful Democrat.

headline: Live Presidential Forecast
abstract: Follow real-time estimates from The New York Times of the outcome in the race between Kamala Harris and Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Follow real-time estimates from The New York Times of the outcome in the race between Kamala Harris and Donald J. Trump.

headline: Trump Is the First Republican Presidential Candidate to Win Miami-Dade County Since 1988
abstract: Florida has transformed from a battleground state into one that votes reliably Republican. The county, a former Democratic stronghold, has followed the trend.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump won Miami-Dade County, Fla., on Tuesday, unofficial election results show, solidifying the remarkable blue-to-red swing of the state’s most populous county.

headline: Contractor Who Defrauded Navy of Millions and Fled Gets 15 Years in Prison
abstract: Leonard Glenn Francis, known as Fat Leonard, bribed Navy officials with cash and luxury goods in exchange for over $30 million in contracts for his business, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A Malaysian ship-supply contractor who bribed U.S. Navy officials to secure tens of millions of dollars in military contracts and fled the country after pleading guilty was sentenced on Tuesday to 15 years in prison, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Trump Team Revokes Election Party Access for Some Journalists
abstract: A reporter for Puck and other journalists were barred after critical coverage of the campaign.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign has blocked multiple reporters from its election watch event on Tuesday night at his Mar-a-Lago club in Florida.

headline: Josh Stein Defeats Mark Robinson in North Carolina Governor’s Race
abstract: Mr. Stein’s campaign focused on education and abortion rights. But the core of his message was that Mr. Robinson, the Republican, was unfit to lead the state.
lead_paragraph: Josh Stein, North Carolina’s Democratic attorney general, won the governor’s race in the state, according to The Associated Press. He defeated Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson, a Republican who had been widely criticized for his extensive record of incendiary remarks.

headline: Why Exit Polls Are Misleading
abstract: Exit polls don’t have a very good track record, and they can contribute to misleading narratives on election night.
lead_paragraph: As you wait for votes to be counted and results to trickle in, you might be curious about whether the exit polls you sometimes see cited on TV or social media can provide a preview of what’s to come.

headline: From Coast to Coast, Americans Cast Their Ballots
abstract: Voters flocked to churches, schools and community centers in an election that is expected to have record turnout.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, tens of millions of voters showed up at town halls, churches and high school gymnasiums across the country to cast their ballots.

headline: Flooding in Missouri Kills at Least 5, Including 2 Poll Workers
abstract: The governor activated emergency operations procedures after the deaths this week following days of heavy rainfall, flash flooding and tornadoes.
lead_paragraph: At least five people, including two poll workers, died in floods across Missouri this week, prompting Gov. Mike Parson to activate an emergency operations plan.

headline: Abortion Rights Measure Fails in Florida
abstract: The defeat is a political victory for Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, who had become the face of a well-funded opposition campaign.
lead_paragraph: A ballot measure that would have enshrined abortion rights in the Florida Constitution failed, according to The Associated Press, delivering a major defeat to proponents who had hoped to restore broad access to the procedure in the nation’s third-largest state.

headline: Republicans Clinch Control of the Senate
abstract: After picking up seats in West Virginia, Ohio and Montana and winning an unexpectedly close race in Nebraska, the G.O.P. sealed a majority. Tight races in swing states will determine their margin.
lead_paragraph: Republicans seized control of the Senate in Tuesday’s voting, picking up at least three Democratic seats and protecting their own embattled lawmakers to end four years of Democratic control.

headline: New Yorkers Pass an Equal Rights Amendment Tied to Abortion Access
abstract: Proposition 1, which enshrines abortion rights into the State Constitution, was aggressively opposed by Republicans, who tried to cast it as an attack on girls’ sports and a giveaway to migrants.
lead_paragraph: A ballot measure in New York designed to safeguard protections for abortion and for those most vulnerable to discrimination passed overwhelmingly on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Site for Crafts
abstract: Has Adam Aaronson gone a bridge too far?
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Alsobrooks Defeats Hogan in Maryland, Keeping a Blue-State Senate Seat
abstract: The Prince George’s County executive will be the first Black woman to represent Maryland in the Senate. Her race against former Gov. Larry Hogan was the most competitive in decades in the deep-blue state.
lead_paragraph: Angela Alsobrooks, the Democratic Prince George’s County executive, has easily defeated former Gov. Larry Hogan to become Maryland’s first Black senator, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Gov. Greg Gianforte of Montana Handily Wins Re-election
abstract: The Republican incumbent fended off a challenge from Ryan Busse. Democrats held the Montana governorship for 16 years, until Mr. Gianforte’s first election in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Greg Gianforte won re-election as Montana’s governor on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, helping Republicans solidify their power in a state that in recent years has taken a sharp turn to the right.

headline: Protests Erupt in Tel Aviv After Netanyahu Fires Gallant
abstract: Crowds lit bonfires and blocked traffic on a major highway after the Israeli prime minister sacked the defense minister, citing “gaps” between their views on handling the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Crowds lit bonfires and blocked traffic on a major highway after the Israeli prime minister sacked the defense minister, citing “gaps” between their views on handling the war in Gaza.

headline: Delaware Lawmaker Wins House Seat, Becoming First Openly Transgender Member of Congress
abstract: Sarah McBride, a Delaware state senator, competed for the state’s only U.S. House seat.
lead_paragraph: Sarah McBride, a Delaware state legislator, won a race for the House of Representatives, The Associated Press reported, making her the first openly transgender person elected to Congress.

headline: Pat Ryan Holds a Democratic House Swing Seat in New York
abstract: Representative Pat Ryan, a moderate Democrat, had been a top Republican target in his Hudson Valley district.
lead_paragraph: Representative Pat Ryan, Democrat of New York, won a second full term on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, holding a key swing district in his party’s quest to flip the House majority.

headline: Kelly Ayotte, a Republican, Is Elected Governor of New Hampshire
abstract: Ms. Ayotte entered the race with greater name recognition than the Democrat, Joyce Craig, and was seen as a natural successor to Gov. Chris Sununu, a moderate Republican.
lead_paragraph: Kelly Ayotte, a Republican and former United States senator, was elected governor of New Hampshire, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Deadly Floodwaters Inundate Missouri
abstract: Intense storms brought tornadoes and flash floods that killed two poll workers when their vehicle was swept off a road.
lead_paragraph: Intense storms brought tornadoes and flash floods that killed two poll workers when their vehicle was swept off a road.

headline: Bitcoin Surges to Record as Crypto Investors Cheer Trump Win
abstract: Bitcoin’s price went above $75,000, breaking the record that the digital currency set in March.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates and results.

headline: Stocks Set Records and Dollar Soars After Trump Election Win
abstract: Bitcoin hit a record, Tesla stock soared and a wide range of markets around the world moved sharply as Donald J. Trump claimed victory.
lead_paragraph: Stocks surged to record highs, the dollar strengthened around the world, and government bond yields soared on Wednesday after a conclusive win by President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Pennsylvania Becomes Hot Spot for Election Disinformation
abstract: More than 60 percent of posts discussing election fraud on X on Tuesday focused on the state, according to an analysis of about 25,000 posts.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania quickly emerged on Tuesday as a hot spot for election disinformation and bogus claims of voter fraud. The vast majority of posts on X about election fraud were focused on the swing state, according to an analysis by PeakMetrics, an analytics company.

headline: Schiff Wins Senate Race to Fill the Feinstein Seat in California
abstract: Representative Adam Schiff, a Democrat, defeated Steve Garvey, a Republican and former professional baseball star.
lead_paragraph: Representative Adam Schiff, who led the prosecution of Donald J. Trump’s first impeachment, won California’s open Senate seat, according to The Associated Press, beating his Republican opponent, Steve Garvey, a former professional baseball star and a first-time candidate.

headline: Japan’s Favorite Snowy Mountain Finally Has Some Snow
abstract: Mount Fuji, the country’s tallest summit, is revered for its snowy peak. A snowfall reported on Wednesday ended its longest snowless period in 130 years.
lead_paragraph: Mount Fuji looms large as Japan’s tallest mountain and one of its most enduring national symbols. Its snowy peak has inspired countless paintings and poems over the centuries, and more recently been featured on travel brochures and merchandise.

headline: Trump Wins North Carolina, a Critical Battleground State for Republicans
abstract: The state has now gone to Donald J. Trump in all three of his presidential bids, underscoring his political strength there.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump won North Carolina, according to The Associated Press, retaining his grip on a fast-growing Southern battleground state that his campaign viewed as a must-win.

headline: With Mannion Win, N.Y. Democrats Flip First House Seat in the Country
abstract: State Senator John Mannion beat the incumbent, Representative Brandon Williams, in central New York, in a crucial win in the battle for the House.
lead_paragraph: State Senator John Mannion has defeated Representative Brandon Williams of New York, according to The Associated Press, delivering Democrats the first flipped House seat in the country.

headline: Missouri Voters Pass Measure to Protect Abortion Rights and End Ban
abstract: A ballot amendment enshrining reproductive rights in the State Constitution would void one of the strictest abortion bans in the country.
lead_paragraph: Missouri voters approved a ballot amendment that enshrines a right to abortion in the State Constitution, The Associated Press reported, a stunning repudiation of one of the nation’s strictest bans on abortion.

headline: Moreno Defeats Brown in Ohio, Putting G.O.P. Within Reach of Senate Control
abstract: With the victory of Bernie Moreno, a wealthy former car dealer and political novice, Republicans had enough seats to win the Senate majority unless Democrats scored an upset.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Moreno, a wealthy former car dealer and hard-right Republican, has defeated three-term Democratic Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio, according to The Associated Press, giving the G.O.P. enough seats to win the Senate majority unless Democrats pulled out an unexpected win in another competitive race.

headline: Ted Cruz Survives Another Re-Election Fight in Texas
abstract: In keeping his seat, he dashed rising hopes among some Democrats that years of demographic changes and urbanization could start to flip the state.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas fended off an aggressive and well-funded Democratic challenger to win a third term and preserve decades of Republican Party dominance in the nation’s most populous red state, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Quote of the Day: He Rebuilt It, and They Came. ‘This Time Willingly.’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 6, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Just thinking about what it was like back in the ’40s when they were stuck here. To me, baseball has always been about connection.”

headline: LaLota Fends Off Democratic Challenge to Win Key New York House Seat
abstract: Representative Nick LaLota, a Long Island Republican, faced a spirited challenge from John Avlon, a former CNN commentator.
lead_paragraph: Representative Nick LaLota, Republican of New York, secured a second term on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, turning back a spirited challenge by John Avlon, a former CNN commentator.

headline: 5 Dead in Arizona After Small Plane Crashes Into Vehicle
abstract: The passenger jet collided with a vehicle as it tried to take off from Falcon Field in Mesa, Ariz., the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Five people were killed after a small passenger plane failed to take off and crashed into a vehicle near the airport in Mesa, Ariz., on Tuesday, the police said.

headline: Republicans Beat Back Democratic Challenge to Hold New Jersey House Seat
abstract: Representative Thomas Kean Jr., a first-term Republican, was re-elected after a hard-fought race against Sue Altman, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Representative Thomas Kean Jr., a first-term Republican, was re-elected on Tuesday after a hard-fought race in New Jersey against a Democratic challenger, Sue Altman, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Democrats Flip Newly Drawn Alabama Congressional Seat
abstract: With the victory by Shomari Figures, Alabama will most likely have two Black representatives in Congress at the same time for the first time in its history.
lead_paragraph: Shomari Figures, a Democrat and former Justice Department official, won election in Alabama’s newly drawn Second Congressional District, according to The Associated Press, handing his party a rare pickup in the South.

headline: Omaha, Nebraska’s So-Called Blue Dot, Goes for Harris
