abstract: Reliably conservative Nebraska had been in the spotlight because it splits its five electoral votes. The state’s Second Congressional District voted Democratic.
lead_paragraph: Voters delivered the one electoral vote up for grabs in Nebraska to Vice President Kamala Harris, according to The Associated Press, a Democratic victory in a hotly contested region.

headline: Fischer Wins in Nebraska, Giving Republicans Enough Seats for a Majority
abstract: Senator Deb Fischer, the two-term Republican from Nebraska, survived a dark horse challenge from Dan Osborn, a mechanic and labor leader who ran as an independent.
lead_paragraph: Senator Deb Fischer, Republican of Nebraska, has won a third term, according to The Associated Press, staving off a spirited and unexpectedly tough challenge from independent Dan Osborn, an industrial mechanic and political newcomer, and giving her party enough seats to take the majority.

headline: Trump Wins Georgia, Re-establishing Republicans’ Dominance There
abstract: His victory in the state reaffirmed many conservatives’ beliefs that the Peach State is fundamentally red, despite Democrats’ inroads in recent election cycles.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump won Georgia’s 16 electoral votes, according to a New York Times projection, flipping the swing state back to Republicans after Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s landmark victory there in 2020.

headline: Nebraska Voters Pass Measure Limiting Abortions
abstract: A competing ballot amendment, which would have established a right to abortion until fetal viability, failed to win more votes.
lead_paragraph: A ballot amendment prohibiting abortion beyond the first three months of pregnancy passed in Nebraska, according to The Associated Press, outpolling a competing measure that would have established a right to abortion until fetal viability.

headline: Jon Stewart Tries to Find Good News on Election Night
abstract: “Look at all the little glass-half-fulls out there,” Stewart said as his “Daily Show” audience applauded a Democratic Senate victory in Maryland.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Democrats Flip a Second House Seat in New York, Toppling Molinaro
abstract: Josh Riley defeated the Republican incumbent, Representative Marc Molinaro. It was the second House seat flipped in New York by Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Democrat Josh Riley has defeated the Republican incumbent, Representative Marc Molinaro, according to The Associated Press, flipping New York’s 19th Congressional District in one of the most watched House races of the cycle.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Donald Trump takes key swing states.
lead_paragraph: As of early this morning, with votes still being counted, Donald Trump was ahead in the race to be the next president of the United States. His fellow Republicans won control of the Senate. Here’s the latest.

headline: Word of the Day: epitomize
abstract: This word has appeared in nine articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word epitomize has appeared in nine articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 17 in “Sausage Legs and Wax Nose Jobs: Peeling the Layers on a Century of Beauty” by Sadie Stein:

headline: Anticipating a Close Race, the Nation Watched Momentum Shift Toward Trump
abstract: A winner was not declared before midnight on Tuesday, but even Donald Trump’s allies seemed shocked by the signs of his strength — and the improbable political comeback it appeared to foretell.
lead_paragraph: The first signs came in the suburbs.

headline: Trump Wins Pennsylvania, a Key Swing State Prize
abstract: Both Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris fought hard for Pennsylvania’s 19 electoral votes, dumping more money into the state than any other by far.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has won Pennsylvania and its 19 electoral votes, according to The Associated Press, flipping the crucial swing state back to his column after President Biden’s victory there in 2020.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Filmmaker’s Private Archive Rekindles Debate Over Her Nazi Ties
abstract: Recent access to Leni Riefenstahl’s estate has prompted new discussions in Germany about her politics and a reconsideration of her photographs of the Nuba people in Sudan.
lead_paragraph: Two decades after her death, the German director Leni Riefenstahl occupies an uneasy place in film history. She directed two influential movies that are still studied for their aesthetic ambitions despite being propaganda for the Third Reich: “Triumph of the Will,” a visually striking film about the Nazi party’s 1934 rally in Nuremberg, and “Olympia,” about the 1936 Berlin Olympics.

headline: Helmet Caps
abstract: Should football players embrace the extra protection?
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. this season is allowing players to wear Guardian Caps, coverings that add a layer of foam to the outside of the helmet, with the aim of reducing brain injuries.

headline: Arizona Voters Approve Abortion Rights Amendment
abstract: Like those in other states, the Arizona measure essentially establishes abortion protections in the State Constitution as a “fundamental right.”
lead_paragraph: Arizona voters approved a ballot amendment enshrining a right to abortion in the State Constitution, according to The Associated Press, joining other states that have pushed back against unpopular abortion bans passed in the two years since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

headline: South Dakota Voters Reject Abortion Rights Amendment
abstract: With voters declining to enshrine a right to abortion in the State Constitution, South Dakota will continue to have one of the strictest abortion bans in the country.
lead_paragraph: Voters in South Dakota rejected a ballot amendment that would have enshrined a right to abortion in the State Constitution, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Trump Speaks as He Moves Closer to an Election Win
abstract: The former president addressed his supporters after he moved closer to a second term in the White House by winning some key swing states.
lead_paragraph: The former president addressed his supporters after he moved closer to a second term in the White House by winning some key swing states.

headline: By Firing Gallant, Netanyahu Removes One Threat but Risks Another
abstract: Yoav Gallant, the departing defense minister, opposed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on key policies. His dismissal has stirred public discontent.
lead_paragraph: By dismissing his defense minister, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has consolidated his hold over his coalition by removing his main internal critic, making it easier for him to set wartime policy in the short term.

headline: TV Networks Prepared for a Long Wait That Wasn’t
abstract: Anchors were ready to camp out in the studio for days on end. Instead, Donald J. Trump declared victory in the early hours of Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to election night, and throughout the early hours of their broadcasts, television news anchors urged viewers to settle in for a long wait.

headline: Barrett Flips Key Michigan Seat for G.O.P., Defeating Hertel
abstract: Tom Barrett, a Republican former state senator, has defeated Curtis Hertel, claiming the Lansing-based seat won by Representative Elissa Slotkin, a Democrat, in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Tom Barrett, a G.O.P. former state senator, has defeated Curtis Hertel, a Democratic former state senator, according to The Associated Press, flipping an open Michigan seat and handing House Republicans a crucial victory in their drive to keep their majority.

headline: Election Results Show a Red Shift Across the U.S. in 2024
abstract: Of the counties with nearly complete results, a vast majority shifted in favor of former President Donald J. Trump in the 2024 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Of the counties with nearly complete results, a vast majority shifted in favor of former President Donald J. Trump in the 2024 presidential election.

headline: Trump Speaks as He Moves Closer to an Election Win
abstract: The former president addressed his supporters after he moved closer to a second term in the White House by winning some key swing states.
lead_paragraph: The former president addressed his supporters after he moved closer to a second term in the White House by winning some key swing states.

headline: A New Luxury Tower Rises From a Seminary and Tries to Blend In
abstract: Claremont Hall, climbing 41 stories above the historic Union Theological Seminary campus, was designed to delight the eye without disrupting the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Claremont Hall, a 41-story luxury residence on the campus of Union Theological Seminary in Morningside Heights, can be easy to overlook. In a sense, it was designed to be. The neighborhood is the closest thing New York has to a Gothic Quarter; among the weathered stone and brick of the seminary, the nearby Teachers College and — directly across Claremont Avenue — the soaring Riverside Church, a showy newcomer would have stuck out like a rude guest. Claremont Hall fits in as though it’s lived there for ages, although it was only completed in June.

headline: The Silly Rule That’s Helping Keep Housing Costs High
abstract: An unnecessary regulation requiring operable windows in residential buildings is preventing a solution to both homelessness and empty downtowns from being implemented.
lead_paragraph: In too many American cities, numerous downtown office buildings sit barely used, their absence of workers gutting nearby businesses. Meanwhile, hundreds of residents, too poor to afford shelter, sleep on the streets. Addressing these problems is within our grasp.

headline: A ‘Wicked’ Tearful Talk With Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande
abstract: The stars of the new movie reflect on their long ride together, getting through Covid and the actors’ strike, and avoiding “playing to the green.”
lead_paragraph: “Excuse me,” Ariana Grande said, flagging down an imaginary waiter. “May we have one million tissues please?”

headline: Her Music Makes Women ‘Feel Free’
abstract: Seductive songs about the pursuit of female pleasure have made the dancehall artist Shenseea a new face of girl power.
lead_paragraph: While touring the Bob Marley Museum in Kingston, Jamaica, on a Saturday in late September, Shenseea, the dancehall pop singer, paused at a glass case. Inside was the Grammy lifetime achievement award that Mr. Marley received posthumously in 2001.

headline: The ‘Super Bowl of Pickleball’ Looks to Grow the Sport
abstract: A world championship in Texas is flush with cash and star players as the Professional Pickleball Association tries to turn amateur interest into long-term fandom.
lead_paragraph: Anna Leigh Waters, a 17-year-old from Delray Beach, Fla., is the world’s top-ranked pickleball player and is widely considered to be the face of America’s fastest-growing sport. But from where she stands, she is still relatively unknown, even among a majority of the racket sport’s fans.

headline: The Perfect Pecan Pie Inspired by Southern Grannies
abstract: Pecans step in for almonds in this play on classic French desserts.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Brewer, owner and baker of the Kitchen Shop in Grand Coteau, La., had a quiet epiphany in culinary school. While practicing pâte sucrée, she realized it was nearly the same dough her grandmother in Louisiana used for her sweet pies, a crumb and texture that isn’t quite a short crust and also isn’t quite a pie dough but its own thing all at once.

headline: The Lip-Reading Hotshot of Celebrity Gossip
abstract: Jackie G goes viral with her readings of stars’ private conversations. She’s kinder about it than any of the people snooping on you.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a video surfaced online that caused a stir, at least among the sizable subset of humanity that is emotionally invested in the matter of Kendall Jenner’s coiffure. The clip, recorded on Sept. 23, captured an encounter between Jenner, the model and reality star, and two fellow celebrities, the singer Camilla Cabello and the actress Eva Longoria, during the annual catwalk show for the cosmetics giant L’Oreal. The three women were in Paris, in the ornate Palais Garnier, the city’s historic opera house, engaged in an animated conversation. What exactly were they discussing? What secrets were being imparted? What dirt was being dished? Was any mention made of Bad Bunny, Jenner’s rumored on-again, off-again beau? As the poet said: Inquiring minds want to know.

headline: Bridget Everett Responds to an Essay on Friendship
abstract: The “Somebody Somewhere” actress reflects on the power of intimacy, without romance.
lead_paragraph: The “Somebody Somewhere” actress reflects on the power of intimacy, without romance.

headline: All Hail the Theater Kid! (We Mean That Sincerely.)
abstract: For stars like Ariana Grande and Lady Gaga, showmanship is a virtue. That’s a big change from the days when Anne Hathaway was vilified for her effortful work.
lead_paragraph: Ariana Grande used to downplay the fact that she was a theater kid.

headline: Bridget Everett Says a Best Friend Can Be Your Greatest Love
abstract: The “Somebody Somewhere” star is tired of the same old love stories.
lead_paragraph: Stories of romantic love are everywhere, but the actor, singer and comedian Bridget Everett says great friendships deserve our time and attention, too. Not just onscreen, but in reality.

headline: $490,000 Homes in Wisconsin, Utah and North Carolina
abstract: A 1928 brick house in Oshkosh, Wis., a Craftsman-style bungalow from 1925 in Salt Lake City, and a duplex apartment in an 1854 mill building in Wake Forest, N.C.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath house is on a wide, tree-lined street and just steps from Lake Winnebago, a popular fishing spot where the catch includes walleye, bass and perch. Menominee Park, which has pickleball and tennis courts, a playground, a seasonal zoo and a waterfront walking trail, is a few minutes away, as is the campus of the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh. The Experimental Aircraft Association Aviation Museum is 15 minutes away, as is the E.A.A.’s Seaplane Base on Lake Winnebago.

headline: She Wrote ‘Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell.’ Then, She Was Gone.
abstract: Twenty years after her debut sold four million copies, Susanna Clarke is back.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, Susanna Clarke, a cookbook editor, published her debut novel, the sprawling 800-page historical fantasy “Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell.” It was a sensation. Clarke sold millions of copies, won literary awards and landed on best-seller lists.

headline: It’s Time to Admit America Has Changed
abstract: Two Opinion writers consider a second term for Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s enduring hold over the Republican Party will send him back to the White House. On this episode of “The Opinions,” the columnist David French joins the deputy Opinion editor Patrick Healy to discuss the future of the G.O.P. and what a second Trump term might mean for America.

headline: Trump Offered Men Something That Democrats Never Could
abstract: A set of easy answers that’s a formula for more alienation and anger.
lead_paragraph: On the long road to Election Day, no group of voters was more loyal to Donald Trump than young white men. One early theory was that his success with this demographic was a result of male isolation and loneliness. But that showed a fundamental misunderstanding of Mr. Trump’s appeal. He did so well with male voters because he is a walking avatar of a kind of masculinity that Democrats could never embrace, and its appeal transcends this electoral cycle.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love the Vibraphone
abstract: Are the vibes good? These tracks by Milt Jackson, Lionel Hampton, Roy Ayers and others, chosen by 12 musicians and writers, should convince you.
lead_paragraph: We’re living in the era of “vibes.” But before that word was everywhere — before elections had “vibe shifts” and before a first date could be breezily ended because the vibes were just off — there was the instrument that started it all: the vibraphone.

headline: Election Results in Key New York Races
abstract: Democrats flipped a House seat in central New York and defended one in the Hudson Valley, and a ballot measure tied to abortion access was approved.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at how key races in New York turned out. We’ll also find out about a “vigil for the healing of the world” that the Episcopal bishop of New York will lead tonight.

headline: What We Just Went Through Wasn’t an Election. It Was a Hostage Situation.
abstract: Telling people they have no choice but to vote for you shows deep contempt.
lead_paragraph: Heading into Tuesday’s vote, a large majority of voters said that the country was on the wrong track and that they were disappointed with the candidates on offer. A plurality of voters said that regardless of who was elected, the next president would make things worse. Nearly 80 percent said the presidential campaigns did not make them proud of America.

headline: The Best Place for a Last-Minute Thanksgiving? Abroad.
abstract: Cheap flights. Fewer crowds. November can be one of the most affordable months for international travel, and travelers can still snag a choice deal.
lead_paragraph: With Thanksgiving just a few weeks away, domestic flight deals have largely evaporated. But the holiday week, when many Americans stay home or fly within the United States, is a golden window for affordable international travel, even for last-minute flights.

headline: Donald Trump Declares Victory and Thanks Supporters
abstract: He said his campaign had “achieved the most incredible political thing,” as news outlets put him on the verge of reclaiming the White House.
lead_paragraph: Flanked by family and supporters, Donald J. Trump declared victory in the small hours Wednesday morning from a star-spangled stage in West Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Donald Trump Returns to Power, Ushering in New Era of Uncertainty
abstract: He played on fears of immigrants and economic worries to defeat Vice President Kamala Harris. His victory signaled the advent of isolationism, sweeping tariffs and score settling.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump rode a promise to smash the American status quo to win the presidency for a second time, surviving a criminal conviction, indictments, an assassin’s bullet, accusations of authoritarianism and an unprecedented switch of his opponent to complete a remarkable return to power.

headline: Trump Wins Wisconsin, Reclaiming Battleground He Won in 2016
abstract: The candidates had fought hard for Wisconsin. In 2020, Joe Biden narrowly won the state.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump flipped Wisconsin, according to The Associated Press, taking him over the 270 electoral college votes needed to win the overall presidential race, and handing him a battleground state that he narrowly lost in 2020 to Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: JD Vance, Trump’s MAGA Successor, Will Be One of America’s Youngest Vice Presidents
abstract: Mr. Vance’s victory caps his ideological reversal from anti-Trump author to pro-Trump senator.
lead_paragraph: JD Vance, a 40-year-old senator who transformed himself from a biting critic of Donald J. Trump to one of his fiercest defenders, was elected the next vice president of the United States on Wednesday, becoming the third youngest and among the least experienced and most polarizing politicians ever to hold the office.

headline: Why Trump Won
abstract: Opinion columnists break down how Trump won the 2024 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnists break down how Trump won the 2024 presidential election.

headline: This Is Why Trump Won
abstract: A vote for Trump meant a vote to evict a failed leadership class from power.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is returning to the White House, and while this will not change what most critics think of him, it should compel them to take a close look in the mirror. They lost this election as much as Mr. Trump won it.

headline: It’s This Man’s, Man’s, Man’s World
abstract: You can’t count him out, sadly.
lead_paragraph: I can no longer count the number of times I’ve counted out Donald Trump.

headline: America Makes a Perilous Choice
abstract: How American democracy can endure through a second Trump presidency.
lead_paragraph: American voters have made the choice to return Donald Trump to the White House, setting the nation on a precarious course that no one can fully foresee.

headline: Stop Pretending Trump Is Not Who We Are
abstract: If we haven’t learned our lesson now, when will we learn it?
lead_paragraph: I remember when Donald Trump was not normal.

headline: 10 Takeaways From the Night Trump Marched Back to the White House
abstract: America’s democracy will again be put to the test, and its government will veer sharply to the right. Kamala Harris and Democrats were dealt stunning defeats across the country.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates here.

headline: Pariah, Felon, President-Elect: How Trump Fought His Way Back to Power
abstract: After the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, even many Republicans believed the former president’s political career was over. He proved everyone wrong.
lead_paragraph: By late January 2021, just days into Donald J. Trump’s unhappy new life as a former president, his world had shrunk to a size he could not abide.

headline: America Hires a Strongman
abstract: This was a conquering of the nation not by force but with a permission slip. Now, America stands on the precipice of an authoritarian style of governance never before seen in its 248-year history.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump told Americans exactly what he planned to do.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 515
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Nov. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Trump, Again
abstract: An early-morning conversation about the state of the election and the potential consequences of a second term for Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Wednesday morning, Donald J. Trump was elected president for a second time.

headline: Trump Defeats Harris to Retake the Presidency
abstract: Plus, Republicans win control of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Montana Voters Approve Abortion Ballot Measure
abstract: The measure establishes an explicit right to abortion in the State Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Montana approved a ballot amendment that enshrines a right to abortion in the State Constitution, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Four More Years of Unpredictability? The World Prepares for Trump’s Return.
abstract: Donald J. Trump has said he would transform America’s relationship with allies and adversaries. He has pledged to end the war in Ukraine in 24 hours, increase tariffs and deport millions.
lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump’s sweeping election victory on Tuesday, the world is preparing for another four years of unpredictability and “America first” protectionism that could reset the ground rules of the global economy, empower autocrats and erase American protection for democratic partners.

headline: For Ukraine, Trump Victory Signals a Shift. To What, Is Unclear.
abstract: As U.S. president, Donald J. Trump will inherit a role as Ukraine’s chief benefactor. But he has been skeptical about continuing aid to Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump’s victory in the United States presidential election, Ukrainians now face an all-but-certain American policy shift in the midst of a war that is turning against them. Russia has made some of the swiftest territorial advances in recent months, and diplomatic efforts are underway by multiple countries to find a negotiated settlement.

headline: Sheehy Defeats Tester in Montana, Extending G.O.P.’s Senate Majority
abstract: Tim Sheehy, a wealthy Republican businessman, was dogged by controversies during the campaign. But Senator Jon Tester, a Democrat, could not outrun the demographic shift in his deep-red state.
lead_paragraph: Tim Sheehy, a wealthy Republican businessman and political novice, has defeated Senator Jon Tester of Montana, according to The Associated Press, giving the G.O.P. another seat in its new Senate majority.

headline: In Trump, Netanyahu Sees a More Favorable U.S. President
abstract: There is a belief in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing Israeli government that a Trump administration will allow it to end its wars on favorable terms.
lead_paragraph: Only a few hours had passed since Donald J. Trump was elected president, when Benjamin Netanyahu, the Prime Minister of Israel, announced that he had already spoken to the U.S. president-elect, noting he was “among the first” to call him.

headline: Truth Social Stock Moves Higher on Trump Election Victory
abstract: Shares in Trump Media were among the most actively traded in the United States after the election was called.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Donald J. Trump’s social media company rose on Wednesday after the former president clinched another term in office but not nearly as much as many shareholders might have hoped.

headline: President Trump, Again
abstract: America has shifted rightward, giving Donald Trump a stunning comeback and a Republican Senate.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has completed a stunning political comeback, and the United States has entered an uncertain new era.

headline: ‘Pedro Páramo’ Review: A Ghost Story Lacking in Spirit
abstract: In this grave adaptation of Juan Rulfo’s surreal novel, the living pray for salvation and the dead murmur regrets, but the filmmaking is oddly orthodox.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican writer Juan Rulfo’s mystifying 1955 novel “Pedro Páramo” is, at least in the English-speaking world, most often invoked for its influence on Gabriel García Márquez. But admirers of the book (Susan Sontag famously among them) have long cited it as a masterpiece of spare surrealism.

headline: ‘Meet Me Next Christmas’ Review: An a Cappella Affair to Remember
abstract: This Netflix Christmas rom-com inexplicably wants to remind viewers that the group Pentatonix still exists.
lead_paragraph: You’d be forgiven if you were convinced in the early goings of “Meet Me Next Christmas” that the Netflix film is just a slightly more expensive Hallmark Christmas movie combined with a wild-goose chase rom-com.

headline: Lawler Wins New York Swing Seat, Lifting Republican House Chances
abstract: Representative Mike Lawler, a Republican, defied a stark Democratic advantage in the New York City suburbs to defeat Mondaire Jones.
lead_paragraph: Representative Mike Lawler, one of the nation’s most endangered Republican incumbents, won a second term, according to The Associated Press, holding onto a suburban New York district that is typically tilted toward Democrats.

headline: I Quit the First Trump Administration. Principled People Must Serve in the Second.
abstract: It’s our best hope.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, as a member of the first Trump administration, I anonymously published an opinion essay in The Times warning that President Donald Trump was unstable and a danger to “the health of our Republic.”

headline: How Trump Won, Again
abstract: He made gains in every corner of the country and with nearly every demographic group.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump won the presidency eight years ago, it was easy to cast his victory as a narrow one — or even dismiss it as a fluke.

headline: The Winners and Losers of Trump 2.0
abstract: Donald Trump’s return to the White House could upend some industries and the economy. But stocks and other assets are soaring on hopes that a new, business-friendly era beckons.
lead_paragraph: In the end, it wasn’t all that close. Donald Trump has reclaimed the presidency, besting Vice President Kamala Harris in what has been one of the most expensive elections in U.S. history.

headline: Control of the House Remains Up for Grabs
abstract: Several important House races were still undecided Wednesday morning after Republicans gained control of the White House and Senate, leaving the fate of the majority unclear.
lead_paragraph: By Wednesday morning, it was clear that Republicans had retaken the White House and the Senate. But it will take longer to know if they can maintain control of the House of Representatives, where dozens of races are still too close to call.

headline: Donald Trump Makes Stunning Return to Power
abstract: During this presidential campaign, Donald Trump played on economic worries and fears around immigration to defeat Vice President Kamala Harris. Shane Goldmacher, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: During this presidential campaign, Donald Trump played on economic worries and fears around immigration to defeat Vice President Kamala Harris. Shane Goldmacher, a national political correspondent for The New York Times, explains.

headline: A Party of Prigs and Pontificators Suffers a Humiliating Defeat
abstract: Democrats may feel righteous, but how’s that ever going to be a winning electoral look?
lead_paragraph: A story in chess lore involves the great Danish Jewish player Aron Nimzowitsch, who, at a tournament in the mid-1920s, found himself struggling against the German master Friedrich Sämisch. Infuriated at the thought of losing to an opponent he considered inferior, Nimzowitsch jumped on the table and shouted, “To this idiot I must lose?”

headline: Morning TV Hosts Digest Trump Victory
abstract: From jubilant to disheartened, the mood on the sets of U.S. morning shows provided stark split-screen reactions.
lead_paragraph: The tone was triumphant early Wednesday morning on “Fox and Friends,” in the hours after the Fox News network called the presidential race for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Trump Is Not the First President to Come Back From Defeat
abstract: More than a century ago, Grover Cleveland secured a second nonconsecutive term in the White House after a campaign plagued with scandal and allegations of a coverup.
lead_paragraph: Declared the winner of the 2024 presidential election, Donald J. Trump is on track for a host of firsts: He is forecast to be the first Republican to win the national popular vote in two decades, and is the first person with a criminal record to win the presidency. Earlier this year, he became the first former president to be convicted of a felony.

headline: Our Daughter Is Having an Affair With a Married Man. How Do We Stop It?
abstract: A 20-something woman who lives with her parents has incurred their disappointment by continuing an affair with her former boss. Since she won’t end things, should they tell the man’s wife?
lead_paragraph: Our daughter (early 20s) is having an affair with her former boss at a fast-food restaurant. He is married, and his wife discovered the affair by seeing texts on her husband’s phone. We discovered it by noticing a big increase in data usage on our phone bill. (They text each other incessantly!) We asked our daughter to stop working at the restaurant, and we believed that the affair had ended and that husband and wife were trying to work things out. Recently, though, I became suspicious and saw on our daughter’s phone that the affair was ongoing. We told her we were disappointed in her, but she refuses to end things. She lives at home and drives our car, and we are fuming. We are tempted to tell this man’s wife about the affair, but we don’t want to crash our daughter’s life worse than she’s doing herself. Thoughts?

headline: Democrats Got the Recovery They Wanted. It Wasn’t Enough.
abstract: America’s economic growth is the envy of its global counterparts. But voters wanted more from the Biden administration — specifically, lower prices.
lead_paragraph: Every major U.S. ally is uncomfortably familiar with one of President Biden’s favorite charts. It is a graph of economic recoveries in the wealthy world since the end of the pandemic recession. It shows growth flatlining for the United Kingdom, Germany and Japan over the past two years — while in the United States, growth keeps rocketing up.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 6, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A Times Insider article on Friday about efforts to make election news accessible for Spanish speakers misspelled the surname of a reporter. She is Jennifer Medina, not Molina.

headline: With Political Victory, Trump Fights Off Legal Charges
abstract: By triumphing at the ballot box, Donald Trump can dispense with federal charges against him while postponing or derailing other pending cases that have dogged him.
lead_paragraph: For all that former President Donald J. Trump’s election to a second term was a remarkable political comeback, it was also the culmination of an audacious and stunningly successful legal strategy that could allow him to evade accountability for the array of charges against him.

headline: ‘Trump’s America’: Comeback Victory Signals a Different Kind of Country
abstract: In the end, Donald J. Trump is not the historical aberration some thought he was, but instead a transformational force reshaping the modern United States in his own image.
lead_paragraph: In her closing rally on the Ellipse last week, Kamala Harris scorned Donald J. Trump as an outlier who did not represent America. “That is not who we are,” she declared.

headline: Trump, Again
abstract: In the early hours of Wednesday morning, Donald J. Trump was elected president for a second time. Shortly before that call was made, the Times journalists Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Lisa Lerer and Astead W. Herndon sat down to discuss the state of the election.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Wednesday morning, Donald J. Trump was elected president for a second time. Shortly before that call was made, the Times journalists Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Lisa Lerer and Astead W. Herndon sat down to discuss the state of the election.

headline: Ohio Voters Reject Ban on Partisan Gerrymanders
abstract: The issue was perhaps the most closely watched among the many democracy-related ballot measures in the country.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Ohio rejected a ban on partisan gerrymandering of state legislative and congressional districts on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, after a ferocious battle that included accusations of political trickery.

headline: Trump, Again
abstract: In the early hours of Wednesday morning, Donald J. Trump was elected president for a second time. Shortly before that call was made, the Times journalists Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Lisa Lerer and Astead W. Herndon sat down to discuss the state of the election.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Wednesday morning, Donald J. Trump was elected president for a second time. Shortly before that call was made, the Times journalists Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Lisa Lerer and Astead W. Herndon sat down to discuss the state of the election.

headline: Tesla’s Stock Jumps After Trump’s Victory
abstract: Investors believe that the electric car company led by Elon Musk will benefit from his support of the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk defied conventional corporate wisdom by committing wholeheartedly to Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, donating tens of millions of dollars and running a get-out-the-vote drive.

headline: Trump Has History of Strong Support for Israel
abstract: Donald Trump staunchly supported Israel during his first term as president, even when that meant reversing decades of American policy.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates and results.

headline: She Was Undecided Until Election Day. Who Did She Choose?
abstract: The New York Times followed a Pennsylvania voter throughout the campaign. She disliked both candidates, and struggled with her decision until the very end.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Reed, 77, who lives on a farm in central Pennsylvania, was undecided about her vote until the very last minute. She and her husband, both retired teachers, were among a group of undecided voters that The New York Times spoke with throughout the presidential campaign, to learn how major events were shaping their choice.

headline: What’s at Stake for Mexico in a Second Trump Presidency?
abstract: Tariffs, border crossings, mass deportations of migrants and military strikes on cartels: Mexico is in the firing line of the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates and results.

headline: Political Betting Markets See Vindication in Trump Victory
abstract: Prediction markets, which surged to prominence during the presidential campaign, started reflecting a likely Trump win several weeks ago, even as opinion polls showed a tight race.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of prediction markets such as Polymarket, Kalshi and PredictIt, where bettors could wager on the outcome of the election, said that the odds reflected reality faster and better than opinion polls. With President-elect Donald J. Trump’s resounding win, those claims seem to have been borne out.

headline: Why the Next Dietary Guidelines Might Not Tackle Ultraprocessed Foods
abstract: There’s not enough evidence to recommend avoiding them, a scientific advisory committee says. Some experts disagree.
lead_paragraph: Hardly a day passes without a new study, and an ensuing round of headlines, sounding the alarm on ultraprocessed foods.

headline: A New Portrait of Trump Family Values
abstract: Melania, Ivanka, Barron and an extended cast of supporters offer a picture of what is to come.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates and results.

headline: When Running 250 Miles Is the Easy Part
abstract: A man with autism, his devoted mother and a seemingly endless race. A story of resilience and love.
lead_paragraph: Zach Bates waited quietly in the morning twilight, outfitted in some of the gear he would need to cover 250 miles: fabric guards to keep the dust out of his shoes, a face covering, sunglasses, a hydration pack and water bottles, hiking poles and a green hat with a neck flap to block the sun. The race, just moments away, would be the hardest thing he had ever taken on.

headline: Who is Gideon Saar, Israel’s new foreign minister?
abstract: Over the years, he has been both a supporter and foe of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: Gideon Saar, Israel’s newly appointed foreign minister, has served in a string of government posts, switching political alliances while maintaining hard-line opposition to Palestinian statehood.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,237
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Is It OK to Put Our Assets in Trust to Qualify for Medicaid?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on an aging couple’s financial plans.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have no children and are aging. Between property we own and our retirement savings, our net worth is over $1 million. We are debating estate planning, especially creating a trust to ensure Medicaid eligibility in the event we need long-term care. This is very common where we live. I feel, however, that this is morally wrong, placing the burden of my care on taxpayers to save my assets. My husband feels if it can be done legally, he would be remiss in not ensuring our future. What do you think? — Name Withheld

headline: N.Y.C. Voters Approve Four Ballot Measures Proposed by Mayor Adams
abstract: Opponents tried to use Mayor Eric Adams’s federal indictment to argue against the measures, and cast them as a bid to lessen the City Council’s power.
lead_paragraph: For months, opponents of five New York City ballot measures had undertaken a broad effort to cast them as an unwarranted power grab by Mayor Eric Adams.

headline: The Crypto Industry Spent Over $130 Million on the Election. It Paid Off.
abstract: The spending spree fueled a string of victories on Tuesday for congressional candidates who had expressed support for cryptocurrencies.
lead_paragraph: Locked in a tight race for the U.S. Senate in Ohio, the Republican candidate Bernie Moreno got a major boost in the weeks before the election: $40 million from the cryptocurrency industry.

headline: Ohio Republicans Expand Control of State Supreme Court
abstract: The race was one of several that reflected the increasing politicization and influence of state supreme courts nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Ohio Republicans expanded their slim majority on the state’s Supreme Court in Tuesday’s elections, turning back efforts to flip partisan control of the chamber, according to The Associated Press.

headline: He’s Getting Raves for a Role He Wasn’t Supposed to Play
abstract: Seventeen years after he first appeared in “Yellow Face,” the veteran actor Francis Jue has returned with a nuanced performance as a blustery patriarch.
lead_paragraph: It’s a well-worn bit of audition advice for actors: Don’t telegraph that you really want the part you are up for — just do your thing. A corollary: The creative freedom you gain when you have relinquished your thirst for a role may spur you to make fearless choices that can seal the deal.

headline: Warren Washington, Groundbreaking Climate Scientist, Dies at 88
abstract: He invented a computer model that made it possible to measure human-induced climate change. He also helped break a color barrier in science.
lead_paragraph: Warren M. Washington, a scientist who helped invent one of the first computer models of the earth’s atmosphere, paving the way to accurately measure human-induced climate change, died on Oct. 18 at his home in Denver. He was 88.

headline: What a Trump Victory Means for Tech
abstract: Another Trump presidency will be good for crypto and Elon Musk, but every big tech company may not benefit from a more hands-off approach to antitrust.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates here.

headline: Another Jolt of Uncertainty for a Global Economy Mired in It
abstract: The U.S. presidential election result has ensured a sharp turn in economic policy expected to upend global commerce and diverge from decades of American norms.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. presidential election is over. What remains is a disorienting miasma of fresh economic uncertainty.

headline: Trump Bump 2.0? Experts Expect Another Audience Surge, With Caveats.
abstract: News fatigue and changing consumption habits could sap some of that enthusiasm over time, several news media experts said.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump pulled off a surprise victory against Hillary Clinton in 2016, the news media was a major beneficiary, as viewers stayed glued to cable news and readers signed up for newspaper subscriptions in droves.

headline: Jeff Bezos Congratulates Trump on Victory
abstract: Mr. Bezos, who also owns The Washington Post, recently quashed the newspaper’s endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon and the owner of The Washington Post, on Wednesday congratulated President-elect Donald J. Trump on his victory, a sign of a potential thawing between Mr. Trump and the billionaire tech mogul.

headline: What to Know About Trump’s New York Criminal Case After the Election
abstract: Donald J. Trump, the first felon elected president, has a sentencing scheduled for Nov. 26. He has many ways to avoid punishment.
lead_paragraph: The People of the State of New York v. Donald J. Trump was the one criminal case against the former president that actually went to trial. Now that Mr. Trump has reclaimed the presidency, it, too, is in jeopardy.

headline: Kamala Harris to Concede Election to Donald Trump
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris is slated to speak at 4 p.m. Eastern time from Howard University, according to a campaign official briefed on her plans.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will address the nation on Wednesday afternoon in what is expected to be her concession speech, officially bringing to a close a furious race to stop former President Donald J. Trump from returning to the White House.

headline: ‘Elevation’ Review: A High Place
abstract: Humans flee monsters who refuse to surpass 8,000 feet in altitude in this “Quiet Place” copycat.
lead_paragraph: If certain movies are to be trusted, the apocalypse will occur when monsters swarm the Earth and hunt to kill people who are powerless to survive — unless they abide by one high-concept rule. Such is the story in “A Quiet Place,” a boffo hit franchise, and now “Elevation,” an action-packed copycat.

headline: ‘It Was Just Jubilation’: Trump Supporters Revel in His Victory
abstract: Although some people were not sure which policies Donald J. Trump would focus on first, they were relieved and elated by the win.
lead_paragraph: Mike Cordeiro, a libertarian-leaning owner of a small Florida cannabis company, woke up on Wednesday morning feeling great. He has long thought the American status quo needed a good shaking. And with the victory of Donald J. Trump, he was optimistic that big change was in the offing.

headline: The Real Reason Harris and the Democrats Were Always Doomed
abstract: This election wasn’t just about the candidates.
lead_paragraph: The 2016 election was a heartbreak for America’s sentimental liberals. This one arrives with more of a deadening thump, with less hope of resistance energy being uncorked by the result than a sort of acquiescent despair.

headline: Trump’s Win Ends a Post-World War II Era of U.S. Leadership
abstract: For the past four years, President Biden has argued that the first Trump term was a blip in American history. The election has proved that President-elect Donald J. Trump was no aberration.
lead_paragraph: It was only four months ago that President Biden invited America’s NATO allies to Washington to celebrate the 75th anniversary of their alliance, the symbol of an era of American global leadership that once was celebrated as a cornerstone of democracy and the best way to keep the peace among great powers.

headline: What Trump’s Victory Says About America
abstract: Readers express fears for the future and speculate about why he won.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Trump’s Victory Could Mean for New York City
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s return to the White House could significantly affect a range of issues in his hometown, including immigration policy and congestion pricing.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s return to the White House may have a significant effect on large Democratic cities, but perhaps none more profound than his hometown, New York City.

headline: Abortion Rights Ballot Measures Succeed in 7 of 10 States
abstract: Voters in red and blue states supported abortion rights, but the movement broke its winning streak.
lead_paragraph: Voters in seven states approved ballot amendments establishing a right to abortion in their state constitutions, continuing a broad repudiation of the abortion bans enacted since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

headline: Inflation Infused the Vote. But Could Trump Reignite It?
abstract: Many Americans fretted about inflation as they headed out to vote. But Donald J. Trump’s approach comes with risks of a renewed boost.
lead_paragraph: Americans have been chafing against higher prices for years now, propelling unhappy voters to the polls and helping to deliver the White House to the Republican candidate, Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Way Harris Lost Will Be Her Legacy
abstract: Her loss is a sign that the age of identity politics is not over.
lead_paragraph: I have always been audacious about Black women’s political aspirations. When I was 15 years old I decided to become a local pageant queen, a Carousel Princess, for our Thanksgiving Parade. It was an uncharacteristic choice. I was an oratory and student government kind of girl.

headline: How Ballot Measures Will Change Abortion Access
abstract: Ballot measures that passed on Tuesday will lift abortion bans in two states and expand access in others. Defeated measures in three states mean their abortion restrictions will remain in place.
lead_paragraph: Ballot measures that passed on Tuesday will lift abortion bans in two states and expand access in others. Defeated measures in three states mean their abortion restrictions will remain in place.

headline: A Simple Roast Chicken
abstract: My favorite recipe is uncomplicated and flexible, calling for only salt, pepper and whatever herbs you like.
lead_paragraph: I’m always heartened by the sight of a roast chicken coming out of the oven. It’s comforting, sustaining and thoroughly delicious.

headline: Trump Captures Michigan, Toppling Harris in a Critical Battleground
abstract: The former president flipped back a state he won in 2016 only to lose in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has won Michigan, according to The Associated Press, defeating Vice President Kamala Harris in a closely divided Midwestern state.

headline: Ride-Hailing Drivers in Massachusetts Win Right to Unionize
abstract: A state ballot measure was the first of its kind in the United States, but labor advocates worry it could lock Uber and Lyft drivers out of full-time employment status.
lead_paragraph: Ride-hailing drivers in Massachusetts won the right to unionize on Wednesday through a statewide ballot initiative, a first-of-its-kind victory that could set a precedent for gig worker legislation across the country.

headline: What Trump’s Victory Means for Climate Change
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump promised to delete climate policy. He could face pushback from Republicans benefiting from a boom in clean energy.
lead_paragraph: The fight against climate change has taken a body blow with the election of Donald J. Trump, who calls global warming a “scam” and has promised to erase federal efforts to reduce the pollution that is heating the planet.

headline: Trumpism Is Not a Fad
abstract: Why America went with Trump, again.
lead_paragraph: In this special post-election episode of “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts take stock of Donald Trump’s triumphant night and what a return of his right-wing populism says about America.

headline: U.S. Election Sends Alarming Message for Global Climate Efforts
abstract: The Trump victory sets back the world’s attempt to rein in dangerous levels of warming and potentially isolates the United States in the global energy transition.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than a decade, the United States is expected to retreat from one of the world’s most consequential challenges: limiting the deadly and costly wreckage of climate change.

headline: How Are You Approaching a Second Trump Presidency?
abstract: After Trump’s big win, we would like to know how you’re feeling.
lead_paragraph: In an astonishing political comeback, Donald Trump rode a wave of anxiousness over inflation and illegal immigration to win a second presidency.

headline: Geoff Capes, World’s Strongest Man, Is Dead at 75
abstract: He pulled dump trucks, flipped cars and tossed five-pound bricks as if they were Kleenex boxes. Tending to parakeets brought out his gentler side.
lead_paragraph: Geoff Capes, a herculean wonder from the English countryside who, in addition to winning the World’s Strongest Man competition twice, was a champion breeder of parakeets, an activity that provided an escape from stunts like bending steel bars around his neck, died on Oct. 23 in Lincoln, England, in the East Midlands. He was 75.

headline: Tammy Baldwin Defeats Eric Hovde in Wisconsin Senate Race
abstract: Ms. Baldwin has once again proven herself a survivor in an evenly divided swing state, where voters went for her and President-elect Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tammy Baldwin, a Democrat from Wisconsin, fended off a stiff challenge from her Republican opponent, Eric Hovde, an affluent banker, earning just enough votes from Wisconsinites who also sided with Donald J. Trump to win a third term.

headline: How the Trump Administration Could Enact a Federal Abortion Ban
abstract: While Donald Trump has distanced himself from supporting a federal abortion ban, Republicans and opponents of abortion rights will pressure him to enact one.
lead_paragraph: As support for abortion rights has grown in the two years since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, President-elect Donald J. Trump has distanced himself from a proposed federal ban on abortion, saying that he supports leaving regulation of the issue to the states.

headline: A California Ballot Measure to Ban Forced Prison Labor Is Failing
abstract: Voters appear to be rejecting Proposition 6 in California, a measure to end involuntary servitude as a punishment for crime.
lead_paragraph: Voters in conservative states like Alabama and Tennessee had already ended involuntary servitude in their prisons in recent elections. So it came as something of a surprise on Wednesday that California voters were rejecting a similar proposal.

headline: When Will Donald Trump Take Office?
abstract: After his election victory, he will enter a two-month transition period as president-elect before being inaugurated on Jan. 20.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump won Tuesday’s election, but he will not immediately return to the White House.

headline: You Might Be Storing Cheese All Wrong
abstract: These expert tips will help you keep those blocks for longer, and use up any odds and ends that linger.
lead_paragraph: Cheese is, by nature, a means of preservation, shrinking gallons of milk to around a 10th of their volume and sending the highly perishable liquid on its “leap toward immortality,” as the essayist Clifton Fadiman once wrote.

headline: Starvation Death of 1-Month-Old on Staten Island Is Ruled a Homicide
abstract: The baby, Joseph Heben Jr., died of malnutrition in July. The police reclassified the case this week.
lead_paragraph: The death of a 1-month-old Staten Island boy from severe malnutrition during the summer has been ruled a homicide, the police said, the second such case to come to light in a month.

headline: Trump’s Win Unfolded on TV as a Muted Reboot
abstract: Election night on 2024 played like an enervated replay of 2016. Was it a harbinger of how the culture will respond to a second Trump term?
lead_paragraph: If you stayed up into the early morning hours to watch the Blue Wall gradually bleed red and Donald J. Trump give a rambling victory speech surrounded by an entourage, you might have thought that you had seen this show before.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘When Two Fantasies Collide’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: A nightly routine, beginning in kindergarten: I laid in bed, asking my mom, “What are we going to do today?” Not understanding when today becomes tomorrow. She drew circles on my back, detailing each activity in a singsong play-by-play as I fell asleep. Even as a teenager, I’d sometimes ask for “circles.” I now crawl under the covers next to my partner of three years, asking her to give me “circles” after long, draining days — like when I was laid off three months into my dream job. Jackie obliges, her circles reassuring me that life always comes back around. — Melanie Rosenblatt

headline: New York City Is Still a Democratic Town. But Trump Made Inroads.
abstract: The rightward shift in the presidential election results was especially pronounced among Asian voters and Hispanic voters in Queens and the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: New York City has rarely been as liberal as the rest of the nation thinks it is.

headline: Eikoh Hosoe, Photographer Who Elevated the Avant-Garde, Dies at 91
abstract: He pioneered a surrealistic narrative style in collaborations with dancers, artists and the author Yukio Mishima, with whom he created startling erotic tableaus.
lead_paragraph: Eikoh Hosoe, an avant-garde photographer who helped pioneer a new kind of art making in postwar Japan, with surreal and often erotically charged images exploring life, death, sexuality and the menace of the nuclear age, died on Sept. 16 in Tokyo. He was 91.

headline: R.F.K. Jr. Lays Out Possible Public Health Changes Under Trump
abstract: Mr. Kennedy, an environmental lawyer who has no medical or public health degrees, has promoted anti-vaccine conspiracies for years.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who President-elect Donald J. Trump has suggested would have a “big role” in his second administration, wasted no time laying out potential public health measures he would oversee if given the chance.

headline: Otherworldly Images of Postwar Japan
abstract: Working with a group of talented collaborators, Eikoh Hosoe redefined what it meant to be a photographer.
lead_paragraph: Eikoh Hosoe, who died on Sept. 16 in Tokyo, was part of a group of avant-garde artists in postwar Japan who were determined to create a new visual language.

headline: On Election Day, He Headed to the Capitol With a Manifesto and a Torch
abstract: A Michigan man tried to enter the Capitol Visitor Center on Tuesday with a letter for Congress expressing his discontent with the government’s response to the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The authorities on Wednesday identified a Michigan man as the person arrested as he tried to enter the U.S. Capitol on Election Day, reeking of fuel and carrying a torch lighter and a flare gun.

headline: Trump’s Victory Is a Major Win for Elon Musk and Big-Money Politics
abstract: The candidate largely let the billionaire run his $175 million ground game — a gamble that future candidates could look to emulate.
lead_paragraph: At a raucous election-night gathering on Tuesday, Elon Musk sat two seats away from Donald J. Trump, ready to claim wide credit for his decisive presidential win.

headline: Man Who Lived Rent-Free in Hotel for Years Is Found Unfit to Stand Trial
abstract: A hearing has been scheduled for next week for a judge to decide whether Mickey Barreto, who stayed at the New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan, should be held in a hospital for psychiatric care.
lead_paragraph: For five years, Mickey Barreto lived in Room 2565 at the storied New Yorker Hotel without paying a dime.

headline: Republicans Make Early Inroads in Their Fight to Keep the House Majority
abstract: Democrats picked up two seats in New York and defended others in Michigan and New Mexico, but Republican gains have narrowed their path, setting up a potential G.O.P. trifecta.
lead_paragraph: Republicans were making early gains on Wednesday in their drive to maintain control of the House, holding a handful of critical seats that Democrats had sought to flip even as the G.O.P. lost a pair of districts in New York.

headline: Pimp Who Dismembered Woman After Watching ‘Dexter’ Gets Life in Prison
abstract: Cory Martin researched his plans by watching violent television shows, prosecutors said. Then he killed Brandy Odom in a scheme to collect a $200,000 life insurance payout.
lead_paragraph: The sad demise of Brandy Odom played out in a two-story home in Queens where she lived with roommates.

headline: What a Trump Presidency Means for the World
abstract: Times foreign correspondents describe what’s at stake for China, Israel, Ukraine, global trade and climate.
lead_paragraph: Times foreign correspondents describe what’s at stake for China, Israel, Ukraine, global trade and climate.

headline: Virginia Carter, a Feminist Adviser to Norman Lear, Dies at 87
abstract: A physicist who headed a chapter of the National Organization for Women, she took a career detour to be a feminist voice in Mr. Lear’s empire of socially aware sitcoms.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Carter, a physicist whose activism for the National Organization for Women led the sitcom impresario Norman Lear to hire her in the early 1970s to be his feminist conscience as he presided over taboo-breaking shows that touched on sensitive social issues, died on Oct. 17 at her home in Redondo Beach, Calif. She was 87.

headline: The Good Whale
abstract: This is the story of a wildly ambitious science experiment to return Keiko to the ocean — while the world watched. A new limited podcast series from Serial Productions and the New York Times.
lead_paragraph: This is the story of a wildly ambitious science experiment to return Keiko to the ocean — while the world watched. A new limited podcast series from Serial Productions and the New York Times.

headline: Rapidly Moving Brush Fire in California Burns Homes and Prompts Evacuations
abstract: Firefighters were working to contain fires in Ventura and Los Angeles Counties amid dangerous weather conditions.
lead_paragraph: Go here for the latest on the Mountain fire.

headline: Path to 218: Tracking the Remaining House Races
abstract: Follow the results in the undecided congressional districts in the race for House control.
lead_paragraph: Follow the results in the undecided congressional districts in the race for House control.

headline: This Is Who We Are Now
abstract: The morning after the apocalypse.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump won the first time, I spoke to a journalist friend in Turkey to commiserate. I told her about all the protests that were planned, and she gently tried to prepare me for disappointment. She and her friends had protested Recep Tayyip Erdogan when he was prime minister, she said. But in time, the protests subsided, and life within a country of diminishing freedoms ground on. This conversation stayed in my mind throughout the Trump presidency as a warning against letting down our guard. When Trump was finally ejected from the White House, I felt patriotic pride in the endurance of the anti-Trump resistance, which had never for a moment accepted his authoritarian grotesquerie as our new normal.

headline: What Is Project 2025, and Why Did Trump Distance Himself From It During the Campaign?
abstract: Democrats had attacked Donald J. Trump’s ties to the conservative policy blueprint for reshaping the federal government. Several of its authors served in his administration.
lead_paragraph: As Donald J. Trump was closing in on the 270 electoral votes that sealed his astounding political victory in the early hours of Nov. 6, one of the first groups to salute him was the Heritage Foundation, the conservative think tank behind Project 2025, a policy playbook that Mr. Trump had feigned ignorance about during the campaign.

headline: Slotkin Defeats Rogers in Michigan Senate Race, Holding a Democratic Seat
abstract: Representative Elissa Slotkin, a centrist with strong national security credentials, won the contest to succeed the retiring Senator Debbie Stabenow.
lead_paragraph: Representative Elissa Slotkin, a Democrat with a strong national security background, has defeated former Representative Mike Rogers in the race for Michigan’s open Senate seat, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Banned From Atlanta: The Challenges of Young Thug’s Unique Probation
abstract: The rapper was released from jail last week after a surprise guilty plea. For 15 years, a set of strict requirements will govern his life and music.
lead_paragraph: One of the defining Atlanta rappers of his generation is no longer welcome in Atlanta.

headline: Top Republicans Hail Trump’s Victory, and Even G.O.P. Critics Congratulate Him
abstract: But Liz Cheney, his highest-profile Republican detractor, was not among those celebrating his win. She emphasized that Americans “must ensure that our institutions hold over these coming four years.”
lead_paragraph: Top Republicans celebrated President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory, and even some of his critics in the party congratulated him on Wednesday, while Democrats largely remained quiet as they awaited remarks from Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Fighting Climate Change Was ‘Never an America-Only Game’
abstract: The head of the World Bank on what comes next after the U.S. election.
lead_paragraph: It’s perhaps an understatement to say that the election of Donald Trump will seriously complicate international efforts to combat climate change.

headline: Voters Were Fed Up Over Immigration. They Voted for Trump.
abstract: Voters across party lines shifted to the right on immigration. They blamed Biden-Harris for failing to control the chaotic border.
lead_paragraph: Emily Schaefer supports mass deportations. She wants less immigration. And she opposes a path to citizenship for undocumented people who have been living in the United States for decades.

headline: Jack Smith Assesses How to Wind Down Trump’s Federal Cases, Official Says
abstract: The decision is in keeping with a longstanding Justice Department policy that bars prosecution of sitting presidents.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel, has begun discussions about how to wind down the two federal cases he brought against President-elect Donald J. Trump, in keeping with a longstanding Justice Department policy that bars prosecution of sitting presidents, a person familiar with the discussions said Wednesday.

headline: California Wildfires Prompt Evacuations and Shelter-in-Place Warnings
abstract: Firefighters battled strong winds and dangerous weather conditions in Southern California on Wednesday in an attempt to control two wildfires in the region.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters battled strong winds and dangerous weather conditions in Southern California on Wednesday in an attempt to control two wildfires in the region.

headline: Parents of Harlem Boy Who Starved to Death Are Charged With Murder
abstract: The parents of Jahmeik Modlin, 4, were initially charged with manslaughter. They are accused of locking away food from their children and showing “depraved indifference” for their son’s life.
lead_paragraph: The parents of Jahmeik Modlin, a 4-year-old boy who starved to death at his Harlem apartment last month, have been indicted on charges of second-degree murder, prosecutors announced on Wednesday.

headline: Germany’s Coalition Collapses, Leaving the Government Teetering
abstract: After months of disputes, Chancellor Olaf Scholz ousted one of his governing partners, adding to the challenges for Europe since Donald Trump’s election.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Olaf Scholz fired his finance minister on Wednesday, effectively ending his three-party ruling coalition and destabilizing his center-left government just as the election of Donald J. Trump in the United States presented Europe with new economic and security challenges.

headline: My Manifesto for Despairing Democrats
abstract: Here’s how to be a watchdog, not a lap dog, for the next four tumultuous years, while holding on to your sanity.
lead_paragraph: So what do we do now?

headline: Why Does It Take So Long to Call the House?
abstract: The volume of seats up for grabs, the painstaking process for calling races and the complexities of California combine to drag out the process, possibly for days.
lead_paragraph: It took a matter of hours after the polls closed Tuesday to know that former President Donald J. Trump had won the presidency and Republicans had seized control of the Senate. So why does it take so long to call the House of Representatives?

headline: An Emboldened G.O.P. Senate Majority Is Ready to Empower Trump
abstract: With a decisive margin in the Senate, Republicans, who have shown their willingness to accommodate the president-elect, will have the numbers to overcome divisions over his personnel and policies.
lead_paragraph: Republicans’ decisive Senate takeover has transformed what was once a body full of traditionalists who viewed Donald J. Trump with skepticism and even some disdain into a compliant and loyal chamber full of allies ready to advance his agenda.

headline: Special Edition: What a Trump Victory Means
abstract: Plus, what to expect from his foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: As Kamala Harris prepared to deliver a speech conceding defeat to Donald Trump, his supporters reveled in his resounding victory.

headline: Trump’s Newest Economic Guides Are Not Like His Old Ones
abstract: A little-known investment banker, a former hedge fund star and an acolyte of George Soros have the president-elect’s ear.
lead_paragraph: To staff his first term as president, Donald J. Trump attracted a group of largely by-the-book aides and advisers who produced an economic record — corporate tax cuts and financial deregulation — that would have been in place in any typical Republican administration.

headline: Zelensky Urges Trump to Help Defend Ukraine Against Russia
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has often shown disdain toward Ukraine and its leader, President Volodymyr Zelensky.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Wednesday urged President-elect Donald J. Trump to help strengthen Ukraine against Russian aggression.

headline: New York Delivers Key House Wins, but Warning Bells Sound for Democrats
abstract: Although Democrats flipped at least two House seats in New York, Donald J. Trump did better than any Republican presidential candidate since the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Democrats flipped two congressional swing seats in New York and were poised to retake a third on Wednesday, reversing embarrassing midterm losses in the state and keeping their party’s slim hopes of a House majority alive.

headline: Harris Asked Voters to Protect Democracy. Here’s Why It Didn’t Land.
abstract: In more than 200 interviews, voters worried not about an endangered country, but about paying rent.
lead_paragraph: Her campaign pitch was moving, even high-minded. If Vice President Kamala Harris were elected to the White House, she would safeguard the ideals of a good nation. Voters had a choice, she said: democracy, constitutional rights and bedrock freedoms — or Donald J. Trump’s “chaos and division.”

headline: Voters Reject Efforts to Loosen Drug Laws in Several States
abstract: Measures to legalize marijuana for recreational use failed in Florida and North Dakota. Massachusetts voters declined to allow psychedelics to be legal for therapeutic use.
lead_paragraph: Voters signaled unease on Tuesday over the country’s loosening drug laws, as hard-fought quests to legalize recreational marijuana in Florida and the therapeutic use of certain psychedelics in Massachusetts fell short.

headline: Harris Shows Trump How to Concede
abstract: Even if only one candidate is gracious enough to do it.
lead_paragraph: Less than 12 hours after the presidential election was called early Wednesday morning, Vice President Kamala Harris did what Donald Trump still can’t bring himself to do four years after his own loss: She conceded.

headline: Elon Musk Helped Elect Trump. What Does He Expect in Return?
abstract: The world’s richest man gave his money and time in campaigning for the president-elect and now is putting in his requests for a friendlier regulatory environment.
lead_paragraph: Even before Donald J. Trump was re-elected, his best-known backer, Elon Musk, had come to him with a request for his presidential transition.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Foe of Drug Makers and Regulators, Is Poised to Wield New Power
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump has encouraged him to “go wild on health” but has not made clear what role Mr. Kennedy will play.
lead_paragraph: When 12,000 public health professionals gathered in Minneapolis last week for the annual meeting of the American Public Health Association, Dr. Jerome Adams, who served as surgeon general in the first administration of President-elect Donald J. Trump, issued a pointed warning about Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

headline: Harris Says She Concedes the Election, but Not Her Fight
abstract: Her commitment to a peaceful transfer of power was more than President-elect Trump ever offered to President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris after they defeated him in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris formally acknowledged her loss to President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday in a defiant and emotional speech, defending her campaign as a fight for democracy that she would continue, even if not from the Oval Office.

headline: Democrats Again Banked on the ‘Blue Wall.’ It Crumbled.
abstract: Donald J. Trump swept the Great Lakes battlegrounds of Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, raising questions about the Democratic coalition going forward.
lead_paragraph: The most overused cliché on the electoral map — the so-called Blue Wall of Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin — tumbled to a rhetorical death this week as President-elect Donald J. Trump swept those states for the second time in three elections.

headline: Harris Delivers Concession Speech at Howard University
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris publicly conceded defeat to President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris publicly conceded defeat to President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday.

headline: It’s ‘Trump’s America’
abstract: We take a look at how Trump won, and what’s next. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, who promised to smash the American status quo and radically reshape the federal government, will be the next president of the United States. That reality became clear to millions of jubilant fans and anxious critics early this morning, when Trump passed the necessary 270 electoral votes. This afternoon, Kamala Harris conceded the race.

headline: How Harris’s Loss Could Haunt Biden’s Legacy
abstract: In the wake of Donald J. Trump’s resounding victory, many Democrats are casting President Biden as a one-term president who set his party on a path to failure in 2024.
lead_paragraph: For 1,333 days, President Biden was the only one, he repeatedly insisted, who could possibly defeat former President Donald J. Trump again.

headline: Early Results Suggest the Polls Were Notably Accurate
abstract: Collectively they indicated that the presidential race would be close, and it appears they got it right without significantly underestimating Donald Trump’s support.
lead_paragraph: Even before former President Donald J. Trump emerged as the winner in the presidential race, the numbers on election night showed signs of a victory … for polling.

headline: 7 Salisbury U. Students Beat Person Because of Sexual Orientation, Police Say
abstract: The students, who face assault and hate crime charges, lured a person to an apartment where they spat on him and broke a rib, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Seven students at Salisbury University in Maryland lured a person they targeted because of his sexual orientation to an off-campus apartment, where they spat on, held and beat him for several minutes, breaking a rib and causing bruises, according to the police.

headline: Richard Winfield, Protector of Press Freedom, Dies at 91
abstract: As a lawyer for The Associated Press and other news outlets, he challenged efforts to muzzle reporters and organized lawyers to promote free expression around the world.
lead_paragraph: Richard N. Winfield, a prominent First Amendment lawyer who worked to protect press freedoms as the longtime general counsel for The Associated Press and who later organized volunteer lawyers to promote free expression and human rights around the world, died on Oct. 22 in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: Grant Ujifusa, 82, Dies; Lobbied for Redress for Japanese Americans
abstract: He helped sway Ronald Reagan to sign a bill offering cash and an apology to Japanese Americans who had been imprisoned during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Grant Ujifusa, a citizen lobbyist who pressed President Ronald Reagan to reverse course and sign a bill offering cash and an apology to Japanese Americans imprisoned during World War II — a rare example of reparations paid for an official injustice toward an ethnic minority — died on Oct. 21 in Lafayette Hill, Pa. He was 82.

headline: After Trump Took the Lead, Election Deniers Went Suddenly Silent
abstract: Trump supporters spent years fomenting concern about election integrity. On Tuesday, they set it all aside.
lead_paragraph: Election deniers spent the weeks leading up to Election Day sounding the alarm online about the potential for widespread voter fraud that would taint the results — something that officials say has never occurred in modern elections. Former President Donald J. Trump claimed “massive CHEATING” in Philadelphia on Tuesday before the polls had even closed.

headline: Will a Woman Ever Be President?
abstract: After Kamala Harris became the second woman to lose a presidential election to Donald J. Trump, some women wondered if the glass ceiling would ever break.
lead_paragraph: On the arduous climb toward the “highest, hardest glass ceiling,” female presidential candidates persisted and resisted. They promised they were unbought and unbossed. Most of all, they believed the nation was ready for them. And, one by one, they were proven wrong.

headline: Hurricane Rafael Delivers Another Blow to Cuba
abstract: The storm’s winds knocked out power across the island before moving ashore as a powerful Category 3 storm.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Rafael arrived in Cuba on Wednesday afternoon, plunging the island into a power failure just before making landfall as a powerful Category 3 storm in the western Cuban province of Artemisa on Wednesday. The storm moved across the island with excessive rains, sustained winds near 115 m.p.h. and higher gusts as well as the threat of storm surge and flash flooding.

headline: Vindman Wins Virginia House Race, Keeping a Key Seat in Democratic Hands
abstract: Yevgeny Vindman, a former Army lieutenant colonel, was fired by the Trump administration for joining his twin brother as a whistle-blower in the first impeachment of President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Vindman, a Democrat and former Army lieutenant colonel who was fired for his role as a whistle-blower in the first Trump impeachment, has defeated the Republican Derrick Anderson to win a competitive congressional seat in Central and Northern Virginia, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Joseph Rykwert, 98, Dies; Historian of Architecture Challenged Modernism
abstract: A “gloriously erudite” critic, he denounced the embrace of blandly functional architecture in efforts to rebuild after World War II.
