lead_paragraph: Joseph Rykwert, an architectural historian who challenged Modernism’s blank-slate approach to architecture and urban design, insisting that healthy communities grew out of deeply felt traditions and values — a position that helped fuel later efforts to make cities more livable and humane — died on Oct. 17 at his home in London. He was 98.

headline: Plea Deals for Accused 9/11 Plotters Are Valid, Judge Rules
abstract: A military judge said he would move forward with accepting guilty pleas from three defendants in exchange for life sentences. The agreements had been rescinded by the defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: A military judge ruled on Wednesday that plea agreements in the Sept. 11 case were valid, reviving the possibility that the man accused of planning the attacks, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, and two accused accomplices could eventually be sentenced to life in prison instead of death.

headline: Voters to Elites: Do You See Me Now?
abstract: Donald Trump is a monstrous narcissist, but there’s something off about an educated class that looks in the mirror of society and sees only itself.
lead_paragraph: We have entered a new political era. For the past 40 years or so, we lived in the information age. Those of us in the educated class decided, with some justification, that the postindustrial economy would be built by people like ourselves, so we tailored social policies to meet our needs.

headline: Resist or Retreat? Democratic Voters Are Torn About Whether to Keep Fighting.
abstract: Many who became activists during the first Trump administration are questioning if they can summon the strength to do it all over again.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Shaw worked at a polling place in the Detroit suburbs on Election Day and went to bed “still hopeful” that Vice President Kamala Harris could win, she said. By Wednesday morning, she was bereft, her head pounding.

headline: How Trump Connected With So Many Americans
abstract: Donald Trump’s campaign was a blend of comedy, fury, optimism, darkness and cynicism. “He gets us,” some voters concluded.
lead_paragraph: The forces that propelled President-elect Donald J. Trump to victory will be endlessly analyzed. Many Americans woke up on Wednesday morning shocked that he could win again. But there is no doubt about one thing: Mr. Trump was a ferociously effective campaigner.

headline: Trump Weighs Personnel Choices and Fields Congratulatory Calls
abstract: On his first day as president-elect after his victory in the 2024 campaign, Donald Trump took calls from Vice President Kamala Harris and President Biden as his transition planning ramped up.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump faced key personnel choices on Wednesday in the wake of his victory as he fielded a concession call from Vice President Kamala Harris and congratulatory messages from foreign leaders.

headline: Her absentee ballot never arrived. So she flew from Chicago to Pennsylvania to vote.
abstract: A University of Chicago student tried for weeks to get an absentee ballot that never came, so she spent hundreds on a last-minute plane ticket. She was not alone.
lead_paragraph: Helen Wu, a 21-year-old senior at the University of Chicago, requested a mail-in ballot from her home in Montgomery County, Pa., on Sept. 10.

headline: The Second Pandemic Election
abstract: Covid cost Trump the presidency in 2020, and it may have cleared the path for his return.
lead_paragraph: The day after an election can bring an uncanny quiet.

headline: In Trump’s Win, G.O.P. Sees Signs of a Game-Changing New Coalition
abstract: Donald J. Trump picked up support among Latino and Black working-class voters, giving the party hope for a new way to win in a diversifying nation.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have sounded alarms for more than a decade about the limits of their overwhelmingly white party. To stay competitive for the White House, strategists warned, they would need to bring more Black, Latino and other voters of color into the fold.

headline: Expecting Clemency From Trump, Jan 6. Defendant Requests Sentencing Delay
abstract: A federal judge promptly denied Christopher Carnell’s request, which was filed hours after Donald J. Trump won the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina man who participated in the 2021 Capitol insurrection requested on Wednesday to have his sentencing delayed because he expects President-elect Donald J. Trump to grant Jan. 6 defendants like him clemency, court records show.

headline: Trump Will Return to Power With a More Expansive Agenda
abstract: The president-elect could reshape government and may dramatically transform foreign and domestic policy in a second term.
lead_paragraph: As he declared victory, President-elect Donald J. Trump said that his mission now was nothing less than to “save our country.” His version of doing that involves an expansive agenda that would reshape government, foreign policy, national security, economics and domestic affairs as dramatically as any president in modern times.

headline: A Dark Suit and a Weary Smile
abstract: In her concession speech, Kamala Harris offered an image for a long fight.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris speaking at Howard University was to be an image for history: a record of the first female president, not to mention the first Black female president and the first president of South Asian descent, giving her victory speech. Instead, what turned out to be her concession speech became the coda to an unprecedented election; the end of one story, rather than the beginning of another.

headline: For Many Arab Americans in Dearborn, Trump Made the Case for Their Votes
abstract: After supporting Joe Biden in 2020, the majority-Arab American city outside Detroit delivered an unlikely win for Donald Trump, who promised to bring peace to the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Ameen Almudhari was one of thousands of people in the majority-Arab community of Dearborn, Mich., who helped Joe Biden win the city and defeat Donald Trump in the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 7, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu firing his defense minister, Yoav Gallant, translated incorrectly a comment from Mr. Gallant. He said, “This is no longer a social issue alone, it is a paramount issue for our existence and future,” not “for our security and existence.”

headline: Rave Party
abstract: Joe Deeney shows us where we’re going (to.)
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: 2024 Temperatures Are on Track for a Record High, Researchers Find
abstract: The new report also says that global warming has hit a threshold, at least temporarily, that countries had pledged to avoid.
lead_paragraph: This year will almost certainly be the hottest year on record, beating the high set in 2023, researchers announced on Wednesday.

headline: See the Voting Groups That Swung to the Right in the 2024 Vote
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s swift victory was driven by red shifts across the country, with gains among seemingly every possible grouping of Americans.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s swift victory was driven by red shifts across the country, with gains among seemingly every possible grouping of Americans.

headline: Hurricane Rafael Lashes Cuba
abstract: Tall waves lashed at the shores of Havana as strong winds knocked out power across the island.
lead_paragraph: Tall waves lashed at the shores of Havana as strong winds knocked out power across the island.

headline: Quote of the Day: There Is Joy in This Mudville: Scientists Solve ‘Magical’ Muck
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 7, 2024
lead_paragraph: “This is the magical thing: It spreads like face cream and grips like sandpaper.”

headline: Record Air Pollution Hospitalizes Hundreds in Pakistani City
abstract: The authorities in Lahore, home to 13 million people and the country’s second-biggest city, have told half the work force to stay home.
lead_paragraph: Impounding polluting vehicles. Tearing down kilns. Banning rickshaws. Closing some barbecue restaurants.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: What another Trump presidency means for America and the world.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump survived a criminal conviction, indictments, an assassin’s bullet, accusations of authoritarianism and an unprecedented switch of his opponent. Now, in an astonishing political comeback, he will be the next president of the United States. He is the first former leader in more than 120 years to be elected for a second nonconsecutive term.

headline: Natural Disaster Destroyed Part of València. Populism May Take Us All the Way Down.
abstract: Rage can be a dangerous political tool.
lead_paragraph: When water mixes with dirt it becomes mud, tons of mud, the kind of mud that, in the wake of flash floods on Oct. 29 and 30, has turned the Spanish region of València into a kind of war zone. More than 200 people are dead; nearly 90 are still missing; hundreds of houses, roads and railways are destroyed; and towns are cut off without electricity, water, or provisions. Hundreds of families have lost everything. Large swaths of the region have been transformed into a brown hell, reeking of decay, after rivers topped their banks, sending water coursing through towns and cities.

headline: How I Discovered I Was Stolen at Birth
abstract: There could have been as many as 50,000 babies trafficked out of Chile between the 1950s and the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: For 42 years, my mother thought I was dead.

headline: Late Night Processes Donald Trump’s Re-Election
abstract: “Trump returning to the White House is a huge historic comeback for someone who literally never went away,” Jimmy Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Typhoon Yinxing Hits Philippines as a Powerful Storm
abstract: The tropical cyclone, which hit the island of Luzon, prompted evacuation orders for more than 160,000 residents. Early Friday, officials warned that “life-threatening conditions persist.”
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Yinxing made landfall in the Philippines on Thursday, bringing dangerous winds and intense rainfall to Luzon, the nation’s most populous island.

headline: Word of the Day: pollinator
abstract: This word has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word pollinator has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 17 in “What’s That Buzz? It’s Probably a Bee Hotel” by James Barron:

headline: Thick Smog Blankets Pakistani City
abstract: Residents of Lahore are suffering from the toxic haze that has pushed the city’s Air Quality Index to off-the-chart levels by U.S. standards.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Lahore are suffering from the toxic haze that has pushed the city’s Air Quality Index to off-the-chart levels by U.S. standards.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Reaching Out
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Trump’s Narrow Loss in New Jersey Signals a Shift to the Right
abstract: In New Jersey, Democrats outnumber Republicans and control every branch of government. But Tuesday’s vote nonetheless reflected a clear shift.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates here.

headline: A Silver Lining for New York Democrats
abstract: Proposition 1, meant to expand equal rights and codify the protections of Roe v. Wade in the State Constitution, passed easily despite a Republican campaign against trans rights.
lead_paragraph: One small point of consolation for New York Democrats undone by the results of the presidential election was the passage of the state’s Equal Rights Amendment, with a 62 percent majority. The ballot measure, known as Proposition 1, introduced a prospective amendment to the State Constitution that would expand and strengthen existing anti-bias protections, the goal being to ensure that no one could be denied rights based on who they were or what they might do to or with their bodies.

headline: Two Empty Nesters Flew to the City With $600,000 for an East Side Studio
abstract: With their daughter in college on Long Island, an Atlanta couple looked for a modest second home in Manhattan so they could visit more often. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: With their daughter in college on Long Island, an Atlanta couple looked for a modest second home in Manhattan so they could visit more often. Here’s what they found.

headline: Canada Shuts TikTok’s Offices Over National Security Risks
abstract: The order, which will allow people to still use the app, cited concerns about TikTok’s owner, the Chinese tech giant ByteDance.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian government on Wednesday directed the video app TikTok, which is owned by a Chinese tech giant, to close its offices in the country because of national security risks.

headline: Nissan Cuts 9,000 Jobs and Slashes C.E.O.’s Pay in Half
abstract: The Japanese automaker is carving deep cuts in its global operations as it struggles with a steep drop in sales.
lead_paragraph: Nissan Motor said Thursday that it was planning deep cuts to its global operations as it seeks to reorient its business and recover ground lost in the growing markets for hybrid and electric vehicles in China and the United States.

headline: Trump’s Win Is Likely to Prolong Gaza Talks Uncertainty
abstract: Any major progress on a cease-fire will probably have to wait until after January’s inauguration, analysts said. Gazans said they were divided about whether Mr. Trump would do much to stop the war.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s election victory is plunging efforts to reach a cease-fire in Gaza into further uncertainty, after a year of failed attempts by the Biden administration floundered because of irreconcilable demands from Israel and Hamas.

headline: Lessons for World Leaders From Japan’s Former Trump-Whisperer
abstract: Shinzo Abe, then the prime minister of Japan, succeeded in making friends with Mr. Trump through golf, entertainment and appealing to his vanity.
lead_paragraph: During the first administration of Donald J. Trump, if any world leader could claim to have had the now president-elect’s number, it was Shinzo Abe, Japan’s prime minister at the time.

headline: Jean Hanff Korelitz Gave Spreadsheets a ‘Workout’ to Plan Her New Book
abstract: A novel within a novel fueled her hit thriller, “The Plot.” Keeping the stories straight was even harder for “The Sequel.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: With ‘Gladiator II,’ Ridley Scott Returns to the Arena
abstract: The director speaks his mind on rejected sequel ideas, Joaquin Phoenix’s plan to quit the original and working with a “fractious” Denzel Washington.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 24 years since the director Ridley Scott scored one of the biggest hits of his career with “Gladiator,” a swords-and-sandals epic starring Russell Crowe that won the Oscar for best picture. Now 86, Scott still works at a prodigious pace, sometimes even directing two films in the same year.

headline: Do You Have a Favorite Wedding Keepsake? We Want to See It.
abstract: Tell us about the items you saved from your wedding day that you still cherish today.
lead_paragraph: When you get married, every wedding keepsake becomes a precious item to illustrate your love and evoke happy memories. These objects are infused with celebration, significance, nostalgia, and, of course, love.

headline: Exhausted by the Election, Some Americans Are Catching Flights Abroad
abstract: For some voters, the campaign season has felt draining. Some are recharging by heading to Mexico City, Barbados or the English Cotswolds, to name a few.
lead_paragraph: While some Americans watched the presidential election results come in this week, others dropped off their ballots, caught flights and left the country.

headline: 8 Factors That Can Raise Your Heart Disease Risk
abstract: Doctors are thinking differently about what drives cardiovascular issues. It’s no longer just about blood pressure and cholesterol.
lead_paragraph: Heart disease is the leading killer of men and women in America — and it has been for more than 100 years, despite major gains in public health.

headline: What Makes a Great Search-and-Find Picture Book
abstract: Perhaps the ultimate test is whether it merits a reread, even after all the objects have been found.
lead_paragraph: Remember Highlights magazine? If you’re as old as I am and ever sat in a children’s dentist’s office in the ’70s or ’80s, you undoubtedly have fond memories of the page known as “Hidden Pictures,” a crude yet captivating drawing of a scene, such as a beachfront or a school playground, embedded with hidden objects: an anchor, a peanut, a hammer. You would consult the guide, which showed you what you had to find, and then set your little self to work feverishly plowing every square inch of the page. It was all the more fun with a friend, when it became a heated race. And there was no bigger bummer than turning to Page 7 (where “Hidden Pictures” lived) to find that some inconsiderate jerk had already circled them.

headline: How Does It Feel to Turn 100? Ask Winnie-the-Pooh
abstract: An imagined chat with Pooh commemorates the 100th anniversary of A.A. Milne’s “When We Were Very Young.”
lead_paragraph: “Pooh,” I said, “your stories have a Distinctive and Irresistible Manner.”

headline: Art Deco’s Bad Girl, Still Ahead of Her Time
abstract: Tamara de Lempicka’s first major U.S. survey invokes her as a trailblazing techno-feminist who borrowed freely from art history. But it also buries her erratic second act.
lead_paragraph: Before Madonna strapped on her funnel-breasted bustier and called it feminism, there was the painter Tamara de Lempicka.

headline: ‘Bird’ Review: In Search of Safety
abstract: Barry Keoghan and Franz Rogowski star in a film about a preteen girl who longs for a stability she’s never experienced.
lead_paragraph: Good parents are a rarity in Andrea Arnold’s movies. Instead, they tend to be neglectful and preoccupied, often for solid reasons: Arnold tells stories of working-class families, mostly British, mostly struggling to get by, mostly the offspring of parents who are, themselves, distracted and uninterested in their children’s lives. An early short film of Arnold’s, “Wasp,” has a mother locking her four children in the car while she tries to woo an old boyfriend in a bar. One of her best movies, “Fish Tank,” features a mother who punishes her daughter by telling her she should have gone through with her planned abortion instead of giving birth. The situation is pretty grim.

headline: ‘The Best Christmas Pageant Ever’ Review: How It Got So Great
abstract: The film, based on a 1972 children’s book by Barbara Robinson, tells the story of an unlikely group of kids stunning a small town for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: From its title onward, “The Best Christmas Pageant Ever” is not shy about stating its ecclesiastical ambitions. The movie — which is not, it may be prudent to point out, a documentary — is practically hellbent on being heartwarming and inspirational in equal measure. It posits the holiday season as one in which we’ll be called to acceptance, called to change, and, yes, explicitly called to faith.

headline: ‘Heretic’ Review: Hugh Grant Puts His Charm to Fiendish Use
abstract: In wily, vamping style, the actor plays a friendly neighbor to two missionaries before turning his home into a horror-filled slaughterhouse.
lead_paragraph: One of the great benefits of watching too many movies are all the life lessons they impart. For instance, if your host mentions that the walls of his house happened to be lined with metal, you should immediately feign a headache and split before he closes the front door. If the windows in his house look too small even for a child to squeeze through, you should also exit. And if there’s also a framed image of hell on a wall, you should definitely conk him on his head and run. That said, if the host is played by Hugh Grant, you may want to stick around.

headline: ‘Small Things Like These’ Review: The Fears of a Watchful Father
abstract: Cillian Murphy of “Oppenheimer” fame plays an Irishman interrogating a system of abuse and forced labor, despite everyone’s warnings to look the other way.
lead_paragraph: “Small Things Like These” plays just a little like a gangster film, except the web of power at its center is spun by nuns. Set in 1985 and based on Claire Keegan’s 2021 novel, it is a story about how people create and maintain control and the many shades of complicity that result. In this case, the setting is southeast Ireland, and the nuns’ control has woven its way into every aspect of life in a small town.

headline: Most of Sean Combs’s Accusers Are Unnamed. Can They Stay That Way?
abstract: The argument over anonymity in civil and criminal sex abuse cases weighs the principle of a fair trial with the desire to protect accusers’ privacy.
lead_paragraph: As Sean Combs faces numerous anonymous accusers in both civil and criminal court who say he sexually abused them, his lawyers have argued that such anonymity is an unfair impediment to his defense.

headline: Here’s Where Minimum-Wage Workers Can Actually Afford Rent
abstract: A study found that people who earn low wages were rent-burdened in all of the country’s 50 largest real estate markets.
lead_paragraph: American renter households are chronically burdened by their rent, meaning they spend more than 30 percent of their income on housing, according to recent census data. For people making minimum wage, finding affordable rent is particularly difficult.

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Franklin Township, N.J., and Darien, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A three-full-and-two-half-bath, 3,400-square-foot house from 1958 with a midcentury design that includes an open-air atrium entrance, a step-down living room with a wood-burning fireplace, banks of oversized windows, finishes of brick, wood and tile, built-in shelving and storage, a finished basement, an in-ground jetted pool, a partially covered deck and an attached four-car garage, on 13.5 acres. Jenna Davie, Turpin Realtors, 973-525-8120; turpinrealtors.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s listings are in Midtown East, Washington Heights and Downtown Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A 1,034-square-foot studio apartment with marble countertops, a sleeping alcove, a bathroom with a double vanity and radiant-heat floors, central heat and air-conditioning, and ample closet space, on the 14th floor of a 63-story doorman building with a resident manager, basement storage cages, a bike room and four floors of amenities including a pool, a gym, a spa, a billiards room and a library. Michele Hinojos and Jad Cary, Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, 929-732-7354; corcoran.com

headline: Democrats Had a Theory of the Election. They Were Wrong.
abstract: Two columnists argue that the left neglected to hear what Americans were telling them over the past four years.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Opinion columnists Lydia Polgreen and Tressie McMillan Cottom discuss what was revealed about America on Tuesday, why the Democrats failed and what individuals can do about the future.

headline: Why This Pianist Can’t Tickle the Ivories
abstract: Julian Gargiulo moved to New York and arranged to have his Steinway shipped from Europe. That’s when his troubles began.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at what happened to the keys on a concert pianist’s piano when he moved to New York from Paris. We’ll also look at what Donald Trump’s victory in the presidential election might mean for New York City.

headline: Gulf States See Trump as Ally They Can Do Business With
abstract: The Gulf region is looking to the next U.S. administration for help in ending the Mideast war and firm cooperation on security and economic interests.
lead_paragraph: About two weeks before the American presidential election, Donald J. Trump sat for an interview with a widely watched Arabic-language TV channel owned by Saudi Arabia and praised the kingdom’s crown prince, calling him a “visionary” and a “friend.”

headline: For Black Women, ‘America Has Revealed to Us Her True Self’
abstract: Kamala Harris’s resounding defeat affirmed the worst of what many Black women believed about their country, even as some looked to the future with a wary determination.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has won the 2024 presidential election. Follow live updates here.

headline: Civilian Terror: Russia Hits Ukrainian Cities With Waves of Drones
abstract: Moscow has been using decoy drones with no warheads to overwhelm defenses, and surveillance drones and strike drones to gather intelligence, Ukrainian officials said.
lead_paragraph: As Russian troops march relentlessly forward with fierce assaults in Ukraine’s east, Moscow is unleashing a different form of terror on civilians in towns and cities: a wave of long-range drone strikes that has little precedent in the 32-month-old war.

headline: Kamala Harris Took Women for Granted
abstract: Apart from promising to safeguard abortion rights, the campaign didn’t do enough to address other issues important to women.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be the big gender gap election. The data showed women leaning heavily Democratic, with abortion rights a primary driver. Women were expected to line up in droves, ready to reel in the vote for their designated glass-ceiling-shattering heroine.

headline: Where the Turkey Comes From the Field, Not the Freezer
abstract: On the hunt for wild birds in Minnesota, where a small but spirited cohort loves the challenge, and the cooking that follows.
lead_paragraph: Kristie Swenstad was napping in the back of plywood deer blind on a cold fall morning when her father nudged her awake and handed her a shotgun.

headline: The Fed Cuts Rates, but the Path Ahead Is Less Clear
abstract: The Federal Reserve is reducing rates in response to cooling inflation. Donald Trump’s presidential victory has pumped up uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials cut interest rates on Thursday, their second reduction of 2024 and the latest sign that policymakers believe that inflation is finally coming under control.

headline: 36 Hours in San Francisco
abstract: As beautiful as ever, this glittering bayside city is expanding its public spaces and arts institutions.
lead_paragraph: As beautiful as ever, this glittering bayside city is expanding its public spaces and arts institutions.

headline: Where Does This Leave Democrats?
abstract: The coalition the Democratic Party built in the Obama years has crumbled. But Democrats can choose how to respond.
lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an audio essay for “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the essay in the player above, or by subscribing to the podcast on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: In Tumultuous Times, Readers Turn to ‘Healing Fiction’
abstract: Cozy, whimsical novels — often featuring magical cats — that have long been popular in Japan and Korea are taking off globally. Fans say they offer comfort during a chaotic time.
lead_paragraph: At Toshikazu Kawaguchi’s book signings, it’s not uncommon for fans to burst into tears.

headline: What Catchy Songs Get Stuck in Your Head?
abstract: What makes something an earworm — a song, jingle, beat or melody that loops in your brain for days?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever had an earworm?

headline: ‘Il Grido’: Love and Loss in Italy’s Po River Valley
abstract: Long overshadowed by Michelangelo Antonioni’s later work, this feature, newly restored, is being revived at Film Forum, complete with once-censored scenes.
lead_paragraph: Michelangelo Antonioni confounded the 1960 Cannes Film Festival with “L’Avventura,” but that high-modernist missing-person mystery did not emerge from a void. Three years before, the Italian master took the top prize at the Locarno festival with a scarcely less radical film, the existential love-story “Il Grido” (The Cry).

headline: Trump Will Test European Solidarity on NATO, Ukraine and Trade
abstract: Another Trump term could spur Europe’s efforts to stand on its own, but it is far from clear its leaders will seize the moment this time.
lead_paragraph: The victory of Donald J. Trump will test the ability of America’s European allies to maintain solidarity, do more to build up their own militaries and defend their economic interests.

headline: How Trump Won, and How Harris Lost
abstract: He made one essential bet: that his grievances would become the grievances of the MAGA movement, and then the G.O.P., and then more than half the country. It paid off.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s chief pollster, Tony Fabrizio, had seen just about everything in his three races working for the controversy-stoking former president. But even he seemed to be bracing for bad news.

headline: China Braces for a New Phase of U.S. Rivalry With Trump’s Return
abstract: Beijing is expecting more volatility and competition with the United States, though a lackluster economy may limit China’s options for pushing back.
lead_paragraph: For the past year, the United States and China have tried to manage their rivalry to reassure the world that tensions between the superpowers would not spiral into conflict. The return of President Donald J. Trump to the White House threatens to upend that delicate balance.

headline: Republicans Carry Ballot Gains to State Houses
abstract: The Republicans’ election dominance carried into state legislatures, where the party made gains in Minnesota, Michigan and Vermont. Democrats, though, broke the G.O.P. supermajority in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Buoyed by strong election showings on the national level, Republicans appear poised to break up Democratic control of state governments in Minnesota and Michigan.

headline: What Trump’s Win Means for Fed Independence
abstract: Donald J. Trump spent his first presidency on a collision course with America’s central bank. Will it intensify?
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump spent his first presidency attacking the Federal Reserve, pushing policymakers to cut interest rates and calling Fed officials names that ranged from “boneheads” to “enemy.”

headline: Democrats Ignored Gaza and Brought Down Their Party
abstract: The war in the Middle East has become this era’s most important progressive cause.
lead_paragraph: During the presidential campaign, journalists trying to assess the electoral impact of Israel's war in Gaza often focused on Arab and Muslim voters, particularly in Michigan. That’s understandable. In the heavily Arab American city of Dearborn, Mich., which supported Joe Biden in 2020, results show that Donald Trump beat Kamala Harris by about six percentage points.

headline: What Is the Worst Version of a Second Trump Administration?
abstract: Opinion columnists break down what the worst version of a second Trump administration would be.
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnists break down what the worst version of a second Trump administration would be.

headline: Tech Giants Face a Familiar Uncertainty With Trump
abstract: Apple, Amazon, Google, Meta and others learned during the last Trump administration to expect the unexpected when it came to Washington scrutiny and support.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting with Google’s Larry Page, Apple’s Tim Cook and other tech leaders in 2016, President-elect Donald J. Trump told the gathering, “I’m here to help you folks do well.”

headline: A Master of the Media Evolved Yet Again in 2024
abstract: Donald J. Trump has embraced tabloids, reality TV, Twitter and cable news. This year, he moved on to podcasts and online streamers.
lead_paragraph: In his improbable journey to the apex of American power, President-elect Donald J. Trump has always adapted to the media tool of the moment.

headline: Kamala Harris Failed to Read the Room
abstract: It was the wrong time to be the defender and champion of the country’s governing establishment.
lead_paragraph: The strategy of the Kamala Harris campaign sounded great on paper. She would stay clear of the unpopular progressive positions of 2019, unapologetically embrace American patriotism and freedom, and establish a broad coalition by gladly accepting the endorsements of former Republican officials and officeholders like Liz Cheney and her father, former Vice President Dick Cheney.

headline: Before the Election, Tech C.E.O.s Were Quietly Courting Trump
abstract: The executives of tech’s biggest companies largely ignored Donald Trump before the 2016 election. This time around, they’re far more friendly.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump first campaigned for president eight years ago, tech executives largely ignored him. They later atoned for their disregard by making a televised walk through the lobby of Trump Tower in New York for a 90-minute meeting with the president-elect.

headline: We Don’t Have Time to Waste in Despair
abstract: What should Trump’s opponents do next?
lead_paragraph: There is no mystery about what happened Tuesday night. Unlike 2016, when the anticipation of Hillary Clinton’s victory turned into the shock of defeat, every smart analyst I know not only thought Donald Trump could win in 2024, they also knew he could potentially win in a blowout. In every election, he’s outperformed his polling, and we knew it could happen again.

headline: One Voter to Understand Trump’s Win
abstract: For one woman in Michigan, it wasn’t an obvious decision, but in the end it came down to this: “frustration and self-Interest.”
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, we’ve been asking pretty much everyone we meet a version of the same question:

headline: Listen: ‘The Day My Family Changed Forever’
abstract: How does divorce affect children?
lead_paragraph: “The Day My Family Changed Forever” is a 24-minute Modern Love podcast that explores the impact of divorce on children. It features Natalie Muñoz, a high school senior, reading excerpts from her Modern Love essay published in 2021 and discussing her struggle with the reality of her parents’ divorce. “Processing a parents’ divorce for any child, but especially for an only child, is a lot like going through the stages of grief,” she wrote in her essay.

headline: Let’s Discuss: ‘Two Young Drivers Take the Wheel. One, a Teen. The Other, a Tesla.’
abstract: How do you feel about automated vehicles? What effects do you think they will have on your generation? Read this article and post your comments and questions for Matt Richtel by Nov. 14.
lead_paragraph: Do you know how to drive? If not, are you looking forward to learning? Is getting a license an important rite of passage for you and your friends?

headline: Putin Lavishes Praise on Trump, Saying Russia Is ‘Open’ to Restored Ties
abstract: Russians close to the Kremlin voiced optimism that Donald J. Trump could help end the war in Ukraine on Russia’s terms. Vladimir V. Putin said Mr. Trump’s remarks on ending the war “deserve attention.”
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin tried and failed for four years to turn President Donald J. Trump’s friendly rhetoric into friendly policy.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 516
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,238
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Donald Trump’s America
abstract: How the former president staged his comeback and how he might change the direction of the country.
lead_paragraph: As the fallout from the election settles, Americans are beginning to absorb, celebrate and mourn the coming of a second Trump presidency.

headline: Democrats Begin the Blame Game, and What Happens to Trump’s Legal Woes
abstract: Plus, pickleball’s Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Canada Could Use a New Approach to Dealing With Trump This Time
abstract: While Canadian lawmakers are publicly sanguine about the incoming U.S. administration, several experts say that Canada faces significant challenges.
lead_paragraph: Following the news that Donald J. Trump would return for a second term as U.S. president, the reaction of Canada’s cabinet ministers was uniform. In essence, they have all urged Canadians to stop worrying because they’ve dealt with Mr. Trump before and they have a playbook.

headline: Several Feet of Snow Are Expected in New Mexico and Colorado
abstract: A slow-moving winter storm was expected to drop up to three feet of snow in parts of the two states through Saturday, causing perilous road conditions and power outages.
lead_paragraph: Several feet of snow were expected to fall in parts of New Mexico and Colorado over the next three days in what meteorologists said could be the worst blizzard to hit the region in decades, as the authorities warned of dangerous road conditions and power outages.

headline: The Day After the Election
abstract: We’re covering how Trump won — and more results from the election.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past year, Democrats comforted themselves with recent election results. Yes, the 2024 polls looked tight, but when it really mattered — when people went to the polls to vote — Democrats won again and again. In 2022, they kept Senate control and nearly won the House, defying the usual midterm curse for the president’s party.

headline: ‘Christmas Eve in Miller’s Point’ Review: Home for the Holidays
abstract: Tyler Taormina’s third theatrical feature is a lightly nostalgic ensemble piece set on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Not much happens plot-wise in “Christmas Eve in Miller’s Point,” the third theatrical feature from Tyler Taormina, but it has, as they say, a lot going on. In this ensemble comedy, centered on the Christmas gathering of a family so large that theaters ought to hand out a genealogy chart, the movie is at once hyper-specific about place — western Suffolk County on Long Island — and intriguingly loose about time.

headline: ‘Meanwhile on Earth’ Review: Outer Space and Inner Turmoil
abstract: A bereaved young woman faces terrible choices in this dreamily uncertain blend of science fiction and moral philosophy.
lead_paragraph: The French filmmaker Jérémy Clapin seems drawn to stories of loss. His animated feature debut, “I Lost My Body” (2019), followed the vivid, sometimes gruesome journey of a severed hand seeking to reconnect with its owner. And though his new film is called “Meanwhile on Earth,” it might well be titled “I Lost My Brother,” the movie’s sense of dislocation and desire for reconnection so reminiscent of its predecessor.

headline: ‘The Last Rifleman’ Review: A World War II Veteran Hits the Road
abstract: Pierce Brosnan plays a man who sneaks out of his retirement home to attend the 75th anniversary of the D-Day landings in this charming, but corny drama.
lead_paragraph: “The Last Rifleman” is a sporadically affecting drama that stars Pierce Brosnan as a World War II veteran who sneaks out of his retirement home in Belfast to attend the 75th anniversary of D-Day in France. At 16, Artie (Brosnan) was petrified to be in Normandy; now 92 and three-quarters (he insists on the fraction), he’s hellbent on confronting his metaphorical ghosts.

headline: The World Isn’t Spending Nearly Enough to Adapt to Climate Shocks, U.N. Says
abstract: A new report, urging rich nations to give more climate aid to poorer ones, comes as Donald Trump’s election throws global climate talks into disarray.
lead_paragraph: After Donald J. Trump’s election threatened to upend global efforts to fight climate change, a United Nations group on Thursday warned in a new report that developing nations need hundreds of billions of dollars per year in aid to adapt to a warming planet.

headline: Bank of England Cuts Interest Rates, but Signals Stickier Inflation
abstract: The central bank said future cuts would be gradual amid higher inflation forecasts after the new government introduced spending and tax increases in its budget.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England cut interest rates as expected on Thursday, but policymakers said it would take longer for inflation in Britain to return to the bank’s 2 percent target after the new government’s budget increased spending and taxes.

headline: Dozens Killed as Israeli Strikes Pound Lebanon, Health Ministry Says
abstract: The deadliest strikes hit the Bekaa Valley, in and around the historic city of Baalbek, overnight.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said Thursday that it had struck dozens of sites in Lebanon, part of its widening offensive against Hezbollah, a bombardment that Lebanese officials said had killed dozens of people.

headline: Dozens of Israeli Strikes Hit the Beirut Area and Eastern Lebanon
abstract: The airstrikes caused damage in Beirut’s southern suburbs and in the eastern city of Baalbek in the Bekaa region, where the Israeli military said it was targeting Hezbollah positions.
lead_paragraph: The airstrikes caused damage in Beirut’s southern suburbs and in the eastern city of Baalbek in the Bekaa region, where the Israeli military said it was targeting Hezbollah positions.

headline: The Wall Street Leaders Who Could Play a Role in Trump’s New Administration
abstract: Lobbyists are trying to connect executives with the Trump transition team, and some familiar names are in the mix for top jobs.
lead_paragraph: Before markets opened on Wednesday, Wall Street was scrambling to figure out what Donald Trump’s commanding win meant for business, including whom he would appoint and what they might do.

headline: Why the Australian Ambassador Deleted Tweets Critical of Trump
abstract: The envoy, Kevin Rudd, said that he had removed the posts “out of respect for the office of the president.” But it was a sign of broader anxiety over Donald J. Trump’s return to power.
lead_paragraph: Like many social media users, Kevin Rudd, a former prime minister of Australia and its current ambassador to the United States, has posted a range of things online: a plug for his new book, cheers for his Australian rules football team and many photographs of his cats.

headline: What Trenton Doyle Hancock Learned From Philip Guston
abstract: The Jewish Museum pairs the Texas artist with a 20th-century master. Together they confront racism with horror — and humor.
lead_paragraph: When Trenton Doyle Hancock discovered the artist Philip Guston, it was a revelation. Hancock had just transferred from junior college in his hometown, Paris, Texas, to nearby East Texas State University. He was taking a printmaking class and working with a haunting photograph he’d made of himself partially cloaked in a white sheet with a noose around his neck. The rope wound around his body, including his semi-bare right arm, which holds up a hammer. Titled “The Properties of the Hammer” (1993), it probed the dark contradictions of being a Black man in America.

headline: What Kamala Harris’s Loss Means To Black Women
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris ran a 107-day campaign under extraordinarily rare circumstances after President Biden dropped out of the race. But burdened by the legacy of her incumbency and the history of a nation that has been reluctant to elect a woman of color, Ms. Harris lost ground among most major groups of voters. Erica L. Green, a New York Times White House correspondent, explains what her emotional and defiant concession speech means to Black women in the country.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris ran a 107-day campaign under extraordinarily rare circumstances after President Biden dropped out of the race. But burdened by the legacy of her incumbency and the history of a nation that has been reluctant to elect a woman of color, Ms. Harris lost ground among most major groups of voters. Erica L. Green, a New York Times White House correspondent, explains what her emotional and defiant concession speech means to Black women in the country.

headline: What the Collapse of Germany’s Ruling Coalition Means
abstract: After decades of relative stability, the country has entered a new era of political fragmentation and will hold new elections at a precarious time.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of its governing coalition is an extraordinary moment for Germany, a country known for stable governments. It has happened only twice before in the 75 years since the modern state was founded.

headline: Jan. 6 Defendants Are Already Angling for Pardons From Trump
abstract: The president-elect said during the campaign that he would grant clemency to some of those who took part in the assault by his supporters on the Capitol nearly four years ago.
lead_paragraph: The legal consequences of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory start with the likelihood that the cases against him will sputter out but could also extend to the cases of hundreds of his supporters who are being — or have been — prosecuted for storming the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: What to Know About Trump’s Tariffs: Higher Prices, Trade Wars and More
abstract: The president-elect says that tariff is “the most beautiful word in the dictionary.” You may be hearing it a lot.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has professed a belief in the power of tariffs for decades. Now, as he prepares to take office, they are a central part of his economic plan.

headline: What Is COP29? Here’s What to Know About Global Climate Talks.
abstract: Diplomats and leaders from around the world are gathering for annual climate negotiations. Here’s what they’re all about and what Donald Trump’s victory means for the meeting.
lead_paragraph: United Nations climate talks began in Baku, Azerbaijan, on Monday.

headline: Trump Is On Track to Win the Popular Vote
abstract: The projection was a further sign of the scale of Donald J. Trump’s victory. In his first successful White House run in 2016, he received fewer votes nationally than Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has already sealed a comfortable majority in the Electoral College. But he is also on course to do something he didn’t do in his first successful campaign for the White House: win the popular vote.

headline: One City’s Secret to Happiness: The Annual Burning of a 50-Foot Effigy
abstract: Every year, Santa Fe incinerates a giant puppet of Zozobra — a ritual meant to purge anxiety and promote a reset.
lead_paragraph: For most of the millions of travelers who make the trek each year, there is no reason to go to Santa Fe except to go to Santa Fe. Just about everything that needs doing can and should be done somewhere else, someplace easier to get to than this tiny city 7,000 feet in the air, whose airport terminal is a fraction of the size of a typical American grocery store. But this town of 90,000 residents strives to ensure that its singularity is reason enough.

headline: For Rent: 4-Bedroom London House. The Owner? Britain’s Prime Minister.
abstract: Keir Starmer has rented out his home in north London since moving to Downing Street, according to newly published official records.
lead_paragraph: For rent: a four-bedroom home within easy reach of the shops, restaurants and bars of fashionable north London. It might be a good idea to look after the place, however. The owner is Britain’s prime minister, Keir Starmer.

headline: Trump’s ‘Drill, Baby, Drill’ Cuts Two Ways for Oil Companies
abstract: The president-elect has promised to make it easier to build energy infrastructure and secure drilling leases. But higher production could hurt prices and profits.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump and oil and gas executives have championed each other. But his victory may prove to be a mixed blessing for the industry.

headline: This Sesame Salmon Bowl Feels Like a Treat
abstract: Inspired by chirashi, Kay Chun’s one-pot dinner combines plump, silky salmon with vinegared rice, crunchy cucumbers, cabbage and a sesame-soy vinaigrette.
lead_paragraph: When I want to do something nice for myself, I eat fish. More specifically, I eat salmon. This hefty, fatty fish feels so wholesome but also like a special treat, simultaneously very healthful and a little luxurious.

headline: With DNA, Pompeii Narratives Take a Twist
abstract: In 79 A.D., a volcanic eruption engulfed a town’s residents. They weren’t all who scientists thought, newly extracted genetic material suggests.
lead_paragraph: The Italian writer Italo Calvino observed that a person’s life consists of a collection of events, the last of which could change the meaning of the whole. In A.D. 79, the final event for many of the inhabitants of Pompeii was the volcanic eruption that buried them under a 20-foot layer of ash and sediment. Dozens of the corpses retained their shapes long enough for the layers of debris to build around them, forming impressions that, with the decaying of soft tissue, became perfect hollow molds.

headline: After a 2,000-Mile Trip, a Penguin Finds Itself on an Australian Beach
abstract: “This is the furthest north I’ve heard of an emperor penguin,” an expert said.
lead_paragraph: It was a day as Australian as you can get: Sun, waves and surfing at the beach.

headline: A Violinist on a Mission to Capture America, Division and All
abstract: Johnny Gandelsman has commissioned 28 pieces for his project “This Is America,” which explores themes of love, hope, inequality and injustice.
lead_paragraph: In a quiet corner of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the violinist Johnny Gandelsman took a few deep breaths and began to play.

headline: Devastated Democrats Play the Blame Game, and Stare at a Dark Future
abstract: In interviews, lawmakers and strategists tried to explain Kamala Harris’s defeat, pointing to misinformation, the Gaza war, a toxic Democratic brand and the party’s approach to transgender issues.
lead_paragraph: A depressed and demoralized Democratic Party is beginning the painful slog into a largely powerless future, as its leaders grapple with how deeply they underestimated Donald J. Trump’s resurgent hold on the nation.

headline: A Spike in Demand, and Fees, for Lobbyists With Ties to Trump
abstract: Corporations and foreign governments are offering to pay steep prices for help dealing with the unpredictable president-elect.
lead_paragraph: When Fox News called the presidential election for Donald J. Trump early Wednesday morning, guests at a private party at a cigar lounge in Palm Beach, Fla., began congratulating the lobbyist who hosted the event.

headline: Trump Agenda Faces a Fiscal Reckoning
abstract: Advisers to President-elect Donald J. Trump and Republicans on Capitol Hill are already looking at ways to scale back some of his more expensive ideas.
lead_paragraph: No tax on tips? Lower corporate taxes? No tax on Social Security benefits?

headline: The New York Comedy Festival Is Huge. These 8 Shows Are a Good Start.
abstract: The intriguing options range from well-known names like Bill Maher and Tracy Morgan to under-the-radar standups like Chloe Radcliffe and Jay Jurden.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Comedy Festival started in 2004, it was a modest affair, with only a dozen standup shows. Twenty years later, it has grown into a bustling, sprawling staple of the comedy season, featuring more than 100 shows, big and small, in every borough. The festival begins Thursday and runs through Nov. 17. Here are a few promising options.

headline: How Could Trump and Abortion Rights Both Win?
abstract: Making sense of this election’s very strange abortion politics.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, the 2024 election results seem incomprehensible. Majorities voted in favor of abortion rights in eight of the 10 states where the issue was on the ballot. But Americans also elected the man most responsible for the demise of those same rights. And in several states where abortion won, so did Donald Trump.

headline: European Leaders Meet to Consider a World in Flux
abstract: Leaders from across Europe and beyond gathered to discuss the war in Ukraine, immigration and plans for a second Trump presidency.
lead_paragraph: A long-planned gathering in a Budapest sports arena took on unexpected urgency on Thursday as European leaders contended with the election victory of Donald J. Trump and the collapse of Germany’s ruling coalition, two pressing issues that added to the tumult of a world already thrown off balance by the war in Ukraine.

headline: Biden Vows a Peaceful Transfer of Power: ‘The American Experiment Endures’
abstract: President Biden spent his campaign warning that Donald J. Trump was a threat to democracy. Now he is seeking an orderly transition.
lead_paragraph: On the day Joseph R. Biden Jr. was declared the winner of the 2020 election, President Donald J. Trump refused to concede, insisted that “this election is far from over” and vowed to fight the results in court. Two months later, as his supporters ransacked the U.S. Capitol in hopes of derailing the vote, Mr. Trump still would not accept defeat.

headline: How Russia Openly Escalated Its Election Interference Efforts
abstract: The Kremlin did not bother to hide its efforts to influence the 2024 presidential election, as it did in the past.
lead_paragraph: In the final days before Tuesday’s vote, Russia abandoned any pretense that it was not trying to interfere in the American presidential election.

headline: Trump’s Believers See a Presidency With God on Their Side
abstract: Many Christian conservatives saw the battle for the White House as a holy war. Now, with Donald Trump’s victory, their vision goes beyond politics.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, conservative Christians wondered if Donald J. Trump, who had just been elected president, would truly be their champion. They were weary, and angry, after wandering in the wilderness of the Obama years when liberal values seemed ascendant and they felt powerless.

headline: Leaders in Democratic States Begin Planning to Fight Trump Policies
abstract: Governors such as Gavin Newsom of California and JB Pritzker of Illinois are calling on state lawmakers to gird for battle, particularly in the courts.
lead_paragraph: As Donald J. Trump savored a sweeping victory in the presidential race, Democratic leaders in at least three state capitals have begun mobilizing to push back against potential Republican policies on issues like reproductive health and the environment.

headline: The Best Place to Find ‘Somebody’s Son’? Try ‘A Black Love Party.’
abstract: After the success of MeAndSomebodySon, her Instagram page dedicated to Black romantic relationships, Zemirah Moffett is taking the party offline.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Ilodi, a 37-year-old nurse practitioner from Cleveland, arrived in New York on Thursday. By Friday night, she was strutting through a crowd of revelers on the second floor of Our Wicked Lady, a bar in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where a dance party centering Black love was underway.

headline: What Fed Rate Moves Mean for Your Finances
abstract: Here’s how the central bank’s interest rate moves influence car loans, credit cards, mortgages, savings and student loans.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is expected to lower its key interest rate by a quarter point on Thursday, after a half-point cut in September — its first reduction in four years.

headline: Democrats, Let’s Get Real About Why Harris Lost
abstract: Americans aren’t joyful. They’re angry. And they’ve been telling us that all along.
lead_paragraph: As Election Day neared, Democrats’ hopes soared. I know because I saw it and heard it all around me — the widening smiles, the brightening voices. Vice President Kamala Harris was ascendant. Donald Trump was done. People could just feel it.

headline: If the Fed Is Cutting Rates, Why Are Mortgage Rates Rising?
abstract: The latest rise, to 6.79% for a 30-year mortgage, reflects bond market concern about President-elect Trump’s agenda. It extends an uptick in mortgage rates despite expected Federal Reserve rate cuts.
lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates jumped this week as investors processed the potential inflationary effects of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s win, accelerating a weekslong increase that could keep many buyers and sellers on the sidelines.

headline: Man Charged in Broad Daylight Shooting That Had Ripple Effect on Subway
abstract: Eduardo Diaz was charged with attempted murder in an incident that prompted subway riders to shelter on floors and caused delays across the system.
lead_paragraph: A 42-year-old Queens man was arrested on Friday and charged with shooting another man in broad daylight on a Manhattan street, the police said.

headline: Australia Moves to Ban Young Teens From Social Media
abstract: The proposed legislation would put the country at the forefront of regulating social media access for children.
lead_paragraph: Australia wants to ban children from social media.

headline: Some Good News for Men Who Love Weird Pants
abstract: The Swedish brand Our Legacy finally gets investment from LVMH.
lead_paragraph: LVMH Luxury Ventures Fund, the venture capital arm of Bernard Arnault’s towering luxury empire, has acquired a minority stake in the insidery Swedish fashion brand Our Legacy.

headline: Man Opens Fire Before Fleeing Into New York City Subway Station
abstract: The shooting happened near West 68th Street and Columbus Avenue. Subway riders were told to get on the ground and keep their heads down.
lead_paragraph: The shooting happened near West 68th Street and Columbus Avenue. Subway riders were told to get on the ground and keep their heads down.

headline: F.D.A. Proposes Removing Ineffective Nasal Decongestant From Stores
abstract: It was added to cold and flu remedies in the 1990s when another ingredient went behind the counter over illicit meth lab concerns.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday proposed removing a common ingredient in over-the-counter cold medicines that was found to have no effect on nasal congestion, despite its widespread use for decades.

headline: A New Farm-to-Table Restaurant in Upstate New York
abstract: Plus: an Australian surf hotel, rubber sculptures and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: When Ivy Nallo and Zack Nussdorf moved to Taghkanic, N.Y., in 2020, they envisioned having a small garden where they could grow enough produce to host dinners on the screen porch. Four years later, the 625-square-foot plot has grown into a one-acre farm with greenhouses and a herd of Mangalitsa pigs, known for their lard. At the end of October, Nallo and Nussdorf opened Restaurant Manor Rock in Hudson, N.Y., a 20-minute drive from their farm. Much of the produce, like the patchwork peppers and the Barbarella eggplants, comes from their land, as does the pork for their loin chops and charcuterie. Nussdorf briefly worked as a line cook at the Michelin-starred Brooklyn restaurant the Four Horsemen. Here, he and the chef Diego Romo, previously of Gem and Estela in Manhattan, are making simple, seasonal dishes, like grilled squid with turnips and potatoes cooked in Mangalitsa lard. Before it hosted a string of restaurants, Manor Rock’s Warren Street space was a townhouse. It was overhauled earlier this year by the design and architecture firm Charlap Hyman & Herrero, who outfitted the restaurant with porcelain sconces, cream-colored walls and a red-oak bar made of trees from Manor Rock Farm. “We wanted it to feel like it’s been here for the last hundred years,” Nallo says. instagram.com/manorrockfarm.

headline: After the Election: Alienation, Fears and Pleas for Healing
abstract: Readers offer personal reactions and reflections. Also: A bill to combat antisemitism; noise in restaurants.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Disappointment on Social Media Looks Different This Time Around
abstract: In 2016, online platforms were awash in calls to protest the day after Donald J. Trump’s victory. On Wednesday, many said it seemed like business as usual.
lead_paragraph: “My feed feels like a funeral,” Julie Mayer, 35, said on Wednesday afternoon, before Vice President Kamala Harris made her speech conceding the election to President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Gillen Defeats D’Esposito in New York, Flipping House Seat for Democrats
abstract: Laura Gillen unseated Representative Anthony D’Esposito, a first-term Republican, on Long Island. Her campaign focused on abortion and the border.
lead_paragraph: Laura Gillen, a former Democratic town supervisor on Long Island, narrowly defeated Representative Anthony D’Esposito of New York, according to The Associated Press, giving her party another crucial pickup in its uphill quest to win the House majority.

headline: No-Rules Friendsgiving
abstract: A November dinner with friends is for cooking whatever you want, like roasted brussels sprouts Caesar or a caramelized onion tachin.
lead_paragraph: It is, somehow, Thursday, Nov. 7. Put in the context of a Big Meals Calendar — which hangs upon the walls of my mind next to Post-its of childhood phone numbers and the lyrics to “Burn” by Usher — we are exactly three weeks from Thanksgiving.

headline: At Salon Art + Design, Nature and Beauty Come Center Stage
abstract: More than 50 galleries tease the lines between function and decoration, in a year when the fair has a far-reaching mission: to give more artists a chance to be seen.
lead_paragraph: This year’s edition of the Salon Art + Design fair at the Park Avenue Armory is back with 54 galleries, five special exhibitions and new leadership.

headline: Lower Rates, Rising Yields: What to Make of the Bond Market Right Now
abstract: Yields on government bonds — which underpin all kinds of borrowing in the economy — are rising. But the Fed is cutting rates. What gives?
lead_paragraph: There is an adage in markets that stock investors are optimists and bond investors are pessimists.

headline: A Classic Holiday Dessert Reimagined
abstract: Quick, easy and glucose-friendly.
lead_paragraph: Quick, easy and glucose-friendly.

headline: Voters Poised to Reject Private School Vouchers in Three States
abstract: The results were part of a wave of ballot measure outcomes that teachers’ unions had sought. Nevertheless, private-school choice is growing nationwide.
lead_paragraph: On a bright Election Day for Republicans, one of their signature education policies — private school choice — was poised to be rejected by voters in three states: Colorado, Nebraska and Kentucky.

headline: Biden Promises Americans an Orderly Transition of Power to Trump
abstract: President Biden vowed to honor the Constitution with an orderly transfer of power to President-elect Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: President Biden vowed to honor the Constitution with an orderly transfer of power to President-elect Donald J. Trump.

headline: Will Trump Have a New Opening to Repeal Obamacare?
abstract: Even without congressional action, a second Trump administration will likely support major changes to Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act’s marketplaces, affecting millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump never revealed the “concepts” of the plan he said he had to replace the Affordable Care Act, the law that he tried unsuccessfully to kill during his first term.

headline: Mackenzie Beats Wild in Pennsylvania, Scoring a Key Pickup for House G.O.P.
abstract: Ryan Mackenzie, a 2020 election denier who aligned himself with President-elect Donald J. Trump during his congressional campaign, flipped a competitive seat in the Lehigh Valley.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Mackenzie, a Republican state legislator, has defeated Representative Susan Wild, a Democrat, according to The Associated Press, flipping a critical House seat in Pennsylvania’s Lehigh Valley in a major victory for the G.O.P.’s effort to hold control of the House.

headline: Bresnahan Beats Cartwright in Pennsylvania, Handing G.O.P. a Key Seat
abstract: Rob Bresnahan Jr., a Republican and business executive, ousted the Democratic incumbent who had kept the Scranton-based district blue for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: Rob Bresnahan Jr., the Republican chief executive of an electrical contracting company, has beaten Representative Matt Cartwright of Pennsylvania, according to The Associated Press, knocking off a battle-tested Democrat in a major gain for the G.O.P.’s effort to hold the House.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in November
abstract: This week in Newly Reviewed, Holland Cotter covers two group shows that illuminate important histories of Asian and Asian American art.
lead_paragraph: This week in Newly Reviewed, Holland Cotter covers two group shows that illuminate important histories of Asian and Asian American art.

headline: Interpol Tightens Oversight on Databases Misused by Autocrats
abstract: The changes are intended to stop governments from using the world’s largest police organization to harass and monitor political dissidents.
lead_paragraph: Interpol, the world’s largest policing organization, has expanded oversight of databases that autocrats and strongmen have used to monitor and harass political dissidents, a senior Interpol official said on Thursday.

headline: Jim Hoagland, Distinguished Journalist on World Affairs, Dies at 84
abstract: A two-time Pulitzer Prize winner, he was a reporter, editor and columnist for The Washington Post, renowned for his deeply sourced dispatches.
lead_paragraph: Jim Hoagland, whose long career as a foreign correspondent, editor and columnist for The Washington Post brought him two Pulitzer Prizes and made his work a must-read among the nation’s top diplomats and politicians, died on Monday in Washington. He was 84.

headline: Two Brush Fires in Southern California Lead to Evacuations
abstract: Firefighters battled strong winds and dangerous weather conditions in an attempt to control two wildfires in the region.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters battled strong winds and dangerous weather conditions in an attempt to control two wildfires in the region.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Where We Work
abstract: Four years ago the pandemic changed where we work. What do you notice about where we work now? What do you wonder?
lead_paragraph: With the onset of the pandemic in March 2020, more than half of workers began working from home at least part of the time, according to Gallup. Since then, the distribution of who works fully in person, who works a hybrid schedule, and who works fully remote has shifted.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 18, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Note: We will live-moderate a discussion about this image on Monday, Nov. 18, and then post the photo’s Reveal by the end of Thursday, Nov. 21.

headline: Trump Whiplash Looms Over Global Climate Talks
abstract: As the world gathers for U.N. climate negotiations in Azerbaijan next week, here’s what we will be watching.
lead_paragraph: World leaders from more than 100 countries will gather next week at the United Nations climate conference in Baku, Azerbaijan, to discuss the threats of a rapidly warming world.

headline: What Teenagers Are Saying About Love
abstract: Students tell us what they have learned from the platonic, familial and romantic relationships in their lives.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, The New York Times introduced a new weekly column about love and relationships called Modern Love. There, writers have shared hundreds of stories about relationships of all kinds and the lessons they have learned from them.

headline: 5 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Art and the circumstances of its creation are at the center of three of our recommended books this week: Nicholas Fox Weber offers a comprehensive new biography of the abstract painter Piet Mondrian, Charles King traces the back story of Handel’s “Messiah,” and the graphic novelist Chris Ware ruminates in real time on the welcome distractions that parenthood puts in an artist’s way. Also up: a fun horror novel that doubles as a romance, and the start of a new detective series set in Arizona. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

headline: A Union Square Date Night for Inter-Borough Relationships
abstract: Find love in a hopeless place (where the subway lines intersect).
lead_paragraph: Here’s a hyperspecific request I get pretty often: What’s a good date spot near Union Square? I attribute its frequency to the many people in borough-gap relationships looking for a spot where their subway lines intersect. So this one goes out to all the couples — or singles on early dates — meeting in the middle.

headline: Fed Chair Says He Won’t Leave if Trump Asks
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the chairman of the central bank, has been a frequent target of the president-elect, who appointed him in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Would Jerome H. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, step aside if asked to do so by President-elect Donald J. Trump? Mr. Powell had a one-word answer on Thursday: “No.”

headline: Friday Briefing: Biden promises a peaceful transition
abstract: Plus, the readers turning to “healing fiction.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden urged Americans to accept the election of Donald Trump and vowed that there would be an orderly transfer of power.

headline: The Clint Squint
abstract: When Clint Eastwood narrows his eyes, pay attention. A master of the big screen is using them to convey seduction, intimidation, mystery and more.
lead_paragraph: When Clint Eastwood narrows his eyes, pay attention. A master of the big screen is using them to convey seduction, intimidation, mystery and more.

headline: Transgender Americans Voice New Anxiety About Trump Agenda
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has promised to “keep men out of women’s sports” and withhold Medicare and Medicaid funding from hospitals that provide gender transition treatment to minors.
lead_paragraph: The steady flow of attack ads portraying Democrats as too liberal on transgender rights began appearing on television over the summer and continued through Election Day: “Kamala is for they/them,” went the tagline on one from Donald J. Trump’s campaign. “President Trump is for you.”

headline: Slower Winds Expected to Aid Fight Against ‘Nightmare’ California Fire
abstract: The fast-moving Mountain fire forced thousands to evacuate and destroyed neighborhoods in the hilly communities of Ventura County. “We figured we were trapped,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters in Southern California expected a reprieve from extreme weather conditions on Friday as they continued to battle a fast-moving fire that has already destroyed over 130 structures and damaged nearly 90 others.

headline: ‘Alan Cumming’s Paradise Homes’ Is a Cheeky and Fabulous Distraction
abstract: Need a healthy does of escapism right about now? Look no further than this series on BritBox.
lead_paragraph: There are certain television shows that seem as if they were created as an excuse for famous people to take nice vacations. “Alan Cumming’s Paradise Homes” is one such program. But that doesn’t mean the series, streaming now on BritBox, isn’t a charming, escapist watch.

headline: A Door Is Unlocked, and 43 Monkeys Make a Bid for Freedom
abstract: Dozens of rhesus macaques escaped a research facility in South Carolina. They’re still on the lam.
lead_paragraph: A caretaker entered an enclosure at a research center in South Carolina on Wednesday, cleaning the space and feeding the 50 rhesus monkeys inside. But on leaving, she failed to latch the double doors behind her.

headline: Voters Sent Mixed Message on Crime and Law Enforcement
abstract: Targeting crime was a central part of the Trump campaign’s message, but some left-leaning prosecutors and measures survived a Republican wave on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: In Orlando, Fla., on Tuesday, voters returned Monique Worrell, a Democrat, to the prosecutor’s office by a wide margin.

headline: Democrats Play the Blame Game
abstract: Also, another interest rate cut. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said today that he accepted Donald Trump’s victory and vowed to honor the Constitution with a peaceful transfer of power, even as he acknowledged the pain felt by supporters of him and Kamala Harris.

headline: Photographing the Newsroom on Election Night
abstract: Simbarashe Cha and Sara Krulwich, two New York Times photographers, documented Tuesday evening in the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: Election night at The New York Times has been documented in photos for decades. This year, Sara Krulwich and Simbarashe Cha, two Times staff photographers, were in the newsroom in Manhattan, making images of the night as it transitioned into morning.

headline: Elwood Edwards, Voice of AOL’s ‘You’ve Got Mail!’ Alert, Dies at 74
abstract: Early in the internet era, he was also behind other AOL messages, including “Welcome!” “They said my voice was heard more than 35 million times a day,” he once said.
lead_paragraph: Elwood Edwards, an announcer who voiced the ubiquitous AOL email alert “You’ve got mail!” at a time when many Americans were just beginning to learn how to navigate the internet, died on Tuesday at his home in New Bern, N.C. He was 74.

headline: Washington Post Employees Ordered Back to Office 5 Days a Week
abstract: All employees at The Post will be expected to return to the office by June 2. Managers must be back in the office full time by Feb. 3.
lead_paragraph: Employees at The Washington Post will be expected to work from the office five days a week next year, according to a new memo from the newspaper’s chief executive, the latest crackdown on pandemic-era remote work policies.

headline: Trump Names Susie Wiles as His White House Chief of Staff
abstract: The president-elect turned to his top political aide to fill a key post managing the White House when he returns to office.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Thursday named Susie Wiles, the Florida strategist who has run his political operation for nearly four years, as his White House chief of staff for his incoming administration.

headline: Giuliani Speaks After Missing Court Deadline for $148 Million Payment
abstract: Rudy Giuliani, the former New York City mayor, owes $148 million from a 2021 defamation case, which he called “a political vendetta.”
lead_paragraph: Rudy Giuliani, the former New York City mayor, owes $148 million from a 2021 defamation case, which he called “a political vendetta.”

headline: Mayor of Jackson, Miss., Is Indicted on Federal Corruption Charges
abstract: The mayor and two other local officials pleaded not guilty on Thursday after being accused of taking part in a scheme in which F.B.I. agents posing as real estate developers offered bribes.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Jackson, Miss., a City Council member and the local district attorney have been indicted on federal corruption charges, with court documents unsealed on Thursday detailing a scheme in which F.B.I. agents posing as real estate developers paid tens of thousands of dollars in bribes to city officials.

headline: Keep Fluoride in New York Water? Mayor Adams Hesitates, Then Weighs In.
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has indicated that he would support ending water fluoridation. Mayor Eric Adams was reticent on the issue, before eventually taking a side.
lead_paragraph: New York City has fluoridated its tap water since 1965, when Mayor Eric Adams was 5 years old.

headline: What’s Next for Kamala Harris? Here Are Six Options.
abstract: Her friends, aides and political allies say it’s too soon for her to even contemplate her next career move. But the speculation has already begun.
lead_paragraph: In 74 days, Vice President Kamala Harris will leave office, with no concrete plans about what to do next or how to proceed as a private citizen for the first time since she was elected San Francisco’s district attorney in 2003.

headline: Giuliani’s Delay in Handing Over Prized Assets Makes Judge Livid
abstract: A federal judge threatened Rudolph W. Giuliani with a contempt charge after a missed deadline to hand over prized possessions, including Yankees swag.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday, having grown exasperated with Rudy Giuliani, said he had heard enough excuses.

headline: Prince William Says Past Year Was Probably the Hardest ‘in My Life’
abstract: While in South Africa for the Earthshot Prize, the prince told reporters that the cancer diagnoses of his wife, Catherine, and his father, King Charles, had been “brutal.”
lead_paragraph: Prince William has talked publicly for the first time about the emotional impact of the dual cancer diagnoses of his wife, Catherine, the Princess of Wales; and his father, King Charles III, over the past year.

headline: Man Who Illegally Accessed Ginsburg’s Medical Records Gets 2 Years in Prison
abstract: The man, a former health care worker, was convicted in July on two charges stemming from the privacy breach and his attempts to cover it up.
lead_paragraph: A former health care worker who was accused of illegally accessing the health care records of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court, posting them online and then trying to hide what he had done was sentenced on Thursday to two years in prison, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Trump’s Strange Bedfellows: Arab Americans and Right-Leaning Jews
abstract: Donald J. Trump won votes from Arab Americans and conservative pro-Israel Jews. Someone is likely to be disappointed.
lead_paragraph: In the final hours before Election Day dawned, some of Donald J. Trump’s top surrogates in Michigan were onstage in a Grand Rapids arena, distilling the choice in the campaign into a stark and striking message.

headline: The Short Campaign May Have Been Harris’s Undoing — and Biden’s Fault
abstract: By seeking re-election, Biden deprived Harris of months of campaigning that might have helped her.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. My colleague Adam Nagourney has covered 10 presidential elections — but never one as short as Vice President Kamala Harris’s speedy sprint. Tonight, he tells us why that could have been one of Harris’s biggest problems. And we’ll take a look at just how far the red wave went. — Jess Bidgood
