headline: New York City Will Stop Giving Debit Cards to Migrants
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams is ending a contentious pilot program that gave 2,600 migrant families debit cards to purchase food.
lead_paragraph: New York City will end a contentious program that provided debit cards to migrant families to purchase food, city officials announced on Thursday.

headline: San Francisco Mayor Concedes Race to Levi Strauss Heir
abstract: Mayor London Breed acknowledged on Thursday that Daniel Lurie, a first-time candidate, would succeed her in office.
lead_paragraph: London Breed, San Francisco’s first Black female mayor, who steered the city through the pandemic but also saw its quality of life sink, conceded her re-election race on Thursday.

headline: On the Ballot, Abortion Rights Proved More Popular Than Kamala Harris
abstract: In states like Arizona and Nevada, some voters split their tickets, supporting abortion rights measures while also backing Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Democrats headed into the election hoping that abortion rights initiatives would drive support for Kamala Harris in states where the measures appeared on the ballot, including two presidential swing states, Arizona and Nevada.

headline: Judge Tosses Out Biden Program for Undocumented Spouses
abstract: The ruling issued by a federal judge in Texas struck down a new initiative aimed at helping undocumented spouses of U.S. citizens stay in the country.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas on Thursday struck down a new Biden administration program that sought to provide a path to U.S. citizenship for hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants married to American citizens.

headline: Read the Judge’s Ruling
abstract: A federal judge in Texas struck down a new Biden administration program that sought to provide a path to U.S. citizenship for hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants married to American citizens.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas struck down a new Biden administration program that sought to provide a path to U.S. citizenship for hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants married to American citizens.

headline: ‘Walden’ Review: My Sister! My Twin! My Astronaut!
abstract: Emmy Rossum and Zoë Winters star in a new Off Broadway play that’s a climate disaster drama cohabiting with a domestic soap opera.
lead_paragraph: Despite its name and original mission, Second Stage Theater, founded in 1979, has in recent years expanded its reach to include many new works by early-career playwrights.

headline: One Who’s on a Roll
abstract: Evans Clinchy opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Suit Against Meta, Using a Tech Shield Law, Is Dismissed
abstract: A professor sued pre-emptively to release software that would let users automatically unfollow everyone in their Facebook feed.
lead_paragraph: An attempt to sue Meta using a law that shields tech giants from liability is dead for now.

headline: Wave of Racist Texts After Election Prompts F.B.I.’s Scrutiny
abstract: The texts, which showed up as early as Wednesday morning, were reported in at least 13 states across the country.
lead_paragraph: A wave of racist text messages summoning Black people to report for slavery showed up on phones across the United States, prompting the scrutiny of the F.B.I.

headline: Quote of the Day: Pakistani City’s Pollution Hospitalizes Hundreds
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 8, 2024
lead_paragraph: “The air feels thick, and it’s exhausting just to breathe.”

headline: ’Til Death (and Maybe Not Even Then) Do They Part
abstract: Brandon Hupp and Lyle Shearer found kindred spirits in each other. What could be more fitting than a wedding on Halloween?
lead_paragraph: Brandon Taylor Hupp has long been drawn to the spooky and macabre. Tim Burton has always been an artistic inspiration, and he considers the dark and moody to be romantic. When he met Lyle Andrew Shearer, who shared his predilections, they knew they might be a match.

headline: All It Took Was 10 Days of Dating
abstract: When Saira Badat and Raed Khan met in July, they knew almost immediately that they would be married — ideally this year.
lead_paragraph: Even before their introductory phone call in July, Raed Shah Khan and Saira Badat knew they would hit it off.

headline: Two Bar Patrons Step Into a Twitter Feed
abstract: Tina Survilla Lindell and Cesar Kuriyama, who met at the start of the pandemic, connected over the temporary closing of their favorite bar.
lead_paragraph: Tina Marie Survilla Lindell and Cesar Alejandro Kuriyama’s relationship began with what Ms. Survilla Lindell calls a “tweet cute.”

headline: First They Built a Relationship. Then They Built a Brand.
abstract: When Barry Bordelon and Jordan Slocum connected on Grindr, becoming the Brownstone Boys was not on their bingo card.
lead_paragraph: Just seven months after Barry Brandon Bordelon and Jordan Noah Slocum met, they put their entire savings together and bought a 19th-century Brooklyn brownstone, Mr. Slocum said. That home, in Bedford Stuyvesant, changed their lives.

headline: Men, Please Stop Talking About Burning Man
abstract: Am I the only woman meeting Burning Mansplainers on dates?
lead_paragraph: I used to be the type of person who enjoyed dating in New York City. A summer afternoon rendezvous perhaps, one that begins with the smell of sticky sidewalks and Aperol and ends with the cheerful patter of synchronized footsteps.

headline: Companies Brace for the Return of Trump’s Old Trade Gripes
abstract: The president-elect is again calling out companies by name in his campaign against what he sees as other countries’ unfair practices.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump repeatedly singled out the Japanese construction equipment maker Komatsu during his 2016 presidential campaign, employees at the company were taken aback.

headline: What to Know About Ireland’s Snap General Election
abstract: The Republic of Ireland will hold a general election on Nov. 29, after Prime Minister Simon Harris dissolved parliament on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Voters in the Republic of Ireland are set to head to the polls later this month for a general election.

headline: Argentina’s Leader Takes Ax to Program That Drove Down Teen Pregnancy
abstract: Argentina has been known as one of Latin America’s most socially progressive countries. But President Javier Milei’s austerity measures have cut programs aimed at helping women.
lead_paragraph: For three years, Silvia Alanis visited high schools in a small town in northern Argentina, teaching sex education and providing teenagers with birth control as part of a federally funded effort to lower high rates of teen pregnancy.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, Donald Trump proposed a variety of loosely defined tax cuts, which, after his election this week, will now face a fiscal reckoning in Washington.

headline: Antisemitic Attacks Prompt Emergency Flights for Israeli Soccer Fans
abstract: Dutch and Israeli officials said the fans had been attacked in Amsterdam after tensions flared around an Israeli team’s visit.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Amsterdam on Friday were investigating what they called antisemitic attacks on Israeli soccer fans that took place amid a charged atmosphere surrounding a soccer match involving a visiting Israeli team.

headline: Mountain Fire Wreaks Havoc on California
abstract: Firefighting teams on the ground and in the air battled the wildfire that was fueled by high-speed winds and swept over Ventura County.
lead_paragraph: Firefighting teams on the ground and in the air battled the wildfire that was fueled by high-speed winds and swept over Ventura County.

headline: Goodbye to Democracy? Not Quite Yet.
abstract: In a year filled with elections, the state of democracy is thriving by many measures. But there are dark clouds on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: In this year of elections, when a full quarter of humanity was eligible to vote, pessimism about the fate of democracy has spread among politicians, civil society, media commentators and political scientists. The victory of Donald Trump on Wednesday, with his demagogy and verbal assaults on what he referred to as “enemies from within,” makes the assessment that democracy is in retreat seem all the more plausible.

headline: Steven Madden C.E.O. Says It Is Moving Production Out of China
abstract: The prospect of higher tariffs under President-elect Trump spurred the company to accelerate its plan to shift where its shoes are made.
lead_paragraph: The American shoe company Steven Madden will cut nearly half of its China production within the next year as it braces for tariffs under a second Trump administration.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Relays Biden’s Promise of a Peaceful Transfer of Power
abstract: “Democrats were like, ‘Well, I guess at this point we can let him speak again,’” the “Tonight Show” host said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: geothermal
abstract: This word has appeared in 63 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word geothermal has appeared in 63 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 25 in “Tracing Dostoyevsky’s Wayward Path Through Three German Spa Towns” by Charly Wilder:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Former Adams Aide Is in Plea Talks in Federal Witness Tampering Case
abstract: Mohamed Bahi was accused of tampering with witnesses and destroying evidence in the corruption investigation into Mayor Eric Adams and his campaign fund-raising.
lead_paragraph: A former City Hall aide charged with tampering with witnesses in the federal corruption investigation into Mayor Eric Adams is talking with prosecutors about a potential guilty plea — raising the possibility that he might cooperate with them against the mayor.

headline: Jump
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: China Reveals $1.4 Trillion Plan to Bail Out Local Governments
abstract: The support package came after smaller measures were announced to jump-start growth. Economists said it was not big enough to address China’s sluggish economy.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government on Friday approved a $1.4 trillion plan to revive the economy, authorizing local governments to refinance crushing debts that have left some cities unable to pay their bills.

headline: Read Your Way Through Shanghai
abstract: Shanghai straddles the past and the future, a dizzying prism of many histories and cultures. The poet Sally Wen Mao shares books that illuminate this cosmopolitan city.
lead_paragraph: Shanghai is a city of transformations and revolutions. Between the leafy corners of the French Concession, the lit eaves of the Old City and Yu Garden, the alleys and residential blocks of shikumen (stone gates), the futuristic Pudong district against the Huangpu River and the colonial architecture of the historical Bund, there is a singular glow about Shanghai: Its prismatic mélange of histories and cultures bristles and brims with human life.

headline: Hostile Takeovers in a World of Grotesquerie
abstract: Slitterhead’s nightmare alley is easier to navigate thanks to the player’s power to possess the bodies of others.
lead_paragraph: The terror-filled indie Slitterhead is notable because it is made by Keiichiro Toyama, the creator of the revered Silent Hill survival horror series. Toyama and his Bokeh Game Studio have produced a bloody, gruesome, sometimes indecipherable tale set within a seedy 1990s-era Kowlong, a fictional city based on a district of Hong Kong. In the game, the slum nights are long, denizens heave into trash cans and neon signs advertise massages.

headline: Yellowstone Is Disappearing. The TV Show May Be Partly to Blame.
abstract: Mounting development is a grave threat because of how it is carving up an ecosystem that must stay relatively intact to function.
lead_paragraph: Each summer, as I drive along the river valleys between Yellowstone National Park and Cody, Wyo., I see new cabins jutting from ridge tops, subdivisions in former hayfields and fences separating them all.

headline: Don’t Say ‘Macbeth’ and Other Strange Rituals of the Theater World
abstract: Pulling back the curtain on the peculiar customs and enduring superstitions that help define life backstage.
lead_paragraph: You may not have realized it, but there’s little chance you’ve heard anyone whistle inside a theater. In the old days, sailors often worked the ropes backstage, bringing to show business codes like command whistles. So a whistle meant as a compliment, or to get a person’s attention, might have landed a piece of scenery on someone’s head.

headline: House Committee Targets Chip Technology Firms for China Ties
abstract: It requested information from a handful of firms that make chip manufacturing possible about their commercial ties to China.
lead_paragraph: A number of technology companies that make semiconductor manufacturing possible are coming under scrutiny from Capitol Hill, as the United States weighs further export restrictions to try to hold back China’s technological advancement.

headline: Rapunzel’s Got Nothing on These Picture Books’ African Heroines
abstract: In “Freedom Braids” and “The Magic Callaloo,” young girls follow cornrowed maps to escape slavery.
lead_paragraph: When I was 10 years old and bored during math, I drew a map on my left arm in blue ink by plotting my freckles, a small bruise, a sprinkling of moles and a scar. My arm country was long and narrow. I drew little triangle trees for a forest, a squiggly river to divide east and west, and a house where I could live. When Mrs. Stern saw that I was writing on myself instead of finishing my subtraction, she scolded me. I cried big fat tears that watered my arm’s forest, made the river rise and blurred the compass rose. I didn’t know how to explain to Mrs. Stern that the body is a map we’re fated to follow.

headline: A Chinese Homecoming Story That’s Universal
abstract: In the finale of Wang Bing’s nonfiction trilogy, garment-factory workers return to their families and wrestle with the questions all young people do.
lead_paragraph: What happens when young people with jobs in the big city return to the homes they left behind? It’s a question that powers a whole bevy of films, including Hallmark’s holiday offerings. But it’s perhaps less expected in a 152-minute Chinese documentary, the final installment in a trilogy stretching nearly 10 hours.

headline: Luxury Mountain Apartments in Switzerland
abstract: From the Schanfigg Valley to the Matterhorn and Mont Blanc, Switzerland offers slopes, hikes and views galore.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom apartment with custom-designed furnishings and other touches is on the third floor of a 18-unit building from 2012 in Arosa, a ski resort town 92 miles southeast of Zurich and 42 miles south of the principality of Liechtenstein.

headline: 3 Days of Healing, Hope and ‘Snake Oil’ With the Wellness Elite
abstract: Thousands of health seekers, many of them distrustful of the medical system, made a pilgrimage to Florida to commune with the influencers and the self-proclaimed healers they believe in most.
lead_paragraph: On the weekend between Halloween and Election Day, more than 2,000 people gathered within the capacious, dim meeting rooms in the Palm Beach Convention Center in Florida to learn and teach about improving one’s health. They flew in from Boston and Vancouver, Dallas and New York City, Boulder and the Bay Area. Some brought their mothers. A few, their dogs. They wore amulets and Oura rings, dressed in stretch pants or long, flowing dresses that evoked beach parties and summertime. I was there, too, curious about why health and wellness were, in these final months of 2024, suddenly receiving the Lollapalooza treatment.

headline: Chopin Drops a New Single
abstract: Nearly 200 years after his death, the piano master is back.
lead_paragraph: Sorting through a collection of memorabilia one day, Robinson McClellan, the music curator at the Morgan Library and Museum in Manhattan, came across something astonishing: a tiny scrap of paper with musical notes on it and the name Chopin written across the top. After he consulted with multiple scholars, it was determined that the manuscript was authentic. On today’s episode, Javier Hernández, a classical music reporter, tells the story of the discovery, and enlists one of the great interpreters of Chopin, the pianist Lang Lang, to play the score.

headline: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Faced a Pitiless Terrain: Adapting Anything ‘Dune’
abstract: The novels were famously tough to adapt until Denis Villeneuve came along. Can an HBO prequel about the origins of the Bene Gesserit follow suit?
lead_paragraph: For over 50 years, Frank Herbert’s best-selling science-fiction novel “Dune” was a puzzle no one in show business seemed able to solve. Published in 1965, the book had inspired a shelf full of sequels and prequels — along with scores of imitators — yet it defied every attempt to turn it into a blockbuster film or TV series.

headline: Is It Difficult Being a Student Athlete?
abstract: More than ever, college athletes have to deal with the dual pressures of being a student and an athlete. To what extent do high school and middle school athletes face similar challenges?
lead_paragraph: Do you play one or more sports? Are you involved with other school activities that require you to attend practices, games, performances or competitions — or even to travel long distances to do any of these pursuits?

headline: Zita Cobb Runs a $1,780-a-Night Inn on a Small Island. Is She the Most Radical Person in Travel?
abstract: The innkeeper at this luxury hotel on Newfoundland’s Fogo Island hopes other places might draw inspiration from an economic model in which tourism is in service to the community, and not the other way around.
lead_paragraph: When Zita Cobb was 10, her hometown almost disappeared. Not just her hometown, but all of the communities on Fogo Island, the island off Newfoundland where Ms. Cobb was born in 1958. The crisis was triggered by the collapse of the near-shore cod fishery, a resource that had sustained her ancestral community since the 17th century. In response, the Newfoundland government proposed to resettle the population to other parts of the province — or somewhere.

headline: The Burning Desire to Wear Burgundy
abstract: As the color has permeated popular culture, interest in wearing it has ballooned.
lead_paragraph: Burgundy’s associations with certain hallmarks of fall — foliage, for example, or uniforms of students going back to school — have made it a color long prescribed for autumn wardrobes.

headline: He’s the F.D.A.’s Cancer Chief, Not a Fortune Teller
abstract: Dr. Richard Pazdur for 25 years has overseen innovations in the treatment of deadly diseases at the agency.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago, cancer was almost a different disease. Despite the so-called War on Cancer, declared in 1971 by President Richard Nixon, treatments had mostly remained the same blunt instruments — brutal chemotherapy, surgery and radiation. It seemed as if cancer had won the war.

headline: An Early Flight Simulator Helped Pilots Learn the Ropes
abstract: In a new museum on Long Island, you can see a simulator that began as an amusement-park ride.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll get an early start on Veterans Day with a look at a new museum that is showcasing a very old flight simulator. We’ll also get a first look at a 74-foot-tall tree that is on its way to Rockefeller Center for the holidays.

headline: Even at a Time Like This, Slow and Steady Works in the Stock Market
abstract: Big changes are coming in the next Trump administration. But your investing plans needn’t change, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. stock market is booming. Since Donald J. Trump declared that he had won the presidency once again, traders have been happily driving share prices up.

headline: Netflix and Lifetime Ask: What if Christmas Movies Were Sexy?
abstract: With “Hot Frosty,” “The Merry Gentlemen” and “A Carpenter Christmas Romance,” holiday fare is headed in a shirtless new direction.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Christmas romance usually know exactly what to expect when tuning in to any of the dozens of new movies on cable and streaming platforms each year.

headline: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include sequels galore and an animated adventure out of Canada.
lead_paragraph: It’s tough to imagine that this Illumination franchise will ever stop churning out movies. Children keep watching, so why not continue with Minion mania? This time around, Gru (Steve Carell), supervillain gone good (sort of), is in the witness protection program with his wife, Lucy (Kristen Wiig), and their kids, including his new baby son, Gru Jr.

headline: How Democrats Helped Trump
abstract: Why the 2024 election’s outcome was uniquely foreseeable.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the night of Nov. 4, 2008, a presidential election went exactly the way that I expected it to go.

headline: How to Build the World’s Largest Cruise Ship (or One of Them, Anyway)
abstract: In a Finnish shipyard, the 250,800-ton sister of Icon of the Seas, the world’s largest cruise ship, is in the final stages of construction. We got an inside look.
lead_paragraph: The valves were opened and more than a thousand workers gathered at the Meyer Turku shipyard in Finland to watch the “float out” of Royal Caribbean’s Star of the Seas. The nine-hour process — which involves flooding a special dock with more than 92 million gallons of water to push the 250,800-ton mega-ship onto a pier for the final stages of construction — had begun.

headline: What Is the Best Version of a Second Trump Administration?
abstract: Opinion columnists break down what the best version of a second Trump administration could look like.
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnists break down what the best version of a second Trump administration could look like.

headline: What a Second Trump Term Could Mean for Your Money
abstract: Here’s what the president-elect has said he might do with your taxes, student loans, Social Security and more.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump made a number of personal finance promises during his presidential campaign. How many will he try to — and be able to — keep?

headline: 10 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: After witnessing a young woman mistreated at a local convent turned Magdalene Laundry, Bill Furlong (Cillian Murphy) reflects on his past and struggles to take action in this Irish drama directed by Tim Mielants.

headline: TL;DR: Blame Biden
abstract: Trump is on track to win the popular vote. There’s a lesson there.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party needs to take a look in the mirror, and fast. This week on ‘Matter of Opinion,’ Opinion columnist and friend of the show Lydia Polgreen joins the hosts to dissect what went wrong for Democrats, and what kind of leadership the party needs to win back voters in Trump’s America.

headline: Musk Believes in Global Warming. Trump Doesn’t. Will That Change?
abstract: The Tesla billionaire is a key figure in the president-elect’s orbit. One question is whether his views on climate and clean energy will have any sway.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has described himself as “pro-environment” and “super pro climate.” But he also threw himself wholeheartedly into electing as president someone who has dismissed global warming as a hoax.

headline: ‘An Earthquake’ Along the Border: Trump Flipped Hispanic South Texas
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s biggest gains were along the Texas border, a Democratic stronghold where most voters are Hispanic. He won 12 of the region’s 14 counties, up from five in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Nowhere in the United States have historically Democratic counties shifted so far and so fast in the direction of former President Donald J. Trump as they have in the Texas communities along the Rio Grande, where Hispanic residents make up an overwhelming majority.

headline: A Red-District Conqueror Wants Fellow Democrats to Look in the Mirror
abstract: Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Perez, who is on track to win re-election in a rural Washington district, says her party needs to stop demonizing others and change the candidates it supports.
lead_paragraph: It’s not always fun to say I told you so.

headline: Let’s Not Lose Sight of Who Trump Is
abstract: The 2024 election has the potential to challenge the New Deal realignment of 1932 as the most consequential election of the past 100 years.
lead_paragraph: In terms of historical perspective, the 2024 election has the potential to challenge the New Deal realignment of 1932 as the most consequential election of the past 100 years.

headline: It’s Time to Resist the Resistance
abstract: Resistance politics inevitably feels conservative. It’s reactionary in a literal sense, and this week, it ended in disaster for the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: What do Democrats stand for? Over the last eight years, the answer has been simple: whatever Donald Trump is against. They have been the party of the so-called Resistance, defending institutions against a dangerous and fundamentally undemocratic movement. Two impeachments, four criminal investigations and 34 felony convictions, along with countless warnings that democracy was in peril: All of it flowed out of the conviction that Mr. Trump was a menace who couldn’t be addressed by politics as usual. It has defined what it means to be a Democrat. And it failed spectacularly this week, helping clear a path for Mr. Trump to return to the White House with a clean victory in the popular vote. This time, there’s no James Comey to scapegoat or Electoral College to blame. It’s a painful defeat — but it could also be a moment of rebirth for the party as it sets out to find a lasting Democratic majority.

headline: Yes, There Are Things to Love About Winter
abstract: It’s not all dark mornings and bulky coats.
lead_paragraph: As soon as the temperature drops, my husband undergoes a transformation. A Midwesterner, Tom starts reminiscing about the Great Blizzard of 1978. He shares chipper platitudes like, “There’s no bad weather, only bad clothing!” And on the first snowy day, he will crow about our car’s all-wheel drive. Like a bear in reverse, he comes alive in winter.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Nov. 8, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: I Study Guys Like Trump. There’s a Reason They Keep Winning.
abstract: Democrats walked into the trap of defending the very institutions most Americans distrust.
lead_paragraph: In December 2019, I traveled to Hong Kong, where a heavy unease hung in the air. For months, young people had taken to the streets to protest the encroachment of the Chinese Communist Party on what was supposed to be a self-governing, democratic system. On walls they had scrawled: “Save Hong Kong! If we burn you burn with us!” All the protesters I spoke to knew their movement would fail; it was a last assertion of democratic identity before it was extinguished by a new order that saw democracy as the enemy within.

headline: With Trump’s Victory, Europe’s Populist Right Sees Return of a Fellow Believer
abstract: Viktor Orban of Hungary and other right-wing European politicians hail the return of a U.S. president who shares their tough views on issues like immigration.
lead_paragraph: For months, Hungary’s media apparatus pumped out stories lionizing Donald J. Trump and deriding Kamala Harris, described in one headline as “extremely unpleasant.”

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,239
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 517
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Nov. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Inside Trump World as the Next Chapter Begins
abstract: In the days following the election, the president-elect has been gearing up for a second administration.
lead_paragraph: In the days since the election, Donald J. Trump has started preparing to retake the White House.

headline: Trump’s Historic Chief of Staff Pick, and What Elon Musk Wants Now
abstract: Plus, for $200, he was the voice of the internet.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: How My War Came Home
abstract: A reporter thought of his city in the west of Ukraine as a haven from Russian bombs — until a strike hit his street.
lead_paragraph: I’ve covered the brutal realities of Ukraine’s war on its eastern front lines since the Russian invasion of 2022, but my home on the other side of the country remained largely untouched by violence.

headline: How Inflation Shaped Voting
abstract: We explain inflation’s role in the election.
lead_paragraph: Why did Donald Trump defeat Kamala Harris? One answer was clear even before Election Day: Voters consistently said the economy was their top issue, driven primarily by concerns about inflation. And they trusted Trump more than Harris to handle it. “It’s the economy, stupid” is an old cliché in American politics, and it often proves true.

headline: The Savior of ‘Satanic Verses’ in India: Bureaucratic Ineptitude
abstract: In 1988, India issued an order forbidding the import of Salman Rushdie’s novel. A Delhi Court has overturned the order, not because of free speech, but because no one could find it.
lead_paragraph: Before the Iranian fatwa condemning the writer to death, before all the protests and burnings of his book and before the stabbing death of his translator, there was India’s customs notification No. 405/12/88-CUS-III.

headline: Last N.I.H. Chimps to Move From New Mexico Facility
abstract: The retired research chimpanzees, which had previously been deemed too frail to move, will be relocated to a Louisiana sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two dozen government-owned chimpanzees, which have been living in an isolated desert facility since being retired from research, will be transferred to a sanctuary in Louisiana, officials from the National Institutes of Health said in an interview on Thursday.

headline: What Trump 2.0 Means for Tech + A.I. Made Me Basic + HatGPT!
abstract: A shake-up is coming for Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: As of this week, we have a new president-elect. We discuss how the incoming administration’s approach to technology will affect Elon Musk, a TikTok ban, Big Tech’s antitrust challenges and the speed of A.I. progress. Then, Kashmir Hill, a technology reporter for The Times, joins to discuss her weeklong experiment of letting A.I. make every decision in her life. And finally, we play a round of election-free HatGPT!

headline: Gazan Rescue Service Has Stopped Operating in the North
abstract: Residents had to dig through rubble in search of their neighbors after the main emergency service in Gaza said it had stopped operations in the north because it had come under Israeli attacks.
lead_paragraph: When an Israeli airstrike hit a home in northern Gaza early Thursday, residents said, there were no paramedics or emergency medical workers around to help pull out people trapped in the rubble.

headline: Forget a Soft Landing. The Fed’s Biggest Challenge May Be Trump.
abstract: The chair of the Federal Reserve made clear he would not resign, even under pressure. But pressure from the White House is likely, market watchers say.
lead_paragraph: Jay Powell and the Fed may have pulled off the improbable soft landing in taming inflation while not crashing the economy into recession, proving many a Wall Street naysayer wrong.

headline: New York’s Wu-Tang Clan Street Signs Sell Out in a Blink
abstract: The 100 replicas of the “Wu-Tang Clan District” sign on Staten Island, where the group was formed in 1992, were gone in less than two hours.
lead_paragraph: New York celebrated the Wu-Tang Clan by releasing on Thursday 100 replicas of the street sign on Staten Island named for the group. They were all snapped up in less than two hours.

headline: Older Workers to Get ‘Super’ 401(k) Catch-Up Contributions in 2025
abstract: Workers who are 60 to 63 will be able to put in up to $11,250 in extra contributions, if they can afford it.
lead_paragraph: Will you be age 60 to 63 next year? Lucky you! You have the option to contribute several thousand dollars more to your workplace retirement plan.

headline: California Shifts Rightward on Crime in an Election Fueled by Frustration
abstract: Voters in the Democratic-run state overwhelmingly approved a measure to impose harsher sentences for crimes and were on their way to ousting two progressive district attorneys.
lead_paragraph: California is known for having some of the most progressive laws in the country. But in Tuesday’s election, the state lurched rightward, as voters sent a clear message that they were fed up with crime and homelessness in their state.

headline: Biden Administration Restricts Development in West to Protect Sage Grouse
abstract: Limits on building energy projects on at least 34.5 million acres could strongly protect the iconic Western bird. But the incoming Trump administration may reverse the rule.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday issued final regulations designed to protect the greater sage grouse, a speckled brown bird with a sprawling habitat across 10 Western states.

headline: Church in Egyptian Desert Reveals Early Christian Burial Practices
abstract: A basilica from the 4th century held a surprising number of tombs with women and children, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, archaeologists began to excavate one of the world’s oldest Christian churches in the middle of a forbidding Egyptian desert. Delayed by war, political unrest and a global pandemic, the dig has turned out to be a revealing and confounding look at how early Christians buried their dead.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 8, 2024
abstract: No Corrections appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: A Coming-of-Age Novel That Crosses America’s Impossible Divide
abstract: “Us Fools,” by Nora Lange, is a tale of two sisters living through the diseased expanse of the country’s recent history.
lead_paragraph: Joanne’s voice has always been in Bernadette’s head. The Fareown sisters can’t escape each other, even if they can escape their roots. Growing up on their Illinois farm in the 1980s, Jo and Bernie have learned to fend for themselves, largely by sticking together.

headline: After the Election, a Call for Women to Swear Off Men
abstract: Interest in South Korea’s 4B feminist movement, which rejects dating, marriage, sex and childbirth, has risen in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Following the results of Tuesday’s election, Jada Mevs, a 25-year-old living in Washington, D.C., is encouraging women to take action by signing up for a self-defense class, deleting dating apps, getting on birth control and investing in a vibrator.

headline: With Trump Tariffs Looming, Businesses Try to ‘Run From a Moving Target’
abstract: Companies are filling their warehouses or looking into moving factories as they weigh President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threats to impose tariffs on foreign goods.
lead_paragraph: Rick Muskat woke up the morning after the election with an urgent task. He got his agent in China on the phone at 4:30 a.m. Beijing time and pressed him to ask their factory how many more pairs of men’s dress shoes they could make before Chinese New Year, at the end of January.

headline: A Pioneer of California Cuisine Turns 35
abstract: Michael McCarty and Kim McCarty will celebrate the New York outpost of Michael’s, their Santa Monica restaurant, with a few hundred regulars.
lead_paragraph: Michael’s, the California restaurant transplant and magnet for boldface names, is marking 35 years in New York. An estimated 300 or so of those hotshots will be on hand to raise a glass and nibble hors d’oeuvres on Nov. 13 to celebrate. Michael McCarty, the vivacious party-loving host, will be in the thick of it.

headline: Trump’s Supreme Court Agenda Is Likely to Include Legal U-Turns
abstract: In recent years, new administrations have not been shy about disavowing positions taken by their predecessors.
lead_paragraph: Under the Trump administration, the government is very likely to flip its position in a major case pending in the Supreme Court, on the rights of transgender minors, a reversal that reflects the sharply changing direction of the next administration.

headline: What It’s Like to Write a New John le Carré Novel
abstract: Nick Harkaway is an accomplished author who also happens to be le Carré’s son. In his latest book, “Karla’s Choice,” he revisits his father’s great spy protagonist, George Smiley.
lead_paragraph: Before the spy novelist John le Carré died in 2020, he extracted a promise from his son Nick Harkaway — also a novelist — to finish the manuscript that le Carré had been working on. Harkaway did, and the resulting book was published in 2021 as “Silverview.” Harkaway figured that, as far as continuing his father’s work, that was that.

headline: Analyzing Why Trump Won the Election
abstract: Readers point to Joe Biden, the economy, “hate and fear” and no-show voters. Also: How Roe v. Wade saved a woman’s life.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Anora’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The writer, director and editor Sean Baker narrates a sequence from his comedy featuring Mikey Madison and Mark Eydelshteyn.
lead_paragraph: The writer, director and editor Sean Baker narrates a sequence from his comedy featuring Mikey Madison and Mark Eydelshteyn.

headline: Watch Mikey Madison Take a Mansion Tour in ‘Anora’
abstract: The writer, director and editor Sean Baker narrates an early sequence from his film, which also features Mark Eydelshteyn.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Ukraine Hit Again Overnight by Deadly Barrage From Russia
abstract: Millions trek to shelters nightly or take their chances at home as unceasing missile and drone attacks drag on. Some Ukrainians are looking — with hope or sarcasm — to Trump for respite.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s latest overnight missile and drone attacks across Ukraine killed 11 people, including a 1-year-old boy, and wounded dozens of others, while triggering the longest aerial attack alert so far in the war in Kyiv, the capital.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in November
abstract: A parade of notable new titles are coming for U.S. subscribers all month. Here’s a roundup of the most promising.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles for U.S. subscribers. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include 2000s nostalgia, feminist thrills and the one and only Corey Feldman.
lead_paragraph: David Moreau’s spectacular single-shot thriller is set at the beginning of the end of the world. It begins as a young woman violently stabs herself in a car driven by Romain (Milton Riche, excellent). It continues as Romain’s girlfriend, Anais (Laurie Pavy, fearless and unhinged), becomes infected with an unexplained affliction that turns her into a feral maniac. And it ends with a despairing scene inside an elevator that — actually, I’ll stop there, because to say more would ruin the perspective-shifting twists that vault this singular French film down its deranged and gruesome path.

headline: Old-Fashioned Beef Stew, That Classic Rib-Sticker
abstract: Five stars and over 20,000 reviews later, it’s still just the thing for a brisk November night.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has a junior hunter program running this weekend out on Long Island. It’s a chance for kids ages 12 to 15 to take to the marsh or the water, accompanied by a licensed adult, to target ducks, coots, mergansers, brants and the Canada geese my father always called flying roast beef.

headline: This Elephant Uses a Hose to Give Herself a Shower Every Day
abstract: In the Berlin Zoo, Mary demonstrated another example of clever elephantine tool use while another animal exhibited a form of mischief with a hose that resembled a prank.
lead_paragraph: Elephants are serious about self care. To stay cool, and protect their skin, they wallow in mud, bathe in dust and use their trunks to spray themselves with water.

headline: Notre-Dame’s Bells Ring Together for First Time Since Fire
abstract: The sound of Notre-Dame’s bells pealed throughout Paris for the first time since 2019 — a symbol of rebirth as it prepares to reopen next month.
lead_paragraph: The bronze bells of the Notre-Dame Cathedral have not pealed together since 2019, when a furious blaze consumed the centuries-old landmark right before the eyes of horrified Parisians.

headline: Grammy Awards 2025: The Full List of Nominees
abstract: Artists, albums and songs competing for trophies at the 67th annual ceremony were announced on Friday. The show will take place on Feb. 2 at Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé is the top nominee for the 67th annual Grammy Awards with 11 nods for her genre-crossing “Cowboy Carter.” The LP and its songs will vie for record, song and album of the year, as well as competitions in pop, rap, country and Americana categories.

headline: Beyoncé and Young Women Pop Sensations Lead 2025 Grammy Nominees
abstract: Charli XCX, Billie Eilish, Chappell Roan and Sabrina Carpenter will compete in the biggest categories, along with Taylor Swift and Kendrick Lamar.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé and Taylor Swift will face off in all top categories at the 67th annual Grammy Awards, leading a pack of nominees that also features buzzy young female stars who have dominated the pop charts over the past year.

headline: Notre-Dame Cathedral’s Bells Ring as Restoration Nears Completion
abstract: The ringing of Notre-Dame’s bells sounded throughout Paris for the first time since the fire in 2019.
lead_paragraph: The ringing of Notre-Dame’s bells sounded throughout Paris for the first time since the fire in 2019.

headline: Is a New Wave of Digital Nomadism Coming? Interest in Moving Abroad Is on the Rise.
abstract: Google searches for “best countries to move to” peaked immediately after the election. Here’s what you need to know about digital nomad visas.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the U.S. election, Americans’ interest in digital nomad visas and moving abroad is on the rise.

headline: Party Whose Leader Is Known for Antisemitism to Join Lithuanian Government
abstract: A new coalition includes a party led by a politician notorious for antisemitic remarks, another blow to the longstanding refusal by Europe’s mainstream parties to join with those seen as extremist.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s fractious and increasingly fragmented politics shattered another taboo on Friday, when a mainstream party in Lithuania announced that it was forming a coalition government with a populist party led by a politician notorious for antisemitic statements.

headline: From a Celebrated Chef, a New Line of Home Goods
abstract: Clare de Boer and her husband, Luke Sherwin, have launched Roseland, a company selling furniture inspired by early American design.
lead_paragraph: This year, the dining-room fires were first lit at Stissing House, the restaurant in Pine Plains, N.Y., on Sept. 26. Last year, it was Oct. 4. The chef Clare de Boer, who took over the upstate tavern in 2022, always notes the date; it marks both a seasonal transition — on the menu, wood-roasted sunshine kabocha squash and fall vegetables with wild rice replace marinated heirloom tomatoes and peach pie — and the start of an important pre-service ritual. The 1782 building has five fireplaces, including one “so large you could fit a queen-size mattress in it,” says de Boer, and lighting them all during the colder months takes 20 minutes a day.

headline: Trump Win Shows Political Limits of Biden’s Industrial Policy Vision
abstract: Long-term economic investments in domestic manufacturing were overshadowed by real-time anxiety over rent and grocery prices.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden addressed the nation this week after a gutting election, his reflections on his economic legacy offered a glimpse into why Democrats were resoundingly defeated.

headline: Finnish Conductors Take Over the New York Philharmonic
abstract: Susanna Mälkki and Santtu-Matias Rouvali made back-to-back appearances with the orchestra, leading similar programs with distinct style.
lead_paragraph: Finland’s top exports may be machinery and fuel, but in classical music it is also one of the world’s leading producer of conductors.

headline: ‘Hippo’ Review: This Coming-of-Age Tale Can Go
abstract: Trafficking in irreverence, the film follows a pair of stepsiblings with sexual tension.
lead_paragraph: Like a stubborn toddler zipping his mouth shut while stomping his feet, “Hippo” manages to be noisily aggravating while saying nothing at all. Directed by Mark H. Rapaport in his feature debut, the indie film traffics in cynicism and irreverence while lacking in the quality it seems to want most: individuality.

headline: The New York Steakhouse That’s Served Everyone From Theodore Roosevelt to Liza Minnelli
abstract: Keens, a fixture in midtown Manhattan since 1885, is a shrine to a bygone city.
lead_paragraph: On West 36th Street, a few blocks from the clamor of Penn Station and Madison Square Garden, a brown awning with white lettering beckons diners into Keens Steakhouse, where New York history is served up along with lavish slabs of U.S.D.A. prime beef, arguably the best in town. There’s also the famous mutton chop, big as your arm, Keens’s signature dish since 1885, when the restaurant first opened its doors.

headline: Judge Grants Jack Smith’s Request for Pause in Jan. 6 Case After Trump’s Election
abstract: The special counsel asked for time to assess how to proceed now that Donald Trump is returning the White House, triggering a Justice Department policy against prosecuting a sitting president.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Friday granted a request from the special counsel, Jack Smith, to pause all filing deadlines in the federal case accusing President-elect Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Iranian Agents Plotted to Kill Trump, U.S. Says in Unsealed Charges
abstract: The allegation came in a complaint that said Masih Alinejad, a Brooklyn activist, had been the target of a second assassination attempt.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said on Friday that Iranian plotters had discussed a plan to assassinate Donald J. Trump before he was re-elected as president this week.

headline: Jonathan Haze, Star of ‘The Little Shop of Horrors,’ Dies at 95
abstract: Best known for his star turn in the cult film about a flesh-eating plant, he was a go-to member of the low-budget auteur Roger Corman’s repertory company.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Haze, a prince of the B-movie who appeared in nearly 20 pulp cinema popcorn munchers by the king of the B-movie, the low-budget auteur Roger Corman — most notably as Seymour, the sniveling flower shop assistant in the original “The Little Shop of Horrors” — died on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.

headline: Old-School Celebrities Could Not Move the Needle
abstract: Hollywood endorsements, once an essential part of a campaign playbook, may have backfired in this election.
lead_paragraph: In an election season in which both parties sought out any possible edge, Democrats clung to one seemingly clear-cut advantage: Celebrities including Taylor Swift and Bruce Springsteen broke hard for that party, even as voters did not.

headline: Read the Special Counsel’s Filing
abstract: Jack Smith, the special counsel, asked a judge to put on hold all filing deadlines in the federal case accusing President-elect Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel, asked a judge to put on hold all filing deadlines in the federal case accusing President-elect Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Pelosi Laments Biden’s Late Exit and the Lack of an ‘Open Primary’
abstract: “Had the president gotten out sooner, there may have been other candidates in the race,” the former House speaker said in an interview with The New York Times, suggesting she had anticipated an “open primary.”
lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the former House speaker, suggested this week that it would have been better for the Democratic Party if President Biden had abandoned his re-election campaign sooner and the party had then held a competitive primary process to replace him.

headline: Playing Out a Dream, a Long, Long Way From Home
abstract: An academy of a team in England’s lower leagues offers Americans at the end of their collegiate eligibility a chance to continue their soccer careers.
lead_paragraph: Izzy Morales first caught sight of the Stadium of Light from the back of an Uber. He had left his home in Canton, Ohio, a couple of days earlier. He was still coming to terms with the novelty, with the distance, of the new life he had chosen. When he touched down in Dublin, en route to the North East of England, it had suddenly struck him that he was traveling “halfway across the world.”

headline: A Mainstay of the Bloomsbury Group, With a Show of Her Own
abstract: Vanessa Bell is often best remembered for the creative milieu she cultivated, but a new exhibition of her work makes a case for her as a groundbreaking artist.
lead_paragraph: In 1932, the historian Kenneth Clark commissioned a ceramic dinner service from the artists Vanessa Bell and Duncan Grant. But he got something different: 48 plates, each painted with a portrait of a famous woman, from the Queen of Sheba to Greta Garbo. (Plus two bearing the images of the artists.)

headline: A New Broadway Musical Asks: Can Robots Fall in Love?
abstract: “Maybe Happy Ending” had an initial Korean-language production in Seoul in 2016. Here are five things to know about the show.
lead_paragraph: Hue Park was sitting in a Brooklyn coffee shop in the spring of 2014 when “Everyday Robots,” an indie pop ballad by Damon Albarn, floated over the speakers: “We are everyday robots on our phones / In the process of getting home.”

headline: Painting by A.I.-Powered Robot Sells for $1.1 Million
abstract: The portrait depicts the British mathematician Alan Turing as the god of artificial intelligence. Its creator is a robot named Ai-Da that resembles a woman with a bob haircut.
lead_paragraph: A portrait of the British mathematician Alan Turing sold at auction for nearly $1.1 million on Thursday, a surprisingly large sum for a painting whose creator wasn’t an artist in the traditional sense, but rather a humanoid robot powered by artificial intelligence.

headline: Trump Put Musk on Phone With Zelensky During Call
abstract: Elon Musk was with Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago when the president-elect spoke with Ukraine’s leader. It is not clear if they discussed any change in U.S. policy toward Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump spoke on Wednesday with Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, and during the call handed the phone to Elon Musk, the increasingly influential billionaire who has played a key role in providing communications capability to Ukraine in its war with Russia, a person familiar with the discussion said.

headline: Linda LaFlamme Dies at 85; Her ‘White Bird’ Reflected a Hippie Fantasy
abstract: With her husband, David LaFlamme, she founded the rock band It’s a Beautiful Day and wrote a soaring paean to a generation’s dreams of escape.
lead_paragraph: Linda LaFlamme, a songwriter and keyboardist who helped found the San Francisco folk-rock band It’s a Beautiful Day in 1967 and who co-wrote the band’s soaring “White Bird,” an enduring anthem of the psychedelic era, died on Oct. 23 in Harrisonburg, Va. She was 85.

headline: Grammys Snubs and Surprises: Charli XCX Levels Up, Beyoncé Spreads Out and the Beatles Persist
abstract: A look at the nominations’ unexpected and intriguing story lines, including the role of an absent Drake, the validation of André 3000’s flute music and overlooked gems.
lead_paragraph: The names headlining this year’s Grammy Award nominations make a lot of sense: Beyoncé, Kendrick Lamar, Billie Eilish and Taylor Swift are perennial favorites with imperial reach. Sabrina Carpenter and Chappell Roan have stormed the mainstream. Shaboozey and Charli XCX made themselves inescapable.

headline: 7 Deep Cuts From the 2025 Grammy Nominations
abstract: Big names dominate the biggest categories, but lovely discoveries await on the ballot too. Hear tracks from Arooj Aftab, Sierra Ferrell, Tems, Idles and more.
lead_paragraph: This morning, the nominees for the 67th annual Grammy Awards were revealed, and the names that appeared most often should be quite familiar: Beyoncé (leading the pack with 11 nominations), Billie Eilish, Kendrick Lamar, Post Malone and Charli XCX (all with seven nods apiece). The Grammys have rarely been so reflective of the top of the charts and the celebrity zeitgeist, and that can make the announcement feel anticlimactic. But if you dig a little deeper into the list — as I do on today’s playlist — plenty of surprises and discoveries await.

headline: After G.O.P. Wins, Senate Democrats Eye Major Push to Confirm Biden Judges
abstract: The loss of the White House and the Senate majority will end Democrats’ ability to fill judicial vacancies come January. They say they want to confirm as many as possible in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats are weighing a major push in the coming weeks to confirm as many of President Biden’s judicial nominees as they can in the lame-duck session of Congress, before their power to reshape the federal courts ends with the Republican takeover of the White House and the Senate in January.

headline: Who Is Susie Wiles, Trump’s Pick for White House Chief of Staff?
abstract: Ms. Wiles, a principal architect of Donald J. Trump’s 2024 presidential campaign, will become the first woman to hold the job.
lead_paragraph: Susie Wiles, the political tactician who managed Donald J. Trump’s 2024 presidential campaign, will become the first woman to serve as White House chief of staff when he takes office on Jan. 20.

headline: The Election’s Other Biggest Losers? Economists.
abstract: Democrats have to reckon with the fact that voters don’t want what economists think is best.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-three Nobel laureates warned last month that Donald Trump’s agenda would “lead to higher prices, larger deficits and greater inequality.” I think they were right. But voters utterly ignored them.

headline: First Major Snow of the Season Pummels Denver Region
abstract: The National Weather Service said snowfall accumulations from Friday into Saturday morning could be significant, with 12 to 20 inches expected south of Denver.
lead_paragraph: An early season snowstorm — one that could be the largest in decades — is expected to clobber much of Colorado and parts of New Mexico starting Friday afternoon.

headline: Ben Baldanza, 62, Dies; Brought No-Frills Flying to Spirit Airlines
abstract: He introduced ticket prices that couldn’t be beat, but asked fliers to pay extra for nearly everything, including water, carry-ons and printed tickets.
lead_paragraph: Ben Baldanza, who turned a small money-losing airline called Spirit into a profit-making powerhouse through a combination of ultralow prices, bare-bones service, outrageous marketing and a no-apologies approach to customer complaints, died on Tuesday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 62.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Nov. 9, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Mayor Adams’s Longtime Girlfriend Retires From Highly Paid Schools Job
abstract: Tracey Collins, a high-ranking Department of Education adviser, stepped down amid allegations that her position was a “no-show” job.
lead_paragraph: Tracey Collins, a senior member of the New York City Department of Education staff and Mayor Eric Adams’s longtime girlfriend, retired this week amid an investigation into a claim that her highly paid position was a “no-show” job.

headline: Man Charged With Staging Car Crash Shown in TikTok Dash Cam Video
abstract: The crash, which prosecutors said was staged, was captured by dash cameras. The footage was uploaded to TikTok, where it has since been viewed more than 74 million times.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who was shown in a popular TikTok dash cam video of a crash on a busy Queens highway was charged with insurance fraud, staging a motor vehicle accident, reckless endangerment and other crimes, prosecutors announced on Friday.

headline: San Francisco Mayor-Elect Wants to Declare a ‘Fentanyl State of Emergency’
abstract: Daniel Lurie, San Francisco’s mayor-elect and heir to the Levi Strauss fortune, expressed his commitment to fighting crime and drugs in the city.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Lurie, San Francisco’s mayor-elect and heir to the Levi Strauss fortune, expressed his commitment to fighting crime and drugs in the city.

headline: Did Beyoncé’s Grammy Nods Really Top Michael Jackson’s for ‘Thriller’?
abstract: Not exactly. But in Grammyland, nothing is simple.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, as the news emerged of Beyoncé’s 11 Grammy nominations for her country-Beyoncé-style album “Cowboy Carter,” some fan accounts on social media trumpeted that it had become “the most Grammy-nominated album of all time,” and claimed that Beyoncé had even topped a record set in 1984 by Michael Jackson’s “Thriller,” the mega-blockbuster against which all other hits have since been judged.

headline: With Ready Orders and an Energy Czar, Trump Plots Pivot to Fossil Fuels
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s transition team for climate and the environment is considering relocating the E.P.A. out of Washington and other drastic changes.
lead_paragraph: As President-elect Donald J. Trump’s transition team plans his energy and environment agenda, it is relying on two seasoned former cabinet leaders and fossil fuel lobbyists to dramatically reshape the agencies charged with protecting the nation’s air, water, climate and public lands, according to six people familiar with the matter.

headline: America’s Wobbly Democracy
abstract: Lessons from a London bridge.
lead_paragraph: On June 10, 2000, London opened the Millennium Footbridge, a futuristic pedestrian path spanning the River Thames, hanging between suspension cables that was designed to look like a ribbon of steel. But as a steady stream of people began to flow across the new bridge, it began to wobble alarmingly from side to side.

headline: Wildfires Spread Across New Jersey and Connecticut: ‘No End in Sight’
abstract: Firefighters in the two states have battled hundreds of blazes during an unseasonably dry fall.
lead_paragraph: A spate of wildfires crisscrossing New Jersey prompted a statewide smoke advisory on Friday, as flames from one blaze in the Palisades, across the Hudson River from Manhattan, roared dangerously close to the nearby suburbs.

headline: Stock Market Rallies to Its Best Week in Over a Year
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump’s win, coupled with a quarter-point interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve, pushed major stock indexes into record territory.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rose on Friday, capping the market’s best week in over a year and extending a rally that came as President-elect Donald J. Trump’s decisive election win put an end to months of uncertainty for investors.

headline: What Trump’s Win Tells Us About the Democratic Party
abstract: What lessons can Democrats take from the 2024 election? Astead W. Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” gives his analysis.
lead_paragraph: What lessons can Democrats take from the 2024 election? Astead W. Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” gives his analysis.

headline: What to Know About the Attacks on Israeli Soccer Fans in Amsterdam
abstract: Dutch and Israeli officials described the clashes after a soccer match as antisemitic. The violence followed confrontations and mounting tensions in the city.
lead_paragraph: Details have been trickling out about the violence that broke out on the streets of Amsterdam last week around a soccer match between Dutch and Israeli teams.

headline: We’re Getting an Induction Range. Is It All Right to Sell Our Old Gas One?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the responsibility one has to dispose of an outmoded appliance.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have decided to purchase a new induction range, to reduce both our fossil-fuel impact and our exposure to toxins. We currently have a beautiful 1940s-era Wedgewood gas range. Would it be unethical to sell or donate our Wedgewood to another user? I am concerned that we would be extending the continued personal risk and environmental impact of our gas range. My husband believes the next user will have decided to obtain a gas range, so the emissions and risk from ours would be displacing those of another, with no net impact. Can you assist us in sorting out the ethical choice? — Name Withheld

headline: André 3000 on 3 Grammy Nods for His Flute Album: ‘Super Duper Cool’
abstract: He was half of Outkast, the last rap act to win album of the year — 20 years ago. His latest nominations are for “New Blue Sun,” an expression of ultimate freedom.
lead_paragraph: An album of the year nomination at the Grammys? André 3000 has been here before.

headline: Who Is Viktor Orban, Hungary’s Authoritarian Leader and Friend of Trump?
abstract: The long-serving prime minister, a champion of ‘illiberal democracy,’ has been politically isolated in much of Europe. But he has found common ground with the former and soon-to-be new U.S. president.
lead_paragraph: Viktor Orban, Hungary’s prime minister, has been at odds with his fellow European Union leaders for years over his right-wing nationalist stance on immigration, minority rights, the rule of law, media freedoms and other issues. He would not get in line with his counterparts’ views on aiding Ukraine and has openly sympathized with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: A Massachusetts Couple Called Off Their Wedding. Who Keeps the $70,000 Ring?
abstract: The state’s Supreme Judicial Court ruled that if wedding plans crumble, the engagement ring must be returned to the person who purchased it.
lead_paragraph: After Caroline Settino met Bruce Johnson in the summer of 2016, they embarked on a whirlwind romance. Mr. Johnson paid for trips to Italy and the Virgin Islands and showered his girlfriend with lavish gifts. A year later, he spent $70,000 on a Tiffany & Co. engagement ring and popped the question at a resort on Cape Cod in Massachusetts.

headline: University of Southern California President Will Retire in July
abstract: Carol Folt took over in 2019, often steadying the university but drawing criticism for her handling of campus protests last spring.
lead_paragraph: The University of Southern California’s president, Carol L. Folt, said on Friday that she would retire next summer, opening the top job at one of the West Coast’s most influential universities months after the campus faced immense turmoil around the war in Gaza.

headline: Trump Makes His First Moves
abstract: Also, an attack on Israeli soccer fans. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: Early signs emerged today of how quickly President-elect Donald Trump’s second administration would shift the government’s legal positions on a wide range of issues facing the Supreme Court, as speculation swirled about whom Trump would tap for critical positions in the government.

headline: What Experts Want You to Know About Plan B
abstract: We asked experts how it works, when you should take it, how much it costs and more.
lead_paragraph: Emergency contraceptives like Plan B, also known as the morning-after pill, are a safe and effective way to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex. They are legal nationwide, though they can be easier to access in some states than in others.

headline: Walz Offers Minnesota as a Liberal Escape From Trump
abstract: Speaking in his home state after he and Vice President Kamala Harris lost this week, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota vowed to “stand ready to stand up and fight.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz, Democrat of Minnesota, addressed supporters in his state on Friday, vowing to protect Minnesota from the “most extreme elements” of a second Trump administration.

headline: Shaboozey Has Something New to Toast: 6 Grammy Nominations
abstract: The country singer’s “A Bar Song (Tipsy)” has been omnipresent; now it’s up for song of the year in February.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the songs of the summer that persisted into the fall: ubiquitous in restaurants, grocery stores, coffee shops and, appropriately, bars.

headline: $7 Million Deal Is Reached for Upper West Side Movie Theater
abstract: A nonprofit group has reached an agreement to buy the shuttered Metro Theater from its owners, but the deal is contingent on raising the money by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: A group trying to restore a landmark Upper West Side movie theater says it has signed an agreement to buy the building for $7 million if it can raise the money by the end of the year.

headline: St. Thomas Church Will Outsource Choir School in Bid to Save It
abstract: The Manhattan church said it would turn over administration of its boarding school for choristers, one of only a few of its kind remaining, because of financial woes.
lead_paragraph: St. Thomas Church in Manhattan, which has been grappling with serious financial problems in recent years, said on Friday that it would outsource the administration of its renowned boarding school for choristers in a bid to preserve the 105-year-old program.

headline: Votes in House and Senate Races Are Still Being Tallied. Here’s the Latest.
abstract: Control of the House remains in the balance, and three Senate seats in swing states have yet to be called.
lead_paragraph: Several key congressional races have dragged on long past the end of the presidential contest. The House remains contested, though Republicans have claimed more seats so far, and vote counting continues in three Senate races in swing states.

headline: Voters in Red and Blue States Repudiate Lenient Drug Policies
abstract: Californians voted for tougher penalties for dealers. Florida, North Dakota and South Dakota rejected proposals to legalize marijuana. Massachusetts denied a measure allowing possession of psychedelics.
lead_paragraph: An electorate that has grown increasingly restive over flagrant drug use and public disorder sent a sharp message through the ballot box on Tuesday.

headline: Disillusioned Young Voters Focus on ‘Community’
abstract: Mutual aid, grass-roots organizing and a belief that people need to take care of each other have been popular topics on social media.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, Devon Blow, an illustrator and writer from Los Angeles, posted a quote on Instagram: “I will never surrender myself to hopelessness and despair. As long as I got you, and you got me, we will be free.”

headline: Inside the Federal Work Force That Trump Has Promised to Eviscerate
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies have pledged to strike fear in the heart of what they term “the deep state.” They have already succeeded.
lead_paragraph: The tremors from Donald J. Trump’s decisive electoral victory have hit every corner of Washington. But their maximum intensity is felt by the capital’s federal work force, which comprises tens of thousands of mostly anonymous employees not-so-fondly referred to by Mr. Trump as “the deep state.”

headline: Read the Trump Assassination Plot Criminal Complaint
abstract: The U.S. charged three men with plotting to kill Donald J. Trump on behalf of Iran.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. charged three men with plotting to kill Donald J. Trump on behalf of Iran.

headline: How Media Outlets on the Right and Left Explained Trump’s Win
abstract: Media outlets on the right said Mr. Trump won because of the left’s embrace of what they called extreme political views. Left-leaning outlets offered a broader variety of explanations.
lead_paragraph: Media outlets across the political spectrum offered very different explanations about why Donald J. Trump won the presidential election this week.

headline: Residents Return to Find Homes Reduced to Rubble After California Fire
abstract: The Mountain fire has torn through more than 20,000 acres and destroyed more than 130 structures in Ventura County. “It’s just devastating,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: In the city of Camarillo, Calif., on Old Coach Drive, the smell of smoke lay heavy in the air. The fire that erupted this week had hopscotched around the neighborhood, leaving some homes relatively unscathed but reducing several to charred piles of wood and rubble.

headline: San Francisco Mayor-Elect Plans to Declare Fentanyl Emergency on Day 1
abstract: Daniel Lurie held his first news conference since Mayor London Breed conceded the mayoral race this week.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Lurie is a man in a hurry.

headline: As Trump’s New Term Looms, Hochul Considers Reviving Congestion Pricing
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul, facing pressure from supporters of the contentious tolling plan, is said to be exploring options for adopting it in some form.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York is exploring options for reviving a congestion pricing plan for New York City before President-elect Donald J. Trump has a chance to kill it, according to four people familiar with the matter.

headline: Walz Offers Hope to Minnesota in Concession Speech
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz, the former vice presidential candidate, gave a concession speech in his home state on Friday, in which he vowed to “stand ready to stand up and fight.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz, the former vice presidential candidate, gave a concession speech in his home state on Friday, in which he vowed to “stand ready to stand up and fight.”

headline: Trump Weighs Key Personnel Choices, Schooled by His First-Term Experience
abstract: The president-elect held his first formal transition meetings and has been given lists of candidates, but is calling around to friends and allies for ideas.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump is not known for adherence to a disciplined and rigorous personnel selection process, but behind the scenes his advisers and allies have been preparing lists of candidates for the most important jobs in his administration.

headline: Dorothy Allison, Author of ‘Bastard Out of Carolina,’ Dies at 75
abstract: She wrote lovingly and often hilariously about her harrowing childhood in a working-class Southern family, as well as about the violence and incest she suffered.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy Allison, who wrote with lyrical, pungent wit about her working-class Southern upbringing — and about the incest and violence that shaped her — and whose acclaimed 1992 novel, “Bastard Out of Carolina,” based on her harrowing childhood, made her a literary star, died on Wednesday at her home in Guerneville, Calif., in Sonoma County. She was 75.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 9, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 2 this weekend misstates the title of a song by the band Lankum. It is “Go Dig My Grave” not “I Dig My Grave.”

headline: The Long Global Trail of Resentment Behind Trump’s Resurrection
abstract: Disillusionment with the world that emerged from the Cold War has fueled a long-gathering revolt against the established order.
lead_paragraph: As the Cold War wound down almost four decades ago, a top adviser to the reformist Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, warned the West that “we are going to do the most terrible thing to you. We are going to deprive you of an enemy.”

headline: Democrats Consider an Autopsy, but Who’s the Coroner?
abstract: The Democratic Party agrees it needs to figure out what went wrong. The question is how.
lead_paragraph: After suffering what could shape up to be their biggest electoral defeat in more than 40 years, Democrats agree on one thing: They need to figure out what went wrong.

headline: Spill
abstract: Chandi Deitmer and Hoang-Kim Vu’s Saturday collaboration might make solvers take a tumble or two.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an unusual phenomenon, as there aren’t many themeless collaborations in Times puzzles. It’s also Chandi Deitmer’s Saturday debut, after six winsome Sundays over the last few years. Hoang-Kim Vu, her collaborator on today’s Crossword, has created a handful of weekend themeless grids. I spent three quarters of my solve in a charmed state: What zingy slang! What clever crosses! Then I spent 25 percent in white-knuckled suspense: Am I going to have to peek at this answer key? Is ordering Indian tonight cheating?

headline: Brush Fire in Brooklyn’s Prospect Park Burns 2 Acres
abstract: The fire drew almost 100 firefighters, the commissioner said. The cause was not immediately determined.
lead_paragraph: About 100 firefighters were called to put out a two-acre brush fire in a heavily wooded section of Prospect Park in Brooklyn on Friday night, prompting officials to warn residents to stay away as they used drones to identify hot spots.

headline: Seattle Police Arrest Man in Connection With Five Stabbings
abstract: Five people were injured in attacks in the city’s Chinatown-International District on Friday, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man was arrested in connection to stabbings that injured five people on Friday in Seattle, according to the local authorities.

headline: Quote of the Day: For Harris, Star Endorsements Didn’t Shine as They Used To
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 9, 2024
lead_paragraph: “She couldn’t get the endorsement of the Teamsters, but she got the endorsement of Hollywood. That’s a tough message for a lot of voters.”

headline: Smile, Flatter and Barter: How the World Is Prepping for Trump Part II
abstract: Foreign leaders have rushed to ingratiate themselves with Donald J. Trump in recent days, nervously recalling the clashes, insults and feuds of his first presidency.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Keir Starmer met Donald J. Trump at Trump Tower for dinner on Sept. 26, it was part of a British charm offensive to nurture a relationship between a left-wing leader and a right-wing potential president. So when Mr. Trump turned to Mr. Starmer before parting and told him, “We are friends,” according to a person involved in the evening, it did not go unnoticed.

headline: Jacky Rosen Holds Off Sam Brown in Nevada, Keeping a Democratic Senate Seat
abstract: Ms. Rosen, the low-key incumbent, hung on, but the race was closer than expected amid President-elect Donald J. Trump’s strength.
lead_paragraph: Senator Jacky Rosen, a Democrat, will hang on to her Nevada Senate seat, according to The Associated Press, narrowly defeating her Republican opponent, Sam Brown.

headline: Trump Wins Nevada, Flipping a Battleground State
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory in Nevada was the first for Republicans in a presidential election since 2004.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has won Nevada, according to The Associated Press, flipping a battleground state Republicans had not won since 2004.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Trump’s Deportation Vow Fuels Fear and a Potential Showdown in New York
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has vowed to prevent mass deportations, but migrants and immigration lawyers are preparing for them.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory this week spread fear and panic across New York City’s more than 400,000 undocumented immigrants as they braced for the impact of one of his central campaign promises: a mass deportation program.

headline: How an Off Broadway Drag Show Choreographer Spends His Sundays
abstract: Spencer Liff, who choreographed “Drag: The Musical,” searches for New York’s best Bloody Mary, stops by the theater and tries to find his next great jacket at the flea market.
lead_paragraph: Before Spencer Liff returned to New York this summer to direct and choreograph the Off Broadway show “Drag: The Musical,” he spent 10 years in Los Angeles as a resident choreographer for “So You Think You Can Dance.”

headline: Gazans Are Living Through a Yearlong Blackout
abstract: Israel cut off electricity in the first days of the war, leaving Palestinians to light the dark with cellphones and to cook over open flames.
lead_paragraph: Mariam Abu Amra’s six children panic when the sun goes down.

headline: Is a ‘Green’ Revolution Poisoning India’s Capital?
abstract: India promised to burn its trash mountains and safely turn them into electricity. But a New York Times investigation found hazardous levels of toxic substances around homes, playgrounds and schools.
