lead_paragraph: The trucks have lumbered through the capital for years, dumping loads of hot, acrid ash from thousands of tons of incinerated garbage close to playgrounds and schools.

headline: How Ukraine’s Widows Are Shouldering Their Grief
abstract: It’s impossible to say how many widows the war in Ukraine has created because Kyiv closely guards its casualty figures. But estimates suggest they number in the tens of thousands.
lead_paragraph: As Ukraine’s cemeteries have filled with dead soldiers, a legion of war widows has been growing.

headline: He’s a Rock Critic, and a Swiftie. What’s Wrong With That?
abstract: In “Heartbreak Is the National Anthem,” Rob Sheffield chronicles how Taylor Swift has made fans, foes and even journalists part of her story.
lead_paragraph: It’s possible that I know too much about Taylor Swift. I know the words to all her singles and every name on her long list of ex-lovers. Thanks to her current relationship with Travis Kelce, I know details about the various social entanglements of his Kansas City Chiefs teammates that I would prefer not to. I listen to her music about as much as the median American, which is to say: all of the time. Swift has become America’s Muzak, her songs the soundtrack to our Starbucks lines and her life the fodder for our tabloid stories.

headline: They Were Ashamed About Their Debt. Bankruptcy Gave Them a Second Chance.
abstract: Many people who should consider filing for bankruptcy avoid doing so out of shame or fear it could ruin their credit. But it can provide much-needed relief.
lead_paragraph: In my 20s, while attending law school at New York University by day and concerts by night, I racked up over $30,000 in credit card debt. I wasn’t thinking about my credit score; I was solely living in the moment.

headline: In a Run-Down Movie Theater, She Found a Window on the World
abstract: Esther Kinsky reflects on the nature of seeing in a book about an old cinema in Hungary.
lead_paragraph: “Where in memory is the boundary between images seen and things experienced, as they say, first hand?” This question is the driving force behind “Seeing Further,” the latest book by the German writer and translator Esther Kinsky, whose name is underrecognized among American readers.

headline: A Messy Problem in Orderly Singapore: Keeping Track of Cats
abstract: The reversal of a 35-year ban on cats in public housing won’t be a quick fix for cat-related problems. It’s not even clear how many cats live in the city-state.
lead_paragraph: Xinderella the foster cat has a microchip, a human guardian and a stable home, but she lives in a state of regulatory limbo. Under murky new rules governing cats in Singapore’s public housing, she is not registered to the apartment where she sleeps.

headline: A Full-Body Dumbbell Workout You Can Do Anywhere
abstract: Try this beginner-friendly routine to build strength and improve your stability.
lead_paragraph: The dumbbell is one of the oldest pieces of strength training equipment — and it has endured for good reason. With one dumbbell or a pair, you can build a full-body workout that challenges your balance, stability and coordination.

headline: Need an Arabic-Hebrew Ketubah? This Artist Can Help.
abstract: Josh Berer makes most of his money designing Arabic tattoos. He also has a side business designing cross-cultural marriage contracts.
lead_paragraph: When a couple from Washington, D.C., a Baha’i man and a Jewish woman, married in 2012, they wanted a ketubah, or Jewish decorative marriage contract, that reflected their diverse backgrounds.

headline: Drinking With the Kids
abstract: Years after bath time and travel soccer, we’re mixing cocktails in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Drinking has changed. And nowhere has it changed more than at my house.

headline: She Inherited Her Family’s Mansion, the Site of Secret Traumas
abstract: In “The Magnificent Ruins,” an Indian expatriate reunites with her estranged family after her grandfather unexpectedly made her heir to his estate.
lead_paragraph: There’s an adage about mothers and daughters in Anne Carson’s poem “The Glass Essay”: “You remember too much,/my mother said to me recently./Why hold onto all that? And I said,/Where can I put it down?” Such grief, born from the scars of maternal abuse, is both an accusation and an inheritance hiding inside Nayantara Roy’s debut novel, “The Magnificent Ruins.”

headline: Kaley Cuoco Drifts Off to Episodes of ‘Dateline’
abstract: The actress returns for Season 2 of the dark comedy “Based on a True Story” as the true-crime aficionado Ava.
lead_paragraph: When Kaley Cuoco learned she was pregnant before shooting began on the first season of the dark comedy “Based on a True Story,” her character, Ava — a true-crime aficionado on the trail of a serial killer — was given a quick rewrite and became an expectant mother, too.

headline: This ‘Wall Street Girly’ Wants to Make Wealth More Accessible
abstract: Vivian Tu is one of a new wave of female influencers who are using TikTok and Instagram to spread the message of personal finance to millennials and Generation Z.
lead_paragraph: Back in August, when it looked like the Federal Reserve was about to cut interest rates for the first time in more than four years, Vivian Tu took to TikTok to explain to her roughly 2.6 million followers what that move by the central bank would mean for them.

headline: Is a ‘Green’ Revolution Poisoning India’s Capital?
abstract: An effort to turn India’s trash mountains into energy has become an acute health crisis for a million people in the capital city, New Delhi. Maria Abi-Habib, an investigative correspondent for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: An effort to turn India’s trash mountains into energy has become an acute health crisis for a million people in the capital city, New Delhi. Maria Abi-Habib, an investigative correspondent for The New York Times, explains.

headline: The Lei Makers Reimagining an Ancient Tradition
abstract: A new generation of floral designers is incorporating fresh styles into their creations.
lead_paragraph: When Leilani Pearson, 42, moved to Maui in 2014 with her partner, they inherited his grandparents’ property, along with its 50-year-old gardenia bushes. Sometimes she made necklace leis by stringing the gardenias together using a needle and thread, as is common throughout Hawaii, but often she braided the flowers with lauhala, dried leaves from the hala tree, using techniques more common in Tahiti, where she was born and raised. Before long, she began to incorporate unusual flowers into large, flat, angular leis, setting scarlet lobster claw heliconia or luminescent blue jade vine blossoms or purple-tipped bromeliad flowers in plaits of lauhala.

headline: This Taiwanese Calligrapher Brings a Message of Freedom to the Met
abstract: Tong Yang-Tze is reviving an ancient but disappearing practice and making it contemporary — writ large.
lead_paragraph: The boulders hiding in the alcove of Tong Yang-Tze’s apartment testify to this Taiwanese calligrapher’s daunting perfectionism.

headline: How a Sex-Positive Cuban Lesbian Helped Her Creator Play Herself
abstract: In “Give Me Carmelita Tropicana!,” Alina Troyano and her former student Branden Jacobs-Jenkins explore the ways art made by one person can live inside others.
lead_paragraph: You never can tell where your inheritance will come from, but the playwright Branden Jacobs-Jenkins almost missed out on some of his.

headline: Do Co-op Board Members Have to Live in the Building?
abstract: And what happens if they don’t?
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a large Lower Manhattan cooperative with nine board members. One board member has sold their apartment and moved to another state. A second member is living in a foreign country with his family and subletting his apartment, saying he will eventually return to the complex. Both are still serving on the board of directors. I think their ability to work for the best interests of the cooperative could well be compromised. Is this legitimate? What can we do?

headline: Piecing Life Back Together After Helene, One Mud-Splattered Photo at a Time
abstract: The Mosses’ home washed away during the hurricane, and with it went their photos of a son who had died as a child. They didn’t know a determined detective was on the case.
lead_paragraph: Four days after Tommy and Mary Moss watched their home float down the Swannanoa River, the couple and their son Dallas returned to their neighborhood in Asheville, N.C., to begin searching through the mud-caked debris.

headline: Low-Profile Donor Makes Big Impact on Los Angeles Arts Groups
abstract: With recent major gifts to several cultural institutions, Jarl Mohn is emerging as an important West Coast philanthropist.
lead_paragraph: Cultural institutions in Los Angeles sometimes bemoan the difficulty of cultivating generous donors who will help fund their operations. Over the last few years, the art collector Jarl Mohn, 72, has emerged as an exception.

headline: Are Seed Oils Actually Bad for You?
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and others claim they’re harming our health, but the evidence suggests otherwise.
lead_paragraph: To their many vocal detractors, they’re referred to as “the hateful eight.” Canola oil, corn oil, sunflower oil and other refined oils made from the seeds of certain plants have become lightning rods for wellness influencers — and some politicians.

headline: Was Wallis Simpson Really a Sex-Crazed Spy?
abstract: As Paul French argues in a new biography, the future Duchess of Windsor’s year in China was less lurid — and more interesting — than her critics knew.
lead_paragraph: Much has been written about Wallis Simpson, the American socialite for whose love King Edward VIII abdicated the throne in 1936. Her eccentric and expensive tastes often demanded attention — who can forget her army of pug pillows or the gold-plated bathtub at their French villa? — but she was also derided as quite ordinary. Cecil Beaton once described her hands as “utilitarian-looking.”

headline: Dwight Yoakam, Country Rebel, Has a New Attitude
abstract: At 68, the Nashville outsider is releasing his first album of original material in nearly a decade, inspired by a joyous shift in his personal life.
lead_paragraph: With the sun setting over the vast expanse of Los Angeles, Dwight Yoakam sighed softly as tears rolled down his cheeks. For a moment, the scene played like one of his own portraits of honky-tonk heartache and regret. But sitting in the country star’s 12th-story offices above the Sunset Strip, it became clear that the emotion gripping him was not sadness, but joy.

headline: America’s Split Screen on Abortion
abstract: The abortion rights movement won in many states — even some that voted for Donald Trump. Where does it go from here?
lead_paragraph: In the first few elections after the Supreme Court’s 2022 reversal of Roe v. Wade, the abortion rights movement created reason for hope among its supporters: It won a string of unexpected victories in ballot measures from conservative states like Kansas and Ohio to moderate ones like Michigan.

headline: How We Found the Dangers Threatening Delhi’s ‘Green’ Energy Future
abstract: In the heart of India’s capital, residents blame chronic, debilitating illnesses on an industrial plant burning the city’s garbage and turning it into electricity.
lead_paragraph: We climbed rooftops and set up machines — each the size of a refrigerator — to take samples of the smoke billowing our way.

headline: Elon Musk Is Positioning X Behind the New Trump Presidency
abstract: Since the election, Mr. Musk has used his social media company to talk up how bright the future will be under the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: Since Donald J. Trump won the presidential election, Elon Musk has gone all in on X to promote the incoming administration.

headline: Drop-Off in Democratic Votes Ignites Conspiracy Theories on Left and Right
abstract: There is nothing suspicious about the shift in Democratic fortunes. But partisans from across the spectrum are questioning the results, for different reasons.
lead_paragraph: When President-elect Donald J. Trump was announced the winner of this year’s presidential contest on Wednesday, the vote tallies initially suggested a sharp drop-off of millions of Democratic votes compared with the results in 2020.

headline: Big Tech’s Hotbeds of Employee Activism Quiet After Trump’s Victory
abstract: Eight years ago, workers loudly protested White House policies. This time around, the companies are trying to keep a lid on activism.
lead_paragraph: If any industry could have said its workplaces were politicized, it was tech.

headline: Harris Had a Wall Street-Approved Economic Pitch. It Fell Flat.
abstract: The vice president vacillated on how to talk about the economy, and ended up adopting marginal pro-business tweaks that both corporate and progressive allies agreed made for a muddled message.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris traveled to a locally owned brewery in New Hampshire to talk about helping small businesses — a major plank of her economic platform — she made sure that one group of Americans felt included: millionaires who wanted to keep more of their profits from selling stocks and real estate.

headline: An Earthling Tunes In to a Hidden Universal Message
abstract: Wonderful ideas are available to all of us, says the singer-songwriter Beverly Glenn-Copeland, a terrestrial fellow traveler.

headline: 58 Movies to Watch This Winter: Bob Dylan Biopic, ‘Moana 2’ and More
abstract: From life stories (“A Complete Unknown,” “The Fire Inside”) to animated tales (“Moana 2,” “Mufasa”), these are the films we can’t wait to see this season.
lead_paragraph: ‘EMILIA PÉREZ’ Four actresses — Zoe Saldaña, Karla Sofía Gascón, Selena Gomez and Adriana Paz — shared a prize at Cannes for their performances in this unlikeliest of musicals, about the friendship between a Mexican cartel kingpin (Gascón) and a lawyer (Saldaña) hired to arrange the kingpin’s gender transition. Jacques Audiard directed. (Nov. 13; Netflix)

headline: Biden and Environmental Groups Try to Protect Climate Policies from Trump
abstract: John Podesta, President Biden’s clean energy adviser, said agencies were racing to deliver money from the 2022 climate law before Donald Trump arrives.
lead_paragraph: Biden administration aides are racing to award hundreds of millions of dollars in grants and finalize environmental regulations in an effort to lock in President Biden’s climate agenda before Donald J. Trump enters the White House, said John Podesta, the president’s senior adviser on clean energy.

headline: Trump Has Made His View of Migrants Clear. Will It Stop Them From Coming?
abstract: The incoming president has promised the largest deportation effort in U.S. history. Now migrants are weighing a new Trump administration in deciding whether to trek to the United States.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday was the day that Daniel García, a Venezuelan delivery worker living in the capital of Colombia, had planned to begin an arduous land journey toward the United States.

headline: Trump Holds Up Transition Process Over Ethics Code
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has not submitted a required ethics plan stating he will avoid conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has not yet submitted a legally required ethics pledge stating that he will avoid conflicts of interest and other ethical concerns while in office, raising concerns that his refusal to do so will hamper the smooth transition to power.

headline: Should Alito and Thomas Be Pushed to Retire? Conservatives Are Divided.
abstract: Coaxing aging Supreme Court justices to give up their power and status during a window of political opportunity can be a delicate endeavor.
lead_paragraph: With Republicans set to regain control of the White House and the Senate, the spotlight has turned to the Supreme Court and whether the two oldest justices may step down, paving the way for President-elect Donald J. Trump to lock down a conservative supermajority for years.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Nancy Pelosi’s Interview With The New York Times
abstract: In her first extended interview after the election, the former House speaker was not interested in analyzing Democratic losses and was eager to put a sunny spin on the future.
lead_paragraph: After the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Nancy Pelosi made it known that she would do everything she could to prevent Donald Trump from becoming president again. Pelosi, who was both minority leader and House speaker during Trump’s first term, was reportedly instrumental in persuading President Biden to end his candidacy over the summer. Like most Democrats, she rallied around Kamala Harris and, as late as the night before the election, projected confidence that Harris would win on Tuesday. That didn’t pan out.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Insists the Election Was Not a Rebuke of the Democrats
abstract: The former House Speaker reflects on Donald Trump’s victory, Kamala Harris’s candidacy and the future of the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no Democratic politician has been a greater antagonist to Donald Trump than Nancy Pelosi. As the House minority leader and then speaker of the House during Trump’s first term, she participated in two Trump impeachments, memorably ripped up a copy of Trump’s State of the Union address after he delivered it and was targeted by an angry mob during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6. Pelosi vowed to never allow Trump back in the White House for another term. By all accounts, she was a key voice in persuading Biden to end his campaign this summer and give another Democrat a shot at beating Trump.

headline: Russia Sentences Soldiers Over Killing of Ukrainian Family
abstract: The case, in which two soldiers murdered nine members of a family after breaking into their home, was a rare prosecution over crimes against civilians in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A court in Russia has sentenced two Russian soldiers to life in prison for killing a family of nine after breaking into their home in occupied Ukraine, a rare legal case against atrocities committed by Moscow’s soldiers in the war.

headline: Train Station Suicide Bombing Leaves Dozens Dead or Wounded in Pakistan
abstract: A banned ethnic separatist group in a restive province claimed responsibility for the deadly attack in Quetta, the provincial capital.
lead_paragraph: At least two dozen people were killed and more than 40 others wounded in a suicide bombing at a train station in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta on Saturday morning, officials said.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 518
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Nov. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,240
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Canada Sends Mixed Signals With TikTok Shutdown Order
abstract: The industry minister closed TikTok’s offices in Toronto and Vancouver over security concerns, but Canadians can still download and use the app.
lead_paragraph: This week Canada shut down TikTok — but not in the way that some people had been expecting.

headline: Playing Favorites
abstract: The foods and music and culture that move us most might not be very good, but that doesn’t diminish their power to comfort and delight.
lead_paragraph: Last month, The Times published a list of New York’s 25 best pizza places. Like any good New Yorker, I made sure my favorite pie was on the list, then vowed to find a new favorite. There’s pleasure in having one’s tastes affirmed by the tastemakers. Then there’s the even sweeter satisfaction of liking something no one else has discovered yet — a vanishingly rare experience in the TikTok era, when influencers trumpet their “secret” spots to eager followers and the next thing you know, there’s a line around the block at your neighborhood bakery.

headline: U.N.-Backed Panel Warns Action Needed in Days to Avert Gaza Famine
abstract: The warning focused on the north comes as the Biden administration has set a mid-November deadline for Israel to deliver more humanitarian supplies to the enclave or face a cutoff of weapons aid.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations-backed panel has warned that famine is imminent in the northern Gaza Strip, days before a deadline imposed on Israel by the Biden administration to deliver more humanitarian supplies to the enclave or risk a cutoff of military aid.

headline: Amsterdam Bars Protests After Antisemitic Attacks on Soccer Fans
abstract: The violence erupted around a soccer match between Israeli and Dutch teams in Amsterdam on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Amsterdam banned demonstrations over the weekend under an emergency order and mobilized additional police officers after what city officials described as antisemitic attacks on Israeli soccer fans during the week.

headline: The Book That Predicted the 2024 Election
abstract: The G.O.P. pollster Patrick Ruffini’s book “Party of the People” outlined the realignments reflected in this year’s election results.
lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: A.I. Companions and the Mental Health Risks for the Young
abstract: Readers discuss an article about a teenager’s suicide.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Maybe Now Democrats Will Address Working-Class Pain
abstract: Democrats can compete if they focus more on minimum wages and child care than pronouns and purity.
lead_paragraph: The other day I was supposed to visit a friend who had been released from prison. He had to cancel to rescue his sister, who is using drugs again.

headline: Scenes From America on the Edge, Partying and Despairing
abstract: Election night and the day after, 2024.
lead_paragraph: The election results came a lot faster than most people expected. On Tuesday it was just voting and waiting and anxiety and an inner sense that anything was possible and then by Wednesday morning, one answer: Donald Trump had shifted the country toward him in a decisive win.

headline: This Is All Biden’s Fault
abstract: Biden too often could not find the best way to help Democrats win.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris lost the election this week, but I mostly don’t blame her. At least, I don’t blame her because of anything she did recently. Since she became the unofficial nominee in July, she played a difficult hand about as well as she could have, running a disciplined campaign that sought to reassure Americans about the economic issues that trouble them most, in a political environment that was very rough for Democrats and for incumbent parties around the world.

headline: The Elites Had It Coming
abstract: Democrats got exactly what they set out to get, and now here we are.
lead_paragraph: Everyone has a moment when he first realized that Donald Trump might well return, and here is mine. It was back in March, during a visit to the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery, when I happened to read the explanatory text beside an old painting. This note described the westward advance of the United States in the 19th century as “settler colonialism.” I read it, and I knew instantly where this nation was going.

headline: Trump Is About to Face the Choice That Dooms Many Presidencies
abstract: Electoral success has a thousand fathers, each with his own agenda.
lead_paragraph: As happens every time a new president is elected, Donald Trump is experiencing a sudden role reversal. His campaign to earn support from voters has ended abruptly and a new one has begun among donors and activists to earn his support for their priorities. The election was about tax cuts, or maybe cryptocurrency, the arguments go. What Americans really want, sir, is fewer protections on the job and a weaker safety net.

headline: Democrats and the Case of Mistaken Identity Politics
abstract: The post mortem is a wake for woke.
lead_paragraph: Some Democrats are finally waking up and realizing that woke is broke.

headline: Could the Bond Market Stymie Trump’s Economic Plans?
abstract: Some fiscal hawks worry that Trump’s policies would increase the deficit and fuel inflation.
lead_paragraph: With Republicans poised to seize control of Congress, Donald Trump’s economic plans could face little legislative resistance. The president-elect has vowed to escalate tariffs, extend a corporate tax cut and introduce tax breaks on tips and Social Security benefits, policies that some fiscal hawks worry would increase the federal deficit, and with it, inflation.

headline: A Banker Is Scouting Trump’s Nominees. Some Will Oversee His Interests.
abstract: Howard Lutnick, co-chair of the president-elect’s transition team and a Wall Street financier, is leading the search for appointees while still running his businesses.
lead_paragraph: The financier Howard Lutnick has been given a high-profile assignment from President-elect Donald J. Trump, one that raises questions about the Wall Street executive’s dual role and what he might gain from it.

headline: Bacon Defeats Vargas in Nebraska, Holding a Key House Seat for Republicans
abstract: The victory of the four-term Republican, who has resisted his party’s veer to the right, dashed Democratic hopes of flipping a critical district.
lead_paragraph: Representative Don Bacon of Nebraska, one of the most politically vulnerable Republicans in the country, has defeated his Democratic challenger and won a fifth term, according to The Associated Press. His victory denies Democrats one of their best opportunities this year to pick up a seat and bolsters his party’s drive to hold its majority.

headline: Weeds Are Everywhere. Why Aren’t We Eating Them More?
abstract: Fast-growing and prolific, these plants are the next frontier in foraging.
lead_paragraph: Copenhagen’s Noma restaurant may have introduced foraging into fine dining, but the concept was hardly a new one: Every culture has its own tradition of gathering wild ingredients, from bamboo shoots in Bhutan to lingonberries in Sweden to gemsbok beans in the Kalahari Desert.

headline: Easy Hand-Pulled Noodles (With Video!)
abstract: This wonderfully doable recipe from Vivian Chan-Tam is a fun bit of kitchen craft time.
lead_paragraph: I’m a pretty fidgety person — apologies to everyone seated in front of me on planes whom I’ve accidentally bumped — so for me, a cooking project is just as much about the finished dish as it is all the handiwork that goes into it. I love folding dumplings, caramelizing onions, wrapping enchiladas, massaging kimchi, rolling meatballs. This “keep my hands busy” philosophy is the same reason I got into knitting. But you can’t eat a sweater, even if it’s knit in brioche stitch.

headline: At Least Two Dozen People Killed in Suicide Bombing in Pakistan
abstract: The Baloch Liberation Army, a banned ethnic separatist group, claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred at a railway station in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta.
lead_paragraph: The Baloch Liberation Army, a banned ethnic separatist group, claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred at a railway station in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta.

headline: Biden and Trump to Meet at White House on Wednesday
abstract: President Biden extended the invitation to his former rival as part of a longstanding tradition to help ease the transition to a new administration.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will host President-elect Donald J. Trump at the White House on Wednesday, extending a presidential tradition to his onetime rival that Mr. Trump did not offer four years ago after Mr. Biden defeated him.

headline: What Do Trump Voters Know About the Future He Has Planned for Them?
abstract: Be careful what you wish for, Part 99.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Donald Trump became the first Republican in 20 years to win the national popular vote and the Electoral College.

headline: Overlooked No More: Go-won-go Mohawk, Trailblazing Indigenous Actress
abstract: In the 1880s, the only roles for Indigenous performers were laden with negative stereotypes. So Mohawk decided to write her own narratives.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Qatar Pauses Role as Mediator in Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, Citing Deadlock
abstract: The Qatari Foreign Ministry announced it had stepped back from talks, saying it would resume once Israel and Hamas “show willingness and seriousness.”
lead_paragraph: Qatar, a key mediator between Israel and Hamas, announced on Saturday night that it had paused its efforts to broker a cease-fire between the two sides to end the war in Gaza, citing the deadlock in talks.

headline: Kenneth Bronstein, Who Put His Faith in Atheism, Dies at 85
abstract: The organization that he led advocated the separation of church and state, with no exceptions for holidays, currency, symbolism or blessings.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Bronstein recalled the first meeting of NYC Atheists that he organized. “It was sad,” he told The Washington Post in 2004. “Ten guys in a room, all arguing with each other.”

headline: FEMA Fires Employee for Telling Milton Relief Workers to Skip Houses With Trump Signs
abstract: The agency said it was investigating the incident in the aftermath of the Category 3 hurricane that hit Florida in October.
lead_paragraph: An employee with the Federal Emergency Management Agency has been fired after reports that in the aftermath of Hurricane Milton, the employee told relief workers in Florida to pass over houses with signs supporting Donald J. Trump, the agency said Saturday.

headline: Government Moves to Thwart Guilty Plea Proceedings in Sept. 11 Case
abstract: Prosecutors plan to appeal the trial judge’s ruling that the defense secretary had not lawfully rescinded the government plea deal with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed.
lead_paragraph: War court prosecutors are asking a military judge to refrain from taking guilty pleas from Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks, and from two men accused of conspiring with him until a higher court decides the validity of their plea agreements.

headline: Trevor Sorbie, Known for the Dorothy Hamill ‘Wedge’ Cut, Dies at 75
abstract: He also styled hair for Helen Mirren, the Beach Boys and others, and he was honored by Queen Elizabeth II for services to British hairdressing.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Sorbie, a celebrity hairstylist who is widely credited with creating the “wedge” cut made popular by the figure skater Dorothy Hamill, and whose scrunch drying method became widely used in the 1980s, died on Friday at his home in Fareham, England. He was 75.

headline: Smoky Smell Engulfs New York City After Fires in Brooklyn and New Jersey
abstract: New Yorkers encountered an unsettling smell on Saturday, a day after fires broke out in Prospect Park and across the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: The smell of acrid smoke spread throughout New York City on Saturday and persisted into the evening, after brush fires broke out on Friday in Brooklyn, the Bronx and nearby New Jersey. It was a surreal experience for a city that is rarely home to wildfires but is in the middle of a drought.

headline: Tony Todd, Prolific Actor Best Known for ‘Candyman,’ Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Todd’s decades-long career spanned across mediums and genres, but he was largely associated with a scary figure summoned in front of a mirror.
lead_paragraph: Tony Todd, a prolific actor whose more than 100 film and television credits included the horror movie franchises “Candyman,” in which he played the vicious title character, and “Final Destination,” died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 69.

headline: Baltazar Ushca, Who Kept Andean Ice Harvesting Alive, Dies at 80
abstract: He trekked up Ecuador’s tallest mountain twice a week for six decades to hack ice off a glacier with a pickax. He is believed to have been the last of his breed.
lead_paragraph: For 60 years, Baltazar Ushca worked a rare but rigorous trade: ice merchant. Once or twice a week, he climbed snow-capped Mount Chimborazo, Ecuador’s highest peak, to hack ice from a glacier with a pickax, wrap the 60-pound blocks in hay and transport them on the backs of his donkeys. He would then sell them to villagers who did not have electricity and needed refrigeration to conserve their food.

headline: From Start to Finish
abstract: Sam Ezersky’s Sunday puzzle flips the script.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: At Women’s March Event, Organizers Say They Are Preparing a ‘Comeback Tour’
abstract: At a demonstration on Saturday, the crowd was small and enthusiasm was lacking. But organizers are planning a big march ahead of the inauguration.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, after former President Donald J. Trump’s re-election dashed progressives’ hopes of a new era for women’s rights and other left-wing causes, Women’s March held a hastily arranged protest-cum-dance party outside the headquarters of a conservative think tank in Washington. Only about a few hundred people showed up.

headline: Judith Jamison, Alvin Ailey Dancer of ‘Power and Radiance,’ Dies at 81
abstract: She became an international star as a member of the company and later directed it, guiding it out of debt and boosting its popularity.
lead_paragraph: Judith Jamison, who became an international star with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, first as a majestic dancer and then as the troupe’s director, building it into the most successful modern dance company in the country, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 81.

headline: Two Militia Founders Are Convicted of Plot to Kill Federal Agents
abstract: “We were going out huntin’,” one of the men said in a video before a planned trip to the Mexico border, where they intended to shoot at immigrants and officials who might stop them, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Two founders of a militia group who were plotting a trip to the U.S.-Mexico border to shoot at immigrants and the authorities who might try to stop them were convicted on Thursday by a federal jury in Missouri of attempting to murder federal agents, prosecutors said.

headline: Trump Should Not Let Putin Claim Victory in Ukraine, Says NATO Official
abstract: Adm. Rob Bauer warned against any peace deal that was too favorable to Russia, arguing that it could undermine American interests.
lead_paragraph: A senior NATO military official suggested on Saturday that any peace deal negotiated by President-elect Donald J. Trump that allowed President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to claim victory in Ukraine would undermine the interests of the United States.

headline: Firefighters Gain More Control of Southern California Blaze That Spread Rapidly
abstract: After the Mountain fire ballooned to more than 20,000 acres in less than 24 hours, improving weather conditions helped crews contain more of the blaze on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Calming winds helped firefighters gain the upper hand on Saturday against the Mountain fire in Southern California, after three days of pitched battle using dozens of aircraft, hundreds of fire trucks and legions of firefighters on foot wielding saws and shovels.

headline: Trump Won’t Have Haley or Pompeo in New Administration
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump ruled out roles for Nikki Haley and Mike Pompeo, who served in his previous administration.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Saturday that he would not invite Nikki Haley, his former ambassador to the United Nations, or Mike Pompeo, his former secretary of state, to join his incoming administration.

headline: Bobby Allison, Hall of Fame NASCAR Driver, Is Dead at 86
abstract: A three-time winner of the Daytona 500, he was ranked as one of NASCAR’s greatest drivers, with 85 victories. But his career was darkened by tragedy and injuries.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Allison, the NASCAR Hall of Fame driver who won 85 top-level events and became one of stock-car racing’s most popular figures while enduring family tragedy and career-ending injuries, died on Saturday at his home in Mooresville, N.C. He was 86.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 10, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 2 this weekend misstates the title of a song by the band Lankum. It is “Go Dig My Grave” not “I Dig My Grave.”

headline: Donald Trump Wins Arizona, Reversing the State’s Blue Trend
abstract: The victory added to the list of battleground states that Mr. Trump lost in 2020 and flipped back four years later.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has won Arizona and its 11 electoral votes, The Associated Press said on Saturday night, flipping yet another swing state and bringing his final Electoral College tally to 312. With his victory in Arizona, Mr. Trump has now won all seven of this year’s battleground states.

headline: TSMC Stops Advanced Chip Shipments to Chinese Customers
abstract: The Taiwanese chip giant will halt shipments to Chinese companies after some of its most advanced chips ended up with Huawei.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the maker of most of the world’s cutting-edge computer chips, discovered last month that one of its chips had ended up precisely where policymakers in the United States did not want it: in a processor made by Huawei.

headline: Taiwan Sees a Higher Price for U.S. Support as Trump Returns to Power
abstract: The president-elect’s call for Taiwan to spend more on its own defense and his complaints about its semiconductor dominance may herald a tenser relationship.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Taiwan’s president called Donald J. Trump to congratulate him after he won the presidential election. Mr. Trump took the call, becoming the first American president or president-elect to speak to a Taiwanese leader in decades.

headline: Once China’s ‘Worst Nightmare,’ Labor Activist Refuses to Back Down
abstract: Neither jail nor exile to Hong Kong has stopped Han Dongfang, a former Tiananmen Square protest leader, from championing workers’ rights. “If you’re born stubborn, you go everywhere stubborn.”
lead_paragraph: Han Dongfang was just another dot in a sea of agitated university students during the mass protests in Tiananmen Square 35 years ago when he suddenly jumped onto a monument to speak.

headline: Light in the Shadow of a Diagnosis
abstract: We are lost without human connection.
lead_paragraph: The doctor said that untreated, I could be dead in months.

headline: A Sex Strike Is a Losing Strategy for American Women
abstract: The philosophy is shortsighted and insufficient for our times.
lead_paragraph: No dating men, no sex with men, no heterosexual marriage and no childbirth. These are the four principles of South Korea’s 4B movement, a radical feminist movement that gained popularity in 2019, in response to sexism, hidden camera pornography and intimate partner violence. After Donald Trump’s victory, some American women have sought out the movement. But it would be a mistake for women in the United States to adopt its principles, which risk alienating those who would be our allies while ensuring little actually changes about our reality.

headline: New York State Parks Worker Dies While Fighting Wildfire
abstract: The blaze in Orange County, N.Y., was the latest in a series of wildfires to plague the region.
lead_paragraph: Officials said an 18-year-old employee of the New York State parks system died on Saturday while battling a wildfire in Orange County, one of several blazes in the New York metro area to break out recently amid drought conditions.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Cast Makes Its Case to Stay off Trump’s Enemies List
abstract: The show parodied its own history of mawkish self-seriousness in an episode that often avoided the topic of the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: A serious development in current events can sometimes leave “Saturday Night Live” unable to make any satirical comment on it, and that was briefly how it appeared the show might react to the re-election this week of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Spectator to a Team Celebrating Pride
abstract: In 2019, a gay couple bought an English rugby team, and the community immediately embraced them. Rory Smith witnessed the unexpected camaraderie.
lead_paragraph: My job title at The New York Times is, on reflection, probably a touch too grand. Officially, I’m a global sports correspondent, but that’s not the sort of title you can mention to people and expect them not to assume you’re boasting. “Correspondent” sounds serious. “Sports” sounds fun. “Global” probably involves hotels.

headline: She Was a Child Instagram Influencer. Her Fans Were Grown Men.
abstract: “Jacky Dejo” was introduced to social media by her parents as a snowboarding prodigy. Now 18, she has seen the dark side of the internet — and turned a profit from it.
lead_paragraph: For her 18th birthday in March, “Jacky Dejo,” a snowboarder, bikini model and child influencer turned social media entrepreneur, celebrated on the secluded island of Dominica.

headline: When Anna Wintour Let Marc Jacobs Do Her Job
abstract: Vogue has its first guest editor. Just call it “The December Issue.”
lead_paragraph: It was late spring, and Anna Wintour, the notoriously decisive editor of Vogue, was stymied. That is not a common state for her. But the presidential election had her in a bind, at least when it came to her December issue. She had to make a magazine in one reality and publish it in another. What to do?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: From Teen Star to Entrepreneur
abstract: Emma Chamberlain has a coffee company, a podcast and a new eyewear collaboration. One thing she isn’t doing much? Posting to YouTube.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday afternoon, Emma Chamberlain passed a tow yard during a photo shoot in Beverly Hills. She walked by a row of dented sedans and sat on the step of a tow truck, her platinum mullet glowing white in the sun.

headline: How Can I Manage a ‘Challenging’ Employee?
abstract: Health issues are affecting a worker’s performance. But is the real problem her supervisor’s handling of the situation?
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: ‘I Can Still Recall One Subway Ride I Took After Moving to New York’
abstract: A trip with an unusual passenger, voices from a Brooklyn past and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: What a Trump Presidency Might Mean for Mayor Adams’s Criminal Case
abstract: Would Donald J. Trump come to the aid of Mayor Eric Adams of New York, an embattled Democrat indicted on federal corruption charges?
lead_paragraph: The United States of America v. Eric Adams was the first criminal indictment of a sitting mayor in the modern history of New York City. But the re-election of Donald J. Trump has invited questions about whether Mr. Adams might appeal to Mr. Trump for help in his federal corruption case — and whether Mr. Trump might entertain providing it.

headline: Hochul, in Unwanted Position, Says She Is Ready to Work With Trump
abstract: While other big state Democrats are reviving the resistance, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York says she is open to working with Donald J. Trump where possible.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York found herself in a situation she had hoped would never come to pass: on the phone congratulating Donald J. Trump, the Republican president-elect.

headline: Quote of the Day: A Child Influencer Whose Avid Fans Were Men
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I honestly didn’t know that it was so bad. I don’t see anything attractive in a 13-year-old girl in a bikini, but apparently others do.”

headline: Unions on Strike and a Newspaper on Pause
abstract: The New York Times and the unions representing its workers have had a handful of labor disputes, including one that left the city without The Times for 114 days.
lead_paragraph: The strike against The New York Times by the Times Tech Guild, which began Nov. 4, is the latest in a century’s worth of sporadic labor troubles between the newspaper and the unions representing its workers.

headline: A Heady History of the Novel Embraces Works That Shock, Not Soothe
abstract: In “Stranger Than Fiction,” Edwin Frank maps a path from Dostoyevsky to Sebald, finding mystical power and surprising ties among 20th-century writers.
lead_paragraph: Is the novel in mortal peril, or remarkably resilient?

headline: A Real Estate Queen and the Secret She Couldn’t Keep Hidden
abstract: Alice Mason was New York City’s broker to the elite and a master at the art of hosting. One fete would alter her legacy and strain her relationship with her daughter.
lead_paragraph: Alice Mason was throwing one of her black-tie dinner parties. For years, she’d been hosting events that New York City’s social pages fawned over, but she didn’t expect that this one would disrupt a secret she’d kept for much of her life.

headline: Joan Didion and Eve Babitz: Contemporaries, Peers, Rivals — and Soul Mates?
abstract: In a dual biography, the journalist Lili Anolik casts the two writers as opposite sides of the same ambitious, 1960s-Hollywood coin.
lead_paragraph: The writers Joan Didion and Eve Babitz were both ambitious California natives, moved in similar circles in Hollywood in the 1960s and ’70s and died within days of each other, in December 2021. In “Didion & Babitz,” the journalist Lili Anolik casts them as opposite sides of the same coin: “two halves of American womanhood, representing forces that are, on the surface, in conflict yet secretly aligned — the superego and the id, Thanatos and Eros, yang and yin.” For all they had in common, the book never quite paints them as the “secret twins” and “soul mates” the author would like us to think they are.

headline: Calling All Misfits: When Greenwich Village Conquered the Music Scene
abstract: In his latest book, the Rolling Stone writer David Browne tracks three decades of folk, blues, rock and jazz below 14th Street.
lead_paragraph: In March 1961, Newbold Morris, New York City’s recently appointed parks commissioner, wrote in a memo that he had been “shocked” by what he saw and heard on a Sunday visit to Washington Square Park, in the heart of Greenwich Village. The park had long been a weekly gathering place for folk singers, and permits for those gatherings had long been routinely granted. But Morris expressed concern about “these fellows that come from miles away to display the most terrible costumes, haircuts, etc., and who play bongo drums and other weird instruments attracting a weird public.”

headline: How Tech Created a ‘Recipe for Loneliness’
abstract: Technology and loneliness are interlinked, researchers have found, stoked by the ways we interact with social media, text messaging and binge-watching.
lead_paragraph: Over the summer, Laura Marciano, a researcher at Harvard, interviewed 500 teenagers for a continuing study investigating the link between technology and loneliness. The results were striking.

headline: He Made a Daring Escape From China. Then His Real Troubles Began.
abstract: He fled brutal repression — only to discover, as so many Uyghur refugees have, that China’s power stretches far beyond its borders.
lead_paragraph: When Hasan Imam was a child, living on his parents’ farm, he would sometimes hide inside a haystack. The farm was scattered across a few acres of a small village. Behind the family house was a cowshed and, next to it, a hay barn. Inside the barn, each haystack was identical to its neighbor, and in the stack farthest from the door his father had arranged some bedding. It was invisible unless you went looking for it.

headline: To Help Fund Stadium, Bills Fans Buy Bonds ‘With an Attitude’
abstract: Critics of using public money to build sports facilities dismissed the bond sale, but some of the team’s devoted followers eagerly paid in.
lead_paragraph: Bill Fitzgibbons grew up a Bills fan south of Buffalo in the 1970s, but left the area 37 years ago to sell agricultural machinery up and down the East Coast. Despite living in New Hampshire, Pennsylvania and now outside Atlanta, he has remained loyal to the Bills and what they mean to western New York.

headline: For Older Unmarried Couples, Caregiving Obligations Can Be Murky
abstract: What should be expected of an intimate partner when a companion suffers a health crisis? Seniors and their families increasingly confront the question.
lead_paragraph: They’ve been an unmarried couple for almost 20 years. Both widowed, and now in their 90s, they maintain separate residences in Florida but mostly live together in her home — an increasingly important issue because, a few years ago, she began developing memory loss.

headline: Still Freddy After All These Years
abstract: With the release of “A Nightmare on Elm Street” 40 years ago, the horror villain Freddy Krueger clawed his way to becoming a pop culture phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: When “A Nightmare on Elm Street” hit theaters 40 years ago this month, few would have predicted a pop culture phenomenon in the making. Yet it would become one of 1984’s most profitable pictures and spur a lucrative franchise.

headline: Palestinians Try to Sway Trump, Reaching Out to Tiffany Trump’s Relative
abstract: The Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas has met with Tiffany Trump’s father-in-law and written conciliatory letters to the president-elect, a strong supporter of Israel.
lead_paragraph: He met with the father-in-law of Donald J. Trump’s daughter Tiffany. He wrote a letter to Mr. Trump condemning the assassination attempt against him. And he quickly congratulated Mr. Trump on his presidential victory.

headline: Missing in Europe: A Strong Leader for a New Trump Era
abstract: Internal political squabbles — and the fallout from a global backlash to inflation, immigration and ruling elites — are hobbling Germany and France.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s return to the U.S. presidency could spell a lonely and dangerous stretch for Europe, which is already mired in economic stagnation and rattled by war on its eastern doorstep. It is a moment that European leaders agree demands renewed and forceful leadership from the continent’s two largest economies.

headline: Immigration Lawyers Prepare to Battle Trump in Court Again
abstract: Nearly eight years after the first challenges to his immigration policies, Donald Trump is returning to the White House promising a more aggressive crackdown.
lead_paragraph: It was just days into his first term when President Trump issued an order banning the entry of people from several predominantly Muslim countries. An SOS went out to immigration lawyers across New York to head to Kennedy Airport, where arriving passengers were already being detained.

headline: The White House Will Be Shedding Its Union Label
abstract: After gains by organized labor under President Biden, a second Trump administration is likely to change course on regulation and enforcement.
lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. promised to be the most pro-labor president in history. He embraced unions more overtly than his predecessors in either party, and filled his administration with union supporters.

headline: Unions Bet Big on Harris. Now They’re Bracing for Consequences.
abstract: Government unions, service worker unions and industrial unions all face possible repercussions from Donald Trump’s victory, but not necessarily all the same kind.
lead_paragraph: Besides the Harris campaign and its affiliated political action committees, few economic or political sectors placed larger bets than organized labor on Vice President Kamala Harris’s winning the presidency.

headline: Was Martha Stewart Really the Original Influencer?
abstract: The new Netflix documentary “Martha” examines the homemaking diva’s illustrious, and complicated, career and personal life.
lead_paragraph: “Martha,” a new documentary now on Netflix, offers a candid portrait of the rise and fall (and rebirth?) of the homemaker extraordinaire, who last year, at 81, appeared on the cover of Sports Illustrated.

headline: 50,000 Russian and North Korean Troops Mass Ahead of Attack, U.S. Says
abstract: Ukrainian officials expect a counteroffensive in western Russia to begin in the coming days as North Korea’s troops train with Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: The Russian military has assembled a force of 50,000 soldiers, including North Korean troops, as it prepares to begin an assault aimed at reclaiming territory seized by Ukraine in the Kursk region of Russia, according to U.S. and Ukrainian officials.

headline: Israeli Strike Kills 23 People North of Beirut, Lebanon Says
abstract: The strike in the Jbeil district of Lebanon came amid an apparent diplomatic push for a cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli strike on a village north of Beirut killed at least 23 people and wounded six others on Sunday, Lebanon’s health ministry said, amid what appeared to be a new diplomatic push for a potential cease-fire there between Israel and Hezbollah.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,241
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: I Refuse to Cede My Love of Fitness to the Far Right
abstract: Wellness should be just a hobby.
lead_paragraph: During a short career in tech, I quickly realized I did not like my job. Rather than confront what this meant for my future, I decided to channel my energy into how much weight I could lift.

headline: Israel Keeps Attacking Journalists. When Will the U.S. Intervene?
abstract: Dozens of journalists have been killed as a result of the Israeli military in Gaza. The Biden administration is not doing enough to stop it.
lead_paragraph: Hunted.

headline: When Did Liberals Become So Comfortable With War?
abstract: If liberals won’t discuss the devastating human costs of war, who will?
lead_paragraph: “Give war a chance,” the maverick strategist Edward Luttwak implored at the tail end of the Clinton administration. The quest for durable peace, he thought, was habitually interrupted by those liberal do-gooders who refused to let wars “burn themselves out.”

headline: The Connections Companion No. 519
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Nov. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Why Shakespeare Remains Relevant Today
abstract: Readers discuss the production of the Bard’s plays today. Also: Elderly and physically active; investing in youth to reduce crime; political corruption.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why We Turn to Crosswords in Times of Crisis
abstract: When life gets tough, we tackle grids for good reason. They offer a singular combination of erudition and escape.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 18, 1941, shortly after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Lester Markel, the Sunday editor of The New York Times, sent a memo to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, the paper’s publisher. In light of the bleak blackout hours to come, he argued, it was time to add a feature that The Times had resisted for nearly three decades: a crossword puzzle.

headline: There Were Two Huge Problems Harris Could Not Escape
abstract: The curling theory of campaigns proves itself again.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Isgur, a longtime Republican campaign operative — and my friend and a senior editor at The Dispatch — has a brilliant sports analogy for the process of campaigning. She compares it to … curling.

headline: The Democratic Blind Spot That Wrecked 2024
abstract: Maybe it would have been better if the red wave had crashed ashore in 2022.
lead_paragraph: The 2022 election went better than Democrats could have hoped. The party picked up governor’s mansions and state legislatures and expanded their Senate majority. It held down losses in the House. The promised red wave never crashed ashore. Perhaps it would have been better if it had.

headline: Russia Says It Shot Down Waves of Drones Above Moscow
abstract: Officials said more than 30 drones had been intercepted over suburban areas of the Russian capital in what was the biggest such attack since the invasion of Ukraine in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Russia said its air defenses had shot down waves of Ukrainian drones over Moscow’s suburbs on Sunday morning, responding to what it called a “massive” attack that wounded at least one person and temporarily halted flights at three regional airports.

headline: Revisiting the Harlem Renaissance
abstract: Why the era still resonates a century later.
lead_paragraph: I’m a Brooklyn girl, but I’m low-key obsessed with the Harlem Renaissance. I’ve written a book about the era and taught its literature at universities. I can, and often do, spend whole weekends rereading Langston Hughes and Zora Neale Hurston, listening to Louis Armstrong and Duke Ellington, thumbing through books featuring artwork by Aaron Douglas and Augusta Savage.

headline: Israeli Strike in Gaza Kills Over 30 Palestinians, Emergency Services Say
abstract: The strike hit a house in the city of Jabaliya, which has repeatedly come under attack as the Israeli military has pressed an offensive in northern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military struck a house in northern Gaza where displaced families were sheltering on Sunday, killing at least 34 people, according to the Palestinian Civil Defense, the main emergency service in the territory.

headline: ‘This Is the Best of the Best’
abstract: Marcella Hazan’s Bolognese sauce, tomato-rich and smoothed with milk, remains a reader favorite.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. When Marcella Hazan, the self-taught Italian cook who showed Americans a new way to cook Italian food, died in 2013, my colleagues on the Food desk of The Times published what we refer to in the office as a “call-out” — a request to readers that they share their answers to a particular question. In this case, we wanted to know which of Hazan’s recipes was their favorite.

headline: Maps: Strong Quakes Strike Near Cuba
abstract: View the location of the epicenters and shake areas.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the epicenters and shake areas.

headline: Reimagining How to Dress a Pope
abstract: In the film “Conclave,” the costume designer Lisy Christl clothed an army of catty cardinals, from their miters down to their quirky glasses.
lead_paragraph: Set in Vatican City, Edward Berger’s new movie, “Conclave,” is ostensibly about a clique of catty cardinals jockeying to become the next pope.

headline: Paul Stephenson, 87, Dies; Advanced Britain’s Civil Rights Movement
abstract: The bus boycott and one-man pub sit-in that he led in the mid-1960s helped pave the way for a law outlawing discrimination in public places.
lead_paragraph: Paul Stephenson, a British civil rights activist who led a boycott of city buses in Bristol, England, in 1963 that helped usher in the nation’s first Race Relations Act, outlawing discrimination in public places, died on Nov. 2. He was 87.

headline: ‘Change the Game’: Saudi Arabia Takes a Stride Into Women’s Tennis
abstract: The kingdom, which has been accused of trying to “sportswash” its human rights record, hosted the WTA Finals, part of its unstoppable advance into the world of sports.
lead_paragraph: The sellout crowd was bathed in purple light and the screens ringing the stadium flashed a countdown to a clubby beat. The latest conquest in Saudi Arabia’s unstoppable advance into the world of sports — soccer, golf, boxing, car racing, now tennis — was about to begin. The Women’s Tennis Association Finals had come to Riyadh.

headline: What Is Paul Taylor Without Paul Taylor? Full of Bumps.
abstract: The Taylor company returns to Lincoln Center with four premieres and a new resident choreographer: Robert Battle, the former director of Alvin Ailey.
lead_paragraph: The Paul Taylor Dance Company is running on the theme of expansion this season. It has a bigger new building in Midtown; its repertory is growing with new dances and there is even a new resident choreographer.

headline: After the Triumph of Tetris, an Unsolved Puzzle
abstract: Alexey Pajitnov, who created the ubiquitous game in 1984, opens up about his failed projects and his desire to design another hit.
lead_paragraph: Alexey Pajitnov, the architect of the falling-and-rotating-block puzzle game Tetris, is one of the industry’s most illustrious designers. The calming and chaotic formula he developed as a computer engineer in the Soviet Union has resulted in dozens of variants — Tetris Plus, Tetris Worlds, Tetris Effect, Tetris 99 — and more than 520 million sales.

headline: Wildfires Spread Across Northeastern U.S. Amid Drought
abstract: Firefighters in New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Connecticut battled hundreds of blazes during an unseasonably dry fall.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters in New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Connecticut battled hundreds of blazes during an unseasonably dry fall.

headline: As Trump Returns to Power, Allies and Adversaries Expect a Wave of Revenge
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s momentary talk of unity on election night may underestimate the depth of his resentment after multiple impeachments, investigations, indictments and lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: On the night he recaptured the presidency, Donald J. Trump declared that “it’s time to unite” and “put the divisions of the past four years behind us.” That was then. It took only 55 hours for him to begin threatening again to use his newly reclaimed power to investigate those who anger him.

headline: 2 New York Men Charged in Monthslong Plot to Kill Iranian Activist
abstract: The men were receiving orders from a third man, who was working as an Iranian operative and was also involved in a plot to assassinate Donald J. Trump, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: On an evening in February when the Brooklyn human-rights activist Masih Alinejad was scheduled to speak at Fairfield University, in Connecticut, two men from New York visited the campus. They had been sent there as part of an Iran-backed plot to murder her, federal prosecutors said last week.

headline: As Wildfire Burns in New Jersey and New York, Rain Offers Little Relief
abstract: The fire, the latest of several in the region over the weekend, had caused one death and was not contained as of Sunday afternoon, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters in New Jersey and New York were working on Sunday to contain the latest of several recent wildfires in the region, where the first forecast rainfall in weeks was expected to bring little relief to areas experiencing drought conditions.

headline: Monday Briefing: Russian and North Korean Troops Assemble
abstract: Plus, does tech make us feel lonely?
lead_paragraph: The Russian military has assembled a force of 50,000 soldiers, including North Korean troops, as it prepares to begin an assault aimed at reclaiming territory seized by Ukraine in the Kursk region of Russia, according to U.S. and Ukrainian officials.

headline: Haitian Prime Minister Is Fired, Adding to the Nation’s Turmoil
abstract: As killings and hunger soar in Haiti, a political power struggle has cost the prime minister his job, another setback for a country plagued by gang violence.
lead_paragraph: The former United Nations official tapped to lead Haiti through a gang-fueled crisis has been fired by the country’s ruling council, following a political power struggle that unfolded amid a wave of kidnappings and killings.

headline: 25 Escaped Monkeys of 43 Are Captured in South Carolina
abstract: The monkeys escaped after a worker at a research center left an enclosure unlocked. One monkey was captured Saturday, and another 24 on Sunday, while the rest remain at large.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five of 43 monkeys that escaped an enclosure at a South Carolina research center were captured on Saturday and Sunday while the rest remain at large, officials said.

headline: Ella Jenkins, Musician Who Found an Audience in Children, Dies at 100
abstract: Performing and recording, she transformed what was seen as a marginal genre in the music industry into a celebration of shared humanity.
lead_paragraph: Ella Jenkins, a self-taught musician who defied her industry’s norms by recording and performing solely for children, and in doing so transformed a marginal and moralistic genre into a celebration of a diverse yet common humanity with songs like “You’ll Sing a Song and I’ll Sing a Song,” died on Saturday in Chicago. She was 100.

headline: Senators Vying to Be G.O.P. Leader Vow to Quickly Confirm Trump Nominees
abstract: Senators Rick Scott, John Thune and John Cornyn quickly responded to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s demand on social media, the latest example of his influence over Republican lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: Senators vying to become the next leader of the Republican conference pledged on Sunday to quickly push through President-elect Donald J. Trump’s appointees after he demanded on social media that they do so.

headline: Painter’s Propper-Upper
abstract: Patrick Gramza and John Kugelman make their collaboration debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Bruce Degen, Who Drew ‘The Magic School Bus,’ Dies at 79
abstract: He memorably portrayed a frizzy-haired science teacher roping her elementary school class into adventures aboard a shape-shifting yellow bus.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Degen, the illustrator of “The Magic School Bus” series of children’s books, which gained a reputation as the clearest and most charming science texts available for elementary school students and have been read by tens of millions of children worldwide, died on Thursday at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 79.

headline: Man Arrested in Shooting That Killed One at Tuskegee University
abstract: The shooting, which also wounded 12 people, happened early on Sunday as crowds gathered at the historically Black school to celebrate the final day of its 100th homecoming week.
lead_paragraph: A 25-year-old man was charged in connection with a shooting on the campus of Tuskegee University in Alabama early Sunday morning that left one person dead and a dozen others wounded as crowds gathered for the school’s homecoming celebration, the authorities said.

headline: Chaos, Provocations and Violence: How Attacks on Israeli Soccer Fans Unfolded
abstract: Antisemitic assaults on visiting Israeli soccer fans, and incendiary chants and attacks by some Israelis: Here’s what we know so far about the violence in Amsterdam last week.
lead_paragraph: Early Thursday morning, taxi drivers gathered en masse outside Amsterdam’s Holland Casino. Hours before, Israeli soccer fans had stolen and burned a Palestinian flag, while others attacked a cab — and the drivers, the police said, were heeding an online call to “mobilize.”

headline: This Is the Cake We Baked
abstract: Talking to people who helped make Donald Trump’s victory happen, and others.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Military Judge Postpones Guilty Plea Proceedings in Sept. 11 Case
abstract: The judge asked defense and prosecution lawyers to settle on a date for the accused mastermind of the terrorist attacks to plead guilty.
lead_paragraph: A military judge on Sunday postponed a hearing to receive the guilty plea of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks, so that prosecutors can seek again to nullify the plea deal.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 11, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Trump’s Return Hangs Over U.N. Climate Negotiations
abstract: The election of Donald J. Trump is sapping momentum from global climate talks as diplomats brace for his pro-fossil-fuel agenda.
lead_paragraph: World leaders gathering in Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, on Monday for a global climate summit face a bleak reality: The United States, the country responsible for pumping the most greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, is expected to soon drop out of the fight against climate change.

headline: Why Is a Petrostate Holding This Year’s Climate Talks?
abstract: The economy of Azerbaijan, host of COP29, relies almost entirely on the fossil fuels that are the main driver of global warming.
lead_paragraph: Heading into this month’s United Nations-sponsored climate negotiations, the world is contending with rising climate chaos and declining democracy.

headline: Quote of the Day: These A.I. Glasses Tell All at a Glance, and Bring Up Thorny Issues
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This is the kind of technology that could be incredibly useful and incredibly destructive.”

headline: Will Trump Rekindle a Bromance With Kim Jong-un? South Koreans Worry.
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s second term brings uncertainty to the Korean Peninsula as nuclear tensions run high. North Korea’s leader may see a chance to re-engage.
lead_paragraph: During his 2024 election campaign, Donald J. Trump described the United States’ alliance with South Korea as a terrible bargain for his country, accusing the Asian ally of not paying enough ​for the 28,500 ​American troops ​stationed on its soil.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: What Trump means for the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: As president, Donald Trump was a staunch supporter of Israel, recognizing Jerusalem as its capital, cutting off aid to the U.N. agency that supports Palestinian refugees and presenting a peace plan that favored Israel. Yet he has also publicly called for the war in Gaza to stop, saying in April, “Israel has to be very careful, because you’re losing a lot of the world.”

headline: Why Did Tens of Thousands of Chinese Students Go on Night Bike Rides?
abstract: Making the impromptu five-hour ride between two Chinese cities became a craze among young people. But as their numbers swelled, the authorities shut it down.
lead_paragraph: The students would emerge on their bikes, in the tens of thousands, seemingly out of nowhere. Like a flash mob on wheels, they rode for hours in the night, by the light of streetlamps, sometimes bursting into verses of the Chinese national anthem. Some carried Chinese flags.

headline: The Quiet Development Shaking America’s Power
abstract: The United States can no longer depend on the loyalty of its friends.
lead_paragraph: With the stunning comeback of Donald Trump as president, America’s allies are scrambling. Behind their sober messages of congratulation is a palpable anxiety that Washington will soon treat them as mere pawns on the global chessboard. It would be quite a change. Under President Biden’s leadership, the United States — sharpening its rivalry with China and seeking to counter Russia’s invasion of Ukraine — put great store in strengthening its alliances and partnerships.

headline: ‘Dune: Prophecy,’ Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV this Week
abstract: Tune into the premiere of the HBO series, see whom Joan Vassos picks for her final rose on “The Bachelorette” and catch up on news.
lead_paragraph: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are available to watch live or stream this week, Nov. 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Trump Names Thomas Homan ‘Border Czar’ With a Wide Portfolio
abstract: Mr. Homan, a senior immigration official in the last Trump administration, has said that workplace raids would restart under the new government.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said late Sunday that he had named Thomas D. Homan, a senior immigration official in his last administration, as the “border czar” in charge of the nation’s borders and its maritime and aviation security.

headline: Mattel Mistakenly Lists Porn Site on Packaging for ‘Wicked’ Dolls
abstract: The site has a similar address to one that promotes a film adaptation of the hit musical. The toymaker apologized for the “unfortunate error.”
lead_paragraph: All may be good in the Land of Oz, but the same can’t be said for the world of Mattel.

headline: He’s Eric Adams’s Third N.Y.P.D. Boss. Does He Have Staying Power?
abstract: Thomas Donlon wants the job of police commissioner permanently, and he’s been acting as though he has it as he navigates friction and uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams’s decision to appoint Thomas Donlon, a 71-year-old former F.B.I. investigator, as New York’s interim police commissioner seemed to bring a sense of stability to a department rocked by several federal inquiries. It didn’t last long.

headline: Trump’s Gains Among Latinos Push a Civil Rights Group to Reflect on Its Past
abstract: From its founding nearly a century ago, LULAC encouraged Hispanic people to embrace American identity even as it fought discrimination. The 2024 election result presents a dilemma on both fronts.
lead_paragraph: On a cold and rainy Sunday in February 1929, a group of Latino men in dapper suits and boater hats gathered in a convention hall in Corpus Christi, Texas, to forge a new Latino civil rights group.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How Trump Divides Chinese Who Aspire to Democracy
abstract: A new HBO documentary about opposition to autocrats says a lot about the complex politics the president-elect inspires for people fleeing countries.
lead_paragraph: The long and loud campaign of Donald J. Trump, and now his re-election as president, have prompted deep divisions among many Chinese who advocate for democracy.

headline: After Trump’s Victory, Mayoral Candidates Unite Against Adams and Cuomo
abstract: Unseating Eric Adams as mayor of New York was a hot topic at a political gathering in Puerto Rico, as Democrats reflected on the impact of Donald J. Trump’s win.
lead_paragraph: At beachfront hotel bars, tropical pool parties and crowded ballroom dance floors, a pressing matter closer to home inevitably arose: How would New York City navigate four years of Donald J. Trump as president, and who might be the best mayor to lead that effort?

headline: Who Has the Best View of the Chrysler Building? These Bees.
abstract: On and around some of New York City’s most iconic buildings, beehives are buzzing.
lead_paragraph: At many corporate offices in Manhattan, the level of activity remains well below its prepandemic levels. But on and around some of New York City’s most iconic buildings, beehives are buzzing seven days a week.

headline: Shigeru Ishiba Wins Vote to Remain as Japan’s Prime Minister
abstract: Parliament voted Monday to stick with Mr. Ishiba, who will lead a minority government after his party suffered heavy losses in an election last month.
lead_paragraph: Despite leading his party to big losses in a snap general election last month, Shigeru Ishiba, the prime minister of Japan, won a vote in Parliament on Monday to carry on as the country’s leader.

headline: Throngs of Cyclists Ride for Hours Between Two Chinese Cities
abstract: They were making the 40-mile journey from Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan Province, to the neighboring city of Kaifeng, a cycling trip that can take up to five hours one-way.
lead_paragraph: They were making the 40-mile journey from Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan Province, to the neighboring city of Kaifeng, a cycling trip that can take up to five hours one-way.

headline: Women Get Less Exercise Than Men. It’s a Problem.
abstract: Experts say the fitness gender gap is because women have less time to work out, and that their health is paying the price.
lead_paragraph: After a full Saturday shuttling her two kids to soccer and play-dates across Manhattan, Neha Ruch, 39, finally carved out a few precious minutes to exercise at 6:15 p.m. She didn’t even bother to change clothes before hopping onto her elliptical machine in a closet-turned-home-gym.

headline: The Unspoken Grief of Never Becoming a Grandparent
abstract: A growing number of Americans are choosing not to have children. Their parents are grappling with what that means for them.
lead_paragraph: Lydia Birk, 56, has held on to her favorite copy of “The Velveteen Rabbit” since her three children — now in their 20s and 30s — were young.

headline: Why Are Cities Still Spending Big on Convention Centers?
abstract: Cities are spending more than ever to land the biggest events, but companies have long pulled back on spending for annual conferences and attendance has dwindled.
lead_paragraph: Are sprawling convention centers worth the money cities need to spend on them?

headline: Fewer Crowds, Bargain Prices: ‘Quiet Season’ Cruising in the Mediterranean
abstract: Overtourism and summer heat have increased the allure of off-season travel in Europe, and the cruise industry is taking note with more winter itineraries. Added bonus: cheaper fares.
lead_paragraph: After a summer of overtourism in cruise ports like Barcelona and Amsterdam, and talk of caps on ship arrivals in Greece and other places, the cruise industry has come up with a surprising suggestion for where to sail in winter: Europe.

headline: I Gave My Son the Books I Loved. He Chose ‘Heidi’ Instead.
abstract: What a 19th-century Swiss novel, and a young fan’s pilgrimage to the Alps, taught me about fatherhood.
lead_paragraph: I went to the Alps in August because my son — a New York City third grader obsessed with baseball, projectiles and YouTube — fell in love this summer with the Swiss children’s novel “Heidi.”

headline: Alcohol Brands Tap the Art World to Woo Younger Drinkers
abstract: Will labels and bottles designed by artists gin up enthusiasm among an increasingly abstinent generation?
