headline: In New York, Reporting on Four Fires in Four Days
abstract: Anything is on the table for a general assignment reporter in New York. Still, a series of brush fires in the city and a big blaze upstate were far from expected.
lead_paragraph: The view was hazy, the hulking trees barely visible through the smoke. A campfire-like smell was wafting through the air vents of my car. Helicopters whirred overhead as they drew water from a lake.

headline: Quote of the Day: Wildfire Risk Only Growing For Northeast
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 21, 2024
lead_paragraph: “Wildland fire wasn’t supposed to be a year-round career.”

headline: Israel and Iran Seemed on the Brink of a Bigger War. What’s Holding Them Back?
abstract: So far, direct attacks between the two adversaries have been precise and calculated. Whether that lasts is another question.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly a month since Israel sent more than 100 jets and drones to strike Iranian military bases, and the world is still waiting to see how Iran will respond.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans voted to block the release of an Ethics Committee report about allegations of sexual misconduct and illicit drug use against Matt Gaetz, President-elect Donald Trump’s choice for attorney general, setting up a possible constitutional clash between the House and the Senate.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Proper Pringle Consumption
abstract: Saddle edges up? Or down?
lead_paragraph: Pete writes: My wife thinks there’s a correct way to eat a Pringle. She says you get more of the salt and flavor if you hold it a certain way. I don’t know which way she thinks is right, but I know she corrects me if I eat them “wrong.”

headline: Duct-Taped Banana Sells for $6.2 Million
abstract: The conceptual artwork, “Comedian,” by the noted prankster Maurizio Cattelan was auctioned at Sotheby’s on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The conceptual artwork, “Comedian,” by the noted prankster Maurizio Cattelan was auctioned at Sotheby’s on Wednesday.

abstract: This word has appeared in 74 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

headline: How High School Graduates Can Improve Their Earnings Potential
abstract: New research shows that 73 “launchpad jobs” can help those without a four-year college degree advance and achieve higher pay.
lead_paragraph: For decades, economic mobility in America has been declining. And those most likely to be left behind are workers without four-year college degrees.

headline: Desi Lydic Says Trump is ‘Picking Mascots,’ Not Leaders
abstract: “The Daily Show” host said Trump could do worse than an “actual doctor” like Dr. Oz to lead the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services: “I’m impressed he didn’t pick Dr Pepper.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Priest, the Power Broker and the Pop Star
abstract: Msgr. Jamie J. Gigantiello is in hot water with his diocese. Prosecutors are looking into his dealings with the New York City mayor’s top adviser. It all started with Sabrina Carpenter.
lead_paragraph: Just a few days after Mayor Eric Adams was indicted on corruption charges, the pop star Sabrina Carpenter stood onstage at Madison Square Garden and said something startling into her glittery microphone: “Should we talk about how I got the mayor indicted?”

headline: Brooklyn Needs Housing. She Has a Vacant Lot. Why Can’t She Build?
abstract: A property owner’s effort to develop an apartment building in a popular neighborhood has been stymied for years. She may just give up.
lead_paragraph: This is The Housing Crunch, a five-part series on New York City’s affordable housing crisis.

headline: Anthony Weiner’s Latest Redemption Tour Starts With a Haircut
abstract: The disgraced New York politician is considering a run for City Council. But even in an era of political comebacks, this might be pushing it.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Weiner walked in mostly unnoticed, quickly taking his place in a barber’s chair, an unlikely prop on his latest reclamation tour.

headline: Figures and Shoulders
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Read the Verdict in the Civil Case Against Amber Guyger
abstract: The jury’s verdict and award of damages against Amber Guyger, who is serving a 10-year sentence for the killing of Botham Jean.
lead_paragraph: The jury’s verdict and award of damages against Amber Guyger, who is serving a 10-year sentence for the killing of Botham Jean.

headline: North Korea Sent Troops to Russia. Russia Is Sending It Bears.
abstract: Vladimir Putin also presented a lion to Pyongyang Zoo, one of the more than 70 animals he sent as an emblem of the deepening friendship between the two nations.
lead_paragraph: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un’s decision to send troops to join Russia in support of its war against Ukraine has led experts to speculate as to what Russian President Vladimir V. Putin might send him in return.

headline: Climate Talks Teeter, With Rich and Poor Countries in a Tug of War
abstract: Western countries are confronting demands for trillions of dollars to fight climate change and to cope with its worsening effects.
lead_paragraph: A two-week marathon of climate talks has entered its grueling final dash. Developed and developing nations were still deadlocked over how many hundreds of billions of dollars wealthy countries should invest to help speed the global transition to cleaner energy and protect the most vulnerable countries against the drumbeat of catastrophes that accompany global warming.

headline: Jury Awards Nearly $100 Million to Family of Texas Man Killed by Police Officer
abstract: A jury in federal court concluded that a white police officer used excessive force and violated the constitutional rights of Botham Shem Jean, a Black man, in 2018.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury on Wednesday awarded nearly $100 million to the family of Botham Shem Jean, a Black man who was eating ice cream and watching television at home in Dallas when he was shot dead by a white police officer six years ago.

headline: Glory Edim Is ‘Patiently Waiting’ for Maya Rudolph to Write a Memoir
abstract: Her own is called “Gather Me: A Memoir in Praise of the Books That Saved Me,” which follows anthologies that grew out of founding the Well-Read Black Girl book club.
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: How Good Is Your Mobility?
abstract: We lose a little range of movement as we age. Here are seven ways to test yours.
lead_paragraph: In your 20s, bending down to tie your shoes or reaching back to grab your wallet feels effortless. As you age, your body’s soft tissues, especially the joints, become more rigid and can make daily tasks much more difficult.

headline: To Quit Their Jobs, Sugar Workers Risk Kidnapping, Assault and Murder
abstract: Why would anyone stay in a job where abuse is rampant and women are coerced into hysterectomies? Because the cost of escaping India’s cane fields is often even higher.
lead_paragraph: When his daughter turned 12, Gighe Dutta decided this would be the year that he and his wife quit cutting sugar cane in the fields of western India. The work required a long migration, and his daughter would have to drop out of school — the first step for many girls on a lifelong path of abuse and poverty.

headline: Republicans Target Social Sciences to Curb Ideas They Don’t Like
abstract: Conservatives in Florida have moved from explosive politics to subtler tactics to uproot liberal “indoctrination” in higher education by removing subjects like sociology from core requirements.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, to attract more students, Jean Muteba Rahier spiced up the name of his introduction to the anthropology of religion course. He called it Myth, Ritual and Mysticism.

headline: This Thanksgiving Appetizer Gives You Dinner and a Show
abstract: Bhel puri is more than just a popular Indian puffed-rice snack. Assembled in a bowl as guests watch, it makes for a captivating performance.
lead_paragraph: Every great host has a party trick, that ingenious move that will always dazzle guests. Mine is bhel puri.

headline: The Secret Lives – and Conflicting Values – of Hulu’s ‘Mormon Wives’
abstract: Our critics on the streamer’s most watched unscripted premiere of the year.
lead_paragraph: Hulu’s hit reality series “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives” follows young mothers in Utah who make TikTok videos together in a clique they call “MomTok.” The show has been renewed for a second season.

headline: In Praise of Adele and the Long Black Dress
abstract: As the artist brings her Las Vegas residency to an end, she leaves behind a major fashion legacy. Just call her Madame A.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, Adele’s Las Vegas residency comes to an end and with it what may have been the most striking series of LBDs since Audrey Hepburn stepped out of a cab in “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” wearing Givenchy. Those initials don’t just stand for little black dress anymore.

headline: How a BFF of Basquiat Is Cracking the Code of the Art World
abstract: Ouattara Watts stayed under the radar for decades. He’s back at Karma Gallery in New York and at the Currier Museum of Art, where he shares a stage with Jean-Michel.
lead_paragraph: The artist Ouattara Watts usually enters his studio in the Bushwick neighborhood of Brooklyn under the blanket of the night. He has often worked between 9 p.m. and 8 a.m. for most of his five-decade career. It is in the relative quiet of these hours that Watts says he can most clearly hear frequencies otherwise muted by the daytime buzz: those of otherworldly and occult elements that appear in his paintings.

headline: ‘We Tire Very Quickly of Being Told That Everything Is on Fire’
abstract: Why invoking a public health crisis too often can lead society astray.
lead_paragraph: The best and worst developments in public health have always come from moments of crisis.

headline: Egon Schiele’s Hidden Obsessions Laid Bare
abstract: The Austrian Expressionist’s portraits and erotically charged nudes have masked another side of his career: his eccentric landscapes.
lead_paragraph: Egon Schiele, the widely celebrated Austrian Expressionist, had one of the shortest-ever careers in art. He was only 28 when he died in the flu pandemic of 1918, and his premature death bolstered his image as a symbol of over-the-top Viennese intensity. He is known mainly for drawings of nudes and semi-nudes that can be unnervingly explicit, and he often appears in his own work. With his stand-up hair, skinny body and long, skeletal fingers, he could pass for a contemporary of ours, a proto-punk figure who would seem at home on the Lower East Side.

headline: After Channeling Rob Gronkowski on TV, He’s Taking On ‘Travis Kelce’
abstract: The actor Laith Wallschleger was playing college football a decade ago. Now he’s playing some of the best tight ends in N.F.L. history.
lead_paragraph: Before his current career as a stuntman, voice-over artist and actor, Laith Wallschleger was a defensive end at the University of Delaware. That college football experience came in especially handy this year, when Wallschleger portrayed onscreen versions of the tight ends Rob Gronkowksi and Travis Kelce, who have seven Super Bowl rings between them.

headline: Canada Fears Trump’s Mass Deportations Will Push Migrants North
abstract: The Canadian authorities are preparing for a possible spike in undocumented migrants, just as Trump appointees complain about too many people arriving from Canada.
lead_paragraph: At 5,525 miles, it is the longest border between any two countries. And that border — separating the United States and Canada — seems set to become a flashpoint between the close allies as President-elect Donald J. Trump prepares to take power.

headline: The Mobility Workout
abstract: Six exercises to keep you moving well as you age.
lead_paragraph: Have a stiff neck? Sore wrists? Struggle to pick things off the ground?

headline: Help! I Was Denied Boarding While Pregnant.
abstract: The policy of La Compagnie, which was not posted online, required a doctor’s note for anyone more than 28 weeks pregnant. A last-minute midwife’s letter would not do.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of July 19, six members of my family were set to fly La Compagnie, a French business-class-only airline, from Newark Liberty International Airport to Nice, France, for a long-planned trip that included the Paris Olympics. When my husband and I arrived at the airport, the other four had already gone through security. The La Compagnie agent congratulated me on my (obvious) pregnancy and asked how far along I was. I answered truthfully: 28 weeks and a day. She said I needed a letter from my doctor saying I was OK to fly. But every doctor and midwife I had spoken to about the trip reassured me it was safe, including the midwife I saw the day before at my 28-week checkup. Even though she was attending someone else’s labor that evening, she managed to send a letter, first through a patient portal and then via email directly to La Compagnie, along with her provider identifier number and, when the staff insisted, a photo of her hospital ID. But even after I did everything they asked, the agent told me the crew had determined I could not board. The La Compagnie desk was closing for the night, and the agent gave me a number to call to rebook. But with no guarantee I would be able to fly, even if there were seats available in the coming days, we booked a flight for the next evening on Air France for about $6,560 each — a steep increase from our $3,530 La Compagnie tickets. La Compagnie offered to return the original $3,530 each, but I believe they were wrong to deny us boarding and should compensate us for the cost of the last-minute flight instead. Can you help? Emma, Brooklyn, N.Y.

headline: ‘A Photographic Memory’ Review: The Imperfect Past
abstract: A daughter hunts for the mother she never knew in an extraordinary, elegiac documentary.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Elizabeth Seed’s mother died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage when Rachel was 18 months old. Sheila Turner Seed was only 42. In “A Photographic Memory,” the daughter, now grown, searches for the mother. But her yearslong journey reaches far beyond personal narrative, blooming into a moving meditation on memory, interpretation and the nature of photography itself. For Rachel, it is both elegy and rebirth.

headline: ‘The Piano Lesson’ Review: Ghosts in the Instrument
abstract: This film adaptation of August Wilson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play falters in some specifics, but is still vital viewing.
lead_paragraph: Riddle me this: When is a piano not merely a piano? Answer: In “The Piano Lesson,” where one piano contains a whole world.

headline: ‘Wicked’ Review: We’re Off to See the Witches
abstract: Cynthia Erivo is the strongest draw in this splashy, overly long movie, which is the first installment in a two-part adaptation of the Broadway show.
lead_paragraph: With its flying monkeys and magical shoes, oh my, the story of the Wizard of Oz has been lodged in the popular imagination for over a century. It is, after all, an archetypal American myth: an epic of good and evil, the comfort (and dreariness) of home, the draw (and freedom) of the road, the perils of power and the yearning for transformation. The 1939 film with Judy Garland, in particular, is so embedded in the American cinematic DNA that it’s inspired everyone from Martin Scorsese to David Lynch, Spike Lee and John Waters, who once called (accurately!) the wicked witch “every bad little boy’s and girl’s dream of notoriety and style.”

headline: Francesca D’Uva Works It All Out Onstage
abstract: With a solo show about grief and life, the comedian and composer brings her experimental musical comedy to an Off Broadway audience.
lead_paragraph: Francesca D’Uva moved across the rehearsal room, singing and dancing, making the space her playground.

headline: John Singer Sargent Painted Them. London Society Talked.
abstract: Jean Strouse’s brisk, wise “Family Romance” takes on the painter’s relationship to the Wertheimers, a vast Jewish clan he immortalized on canvas.
lead_paragraph: When London’s National Gallery exhibited nine portraits by John Singer Sargent in 1923, a magazine ran a cartoon of Rembrandt, Velázquez and other greats welcoming him. “Well done,” they say. “You’re the first master to break the rule and get in here alive.”

headline: Why Mexico Isn’t Panicking About Another Trump Presidency
abstract: Mexico is banking on its ability to negotiate with a deal maker like Donald J. Trump, and many officials say the country is better prepared and has more leverage than it did during his first term.
lead_paragraph: On his path to the presidency, President-elect Donald J. Trump consistently made Mexico a target. He threatened extreme tariffs on the country’s exports to the United States and vowed to carry out mass deportations. He even challenged Mexican sovereignty by proposing military strikes against drug cartels there.

headline: 36 Hours in Tucson, Ariz.
abstract: Stargaze from desert observatories, try traditional Sonoran spirits and hit the local trails in Arizona’s mountain-ringed second city.
lead_paragraph: Stargaze from desert observatories, try traditional Sonoran spirits and hit the local trails in Arizona’s mountain-ringed second city.

headline: What is Debt Bondage? And How Does It Lead to Coerced Hysterectomies in India?
abstract: Our correspondent explains how an exploitative labor system has produced a system of brutality in the country’s sugar fields.
lead_paragraph: My colleagues and I have spent months investigating the sugar industry in the western Indian state of Maharashtra. We’ve documented illegal underage marriage, brutal working conditions and a pattern of women being coerced into unnecessary hysterectomies.

headline: What ‘Mass Deportation’ Actually Means
abstract: How big will the Trump administration go, and how quickly?
lead_paragraph: If you didn’t think they were serious before, you certainly ought to know better now.

headline: 5 Ways to Talk to Your Teen About What They Watch Online
abstract: These conversation starters can get the discussion flowing about A.I., YouTubers and unsettling content.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers are consuming digital media more than ever before, spending an average of nearly two hours per day on YouTube and 1.5 hours per day on TikTok alone. And that doesn’t sit right with some of their parents. About half of teens who report spending a lot of time online say that they argue with their parents about it, according to a Pew Research Center survey conducted last year.

headline: Rain, Finally. But We Need a Lot More.
abstract: As New York contends with a drought, residents are likely to welcome today’s expected downpour.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at whether today will be the day when rain eases the drought. We’ll also get details on a 20th-anniversary retrospective of “The Gates,” the art installation that fluttered and flapped in Central Park.

headline: Bathing in Oil at a Climate Summit? It Leaves a Stain.
abstract: In Azerbaijan, site of the COP29 climate talks and a petrostate, people aren’t only proud of their oil. They swear by its health benefits and visit resorts to soak in it.
lead_paragraph: I bathed in oil during the U.N. climate summit.

headline: What Democrats Think Went Wrong
abstract: A political autopsy. A focus group. A return to Herndon family hospitality.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Astead took “The Run-Up” listeners home for Thanksgiving.

headline: Maira Kalman Does Have Regrets, Actually
abstract: In a collection of mini essays, poems and painted vignettes, the artist and writer reckons with remorse and joy.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody’s saying, ‘Well, what do you mean by remorse?’” said the artist Maira Kalman, whose latest book, “Still Life With Remorse,” is a meditation in words and pictures on the nature of remorse, memory and family lore.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Turtle Bay, Hell’s Kitchen and Greenpoint.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, two-bath, roughly 1,408-square-foot apartment on Beekman Place with an open floor plan, granite countertops and a breakfast bar on the first level, and a large bedroom and full bath on the second level, in a 13-story doorman co-op building with a resident manager, basement storage cages, a bike room, shared laundry and a patio. Pamela Marcus, Phil Wells and Savannah Likitsakos, Corcoran Group, 917-993-4137; corcoran.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Norwalk, Conn., and a four-bedroom in Irvington, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath, 2,123-square-foot home from 1923, with hardwood floors and arched doorways, an enclosed side entryway, a combined living and dining room with an original fireplace, a charming sunroom, an eat-in kitchen with an island and French doors to a patio, a butler’s pantry with a wet bar, a powder room, an en suite primary bedroom with a skylight, an office, and an attached two-car garage, on 0.29 acres. Phil Crosland, 917-714-2755, Nancy Crosland, 203-216-3110, William Pitt Sotheby’s International; williampitt.com

headline: Where Are the Most Million-Dollar Homes?
abstract: While many metropolitan areas have homes valued at $1 million or more, California is leading the pack.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. median home sale price is up 5.2 percent from last October, to about $435,000, according to Redfin. But prices vary widely by location, with the median home value in a couple of metro areas topping $1 million, according to a recent study from LendingTree.

headline: Sex and Horror and the End of the World, in November’s Graphic Novels
abstract: This month’s offerings include a collection of warped horror stories, an apocalyptic flood narrative and a hero doing battle with a super-being who sees humankind as a race of pests to eliminate.
lead_paragraph: WORLD WITHIN THE WORLD (Fantagraphics, 320 pp., $39.99) is both a collection of Gfrörer’s short works since 2010 and a sort of wide-ranging, loosely arranged survey of Western storytelling from cave paintings to the present day, including the NBC sitcom “Frasier.” Her taste in types of trauma and dismay is just as catholic — think of this book as the Norton Anthology of Violence.

headline: How Concerned Should We Be About the Dangers of Nuclear War?
abstract: Last month, the 2024 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to a collective of Japanese atomic bomb survivors. What can we learn from their stories and their efforts to rid the world of nuclear weapons?
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 6 and 9, 1945, American B-29 bombers dropped two atomic weapons on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

headline: Democrats, It’s Time to Say Goodbye to Our Neoliberal Era
abstract: The Democratic Party can seize defeat to establish a new order, but the era of tinkering around the edges is over.
lead_paragraph: In the months ahead, Democratic Party officials and operatives will analyze election returns and voting patterns to try to make sense of what happened on Election Day. There will be a push to identify problems that can be easily solved by the same campaign experts who have allowed one of the least popular politicians of our time to dominate politics for three consecutive elections and rewrite the political order in a way we haven’t seen since the Goldwater movement laid the groundwork for Ronald Reagan’s presidency.

headline: Is She Playing Games, or Simply Excelling in a Male Field?
abstract: In a series of tongue-in-cheek TikTok videos purporting to highlight #WomenInMaleFields, female users are sharing stories of negative experiences dating men.
lead_paragraph: What do you call a woman who breaks up with a man and then takes a flight to see her ex-boyfriend from two years ago the very next day? What about one who asks a man what he’s looking for in a girlfriend but has zero intention of actually meeting those standards?

headline: Dr. Oz, Fox Hosts and a Star of ‘The Real World’ Join Trump’s Season 2 Cast
abstract: The president-elect is rounding out his second administration with television stars.
lead_paragraph: After an election where podcasts and influencers played an outsize role, conservatives were quick to declare that traditional media was dead.

headline: Should Olaf Scholz Step Aside in the New Race for German Chancellor?
abstract: Increasing numbers in his own center-left party say he should, arguing for a more charismatic leader who might better their electoral chances.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, as he prepared to give one of the most important speeches of his political career, Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany appeared before Parliament in a suit that appeared at least a size or two too large.

headline: She Took Her $300,000 Budget to the Washington, D.C., Area. Could She Afford Something in the City?
abstract: Excited to start a new government job, a young first-time buyer considered starter apartments inside and outside the Beltway. Here’s what she found.
lead_paragraph: Excited to start a new government job, a young first-time buyer considered starter apartments inside and outside the Beltway. Here’s what she found.

headline: The Greatest Cancel Culture Warrior in America Is Donald Trump
abstract: Sure, the left can be nuts, but have you looked at the right lately?
lead_paragraph: There is something I want to get off my chest.

headline: How an Empty Internet Gave Us Tradwives and Trump
abstract: Trump excelled at tapping into the information ecosystems where minority and young voters express their identity.
lead_paragraph: Everyone is in a tizzy.

headline: Israel Strikes Near Beirut as U.S. Envoy Pushes Ahead on Cease-Fire Talks
abstract: The envoy, Amos Hochstein, was in Israel and planned to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, seeking a truce in the country’s war with the militant group Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Israel resumed its bombing campaign on Thursday in the Hezbollah-controlled area south of Beirut, as a top U.S. envoy visited Israel to talk to officials there and try to nail down the terms of a cease-fire between the two warring sides.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,252
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 530
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Nov. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Gaetz Ethics Report Blocked, and the Trial That’s Horrified France
abstract: Plus, a $6.2 million piece of fruit.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Murder of Laken Riley
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has repeatedly cited the case in his push for the mass deportation of millions of undocumented people.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains graphic descriptions of violence and death.

headline: Trump’s Tariffs
abstract: We explore his promise to impose a charge on foreign products entering the U.S.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump calls tariffs “the most beautiful word in the dictionary.” He has talked about them again and again as a fix for America’s economic relationship with the rest of the world.

headline: Deaths of at Least 5 Tourists in Laos Raise Alarm About Tainted Drinks
abstract: Travelers from the United States, Britain, Australia and Denmark have died in the Southeast Asian nation in recent days. Officials warned of poisoning caused by alcoholic drinks containing methanol.
lead_paragraph: At least five people traveling in Laos, including an American, have died in recent days as officials in Australia and New Zealand said there has likely been an outbreak of methanol poisoning in that country caused by tainted alcoholic drinks.

headline: ‘The Black Sea’ Review: Bulgarian Dreams
abstract: In this quietly sweet indie, a Black Brooklynite finds himself stranded in a Bulgarian seaside town, where he finds unlikely redemption.
lead_paragraph: “They have dreams in Bulgaria?” Khalid asks a man, hiding from the downpour, in “The Black Sea.” One might say they do: “Like the American dream, but in Bulgarian way,” the stranger responds. In a sense, it’s what Khalid (Derrick B. Harden) has unwittingly found as he tidies up in the cafe he’s cobbled together in a small seaside Bulgarian town.

headline: ‘Bread & Roses’ Review: A Spirit of Resistance
abstract: Three Afghan women struggle for rights in Sahra Mani’s documentary of life under Taliban rule today.
lead_paragraph: When the Taliban regained control of Afghanistan three years ago, one of the group’s first orders of business was to systematically erase women’s rights. Girls’ schools shuttered, women were barred from public spaces and female professionals were told not to return to work.

headline: ‘Ernest Cole: Lost and Found’ Review: Chronicling Apartheid and Beyond
abstract: Raoul Peck looks at the compelling South African photographer, who died in 1990, whose work gets a second life onscreen.
lead_paragraph: Ernest Cole, the groundbreaking South African chronicler of apartheid, died in 1990 in Manhattan. He was 49 and had been in exile since 1966. A new documentary directed by Raoul Peck, “Ernest Cole: Lost and Found,” revives interest in the photographer, who trained his gaze on fellow Black South Africans living with the daily outrages and violent outbursts of a system that controlled their movements but not their meaning.

headline: ‘Flow’ Review: A Cat’s Life
abstract: A cat, a dog and a capybara embark on an epic adventure in this earnest and refreshingly unconventional animated film.
lead_paragraph: “Flow,” an animated adventure film with a touch of magical realism, is a welcome entrant in the cat-movie canon, exuding a profound affection for our four-legged friends.

headline: ‘Joy’ Review: The Humans Behind I.V.F.
abstract: Thomasin McKenzie plays an unheralded pioneer of in vitro fertilization in a new biography.
lead_paragraph: In vitro fertilization is considered by many to be a miracle. It’s still controversial in some circles, as was seen in the recent election, when politicians made often contradictory pronouncements about it.

headline: ‘Out of My Mind’ Review: Schooling a Teacher
abstract: In this film adaptation of Sharon M. Draper’s novel, a nonverbal sixth-grader with cerebral palsy holds her own.
lead_paragraph: Like many a self-respecting tween, Melody Brooks has a thing or two to say about this and that, and a need to be heard. But that need has a particular urgency: Melody, the central character in “Out of My Mind,” has cerebral palsy and is unable to speak.

headline: ‘Porcelain War’ Review: A Defiant Dispatch From Ukraine
abstract: A new documentary follows artists in wartime, on and off the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: The latest documentary dispatch from Ukraine, “Porcelain War,” brings a message of hope rooted in art. Making art does feel like an act of resistance during the Russian invasion, when Kremlin propaganda attacks the very existence of Ukrainian culture. But what’s intriguing is that the directors, Brendan Bellomo and Slava Leontyev, also celebrate Ukraine’s military defense, making for a jangly mix of idyll and warfare.

headline: ‘A Traveler’s Needs’ Review: Language Lessons
abstract: Iris (Isabelle Huppert), a stranger who teaches French in Seoul, is at the center of an enigmatic film by Hong Sang-soo.
lead_paragraph: “Why’d she come to Korea?” a man (Kwon Hae-hyo) asks his wife (Lee Hye-young) in the park, as Iris (Isabelle Huppert) is walking away from them. Iris is a stranger in Seoul who has started teaching French to the wife. Whether Iris is up to the task is uncertain. She has no background in instruction, and the only language that she and her pupils share is English, which is not a native tongue for any of them.

headline: ‘Sabbath Queen’ Review: Capturing the Act of Questioning
abstract: Sandi DuBowski’s documentary about Rabbi Amichai Lau-Lavie observes the making of a Jewish identity.
lead_paragraph: When Amichai Lau-Lavie was ordained a rabbi, in 2016, he joined a family tradition that had been going on uninterrupted since the 11th century. And yet this had been a fraught process for Lau-Lavie, an Israel-born gay man who just a few years before entering New York’s Jewish Theological Seminary had been a pillar of a “God-optional” community. How he went from the Radical Faeries’ joyous, transgressive vision of queerness — which led to creating his drag alter ego, Rebbetzin Hadassah Gross — to embracing Conservative Judaism is the subject of Sandi DuBowski’s fascinating look at the act of questioning yourself and your family, your surroundings and your decisions.

headline: ‘Witches’ Review: Redeeming the Wicked Witch
abstract: The director Elizabeth Sankey’s experience with postpartum depression anchors this documentary about the pop-cultural representation of witches.
lead_paragraph: The arrival of “Witches,” a documentary streaming on Mubi, seems strategically timed. The director Elizabeth Sankey’s contribution is part essay film, part personal testimony, though like Jon M. Chu’s musical blockbuster “Wicked” she, too, starts in the land of Oz.

headline: Watch: ‘Obon’
abstract: What can the story of a Hiroshima survivor teach us about the horrors of nuclear weapons — and love, family and the human spirit?
lead_paragraph: Note to Teachers: The film includes graphic and disturbing images. Please preview it to make sure it is appropriate for your students.

headline: Dissecting the DOGE Playbook
abstract: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy have unveiled their first plans to trim government spending, a blueprint that mirrors how the tech mogul cut costs at Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump picked Elon Musk and the financier Vivek Ramaswamy to tackle one of his administration’s biggest priorities — reducing the size of the federal government.

headline: Bribery Charges Against Tycoon Strike at Heart of Modi’s India
abstract: The U.S. indictment names Gautam Adani, one of India’s richest businessmen, but it points to an even bigger target: how business is done there.
lead_paragraph: Gautam Adani is no ordinary Indian billionaire. Over the past 10 years, he has become in effect an extension of India’s government. His conglomerate, Adani Group, builds and buys ports, factories and power plants, often under state contract or license. It operates airports. It even owns a TV news channel.

headline: I.C.C. Prosecutor Sought Warrants for 3 Hamas Leaders. At Least 2 Are Now Dead.
abstract: Karim Khan had asked the court to issue warrants for Hamas’s top leader in Gaza, Yahya Sinwar; its political leader, Ismail Haniyeh; and its military chief, Muhammad Deif.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court on Thursday issued an arrest warrant for a single Hamas official — not three as the chief prosecutor had initially sought in May. That’s because two of them have since been killed.

headline: With Use of New Missile, Russia Sends a Threatening Message to the West
abstract: The intermediate-range missile did not carry nuclear weapons, but it is part of a strategic arsenal that is capable of delivering them.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin escalated a tense showdown with the West on Thursday, saying that Russia had launched a new intermediate-range ballistic missile at Ukraine in response to Ukraine’s recent use of American and British weapons to strike deeper into Russia.

headline: Let’s Discuss: ‘Our Rodent Selfies, Ourselves’
abstract: What can two rats teach us about our addiction to social media? Read the article and post your comments and questions for Emily Anthes by Dec. 5.
lead_paragraph: Why do so many of us feel compelled to photograph our lives and share those images online?

headline: John Prescott, Ex-Deputy Prime Minister of Britain, Dies at 86
abstract: He was a cruise ship waiter before rising in the trade union movement and becoming one of the country’s best-known Labour politicians under Tony Blair.
lead_paragraph: John Prescott, who rose through Britain’s trade union movement to become one of the country’s best-known politicians, serving as deputy prime minister for a decade, died on Wednesday. He was 86.

headline: Newsom to Visit California’s Trump Country: ‘Message Received’
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom acknowledged that residents were frustrated by economic problems and said that Democrats needed to address their concerns.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Gov. Gavin Newsom made the first of three post-election visits to California counties that Donald J. Trump won in the presidential race, reaching out to working-class voters in the Central Valley who remain frustrated by economic woes.

headline: She Went for a Walk on the Beach and Found a Rare ‘Doomsday Fish’
abstract: In Japanese mythology, the deep-sea-dwelling oarfish is a harbinger of impending disaster. For scientists in California, where three oarfish have washed up in recent months, it’s an exciting find.
lead_paragraph: Everything seemed picture-perfect on a recent day at Grandview Beach in Encinitas, Calif. — the waves shimmered under the California sun, and locals sunbathed and swam.

headline: Few Sitting Leaders Have Faced I.C.C. War Crimes Charges
abstract: The short list includes Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the deposed president of Sudan, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has joined a short list of sitting leaders charged by the International Criminal Court.

headline: Holiday Ornaments That Are Out of the Ordinary
abstract: A roundup of unusual Christmas baubles, from diamonds made of lichen to glass flowers and strawberry tarts.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-based floral designer Alex Crowder, 36, makes a point of limiting her materials to plants grown within 200 miles of New York City. To create arrangements for a lighting exhibition organized by the design firm Roman and Williams that opened this week in TriBeCa, she and her team at Field Studies Flora worked with SpadaFlora, a foraging company in New Jersey, to source “incredible twisty branches,” she says, while coppery spider chrysanthemums came from the Hudson Valley’s Treadlight Farm. On a 15-foot-tall Christmas tree spangled with red ribbon at Roman and Williams’s SoHo boutique, Crowder hung ornaments made from spiky datura seed pods and clusters of pine cones adorned with acorns. “We had an excess of them in the studio from other holiday projects,” says Crowder of the materials, “and we were trying to figure out, ‘How do we reuse these in a new, interesting way?’” She’s now selling the two designs through her website, along with a cocoon-like diamond of lichen, all strung from black velvet ribbons. Crowder’s aim, with the ornaments and her floral business as a whole, is to “draw people’s attention to materials that are often overlooked,” she says.

headline: At Least 38 Killed as Gunmen Ambush Shiite Convoys in Pakistan
abstract: The attack was one of the deadliest in months of violence between Sunnis and Shiites in the Kurram region.
lead_paragraph: At least 38 people, most of them Shiite Muslims, were killed in northwestern Pakistan on Thursday as gunmen ambushed convoys of vehicles that had been under the protection of security forces.

headline: Here’s Why the I.C.C. Says It Issued the Arrest Warrants
abstract: The International Criminal Court said there were grounds to hold two Israeli leaders responsible for the crisis in Gaza, and a Hamas military leader for crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court’s arrest warrants for two Israeli leaders say that there are grounds to believe they bear “criminal responsibility” for the devastating humanitarian crisis in Gaza, according to a statement released by the court on Thursday.

headline: New Thanksgiving Recipes That Earned Raves From Our Testers
abstract: Including a caramelized onion tahchin that’s “wonderfully comforting and absolutely crucial.”
lead_paragraph: If you’re going to trust anyone about whether or not a dish is truly delicious, you can trust a New York Times Cooking recipe tester. These very thorough professionals work through every recipe to make sure each one is clear, delivers as promised and, of course, tastes wonderful. So when a recipe earns rave reviews from them — cooks who work on hundreds of recipes each year — you know it’s really, really good.

headline: Should Gay Couples Worry About Their Benefits Under Trump?
abstract: Readers had concerns about whether same-sex married couples and their protections would face new risks during a second Trump term.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, same-sex married couples have received the same federal rights and protections that their straight counterparts enjoy. They include a long list of financial benefits, from spousal health coverage to less expensive tax preparation, not to mention the immeasurable comfort from knowing their unions must be recognized.

headline: House Passes Antiterror Financing Bill as Democrats Warn Trump Could Abuse It
abstract: Most Democrats opposed the measure, reversing their previous positions as they warned that President-elect Donald J. Trump could use it to punish nonprofit groups he saw as political antagonists.
lead_paragraph: The House on Thursday passed legislation that would allow the government to revoke the tax-exempt status of nonprofit groups it accuses of supporting terrorist entities, despite significant opposition from Democrats who warned that President-elect Donald J. Trump could exploit it to target his political enemies.

headline: Inside the Lobbying Career of Trump’s New Chief of Staff
abstract: Before managing the campaign of President-elect Donald J. Trump, Susie Wiles represented a tobacco company and a mining project, among others.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s first presidential transition was marked by chaos and vows to drain the swamp.

headline: So You’re Thinking of Leaving X for Bluesky. How Does It Work?
abstract: The apps look and feel similar. Here is how to use Bluesky and what you might miss from X.
lead_paragraph: Bluesky, the Twitter-like social media platform that emerged as an alternative for X users who had become frustrated with Elon Musk’s ownership of the platform, is having a second wind.

headline: Jussie Smollett’s Conviction for False Hate Crime Claim Is Overturned
abstract: The Illinois Supreme Court ruled that he should not have been prosecuted a second time after the charges against him had been dismissed with a negotiated agreement.
lead_paragraph: The Illinois Supreme Court on Thursday overturned the actor Jussie Smollett’s conviction on charges that he lied to the police about being the victim of a racist and homophobic attack in 2019. The court ruled that Mr. Smollett had been unjustly prosecuted after he had already reached a deal to resolve the case without jail time.

headline: U.S. Defense Firms Are Warned About Russia’s Sabotage Campaign
abstract: A new warning urges defense companies to increase security and to be on the lookout for surveillance and signs of trespassing.
lead_paragraph: U.S. officials warned on Thursday that Russia may be targeting American defense companies in a potentially stepped-up sabotage campaign.

headline: Want to Get Married in Central Park? This Planner Can Help.
abstract: Claire Ady started her business helping international couples navigate the process of getting married in the iconic park after planning her own wedding there.
lead_paragraph: On July 1, 2011, Claire Ady and Noel Ady, who had moved to New York from England, said “I do” as they stood under the Ladies Pavilion, a cast-iron, covered structure in a tranquil spot in Central Park that overlooks the lake.

headline: Automakers to Trump: Please Require Us to Sell Electric Vehicles
abstract: Donald J. Trump promised to erase Biden tailpipe rules that are designed to get carmakers to produce E.V.s. But Detroit wants to keep them.
lead_paragraph: Three of the nation’s largest automakers, Ford, General Motors and Stellantis, are strategizing with other car manufacturers on how to make a delicate request of President-elect Donald J. Trump: Don’t scrap the federal regulations that compel the industry to sell electric vehicles.

headline: First Close-Up of Star Outside Our Galaxy Shows a Giant About to Blow
abstract: Astronomers zoomed in on a stellar behemoth in the Larger Magellanic Cloud, a galaxy that orbits about 160,000 light-years from the Milky Way.
lead_paragraph: In a stunning scientific and technological feat, a group of astronomers said Thursday that it had managed to take the first close-up picture of a star in another galaxy. Not only was the image a distance record for such cosmic intimacy, but the star, bulging like an overripe fruit, looks as if it is getting ready to explode.

headline: Can the Senate Survive Donald Trump?
abstract: The vaunted chamber’s degradation preceded him. But he may trash it once and for all.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news events.

headline: ‘Interior Chinatown’ Review: Off the Shelf
abstract: Charles Yu adapts his award-winning novel into a series that is both starkly different from the original and frustratingly familiar.
lead_paragraph: “Interior Chinatown” was never going to be an easy adaptation. The novel’s success — which was considerable, including a National Book Award in 2020 — flowed from how seamlessly its author, Charles Yu, deployed the metafictional device at the book’s heart. His gimmick was simple enough in outline, but it was hard to see how it would work onscreen (even though it was, in part, about television).

headline: What Forecasters Say the Powerful Storm on the West Coast Will Do Next
abstract: More extreme rain will fall across the region on Thursday as forecasters warn of the potential for dangerous flooding.
lead_paragraph: The first major atmospheric river of the season is parked over Northern California, and it’s being held in place by two bomb cyclones — one of them among the strongest on record — in an unusual meteorological event that is expected to feed a continuous surge of moisture into the West Coast for the next several days.

headline: Spain Looks to Grant Residency to Nearly 1 Million Undocumented Migrants
abstract: The government said new rules could give legal status — and work permits — to about 300,000 people a year over the next three years to address gaps in the labor market.
lead_paragraph: Spain said it could give residency and work permits to about 900,000 undocumented migrants in the country over the next three years to help address a growing need for workers, even as other European countries embrace tougher stances on immigration.

headline: Republicans Rally Behind Pete Hegseth Amid Sexual Assault Accusations
abstract: Some Republican senators, who will consider his nomination to be defense secretary, shrugged off the accusations and defended him.
lead_paragraph: Vice President-elect JD Vance brought two of Donald J. Trump’s potential cabinet members to the Senate this week to shore up support for the president-elect’s picks, but he’s leaving with only one.

headline: For Netanyahu, Subject to Landmark Warrant, a Smaller World
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has allies among the members of the International Criminal Court. But he will have to plan his travel more carefully than before.
lead_paragraph: The arrest warrant issued by the International Criminal Court for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will confront governments around the world with a dilemma: whether to detain the leader of a democracy that is also an ally of many of their countries.

headline: What’s Behind the Remarkable Drop in U.S. Overdose Deaths
abstract: Experts are puzzling over which interventions are saving lives. The evolving illicit supply itself may hold important clues.
lead_paragraph: After years of relentless rises in overdose deaths, the United States has seen a remarkable reversal. For seven straight months, according to federal data, drug fatalities have been declining.

headline: Morgan Wallen Wins CMA’s Entertainer of the Year Award
abstract: The singer, who is among the most popular artists in music, won country’s top prize in absentia, three years after being rebuked by the genre’s gatekeepers.
lead_paragraph: The pop-country superstar Morgan Wallen won entertainer of the year, the top honor at the 58th annual Country Music Association Awards in Nashville on Wednesday night. The award recognized Wallen’s status atop the genre three years after the association banned him from performing at the 2021 show.

headline: Jay Leno Says He Was Injured in a Fall
abstract: He told Inside Edition that he fell down a hill after taking an ill-advised shortcut, leaving him with a broken wrist and a black eye.
lead_paragraph: Jay Leno, the comedian and former “Tonight Show” host, said he fell down a hill near Pittsburgh last Friday, leaving him with a broken wrist, a black eye and bruising on the left side of his face.

headline: Matt Gaetz Withdraws From Consideration for Attorney General
abstract: Mr. Gaetz has consistently denied the allegations of sexual misconduct and drug use, but his prospective nomination ran into trouble in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Matt Gaetz, who faced a torrent of scrutiny over allegations of sex trafficking and drug use, abruptly withdrew his bid to become attorney general on Thursday in the first major political setback for President-elect Donald J. Trump since his election this month.

headline: Matt Gaetz Bows Out, to Sighs of Relief
abstract: Readers respond to Matt Gaetz’s withdrawal. Also: Dr. Mehmet Oz and Robert F. Kennedy Jr.; Russia’s nuclear pose; political spending; election lessons; homelessness.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: He Was a National Hero in Britain. His Daughter Profited From His Name.
abstract: The family of Captain Tom Moore, who raised $50 million for Britain’s health service during the pandemic, has been criticized for ‘serious and repeated’ misconduct by an official inquiry.
lead_paragraph: His walk for charity at the age of 99 captivated a nation in the grip of the coronavirus pandemic. But the legacy of Captain Tom Moore, the decorated British Army officer who raised nearly 40 million pounds, or $50.5 million, for the National Health Service, has been tarnished by disclosures about how his family profited from the sudden fame of their plucky patriarch.

headline: A Very Veggie Thanksgiving
abstract: Gorgeous mains, vibrant sides and — most important — stuffing.
lead_paragraph: Across the internet (Instagram), people far and wide (dear friends, distant relatives and women I met once at parties in college) are soft-launching their Thanksgiving menus. With the Friendsgiving season in full swing, stuffings and green bean casseroles and all manner of potatoes clutter my feed, just as they’ll clutter the holiday table a week from today.

headline: The Metamorphosis of Pete Hegseth: From Critic of War Crimes to Defender of the Accused
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Defense Department was described by peers as a skillful soldier who became embittered by military dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: When Pete Hegseth was an earnest, young Army lieutenant in Iraq in 2005, he was cleareyed on how he viewed crimes committed by soldiers in war.

headline: Northvolt, Europe’s Hope for a Battery Champion, Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The company’s woes are symptomatic of a wider malaise among companies that make batteries for electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish battery maker Northvolt, once seen as Europe’s strongest competitor to Chinese battery manufacturers, filed for bankruptcy protection in the United States on Thursday.

headline: Why Some Countries Won’t Join the I.C.C.
abstract: More than 120 countries are members of the court. The United States, China, India, Russia and Israel are not.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court is the world’s highest criminal court, prosecuting warlords and heads of state alike. But several powerful countries, including the United States, do not recognize its authority and refuse to become members.

headline: Trump’s Vow to End the War Could Leave Ukraine With Few Options
abstract: One question is whether the new administration and Europe will provide security guarantees to prevent Russia from taking more territory.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Gen. Mark A. Milley, then the chief military adviser to President Biden, suggested that neither Russia nor Ukraine could win the war. A negotiated settlement, he argued, was the only route to peace.

headline: I.C.C. Issues Arrest Warrant for Netanyahu Over War in Gaza
abstract: The International Criminal Court’s arrest warrants for Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his former defense minister, Yoav Gallant, were issued for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Gaza. The court also sought to arrest Hamas’s military chief, Muhammad Deif, for crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court’s arrest warrants for Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his former defense minister, Yoav Gallant, were issued for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Gaza. The court also sought to arrest Hamas’s military chief, Muhammad Deif, for crimes against humanity.

headline: Dallas Long, Record-Setting Shot-Putter, Is Dead at 84
abstract: In an era when America dominated the event, he was one of the best. He retired after winning gold at the 1964 Tokyo Summer Olympics and became a doctor.
lead_paragraph: Dallas Long, a brawny shot-putter who established himself as one of the best of his era by equaling or setting the world record in that track and field event seven times and winning a gold medal at the 1964 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, died on Nov. 10 in Columbia Falls, Mont. He was 84.

headline: ‘Gladiator II’ Review: Thumb’s Up!
abstract: Denzel Washington’s performance shows skill, intensity and absolute confidence in Ridley Scott’s pleasurably immersive epic about ancient Roman fighters.
lead_paragraph: When Denzel Washington sweeps into “Gladiator II” — Ridley Scott’s epic about ancient Rome and men at war and sometimes in love — it’s with such easy grace that you may mistake his character’s loose bearing with indifference. What you’re seeing is power incarnate, power that’s so raw and so supremely self-possessed that it doesn’t announce itself. It just takes. And it keeps taking as warriors enter the Colosseum to fight and die in the blood sport that gives this sequel to Scott’s 2000 drama “Gladiator” its sober backdrop and much of its juice. It is a performance of charismatic evil and of mesmerizing stardom both.

headline: Trump Media May Be Mulling a Crypto Payment Service
abstract: The parent company of Truth Social filed a trademark application for a crypto payment service it called TruthFi.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s social media company is considering developing a cryptocurrency payment service, according to a trademark application filed this week, the latest sign of the president-elect’s embrace of the crypto industry.

headline: From Chimpan-A to Chimpanzee, These Apes May Have Humanlike Culture
abstract: Researchers describe a link between genetic relatedness and sophisticated tool use in primates in East and Central Africa, suggesting their culture is cumulative.
lead_paragraph: It’s amazing what chimpanzees will do for a snack.

headline: Brazilian Police Accuse Bolsonaro of Plotting a Coup
abstract: Former President Jair Bolsonaro could face criminal charges over accusations that he was involved in plans to stage a coup after losing the 2022 elections.
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian authorities announced on Thursday that they were recommending criminal charges against former far-right President Jair Bolsonaro over his role in a broad plot to cling to power after he lost the 2022 presidential election.

headline: The Clean Energy Boom in Republican Districts
abstract: Trump has said he’ll repeal President Biden’s climate law, but one North Carolina district shows how hard unwinding multibillion-dollar projects could be.
lead_paragraph: Randolph County, a rural square of green woods and farm fields in the middle of North Carolina, is the unlikely home of one of the biggest electric vehicle battery projects in the world.

headline: Man Who Faked Kayaking Death Says in Video He’s ‘Safe’
abstract: Ryan Borgwardt, who is believed to be in Eastern Europe and has been communicating with the authorities, has not committed to returning to the U.S., officials said.
lead_paragraph: A Wisconsin man who faked his own death and left his family three months ago after communicating with a woman in Uzbekistan has been in regular contact with the authorities and sent them a video this month, saying he was “safe” and “secure.”

headline: Gaetz’s Withdrawal Means the Senate Passed Its First Test
abstract: Trump failed to push Republicans past their red line.
lead_paragraph: Talk about a quick and humiliating smackdown. Florida Man Matt Gaetz was announced as Donald Trump’s pick for attorney general on a Wednesday. Eight days later, his complete unfitness for the job had become so undeniable and insurmountable that he withdrew from consideration. The nomination didn’t last even a full Scaramucci.

headline: In ‘Music City’ and ‘Babe,’ Existential Battles of the Heart and Soul
abstract: Bedlam’s country music show is a rollicking good time. But the New Group’s production of “Babe,” starring Marisa Tomei, is a frustrating one-act lacking cohesion.
lead_paragraph: If country music has a superpower, it’s the ability to spin conventions and catchphrases into affecting narratives. The book for “Music City,” a terrific new jukebox show mining the JT Harding catalog, essentially does the same thing on a larger scale.

headline: White Supremacist Incidents Are Rising Across the U.S.
abstract: Flash demonstrations intended to spread fear and anxiety are happening almost weekly, say experts who track the incidents.
lead_paragraph: A neo-Nazi group scattered fliers across lawns and doorsteps in three Waterloo, Iowa, neighborhoods just before Veterans Day. The handouts offered a chilling assessment of the group’s proximity, in capital letters: “We are your neighbors! We are the random stranger holding the door open for you!” it read. “We are everywhere.”

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 2, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: Note: We will live-moderate a discussion about this image on Monday, Dec. 2, and then post the photo’s Reveal by the end of Thursday, Dec. 5.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Dec. 4, 2024
abstract: What do you notice and wonder about the severity of drought in the U.S.?
lead_paragraph: Note: We will live-moderate a discussion about this graph on Wednesday, Dec. 4, and then post the graph’s Reveal by the morning of Friday, Dec. 6.

headline: The Alluring Dream That Black America Needs to Wake Up From
abstract: Cleopatra is not our mother.
lead_paragraph: Since the 19th century, a strain in Black American culture has claimed ancient Egypt as ancestor and inspiration. A fascination with that long-ago land has permeated Black art deeply enough to seem like one of its very foundations. In the early 20th century, the emblem of the N.A.A.C.P. house organ, “The Crisis,” looked like a sphinx, and many covers featured beautiful Egyptian motifs. In the 1990s, many thinkers warmly embraced the book “Black Athena” by the historian Martin Bernal, which made the claim — since rather roundly debunked — that the ancient Greeks had stolen much of the glory of their culture from “Black” Egypt. So strong has this current of thought been that it fills an exhibition currently on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art titled “Flight Into Egypt: Black Artists and Ancient Egypt, 1876-Now.”

headline: Landslides Are a Growing Climate Threat. What Do We Know About The Risks?
abstract: Deadly landslides are becoming more common and large amounts of rain are a known trigger. An atmospheric river is dumping rain out West. What you should know about your risk.
lead_paragraph: A storm of heavy rain, snow, and strong winds brought dangerous conditions to the Pacific Northwest this week. By Friday, up to 16 inches of rain could inundate Northern California.

headline: Steven J. Rosen, Fiercely Influential Advocate for Israel, Dies at 82
abstract: He was a prominent behind-the-scenes figure in Washington whose career was derailed when he was charged with leaking government secrets. The case was later dropped.
lead_paragraph: Steven J. Rosen, a hawkish supporter of Israel who strengthened the clout of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a Washington lobbying group, but whose career was derailed when he was charged with leaking government secrets, a case that was later dropped, died on Oct. 28 near his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 82.

headline: Israel Indicts Netanyahu Aide Over Leaked Document on Hamas
abstract: One of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s advisers is accused of leaking a top-secret document to a German tabloid in an attempt to influence public sentiment on hostage negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Israeli prosecutors indicted one of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s aides on Thursday, charging the aide with leaking classified information on Hamas and most likely harming national security, the latest development in a web of legal scandals that has entangled the country’s leader.

headline: Russia Launches New Intermediate-Range Missile at Ukraine
abstract: President Vladimir Putin said the attack was in response to Ukraine’s recent use of American and British weapons to strike deeper into Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin said the attack was in response to Ukraine’s recent use of American and British weapons to strike deeper into Russia.

headline: A Rite of Passage for Congressional Newcomers: Picking an Office
abstract: Since 1906, new members of Congress have drawn lots to choose their new homes on Capitol Hill. Staff and lawmakers often scout and strategize far in advance to find the best spaces.
lead_paragraph: Early Thursday morning, in a packed subterranean room near the Capitol, newly elected members of Congress took turns approaching a wooden box and drawing lots to claim their spots in a storied pecking order.

headline: Mali’s Junta Replaces Civilian Prime Minister With One of Its Own
abstract: The prime minister had been fired for criticizing the country’s junta.
lead_paragraph: The ruling junta of Mali appointed its spokesman as the country’s new prime minister on Thursday, after his civilian predecessor was fired for criticizing the administration.

headline: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Two of our recommended books this week put rock music front and center: Peter Ames Carlin’s biography of the band R.E.M., and Izumi Suzuki’s novel of Tokyo’s rock scene in the early 1980s. We also like a biography of the physicist Roger Penrose, a study of the 20th-century novel, and fiction by Elias Khoury and Sergio De La Pava. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

headline: Some Republicans Welcome Gaetz’s Withdrawal: ‘Probably a Good Decision’
abstract: Matt Gaetz, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice for attorney general, faced what appeared to be long odds of securing the votes needed for confirmation in the Republican-controlled Senate.
lead_paragraph: After former Representative Matt Gaetz abruptly withdrew from consideration to become attorney general on Thursday amid intense scrutiny of allegations of sex trafficking and drug use, some Republicans in the Senate welcomed his withdrawal.

headline: 2 Festive Ways to Get Cranberry Sauce on the Thanksgiving Table
abstract: Genevieve Ko wants you to think beyond those canned rounds and adds the fruit to a dipping sauce — and also a creamy ricotta cheesecake.
lead_paragraph: My first experience with cranberry sauce was like that of many others: carefully picking the razor-edged lid off a can, then holding the open end over a plate to let the magenta cylinder shimmy out and land with a soft fwop. Even better than the sauce’s mesmerizing jiggle was the taste, intriguing in how it was both overly sugary but not sweet enough to hide its sourness.

headline: U.N. Watchdog Censures Iran Over Nuclear Program Secrecy
abstract: The action could lead to sanctions against Tehran, which has barred international monitoring of its accelerated uranium enrichment efforts.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency censured Iran on Thursday evening for failing to cooperate fully with the agency’s monitoring and inspection, as the country is obligated to do under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

headline: Friday Briefing: Gaetz Ends Bid for Attorney General
abstract: Plus, bathing in crude oil.
lead_paragraph: Matt Gaetz yesterday abruptly withdrew from consideration to become attorney general, a week after President-elect Donald Trump picked him as a potential nominee. It is Trump’s first major political setback since he was elected.

headline: International Criminal Court Seeks Netanyahu’s Arrest Over Gaza War
abstract: The court accused Benjamin Netanyahu and his former defense minister of having “intentionally and knowingly deprived” Gaza’s population of food, water, fuel and medicine.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court on Thursday issued arrest warrants for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his former defense minister, Yoav Gallant, accusing them of war crimes and crimes against humanity in the Gaza Strip and dealing an extraordinary blow to Israel’s global standing as it presses on with wars on multiple fronts.

headline: Theft of ‘Nutcracker’ Set Pieces and Props Can’t Stop a Michigan Production
abstract: After a trailer containing major props was stolen, members of the Plymouth-Canton Ballet Company have come together to make sure the annual show still goes on.
lead_paragraph: The 40th annual performance of “The Nutcracker” in Canton, Mich., was weeks away, and June Smith was anxiously awaiting one of her last Sunday rehearsals with dozens of her student dancers.

headline: New N.Y.P.D. Boss Takes Over a Department With ‘Phenomenal Problems’
abstract: Jessica Tisch will oversee top officials who have behaved questionably in public and private. Her supporters say she does not put up with posturing or incompetence.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Tisch will confront a crushing list of problems as soon as she returns to the New York Police Department next week.

headline: Peeling the $6.2 Million Banana: An Auction Explainer
abstract: Answers to six immediate questions you might have about the art world after a crypto entrepreneur spent millions on a 35-cent fruit.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t just a banana. It was a banana with a back story.

headline: Buttigieg Warns Trump-Panicked Democrats, ‘We Cannot Be Mesmerized’
abstract: The transportation secretary, one of several ambitious Democrats jockeying for prominence, gave advice in a speech but was coy about his own plans: “I know that I will make myself useful again later.”
lead_paragraph: As Democrats in Washington and beyond absorb the chaotic dawn of a new Trump administration, one of the party’s ambitious, young leaders is cautioning them to remain calm.

headline: Officer’s Fatal Shooting of 911 Caller in Las Vegas Prompts Push for His Arrest
abstract: Body camera footage shows an officer fatally shooting a Black man who was struggling with a woman over a knife. The man had called the police for help.
lead_paragraph: A Las Vegas family is calling for the arrest of a police officer who fatally shot a Black man inside his house after the man had called 911 seeking help during a home invasion.

headline: An Immigrant Family’s Dreams, Shattered by a Random Stabbing Spree
abstract: On Sunday, Angel Lata Landi, a construction worker, called his mother in Ecuador, whom he helped support. The next day, he was one of three people stabbed to death on the street in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Angel Lata Landi called his mother in Ecuador on Sunday, as he did every week. He told her he would not be able to send her money as he usually did because his bills had mounted. But he promised to make up for it soon.

headline: Spencer Lawton Jr., D.A. in ‘Midnight in the Garden’ Case, Dies at 81
abstract: He devoted much of his 28 years in office in Savannah to victims’ rights, but he was best known for his role in a 1981 murder at the center of a best seller and its movie version.
lead_paragraph: Spencer Lawton Jr., whose achievements as a reform-minded district attorney in Savannah, Ga., were overshadowed by his role as the lead prosecutor in the murder case featured in the best-selling book “Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,” died on Nov. 13 at his home in Savannah. He was 81.

headline: Alvin Ailey Dance Chooses Alicia Graf Mack to Be Next Leader
abstract: Mack, director of the dance division at Juilliard, will be the popular company’s fourth artistic director.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has chosen Alicia Graf Mack to be its next artistic director, it announced on Thursday.

headline: ‘Midnight Family’ Is a Fresh and Energetic Medical Drama
abstract: Set among a family of private ambulance drivers in Mexico City, the Apple TV+ series is a thoughtful and cinematic adaptation of a 2019 documentary.
lead_paragraph: “Midnight Family,” on Apple TV+, is a Mexican drama (in Spanish, with subtitles or dubbed) about a family that runs a private ambulance. There aren’t enough ambulances for all the emergencies in Mexico City, so bootleg paramedics blare their own sirens and pitch in.

headline: Dinner and a Show and a Little Hustle Near the Theater District
abstract: Yes, you can play it safe for a meal around the corner from your theater. But a few extra blocks will serve you well.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the theater! One of the many great reasons to live in this city, despite the horrors. Especially in the doldrums of late autumn, there’s nothing better than getting gussied up to see a show. (I know, I know, people wear sweatpants to the theater now. I refuse!)

headline: What’s the Worst Date You’ve Ever Been On? We Want to Hear About It.
abstract: Tell us about your experience, and you may be featured on the Modern Love podcast.
lead_paragraph: When you go on a date, there’s always a chance that sparks will fly. But sometimes you have a date where something so absurd, embarrassing or infuriating happens that your only positive takeaway is the story you can tell your friends afterward.

headline: Gaetz Withdrew From Attorney General Consideration
abstract: Also, Putin said Russia struck Ukraine with a new missile. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Matt Gaetz, the former Florida congressman who Donald Trump tapped last week as his choice for attorney general, announced today that he would withdraw from consideration.

headline: The 2026 Georgia Governor’s Race Kicks Off With a First Hat in the Ring
abstract: The state’s attorney general, Chris Carr, a Republican, is the first person in either major party to declare his candidacy for statewide office in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: The Republican attorney general of Georgia, Chris Carr, announced his candidacy for governor in the state on Thursday, marking the start of another frenzied midterm-election cycle directly on the heels of the presidential contest.

headline: David McCormick Defeats Senator Bob Casey in Pennsylvania
abstract: Mr. McCormick, a Republican former hedge-fund executive, toppled Mr. Casey, a three-term Democrat, in one of the nation’s top Senate races and biggest 2024 upsets.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bob Casey, a three-term Democrat from Pennsylvania long seen as an institution in state politics, was defeated on Thursday by his Republican challenger, the former hedge-fund executive David McCormick, in a stunning upset in one of the nation’s top Senate races.

headline: N.Y.C. Housing Plan Moves Forward With an Unexpected $5 Billion Boost
abstract: A City Council committee passed a major proposal that would ease restrictions on housing growth in New York. The full Council is likely to approve it next month.
lead_paragraph: A major plan seeking to address New York City’s housing crisis won approval from a City Council committee in a key vote on Thursday, bolstered by an unexpected pledge of $5 billion in city and state funds for affordable housing and infrastructure projects.

headline: Trump’s Education Secretary Pick Named in Sexual Abuse Lawsuit
abstract: Linda McMahon, who ran World Wrestling Entertainment for decades, was accused in the lawsuit of not preventing one of the organization’s employees from victimizing children who helped set up wrestling rings.
lead_paragraph: Linda McMahon, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice for education secretary, has been accused in a recent lawsuit of failing to stop a ringside announcer for World Wrestling Entertainment from grooming and sexually abusing children in the 1980s and 1990s.

headline: 6 Airports in Northern Haiti Are Reopened to U.S. Flights
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Thursday it was allowing air traffic to resume at half a dozen airports in Haiti, but the country’s main flight hub in the capital would remain off limits.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Thursday it was allowing U.S. flights to resume to six airports in northern Haiti.

headline: Seattle Power Outages Could Linger as Strong Storms Pelt the West Coast
abstract: A series of atmospheric rivers is flooding the Pacific Northwest and parts of California, with more wind and rain forecast as utilities try to restore power to hundreds of thousands of people.
lead_paragraph: Utility crews across the Seattle area scrambled to clear fallen trees and restore power to nearly 200,000 homes, schools and businesses that remained without electricity early Friday, as another round of heavy wind and rain pelted the region.

headline: Powerful Storm Drenches Northern California
abstract: The first major atmospheric river of the season flooded roads and vineyards, brought down trees and damaged houses and cars.
lead_paragraph: The first major atmospheric river of the season flooded roads and vineyards, brought down trees and damaged houses and cars.

headline: How Hostility to Immigrants Will Hurt America’s Tech Sector
abstract: Don’t assume that highly educated foreigners will be spared by the new administration.
lead_paragraph: Will business prosper under a second Donald Trump presidency? As far as I can tell, many business leaders are pinning their hopes on the belief that he won’t actually follow through on his campaign pledges on tariffs and mass deportation — that they’ll be like his border wall, which, for the most part, he never built but claimed he had.

headline: Trump Picks Pam Bondi, Florida’s Former Top Prosecutor, for Attorney General After Gaetz Withdraws
abstract: In Ms. Bondi, who served on his legal team during his first impeachment, the president-elect turned to a loyal ally to put his stamp on a Justice Department that he sees as hostile to him.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Thursday that he would nominate Pam Bondi to be attorney general, turning to a longtime loyalist who served as state attorney general in Florida to put his stamp on a Justice Department that he sees as politically hostile to him.

headline: Peter Sinfield, Poetic Lyricist for Prog Rock’s King Crimson, Dies at 80
abstract: His swirls of imagery helped define progressive rock in the 1970s. He later turned his focus to pop acts like Celine Dion.
lead_paragraph: Peter Sinfield, whose mystical and at times politically pointed lyrics for the British band King Crimson became emblematic of the progressive rock movement of the 1970s, died on Nov. 14 in London. He was 80.

headline: Phillips 66 Is Accused of Violating the Clean Water Act
abstract: The oil company was indicted on charges of dumping nearly 800,000 gallons of contaminated wastewater into the Los Angeles County sewer system.
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury on Wednesday indicted Phillips 66 on charges of violating the Clean Water Act by dumping nearly 800,000 gallons of contaminated wastewater into the Los Angeles County sewer system and failing to report the incident to authorities.

headline: M.I.T. to Offer Free Tuition to Families Earning Less Than $200,000
abstract: For students whose families earn less than $100,000 per year, the school will also cover other costs, including housing, dining, fees and an allowance for books and personal expenses.
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced on Wednesday that it would eliminate tuition costs next fall for all undergraduate students whose families earn less than $200,000 per year — following a national movement to try to make higher education more accessible.

headline: Why a Police Shooting Victim’s Family Won’t Get a $100 Million Payout
abstract: Cities have paid out billions of dollars in police misconduct cases, but depending on the case, families may not receive any money at all. A recent $100 million penalty for a police shooting case in Dallas may never lead to a payout.
lead_paragraph: The family of George Floyd received $27 million after he was killed by police officers in Minneapolis. The family of Breonna Taylor got $12 million. Richard Cox, who was paralyzed after a ride in a police van in New Haven, Conn., got $46 million.

headline: Three Short Posts Show a New Power Dynamic Between Musk and Bezos
abstract: The world’s two richest men are longtime business rivals, but now one of them has the ear of the next president of the United States.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, a three-post exchange between Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk on Mr. Musk’s X would have passed for petty sniping between billionaire rivals.

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene Will Lead New ‘DOGE’ Panel on Government Efficiency
abstract: The rise of the Republican representative from Georgia signals the ascendancy of the MAGA wing of the G.O.P. in Congress.
