lead_paragraph: When she arrived in Congress in 2021, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, Republican of Georgia, was quickly stripped of her two committee assignments by Democrats and shunned by her colleagues on Capitol Hill.

headline: The Road to Trump’s ‘Grand New Party’
abstract: Ross Douthat and Reihan Salam had a vision for how Republicans could reclaim the working class. They never expected Trump to fulfill it.
lead_paragraph: Ross Douthat and Reihan Salam had a vision for how Republicans could reclaim the working class. They never expected Trump to fulfill it.

headline: West Bank Settlement Supporters Have Big Hopes for Trump’s Presidency
abstract: As Donald J. Trump nominates staunch supporters of Israel to key positions, advocacy groups are taking aim at the departing administration's policies.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration this week imposed sanctions on more groups and individuals it accuses of having ties to Israeli settlers inciting violence in the occupied West Bank, a last-ditch show of disapproval of Israelis’ annexation of land there before U.S. policy on the issue most likely swings the other way under the next administration.

headline: As a Lobbyist, Bondi Had Clients Including Amazon, G.M., Uber and Qatar
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s new choice to be attorney general joined a powerhouse Republican firm after her second term as Florida’s attorney general.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to be attorney general, Pam Bondi, is a lobbyist for a powerhouse Republican firm, for which she represented major corporations and foreign governments with interests before the U.S. government.

headline: China’s Hacking Reached Deep Into U.S. Telecoms
abstract: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said hackers listened to phone calls and read texts by exploiting aging equipment and seams in the networks that connect systems.
lead_paragraph: China’s recent breach of the innermost workings of the U.S. telecommunications system reached far deeper than the Biden administration has described, the chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee said on Thursday, with hackers able to listen in on telephone conversations and read text messages.

headline: Review: In ‘Death Becomes Her,’ Spiking the Fountain of Youth
abstract: Hilarious star turns from Megan Hilty and Jennifer Simard make the mostly unfunny 1992 film into an intermittently memorable Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: Not since Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne themselves performed there in 1958, leaving a trail of scrapes and bite marks in their wake, has Broadway’s Lunt-Fontanne Theater housed such equal-billing dragons as the ones Megan Hilty and Jennifer Simard play in “Death Becomes Her.” The musical, which opened on Thursday, stars the two comic treasures as lifelong frenemies for whom the “lifelong” part is an understatement. Their animosity is eternal.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 22, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the prison sentence for Bill Hwang, the founder of Archegos Capital Management, misstated the office that prepared his presentencing report. It was prepared by the probation department, not by the prosecution.

headline: Pam Bondi Is Trump’s New Choice for Attorney General. Here’s What to Know About Her.
abstract: Florida’s first female state attorney general, she became a member of Donald Trump’s impeachment defense team and backed his false claims of election fraud in 2020.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump quickly swept aside Thursday’s bad headlines about Matt Gaetz by speedily substituting Pam Bondi, a fellow Florida Republican with a starkly different profile — but a similar reputation for fealty — to be his attorney general.

headline: Field of Stars
abstract: Sarah Sinclair and Rafael Musa invite solvers to a tug of war.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: ‘The Blood Quilt’ Review: An Elaborate Tapestry
abstract: Katori Hall’s new play about sisters gathering after their mother’s death features standout performances but an overabundance of themes.
lead_paragraph: Quilting is about more than just fabric and stitches; it’s about blood, love, memory and trauma. That’s the premise at the center of Katori Hall’s “The Blood Quilt” at Lincoln Center, about four sisters gathering to complete a quilt three weeks after their mother’s death. The play itself a beautiful patchwork of themes and ideas that feel packed to the seams.

headline: Police in New Jersey’s Capital Violate Residents’ Rights, U.S. Finds
abstract: Officers in Trenton have caused the deaths of innocent people, a Justice Department report found, citing a fatality that occurred after officers pushed a man’s face into the ground.
lead_paragraph: Police officers in Trenton, N.J., systematically violate the constitutional rights of the city’s residents, conduct illegal searches and needlessly escalate peaceful interactions into violence, the U.S. Department of Justice found in a report published Thursday.

headline: Quote of the Day: Crypto Entrepreneur Pays $6.2 Million for Banana-as-Art
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 22, 2024
lead_paragraph: “I bet the Sotheby’s staff absolutely can’t wait to stop having to listen to banana jokes and pretend like it’s the first time they heard them.”

headline: ‘Star Wars’ Actress Finds the ‘Cool Nerd’ She Sought. A ‘Bridgerton’ Wedding Followed.
abstract: Philicia Saunders and Jordan Wilson discovered a mutual love of cosplay, anime, video games — and, eventually, each other.
lead_paragraph: “I’m literally a walking nerd billboard.” That’s how Jordan Alexander Wilson describes himself.

headline: Their Life as a Classic Movie (With a Modern Twist)
abstract: Sydney Reade and Samuel Zweighaft, both fans of the TCM channel, met four years ago. Their first conversation lasted four hours.
lead_paragraph: Sydney Dana Reade was drawn to Samuel Bennett Zweighaft’s Hinge profile in mid-January 2021 after seeing the initials TCM, which she immediately recognized as Turner Classic Movies, the classic film TV channel.

headline: Sharing More Than a Last Name
abstract: Haley Cohen and Jason Cohen met briefly as children, then matched on an app as adults. “It just seemed like fate,” the groom said.
lead_paragraph: When Haley Alexandra Cohen and Jason Dean Cohen were matched on the Jewish dating app JSwipe in November 2019, they instantly realized that their connection went back years — to when they were 8, to be exact.

headline: Six Weeks After Their First Date, They Moved to Paris
abstract: Soon after they met, Delanie Linden and Zack Burton took a leap of faith and flew to France. There, they fell in love.
lead_paragraph: When Delanie Joy Linden first saw Zachary Florentino Murguía Burton, he was lost.

headline: When the Cost of Being Unmarried Is Too High
abstract: In an uncertain world, a marriage skeptic comes around.
lead_paragraph: In February 2022, a few days after Russia invaded Ukraine, I sent my partner a panicked text: “Maybe we should get married.”

headline: Britain Faces a Dilemma: Cozy Up to Trump or Reconnect With Europe?
abstract: A Trump administration may force Prime Minister Keir Starmer to choose between his country’s most powerful ally and its biggest trading partner.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain joined President Emmanuel Macron of France in Paris last week to celebrate Armistice Day — the first British leader to do so since Winston Churchill in 1944 — it was a striking illustration of his Labour government’s desire to reset relations with Europe.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Donald Trump’s new choice for attorney general.
lead_paragraph: Hours after Matt Gaetz abruptly withdrew from consideration as attorney general, President-elect Donald Trump announced that he would nominate Pam Bondi, a former Florida attorney general, for the role.

headline: Chuck Scarborough to Step Down as WNBC News Anchor After 50-Year Career
abstract: The celebrated broadcaster, who started at the New York station in 1974, announced that he would wrap up his anchoring career on Dec. 12.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Scarborough, the broadcaster who for 50 years brought New Yorkers news of blizzards, financial collapses, terror attacks and assassinations, said Thursday that he would step down from his anchoring duties at WNBC.

headline: What Democrats Are Getting Wrong About Transgender Rights
abstract: Trans rights aren’t just trans rights. They’re reproductive rights.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of an election in which Donald Trump stoked fear about trans people — as in the much-discussed ad that warned “Kamala is for they/them. President Trump is for you” — Democrats are now debating how much the issue of trans rights hurt them and how fast they should retreat from it. Which is remarkable, because throughout her brief campaign, Kamala Harris was all but silent on the subject. It’s not clear how much further Democrats could actually retreat.

headline: Late Night Can’t Believe Matt Gaetz Won’t Be Attorney General
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel said the scandal-ridden ex-congressman’s withdrawal was “exciting news for Judge Jeanine Pirro, who will be our next attorney general.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: provost
abstract: This word has appeared in 87 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word provost has appeared in 87 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 15 in “Harvard Names Conservative Legal Scholar as Permanent Provost” by Anemona Hartocollis:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: After Banning Booze for 120 Years, a Town Prepares to Open the Tap
abstract: Haddon Heights, N.J., voted to issue liquor licenses for the first time in its history. Not everyone is happy.
lead_paragraph: As suburbs go, Haddon Heights, N.J., has a lot to recommend it. Kids can walk to school and play safely under leafy trees. It’s close to Philadelphia, but full of small-town charm. It has an almost century-old grocery store, good restaurants, plenty of longtime residents and small business owners who know one another by name.

headline: New York’s Soccer Clubs Meet in a Playoff, and the Loathing Is Mutual
abstract: The Red Bulls and the New York City Football Club face one another on Saturday. Much of the metro area is blasé, but the fan bases are frothing.
lead_paragraph: It does not produce the passions stirred by Barcelona versus Madrid. It does not make New York stop dead like Buenos Aires does when River Plate plays Boca Juniors. It does not even match the historical enmity of Islanders-Rangers hockey at Madison Square Garden.

headline: A Surprise
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration, or describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: The Liberal New Yorkers Who Say They’re Tuning Out the News
abstract: In the wake of the election, some New York City news addicts are quitting cold turkey. Can they really keep it up?
lead_paragraph: Since the presidential election more than two weeks ago, it has been common to hear certain kinds of left-leaning, reflective New Yorkers declare that they were breaking up with the news. The prospect of a second Trump administration with all the anticipated chaos felt like too much — they were drained, exhausted, resigned, ready to choose a plaintive ignorance. These were high-information voters who mainlined political coverage through every available 21st- century platform; a month ago they would have been able to give you the over-under on statehouse races in rural Ohio.

headline: ‘Spellbound’ Review: Borrowed Wonder
abstract: Any magic this animated musical has feels distinctly, almost insultingly poached.
lead_paragraph: Princess Ellian, heir to the throne of Lumbria, has a problem: A year earlier, her parents, traveling through the Dark Forest of Eternal Darkness, fell under a curse. That sort of thing happens when you’re passing through a wood “so dark they named it twice” — but let’s not cast blame. The curse transformed the king and queen into roaring, rampaging monsters. They can’t comprehend much or speak, but they can be distracted with chew toys.

headline: An Asteroid’s Destruction May Have Given Mars Rings, Then Moons
abstract: Scientists simulated a situation that may offer an improved explanation for how the Red Planet ended up with small Phobos and tiny Deimos.
lead_paragraph: Something’s not quite right about the moons of Mars. They are too small — Phobos is 17 miles across, and Deimos is a mere nine miles in length. And they aren’t round, but lumpy, misshaped objects. Frankly, they don’t resemble moons at all.

headline: A Stroke Paralyzed Jesse Malin. Next Month, He’ll Stand Onstage Again.
abstract: The New York rock stalwart suffered a rare spinal stroke at a dinner party last year. His journey back to music has been filled with painful challenges and hope.
lead_paragraph: On a September afternoon in his East Village apartment, Jesse Malin was learning to stand up in front of a microphone. He pressed his right hand on his knee and grabbed a mic stand with his left. A physical therapist stood behind him in case he started to fall. He wore a yellow T-shirt emblazoned with a Lion of Judah, a Rasta symbol that gave him inspiration.

headline: Explore Your Roots: How to Plan a Family Heritage Trip
abstract: Online tools are helping Americans travel abroad to discover their ancestry, seek out relatives and obtain documentation for dual citizenship. Here are tips for your journey.
lead_paragraph: In the second season of the TV show “The White Lotus,” three generations of a fictional American family travel to Sicily to try to reconnect with their ancestral roots. Though their journey goes hilariously wrong at times, heritage trips like theirs have become serious business.

headline: 6 Minutes. 62 People. 1 Epic ‘Sunset Boulevard’ Sequence.
abstract: Down the stairs, out the doors and onto the sidewalk, a Broadway show hits the street. Here’s how they pull it off.
lead_paragraph: A group of young men and women, all dressed in black, marches down a busy street in the heart of Times Square. Walking in formation, they dodge parked cars, bicycles and pedestrians, as the man leading them belts out a song.

headline: The World Chess Champion Could Lose His Title, and It Might Not Be Close
abstract: Chess’s biggest event starts next week. The reigning champion, Ding Liren, is seen as an underdog compared to an 18-year-old competitor.
lead_paragraph: Never has a chess world championship titleholder seemed as vulnerable.

headline: Jon M. Chu Waited 20 Years for the Chance to Direct ‘Wicked’
abstract: He never doubted it would work as a movie. He just hoped he would be the one to film it: “I have my own experiences with being green.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning, Jon M. Chu was in his office in the Toluca Lake neighborhood of Los Angeles, describing what it was like to direct “Defying Gravity,” the thrilling finale of his forthcoming adaptation of “Wicked.” In the Broadway version of the scene, the green-hued Elphaba, a.k.a. the Wicked Witch of the West, rises above the stage atop a huge platform, its mechanical guts hidden behind an enormous black cape. Onstage, the effect is showstopping.

headline: For a Raw Portrait of War, Look to Palestinian Poets
abstract: In their new collections, Mosab Abu Toha and Najwan Darwish share unvarnished views of destruction, displacement and loss.
lead_paragraph: Mosab Abu Toha held his hands six inches apart to demonstrate the flattening of his home in Gaza on Oct. 28, 2023.

headline: Two Picture Books That Set the Table for an Object Lesson
abstract: Sometimes a spoon is just a spoon.
lead_paragraph: The spoon’s best-known role in the annals of children’s literature is as the dish’s paramour. But the spoon can be more than a consort. In Amy Krause Rosenthal’s classic tale of identity crisis, the titular implement has thoughts and feelings. (Spoon wants to be a fork.) It is exceedingly rare, however, for this most well-rounded of utensils to be considered not a character with agency but an object to use — you know, like a spoon. In part that’s because we tend to remake everything in our own image, as if it’s somehow comforting — rather than terrifying — to think of spoons (and sausages and scissors and seeds) as sentient. It’s also infinitely more difficult to craft a narrative around a soulless, spoony spoon: humble, edgeless, concave, mute.

headline: The Complexities of Fighting for Democracy
abstract: “Night Is Not Eternal,” which follows the Cuban activist Rosa María Payá, is the rare nuanced political documentary that is likely to challenge every viewer’s perspective.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve watched a lot of political documentaries, especially those that deal with American politics, I think you’ll agree with me on this: Many, if not most, are overly simplistic. It’s just hard to explain the current social and cultural moment, or adequately chronicle the rise of a controversial figure, in a couple of hours. Most often I find they fall along ideological lines with easy answers, rarely challenging partisan orthodoxies or prodding the viewer into new mental territory.

headline: Let’s End This Turkey Pardoning Nonsense
abstract: President Biden should cancel the Thanksgiving tradition of pardoning a turkey.
lead_paragraph: Someone at the National Turkey Federation once had an idea: Let’s send a live turkey to Harry Truman for a presidential holiday feast! Previously, some individual turkey producers had sent their products to the president to promote them, but the greater resources of the National Turkey Federation meant that the story could be promoted more effectively.

headline: Inside the Deadliest Job in America
abstract: Logging has long been a way of life for rural communities in the Pacific Northwest and South. It also comes with grave risk.
lead_paragraph: Mostly employed in densely forested pockets of the Pacific Northwest and the South, loggers have the highest rate of fatal on-the-job injuries of any civilian occupation in the nation, outpacing roofers, hunters and underground mining machine operators.

headline: $650,000 Homes in Normandy, France
abstract: A renovated thatched-roof cottage, a stone house with a glass pavilion, and a restored 19th-century fisherman’s cottage in Villerville.
lead_paragraph: Made of mud and straw, the thatched roof atop this four-bedroom, one-bathroom cottage is designed to retain heat during winter and to cool the interiors in the summer. The sellers, a couple from the south of France, bought the 1970s house from a French architect who completed an extensive renovation in 2022.

headline: Twists and Turns in Sept. 11 Plea Process Are Agonizing, Families Say
abstract: No matter whether they prefer a trial or swift resolution, relatives of victims of the attacks consider the on-again, off-again plea deal to be cruel.
lead_paragraph: Families of the nearly 3,000 victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks may be divided over whether the man accused of being the mastermind of the plot should someday face a death penalty trial or be allowed to plead guilty in exchange for life in prison.

headline: The Flag That Covered Lincoln’s Coffin Goes Up for Auction
abstract: The Museum of Southern History in Florida is selling the flag, which will be auctioned off by Guernsey’s, along with other Lincoln memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at the flag that covered Abraham Lincoln’s coffin on the funeral train in 1865. It is on the auction block in New York. We’ll also get details on a major housing plan that is now headed for a vote by the full City Council.

headline: Facing 8 Years in Prison, a Director Flees Iran
abstract: Mohammad Rasoulof had to make the most difficult decision of his life.
lead_paragraph: In the early months of 2024, a few weeks into the shooting of his new film, “The Seed of the Sacred Fig,” Mohammad Rasoulof learned that his lawyers received a letter. Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Court had processed his case, composed of several charges against his previous movies and activism, and sentenced him to eight years in prison. Rasoulof asked his lawyers how much time he had before the authorities took him in. The process of filing an appeal, they told him, could take up to two months. He still had some time.

headline: How Saudi Arabia Is Stalling Global Climate Talks
abstract: Despite endorsing a transition away from fossil fuels last year, Saudi Arabia has since worked to undermine it, diplomats say. Lisa Friedman, a New York Times reporter covering climate policy and politics, describes how the opposition is unlike anything climate negotiators say they’ve seen before.
lead_paragraph: Despite endorsing a transition away from fossil fuels last year, Saudi Arabia has since worked to undermine it, diplomats say. Lisa Friedman, a New York Times reporter covering climate policy and politics, describes how the opposition is unlike anything climate negotiators say they’ve seen before.

headline: We Wanted a ‘Grand New Party.’ Trump Delivered.
abstract: Ross Douthat and Reihan Salam had a vision for how Republicans could reclaim the working class. They never expected Trump to fulfill it.
lead_paragraph: On this episode of “Matter of Opinion,” Ross Douthat is joined by his good friend Reihan Salam, a former housemate and co-author and the president of the Manhattan Institute. As young conservatives, the two teamed up in the waning days of the George W. Bush era to write “Grand New Party: How Republicans Can Win the Working Class and Save the American Dream.”

headline: How a Tale of Sean Combs Sex Tapes Landed One Man in Court
abstract: Courtney Burgess, a one-time music industry bit player, said he had videos showing encounters involving celebrities. Prosecutors recently subpoenaed him.
lead_paragraph: In federal court, the music mogul Sean Combs is facing a sweeping indictment that accuses him of running a criminal enterprise that engaged in sex trafficking and racketeering conspiracy.

headline: Trump Gained 95,000 Votes in New York City. Democrats Lost Half a Million.
abstract: In every neighborhood in New York City, from Red Hook in Brooklyn to Riverdale in the Bronx, Vice President Kamala Harris received markedly fewer votes than Joseph R. Biden, Jr., did in 2020, while in most neighborhoods, Donald J. Trump notched modest increases.
lead_paragraph: In every neighborhood in New York City, from Red Hook in Brooklyn to Riverdale in the Bronx, Vice President Kamala Harris received markedly fewer votes than Joseph R. Biden, Jr., did in 2020, while in most neighborhoods, Donald J. Trump notched modest increases.

headline: The High Risk, High Reward Trump Market
abstract: Faced with unconventional and disruptive proposals, investors are figuring out how to place their bets.
lead_paragraph: Markets abhor uncertainty. That bit of Wall Street wisdom helps explain their ebb and flow since Donald J. Trump’s victory on Election Day, and even earlier.

headline: Creating New Cinematic Languages, Without Words
abstract: “Flow” is the latest dialogue-free animated film to look to movement and sound to express its characters’ emotions.
lead_paragraph: Like Noah’s Ark minus the humans, a vessel carrying an odd bunch of creatures is afloat after a flood in the immersive computer-animated film “Flow.” Led by a black cat, the group faces the dangers of nature together, often struggling to get along yet communicating entirely without dialogue.

headline: The Fleeting Comforts of the Celebrity Look-Alike Contest
abstract: The culture-wide search for doubles of famous men is an election-season gift: an apolitical democratic event where — for a brief moment — everybody wins.
lead_paragraph: It may be a coincidence that the celebrity look-alike competition returned to prominence just as American citizens were voting in what some called “the most significant presidential election in our lifetimes.” But once it happened, the appeal was obvious. Here was a different kind of democratic event: a totally insignificant one, in which attractive men with slightly off-kilter features were lined up in public and ranked by the roaring crowd.

headline: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: At a magical university, two witches — Glinda and Elphaba — meet and become unlikely friends in this musical directed by Jon M. Chu, the first installment in a two-part adaptation of the Broadway show.

headline: 6 New Documentaries Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual viewer or certified fan of the genre, our reviewers think these documentaries are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Elizabeth Seed’s mother, Sheila Turner Seed, died when she was 42 and Rachel was 18 months old. In this documentary, she seeks to connect with her mother through her photography.

headline: Liberals Bet They Could Beat Trump With the Law. They Lost.
abstract: A few victories made it easy for Democrats to forget that the law is just another domain of politics where their enemies enjoy power too.
lead_paragraph: The yearslong effort to vanquish Donald Trump in court was a dismal failure.

headline: Why Trump Allies Say Immigration Hurts American Workers
abstract: JD Vance and others on the “new right” say limiting immigration will raise wages and give jobs to sidelined Americans. Many studies suggest otherwise.
lead_paragraph: As President-elect Donald J. Trump’s second administration takes shape, his plans for a signature campaign promise are becoming clear: mass deportations of undocumented immigrants, including new detention centers, workplace raids and possibly the mobilization of the military to aid in expulsions.

headline: This Beer Is Made From Sewage. And at the Climate Summit, That’s OK.
abstract: The hoppy pilsner from Singapore, where freshwater is scarce, is part of an effort to promote recycling solutions.
lead_paragraph: Food and drink, the fuel that keeps negotiators negotiating and reporters reporting, always gets a lot of attention at climate summits.

headline: Will This Poem Find Life in Outer Space?
abstract: Together, NASA and the U.S. poet laureate Ada Limón bring a little bit of humanity to the second moon of Jupiter.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 14, 2024, the Europa Clipper, the largest interplanetary spacecraft NASA has ever built, launched into the cosmos. If all goes according to plan, over five and a half years, the probe, which has no crew, will travel 1.8 billion miles to see if the watery landscape beneath the icy crust of Jupiter’s second moon, Europa, might be conducive to life. In other words, this mission has the potential to change humanity’s understanding of our place in the solar system.

headline: The Tallest Building in Queens Rises in Long Island City
abstract: The Orchard, a rental tower with a dizzying array of luxury amenities, caps a decade of rapid development in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The Orchard is set to be the tallest building in Queens, after topping out at 823 feet this summer. The amenity-rich rental tower in Long Island City is expected to open in early 2026, with 824 units, a third of which will be designated as affordable housing.

headline: What Green, Yellow and Red Flags Do You Look For When It Comes to Dating?
abstract: What behaviors or actions from a potential partner tell you to go ahead, slow down or hit the brakes?
lead_paragraph: Imagine you have started dating someone new. What signs might you see that would tell you to keep going out with this person? What signs would tell you to hit the brakes?

headline: The ‘Landslide’ That Wasn’t: Trump and Allies Pump Up His Narrow Victory
abstract: The latest vote count shows that Donald J. Trump won the popular vote by one of the smallest margins since the 19th century. But Mr. Trump claims a “powerful mandate.”
lead_paragraph: On the night he won a second term, President-elect Donald J. Trump rejoiced in the moment. “America has given us an unprecedented and powerful mandate,” he boasted. In the two and a half weeks since, his campaign has repeatedly heralded his “landslide,” even to market Trump merchandise like the “Official Trump Victory Glass.”

headline: In This House, We’re Angry When Government Fails
abstract: The Democratic Party needs to rethink what it means to be the party of institutions.
lead_paragraph: In any political moment, where the rage collects, where the opposition rallies tells you a lot. Behind Matt Gaetz, the liberals I know have been far angrier about the choice of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to lead the Department of Health and Human Services than any of Donald Trump’s other picks.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Nov. 22, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Will Musk Be the Death of NASA?
abstract: SpaceX is on top right now, and, presumably, Musk wants to keep it that way.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump recently asked Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy to head what he called the Department of Government Efficiency, or DOGE, an unofficial initiative for reducing the size of the federal government. It’s not going to be a real department, but its informal advice could guide the budget-cutters at the White House and in Congress.

headline: This House Democrat Keeps Winning in Trump Country. Here’s What She Knows.
abstract: Lessons from a Democratic winner in Trump country.
lead_paragraph: I first met Marie Gluesenkamp Perez in 2022, when she was running what was widely seen as a long-shot Democratic campaign for Congress in a solidly Republican, heavily rural part of Washington State. Shortly before the election, the polling aggregator FiveThirtyEight estimated her chance of victory at a mere 2 percent. But she won, defeating a burgeoning star of the MAGA movement named Joe Kent.

headline: Trump’s Crown Doesn’t Fit
abstract: The Constitution is not a grant of power for a king.
lead_paragraph: The Constitution is not a grant of power for a king.

headline: How to Avoid Awkward Holiday Conversations
abstract: All you need is 30 seconds to prep.
lead_paragraph: I’m hosting Thanksgiving for my extended family this year, and I want it to be restorative and fun.

headline: ‘This Helps Netanyahu’: Israelis Rally Around Leader Over Warrant, for Now
abstract: An I.C.C. arrest warrant for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the war in Gaza spurred outrage across Israel’s political spectrum. But in the long term, it’s not a good look for a prime minister.
lead_paragraph: The more Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is cast as an international pariah, the more many Israelis appear to embrace him.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1253
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Nov. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 531
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Nov. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Trump’s New Pick for Attorney General, and a Surprise Turn in U.S. Drug Deaths
abstract: Plus, a “Wicked” warning.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Matt Gaetz Calls It Quits
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump’s first pick for attorney general had faced scrutiny after allegations of sexual misconduct and drug use.
lead_paragraph: After just nine days as Donald Trump’s pick for attorney general, Matt Gaetz has withdrawn from consideration.

headline: As Ukraine Fires U.S. Missiles, Putin Sends a Chilling Message
abstract: The Russian leader ominously declares that America risks nuclear war as it expands its aid.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, President Vladimir V. Putin seems to be winning.

headline: Ukraine Cancels Parliament Session, Citing a Warning Over a Missile Attack
abstract: This is the first time Parliament has canceled a session since Russia invaded Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s Parliament canceled a session on Friday over a warning that Russia could target the building in an attack with a missile that Ukraine’s air defenses cannot shoot down, lawmakers said.

headline: Changes in New York City
abstract: How city and state officials are trying to make the city more livable.
lead_paragraph: New York City faces an affordability crisis. Rents have soared. The century-old subway needs to be modernized, and buses are painfully slow. Piles of trash bags often line the sidewalks. The person tasked with fixing these problems, Mayor Eric Adams, faces a major corruption scandal.

headline: Israel Strikes Across Lebanon After Ordering Evacuations of Southern Towns
abstract: The wide-scale bombardment continued a day after a U.S. envoy held talks with Israeli officials on a possible cease-fire with Hezbollah militants.
lead_paragraph: Israel pressed on with its bombardment of Lebanon on Friday after issuing widespread evacuation warnings in the country’s south, as its conflict with Hezbollah militants showed no sign of abating despite a U.S.-led push for a cease-fire.

headline: Russia Supplies Antiaircraft Missiles to North Korea, South Korea Says
abstract: Pyongyang has long coveted an advanced air-defense system to guard against missiles and war planes from the United States and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Russia has supplied North Korea with antiaircraft missiles in return for the deployment of its troops ​to fight in Russia’s war against Ukraine, South Korea’s national security adviser said on Friday.​

headline: Trump’s Next Online Speech Cop + Doctors vs. ChatGPT + Hard Fork Crimes Division
abstract: “I feel very strongly that the First Amendment is under the most direct threat that any of us will ever really experience.”
lead_paragraph: This week, President-elect Donald Trump picked Brendan Carr to be the next chairman of the F.C.C. We talk with The Verge’s editor in chief, Nilay Patel, about what this could mean for the future of the internet, and for free speech at large. Then, a new study found that ChatGPT defeated doctors at diagnosing some diseases. One of the study’s authors, Dr. Adam Rodman, joins us to discuss the future of medicine. And finally, court is back in session. It’s time for the Hard Fork Crimes Division.

headline: A 47-Foot-Long Whale Carcass Captivates an Alaskan City
abstract: Crowds in Anchorage have braved freezing temperatures and slippery ice to see the hulking carcass of a rare fin whale, which washed ashore a few miles from downtown.
lead_paragraph: Sue Heverling wrapped herself in a winter coat, clutched a pair of hiking poles and set out across a frozen mud flat near Anchorage, braving five-degree temperatures and treacherous ice to see the Alaskan city’s newest, and largest, spectacle.

headline: Merkel Memoir Recalls What It Was Like Dealing With Trump and Putin
abstract: The new book by former Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany also aims to justify decisions she made that are still affecting her country and the rest of Europe.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Donald J. Trump’s 2017 inauguration, Angela Merkel, who was then Germany’s chancellor, visited Washington. As the world looked on, the two leaders sat in front of an unlit fireplace, awkwardly and silently waiting for the photographers to do their work.

headline: What Bondi Might Do as Attorney General
abstract: Donald Trump’s new pick to lead the Justice Department fought to overturn the Affordable Care Act, and has lobbied for Amazon, Uber and General Motors.
lead_paragraph: Heads in Washington are still spinning after Donald Trump named Pam Bondi as his choice for attorney general, just hours following Matt Gaetz’s withdrawal from consideration.

headline: Frozen Out: Yelloh, Formerly Schwan’s Home Delivery, Closes
abstract: The frozen food delivery company, known for its yellow trucks, has closed after losing ground to its competitors and renaming itself Yelloh.
lead_paragraph: Yelloh, the frozen food delivery service formerly called Schwan’s Home Delivery, which had once been known for its reach with rural Americans and its direct-to-consumer business model, is closing its doors on Friday after decades of decline.

headline: The New York Times Presents: ‘Weight of the World’
abstract: As GLP-1 medications like Ozempic soar in popularity, our new documentary follows three people on their weight-loss journeys — and explores how decades of diet culture paved the way for the drugs’ rise.
lead_paragraph: Watch our new documentary on FX and Hulu starting Friday, Nov. 22, at 10 p.m. Eastern.

headline: High-Yield Savings Accounts Are Still a Good Deal
abstract: Interest rates have been falling, but deposits are earning more than inflation.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably been discouraged to see the interest rate on your high-yield savings account fall during the past couple of months. But your money is still earning much more than it would in a traditional savings account — and more than inflation.

headline: Guard at U.S. Embassy in Norway Accused of Spying for Russia and Iran
abstract: The Norwegian man was arrested this week in Oslo and ordered jailed pending further investigation in what the authorities called a ‘very serious case.’
lead_paragraph: Authorities in Norway have arrested a Norwegian man who worked as a security guard at the U.S. embassy in Oslo, accusing him of passing sensitive information to Russia and Iran.

headline: Orban Invites Netanyahu to Hungary, Flouting I.C.C. Arrest Warrant
abstract: Hungary, unlike the United States, is a signatory to the court, which accused the Israeli leader of war crimes in Gaza. Responses to the warrant from other European countries were varied.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, Europe’s perennial rule-breaker and a champion of national sovereignty, said on Friday that he had invited Israel’s leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, to visit his country and would ignore an International Criminal Court arrest warrant against the Israeli prime minister.

headline: Behind Schumer’s Silence on Trump’s Picks, a Bid to Spotlight G.O.P. Divides
abstract: The Senate majority leader is staying out of Republican turmoil over the more contentious picks for strategic reasons.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, the New York Democrat and majority leader for a few more weeks, is not known for keeping his thoughts to himself. But he has been uncharacteristically restrained about offering up his views on even the most eyebrow-raising potential Trump administration nominees emanating from Mar-a-Lago.

headline: When Your Living Room Is Also a Gallery
abstract: Tired of the featureless white cube, curators and dealers are staging shows in the most personal spaces of all: their homes.
lead_paragraph: Located on a quiet residential street in North London, the Victorian-era townhouse that was, until his death in 2012, the home and studio of the activist, writer and potter Emmanuel Cooper still bears the name of his business, Fonthill Pottery, above the first-floor windows. Over the course of its 153-year history, the building has also been a butcher shop and a supplier of valves and transistors. Now it’s taking on a new identity: live-in art gallery. On a warm October night during the city’s Frieze Art Fair, the curator Rajan Biljani, 40 — who has owned the property since 2014 — invited 150 guests to his home for the opening of an exhibition showcasing work from South Asian diaspora artists, including Harminder Judge and Vipeksha Gupta, alongside rare furniture pieces by Pierre Jeanneret and Le Corbusier collected from Chandigarh, the Modernist city in India conceived in 1947 by the country’s first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru. “I wanted to share the house and honor the fact that it was an artist’s studio,” says Biljani of his motivation for turning his residence into a by-appointment gallery.

headline: How to Survive Thanksgiving Travel
abstract: The busiest travel period of the year can be daunting, but we’ve got tips to help minimize the stress, at the airport and on the road.
lead_paragraph: Planes, trains, highways, they’re all going to be packed over the Thanksgiving holiday, traditionally one of the busiest periods for travel.

headline: Amazon Invests $4 Billion in Anthropic, Deepening Its A.I. Ties
abstract: Since last September, the tech giant has pumped $8 billion into the artificial intelligence start-up, a sign of intense competition in developing tools that are reshaping the tech sector.
lead_paragraph: Amazon said on Friday that it would invest another $4 billion in Anthropic, a start-up that competes with OpenAI and Google in the increasingly competitive field of artificial intelligence.

headline: Far From the Climate Talks: The Human Cost of Global Warming in 2024
abstract: Every month so far has seen floods, fires, smashed heat records or some combination of extreme weather. Little time remains for leaders to agree on what to do about it.
lead_paragraph: The dissonance is jarring.

headline: What Elon Musk Needs From China
abstract: From electric cars to solar panels, Mr. Musk has built businesses in high-tech manufacturing sectors now targeted by Beijing for Chinese dominance.
lead_paragraph: No American business leader has more visibly and lavishly supported President-elect Donald J. Trump than Elon Musk — and few if any have a more complex relationship with China, a country that Mr. Trump has vowed to confront with higher tariffs and other measures.

headline: Turkey Stock and Pie Crusts and Cranberry Sauce and Shallot Gravy
abstract: And cornbread stuffing with esquites and roasted beets with hazelnuts and honey. Let’s go.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. This is it. We’re in the chute now, inexorably headed toward the Thanksgiving feast. This is a weekend for list-making, for shopping, for firming up travel plans, for pledging that this is the year you’re not going to argue with your sister about nuts in the cranberry sauce.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a heart-wrenching animated Filipino film, a yeasty savior and the return of Carrie-Anne Moss.
lead_paragraph: To communicate, Eric (Carlo Aquino) needs to write: texts on his phone or messages on a dry-erase board he always carries with him. How could he talk? After all, there is a blur where his mouth should be — an effect that is poetically rendered in Carl Joseph Papa’s animated film, which used the rotoscoping technique to trace drawings over its live cast. Not that anybody appears to notice anything amiss with Eric’s face, including his mother, Rosalinda (Dolly De Leon, a Golden Globe nominee for “Triangle of Sadness”), and his sweet co-worker Carlo (Gio Gahol), who may be flirting. In flashbacks told in childlike scrawls, we see Eric being taken by aliens, who turn out to be more inquisitive than hostile. He escapes, but they haunt his memories and likely are the key to his silence.

headline: Covid Can Raise the Risk of Heart Problems for Years
abstract: People who had severe infections are especially vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Since nearly the start of the pandemic, scientists have known that a Covid-19 infection increases the risk of heart problems. A growing body of research now suggests that this risk can last until well after the infection has cleared.

headline: Loathe Thy Neighbor, at Least in These 4 Crime Novels
abstract: Our critic on November’s best new books.
lead_paragraph: I’ve long appreciated the way Burnet’s novels are in conversation with earlier times. “His Bloody Project” and “Case Study,” in particular, mine the postmodern era without pretense and with deep respect. And I harbor a soft spot for his Frenchified crime novels, those initially purported to be written by “Raymond Brunet,” which are in the vein of Georges Simenon’s romans durs and the work of Jean-Patrick Manchette.

headline: A Range of Lessons From Trump’s Victory
abstract: Readers respond to an essay by Roxane Gay. Also: A Republican plan to bar a transgender member from the women’s bathroom; Matt Gaetz; Elon Musk’s cuts.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Carl the Collector’ Puts an Autistic Child (Well, Raccoon) in the Lead
abstract: Several recent TV series for adults have featured autistic lead characters. A new PBS show looks to expand that trend into children’s programming.
lead_paragraph: Carl isn’t unlike many small children you may know. He balks when his mother suggests he get rid of some of his many stuffed animals. If his friends want to play a game that isn’t his favorite, he feels frustrated. And when he realizes he has left one of his prized toy collections away from home, he needs help falling asleep.

headline: Scholars Thought White Women Were Passive Enslavers. They Were Wrong.
abstract: For generations, scholars argued that white women were rarely involved in the active buying and selling of Black people. A growing body of research says otherwise.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Blue States Worry That Blocking Trump Will Be Tougher This Time
abstract: Democrat-led states successfully challenged policies during the first Trump administration. Now, they worry the new White House will be more prepared and less restrained.
lead_paragraph: During the early days of Donald J. Trump’s first presidency, lawyers at the attorney general’s office in Washington State would gather to strategize about what they saw as troubling directives being handed down by the White House.

headline: Bluesky, Smiling at Me
abstract: Bluesky has a hint of the old Twitter magic, but the feeling of freedom it offers might be even better.
lead_paragraph: After an hour or so of scrolling through Bluesky the other night, I felt something I haven’t felt on social media in a long time: free.

headline: M. Jodi Rell, Former Republican Governor of Connecticut, Dies at 78
abstract: She was lieutenant governor when her boss, Gov. John G. Rowland, resigned in a corruption scandal. The second woman to lead the state, she was later elected in her own right.
lead_paragraph: M. Jodi Rell, who was the first and, to date, the only Republican woman to serve as governor of Connecticut, beginning her seven years in office when the incumbent resigned in a corruption scandal, died on Wednesday in Florida. She was 78.

headline: Why Germany’s Economy, Once a Leader in Europe, Is Now in Crisis
abstract: The country is facing a second year of zero growth, with industry leaders gloomy and worried about potential tariffs from President-elect Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: As Germans prepare for a snap election after the collapse of a fragile government coalition, one issue at the top of voters’ minds will be how the new government would revive the country’s once powerful economy at a time when energy prices are high and companies are cutting jobs.

headline: Congestion Pricing Plan Set to Come to New York City on Jan. 5
abstract: The Federal Highway Administration approved the program on Friday, though it could still be stopped by lawsuits. President-elect Donald Trump is also opposed to the plan.
lead_paragraph: Come January, most drivers will pay $9 to enter the heart of Manhattan, after New York City was granted federal approval for a tolling plan, decades in the making, that will be the first of its kind in the nation.

headline: Elon Musk Gets a Crash Course in How Trumpworld Works
abstract: The world’s richest person, not known for his humility, is still learning the cutthroat courtier politics of Donald Trump’s inner circle — and his ultimate influence remains an open question.
lead_paragraph: For the first 53 years of his life, Elon Musk barely spent any time with Donald J. Trump. Then, beginning on the night of Nov. 5, he spent basically no time without him.

headline: Former Building Superintendent Charged With Stealing From Older Tenant
abstract: The super has denied wrongdoing and pleaded not guilty to charges in New York Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A former building superintendent in Manhattan has been charged with stealing more than $350,000 from a 100-year-old tenant who lives in the co-op where she worked.

headline: Slavery’s Ghost Haunts a Booker Prizewinner’s First TV Show
abstract: Marlon James’s new HBO detective series, “Get Millie Black,” draws on Jamaica’s colonial history as well as his family’s experiences.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, the author Marlon James was in London, where he had just won the Booker Prize for his novel “A Brief History of Seven Killings.” Holed away in a hotel room after the ceremony before he flew home to Minneapolis, the characters for a TV show began to take shape.

headline: Trump’s Sentencing in New York Is Officially on Hold
abstract: The judge in the case confirmed that the former and future president, who was convicted on 34 felony counts, would not receive his punishment next week.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge on Friday postponed President-elect Donald J. Trump’s sentencing in his Manhattan criminal case, confirming that the former and future president would not receive his punishment next week.

headline: Some Clonazepam Pills Recalled Over Incorrect Doses on Label, F.D.A. Says
abstract: The drug, known by the brand name Klonopin, is used for panic disorder and seizures.
lead_paragraph: A company that makes clonazepam, a drug commonly prescribed for anxiety and seizures, has expanded its recall of some of the pills after it discovered that they were labeled with the wrong strength, the Food and Drug Administration announced this week.

headline: Terms of Proposed Lebanon Cease-Fire Begin to Take Shape, Officials Say
abstract: Key details still needed to be worked out between Israel and Hezbollah, and disagreements could scuttle or delay any deal, the officials said. But some cited reasons for cautious optimism.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of deadly Israeli airstrikes in Lebanon and punishing combat between Israeli forces and the Hezbollah militant group, the contours of a potential cease-fire agreement appear to be taking shape, according to several regional and U.S. officials briefed on the ongoing diplomacy.

headline: A Moment of Genuine Warmth and Sadness on ‘The Great British Bake Off’
abstract: The current season has one of the most memorable characters of the series.
lead_paragraph: I have been watching “The Great British Bake Off” since it arrived on American shores about 10 years ago as “The Great British Baking Show.” The baking competition was such a staple of my mid-aughts TV routine that my older daughter used to call it “cake channel” when she was in preschool.

headline: In ‘A Man on the Inside,’ Ted Danson Finds Another Good Place
abstract: Created by Michael Schur and starring Danson, this Netflix sitcom synthesizes the most gutting realities of life and death into cozy, low-stakes comedy.
lead_paragraph: “A Man on the Inside,” created by Michael Schur and starring Ted Danson, synthesizes the most gutting realities of life and death into a cozy, low-stakes comedy populated by well-intentioned sweethearts. The show is as gentle and mild as baby soap, though it could hardly promise no tears.

headline: South Africa’s A.N.C. Rejects Jacob Zuma’s Appeal Against His Expulsion
abstract: The country’s governing party had severed ties with the former president in July after he campaigned for an opposition party in the last general election.
lead_paragraph: South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, affirmed its decision to expel its former leader Jacob Zuma on Friday, rejecting his efforts to remain in the party.

headline: Caravaggio Painting, Unseen for Decades, Goes on Display
abstract: A portrait by the artist had a public debut in Rome on Friday, after decades hidden away in a private collection. Now Italy wants to buy it.
lead_paragraph: When Thomas Clement Salomon became the director of Italy’s National Galleries of Ancient Art last January, he lost no time in hatching an ambitious plan: to bring Caravaggio’s “Portrait of Monsignor Maffeo Barberini” on public view.

headline: Kendrick Lamar Releases a Surprise Album, ‘GNX’
abstract: The rapper’s sixth studio album follows the success of a pair of tracks this year that were sparked by a war of words with Drake.
lead_paragraph: Kendrick Lamar, the rapper laureate and one of the music world’s least predictable stars, released a surprise new album, “GNX,” on Friday.

headline: Jonathan Majors Settles Assault and Defamation Lawsuit by Ex-Girlfriend
abstract: Mr. Majors was criminally convicted last year of assaulting and harassing Grace Jabbari, who then sued him in March.
lead_paragraph: The actor Jonathan Majors and his ex-girlfriend Grace Jabbari have settled the assault and defamation lawsuit that she filed against him in March, a lawyer for Ms. Jabbari announced on Friday.

headline: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Strikes as U.S. Pushes for a Cease-Fire
abstract: As U.S. diplomat Amos Hochstein visited the region to push for a ceasefire, Israel struck Beirut’s southern suburbs and the eastern Bekaa region, and a barrage of rockets fired from Lebanon killed a man in northern Israel.
lead_paragraph: As U.S. diplomat Amos Hochstein visited the region to push for a ceasefire, Israel struck Beirut’s southern suburbs and the eastern Bekaa region, and a barrage of rockets fired from Lebanon killed a man in northern Israel.

headline: Bible-Based Lessons for Public Schools Get Final Approval in Texas
abstract: The state’s board of education narrowly voted to allow schools to start using the reading and language arts curriculum next fall if they choose.
lead_paragraph: Texas education officials on Friday approved a new elementary school curriculum that draws from the Bible, the final step of a contentious effort to expand religious instruction in the state.

headline: Alcohol Deaths Have More Than Doubled in Two Decades, Study Finds
abstract: Americans are dying of illnesses related to alcohol at roughly twice the rate seen in 1999.
lead_paragraph: The number of deaths caused by alcohol-related diseases more than doubled among Americans between 1999 and 2020, according to new research. Alcohol was involved in nearly 50,000 deaths among adults ages 25 to 85 in 2020, up from just under 20,000 in 1999.

headline: Jack Harlow Expands His Romantic Options, and 7 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Horsegirl, Tyla, Amber Mark and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: DirecTV Calls Off Plans to Acquire Dish Network
abstract: The deal, which would have created one of the largest pay-TV providers in the United States, fell apart after strong objections from Dish’s lenders.
lead_paragraph: A second attempt at a major media deal seems to be heading in the same direction it did the first time around — in failure.

headline: The Post-Cold War Era Is Finished. Liberalism and Democracy Will Go On.
abstract: A new world order doesn’t mean the old politics simply disappears.
lead_paragraph: My column last weekend made some pretty sweeping historical claims: that the re-election of Donald Trump proved that we have definitively exited the post-Cold War era, that the phase of history that began in 1989 terminated somewhere in between the early days of the pandemic and Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, that wherever we are going now we are definitely going, not just paddling in circles or in place.

headline: A Playlist That’s as Cool as Kim Deal
abstract: Hear tracks from her first solo album, the Breeders, Pixies and more.
lead_paragraph: Today marks an occasion four decades in the making: the indie-rock icon Kim Deal, at age 63, is releasing her first ever solo album, a collection of woozy pop ballads and distorted rockers titled “Nobody Loves You More.”

headline: 4 Fantasy Books to Get Lost In
abstract: There are few pleasures as delicious as losing yourself in a great fantasy book. Jennifer Harlan, an editor at The New York Times Book Review, lists a few of her favorite fantasy books.
lead_paragraph: There are few pleasures as delicious as losing yourself in a great fantasy book. Jennifer Harlan, an editor at The New York Times Book Review, lists a few of her favorite fantasy books.

headline: Is Kim Kardashian Trying to Tell Us Something?
abstract: She parties with Ivanka Trump and has turned Tesla products into fashion accessories on social media. Assuming these are political statements may be incorrect.
lead_paragraph: Has Kim Kardashian gone MAGA?

headline: Is It Possible the Democrats Were Hurt by a Strong Economy?
abstract: An interesting theory about the election that’s the opposite of what you’ve heard.
lead_paragraph: There’s an intriguing theory that the presidential bid of Vice President Kamala Harris was hurt by the performance of the U.S. economy — not because it was too weak, but because it was too strong. I can’t figure out whether I buy it, but it’s definitely worth a think.

headline: A Prominent Figure in Canada’s Trucker Protests Is Found Guilty
abstract: The verdict was in the high-profile case of Pat King, a man accused of helping provoke disruptions during the so-called trucker convoy, which paralyzed Canada’s capital during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Through his social media influence and his many videos, Pat King rose to become one of the most prominent figures in protests that paralyzed Canada’s capital for over a month, contesting coronavirus restrictions.

headline: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’
abstract: Gabriel García Márquez’s classic novel about the rise and fall of a rural Colombian village as seen through generations of its founding family remains the leading exemplar of magical realism.
lead_paragraph: It begins with one of the most iconic lines in literature: “Many years later, as he faced the firing squad, Colonel Aureliano Buendía was to remember that distant afternoon when his father took him to discover ice.”

headline: Easy Whiskey Drinks for a Relaxed Thanksgiving
abstract: These simple cocktails call for a few simple ingredients — shaker optional.
lead_paragraph: The distance from no Thanksgiving cocktail to Thanksgiving cocktail should be short: bottle to glass to hand. But unless you’re aiming to pour rounds of liquor directly on the rocks and call it a holiday, you’ll want to find inspiration in three-ingredient classics.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, Nov. 23, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Why You May Be Wrong About Harris’s Loss
abstract: We won’t have enough data to tell the full story of the election for some time. But there are a few things we can say for sure now.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election was two weeks ago, and the country’s liberals are already deep into the blame phase. Though we don’t yet have accurate data about how various demographic groups voted and won’t for months, we’ve entered a preliminary round of explanations and recriminations — a menu of lessons to learn about and adjustments to make to the ideology, worldview and strategy of liberals, which, if history is any guide, will both prove hugely influential and probably, in big ways, wrong. Before those premature post-mortems get fully baked into conventional wisdom, though, I wanted to flag a handful of observations about the race and how it’s already being interpreted — some caveats, some counterpoints, some context that may help us understand the meaning of a big messy election in a big messy country, at least until we get the actually reliable voter data.

headline: My Mom Voted for Trump. Can We Let It Go?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how a family might proceed in the wake of a momentous presidential election.
lead_paragraph: My mother, a two-time Trump voter in Florida, has moved closer to us in a safely blue state. While I don’t know what her vote was in the 2024 presidential election, it wouldn’t have affected the outcome. I strongly oppose Trump, as do my wife and her family, who live nearby. I’m troubled by my mother’s support of someone I consider morally abhorrent and dangerous, especially when she voted in a former swing state.

headline: Do Hair Growth Supplements Work?
abstract: The internet is awash with advertisements for hair growth supplements promising dramatic results. Do they actually work? Julia Calderone of Well, the personal health news section of The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: The internet is awash with advertisements for hair growth supplements promising dramatic results. Do they actually work? Julia Calderone of Well, the personal health news section of The New York Times, explains.

headline: Heavy Rains and Wind Wreak Havoc on the West Coast
abstract: A series of atmospheric rivers has caused flooding and damage in the Pacific Northwest and Northern California, knocking out power for hundreds of thousands of people.
lead_paragraph: A series of atmospheric rivers has caused flooding and damage in the Pacific Northwest and Northern California, knocking out power for hundreds of thousands of people.

headline: The Lady Jaguars
abstract: The New York Times first reported on a winless basketball team of troubled teens in Tennessee in 2012. Explore our years of coverage here.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times first reported on a winless basketball team of troubled teens in Tennessee in 2012. Explore our years of coverage here.

headline: Stabbing Suspect’s Descent Into Madness Went Undetected by Authorities
abstract: Ramon Rivera, who had a history of mental illness and minor crimes, missed a check-in with a case manager. Days later, he went on a killing spree in Manhattan, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 11, a 51-year-old homeless man named Ramon Rivera who had been charged with stealing a $1,500 acrylic bowl from a fancy furniture store in Manhattan had a court-ordered appointment scheduled with his case manager.

headline: Sean Combs Will Remain Jailed Until Judge Rules on Third Bail Request
abstract: A federal judge is still weighing the music mogul's arguments that he should be freed while awaiting trial on sex trafficking and racketeering charges.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the embattled music mogul who has been charged with sex trafficking and racketeering, will remain in jail after a federal judge on Friday said he would continue to weigh arguments about Mr. Combs’s release.

headline: Kennedy Doesn’t Like Ozempic. Here’s What He Can Do About It.
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump is set to nominate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to lead the Health and Human Services Department, where he would have limited power over drugs.
lead_paragraph: Ozempic? Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is not a fan.

headline: A Difficult Few Days for Bolsonaro’s Right-Wing Movement
abstract: Accusations that former far-right President Jair Bolsonaro plotted a coup arose after a former top aide of his was implicated in a plan to kill the current president.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s far-right movement and its leader, former President Jair Bolsonaro, have had a challenging few days.

headline: Lottery to Be Held for Coveted Seats at Menendez Brothers Hearing
abstract: The court is expecting high demand and has announced a public lottery for a limited number of seats at a status hearing in Los Angeles on Monday.
lead_paragraph: What’s one of the most exclusive tickets in Los Angeles? It may not be what you think.

headline: Powerful Storm Soaks the Bay Area After Flooding Wine Country
abstract: An atmospheric river that has brought damaging wind, rain and snow to the Pacific Northwest fed a storm spreading as far south as Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: A gusty storm drawing torrents of moisture from the Pacific Ocean parked itself on Friday over the San Francisco Bay Area, flooding highways and toppling power lines. Officials warned the region’s nearly eight million residents to be ready for possible floods, landslides and widespread outages.

headline: Clear Eyes. Foam Head. Can’t Lose.
abstract: The New York Times for Kids goes inside the sweaty, funny, heartfelt world of high school mascots.
lead_paragraph: Mackenzie Barnes has been a cheerleader since she was 10, so she’s used to being in front of crowds and getting fans excited for games. But last year, when Mackenzie, who is 15, became the mascot for her high school in Lancaster, Ohio, the job of making people cheer took on a new twist. Now, people are yelling her name.

headline: Conor McGregor, U.F.C. Fighter, Is Held Liable for Sexual Assault in Ireland
abstract: The mixed martial arts fighter known as “Notorious” was ordered to pay the equivalent of about $260,000 to a woman who said he raped her in 2018.
lead_paragraph: A woman who had accused the mixed martial arts fighter Conor McGregor of raping her in a hotel penthouse in 2018 was awarded nearly 250,000 euros, or about $260,000, in damages on Friday after a jury found him liable for sexual assault in a civil trial in Dublin.

headline: E.P.A. Proposes Limits on Harmful Pollutant From Power Plants
abstract: Nitrogen oxides, a group of gases from the burning of fossil fuels, is linked to a range of health effects.
lead_paragraph: A rule proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency on Friday could better protect communities against pollution from natural gas plants.

headline: Harold W. Sims Jr., Whose Museum Honored the House Cat, Dies at 89
abstract: He displayed some 10,000 cat-themed artifacts at the American Museum of the House Cat in North Carolina, which welcomed several thousand people a year.
lead_paragraph: Harold W. Sims Jr., a fanatic for all things feline who poured his life savings into his own no-kill animal shelter and then took his passion a step further by founding the American Museum of the House Cat — which displays some 10,000 cat-themed artifacts, including antique windup tabbies and an ancient Egyptian cat mummy — died on Nov. 17 in Sylva, N.C. He was 89.

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Fresh Challenge to Agency Power
abstract: A conservative group argues that Congress gave the Federal Communications Commission too much discretion over an $8 billion fund.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, which dealt a major blow to the power of federal agencies in June, agreed on Friday to consider another: whether Congress violates the Constitution by delegating broad discretion to them.

headline: Mike Shatzkin, Colorful Publishing Industry Guru, Dies at 77
abstract: His blog, The Shatzkin Files, was an essential read for industry insiders. His observations about the changes digital publishing would bring were prophetic.
lead_paragraph: Mike Shatzkin, a charismatic publishing consultant who counseled industry figures on nearly every facet of the trade, from inventory management to supply-chain quandaries to the seismic paper-to-digital transformation of book selling, died on Nov. 7 in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: The New Pick for Attorney General
abstract: Also, New York’s congestion tolls were approved. Here's the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: Pam Bondi, who Donald Trump tapped last night for attorney general after former Representative Matt Gaetz dropped his bid, is arriving on the national stage with a smaller profile and less political baggage than Gaetz.

headline: What to Know About the Methanol Poisonings in Laos
abstract: At least six tourists who traveled to Laos have died in recent days, prompting international alarm about the dangers of consuming alcoholic drinks that contain methanol.
lead_paragraph: Officials in several countries are warning of the dangers of consuming alcoholic drinks that contain methanol after at least six tourists who had traveled to Laos died.

headline: Trump Taps Investor Scott Bessent as Treasury Secretary
abstract: The hedge fund manager will be responsible for steering President-elect Donald J. Trump’s unconventional economic agenda.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump picked Scott Bessent to serve as Treasury secretary on Friday, tapping a billionaire hedge fund manager to lead an economic agenda that is expected to be built around raising tariffs and cutting taxes.

headline: Ex-Treasurer in Arizona Pleads Guilty to Embezzling $38 Million
abstract: A former elected official for a small county used public money to renovate her ranch and buy at least 20 vehicles, including Cadillacs and an Airstream travel trailer, the Justice Department said.
lead_paragraph: As the elected treasurer in Santa Cruz County, Ariz., for more than a decade, Elizabeth Gutfahr’s job was to safeguard public funds for one of the state’s smallest counties.

headline: Republicans Blocking Proposal to Narrow Part of a Surveillance Law
abstract: The second Trump administration appears likely to inherit broader powers to force American service providers to help a warrantless wiretapping program.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans are blocking a proposal that would narrow a disputed new provision in a surveillance law, potentially handing President-elect Donald J. Trump broader power to force myriad types of American service providers to help the government spy.

headline: Matt Gaetz and the D-word
abstract: The former representative from Florida said he had become a “distraction.” Perhaps that was the point.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a story that could unfold only on the eve of a second Trump era: A congressman, embattled by allegations of sex-trafficking a minor, was chosen to run the Department of Justice, the same agency that had once investigated him.

headline: Iran Declares It Is Doing More Nuclear Enrichment After I.A.E.A. Rebuke
abstract: With thousands of advanced centrifuges on standby, Tehran says it is now spinning more, which could increase its stockpile of near-bomb-grade atomic fuel.
lead_paragraph: Iran said Friday it would begin operating new machines to enrich more uranium, which could bring it closer to having a weapon. The move came in response to a censure by the International Atomic Energy Agency for failing to cooperate fully with atomic inspectors.

headline: Pam Bondi, a $25,000 Donation and Trump University: Questions Remain
abstract: While Ms. Bondi, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for attorney general, served as attorney general of Florida, her office declined to investigate allegations of fraud against his for-profit school.
lead_paragraph: Reports of deceptive practices and fraud by Donald J. Trump and his Trump University business unit had been piling up for several years in states across the nation, including in Florida.

headline: Trump Picks Key Figure in Project 2025 for Powerful Budget Role
abstract: Russell Vought, who would lead the Office of Management and Budget, has spent years building plans to rework the American structure of government in ways that would enhance presidential power.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Friday picked a key figure in Project 2025 to lead the Office of Management and Budget, elevating a longtime ally who has spent the last four years making plans to rework the American government to enhance presidential power.

headline: Penny Trial Defense Shifts Focus From Choke to Sickle Cell and Drug Use
abstract: Lawyers for Daniel Penny, who is accused of choking Jordan Neely to death, called an expert who argued that a combination of factors led to Mr. Neely’s death.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Neely, a Black man who died after he was choked in a subway car last year, had the sickle cell trait, a genetic condition that can affect blood cells and overwhelmingly occurs in Black people. Whether Mr. Neely knew that he had the trait is unclear. But since his death, it has become a point of contention for lawyers.

headline: ‘Glicked’ Fans Rejoice in Bloodshed and Broadway Songs
abstract: “Wicked” and “Gladiator II,” which opened on Friday, drew moviegoers who attended a double feature that emulated the rage over “Barbenheimer” last year.
lead_paragraph: Swords clashing and blood curdling screams of gladiators emanate from one room. Across the hallway, witches belt out show tunes.

headline: Dr. Martin Makary Chosen to Head the F.D.A.
abstract: A frequent Fox News commentator, Dr. Makary has a penchant for challenging the medical establishment, and stirred pandemic concerns with his views on Covid immunity and vaccine mandates.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Friday that he would nominate Dr. Martin A. Makary, a Johns Hopkins University surgeon with a contrarian streak, to be commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: Florida’s Top Health Official Urges an End to Putting Fluoride in Water
abstract: The recommendation followed similar pushes from Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s surgeon general issued guidance on Friday that called for a halt to adding fluoride to the water supply, backing a similar push by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline: Emerging Details of Chinese Hack Leave U.S. Officials Increasingly Concerned
abstract: Leaders of the big telecommunications companies were summoned to the White House to discuss strategies for overhauling the security of the nation’s telecommunications networks amid growing alarm at the scope of a Chinese hack.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the top telecommunications companies were summoned to the White House on Friday to discuss a security problem that has been roiling the government: how to expel Chinese hackers from the deepest corners of the nation’s communications networks.

headline: Israel Is Not an I.C.C. Member. How Can the Court Prosecute Israeli Leaders?
abstract: The jurisdiction of the court in The Hague can extend beyond member states.
lead_paragraph: The arrest warrants issued this week by the International Criminal Court for leaders of Israel and Hamas, for crimes it accuses them of committing in Gaza, offer important insights into both the extent of the court’s jurisdiction and the limits of its power.

headline: Labor Secretary Pick Is Rep. Lori Chavez-DeRemer of Oregon
abstract: A moderate from a swing district, she received endorsements from several unions but narrowly lost her bid for a second House term.
lead_paragraph: Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a first-term Republican representative from Oregon who narrowly lost her House seat this month, was chosen on Friday to serve as labor secretary in the coming Trump administration.

headline: Trump Chooses Dr. David Weldon, a Former Congressman, to Lead the C.D.C.
abstract: In selecting a doctor who is skeptical of vaccine safety, the president-elect is emphasizing his commitment to reforming the role of federal health agencies in radical ways.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump chose Dr. David Weldon, a former congressman, on Friday to serve as the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Reacts Like a Superfan
abstract: Ryan McCarty’s themeless puzzle is a crowd-pleaser.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Ryan McCarty is in a group of constructors whose work almost always appears on Saturdays: This is his 24th such grid, and his fifth in a row. Mr. McCarty also specializes in variations on the chunky pattern we have here, which is challenging to solve because its dense patches are connected only by an entry or two. You can be grooving nicely on one corner, thinking it’s a walk in the park, and next thing you’re stranded on an island of empty squares without a helpful crossing entry in sight.

headline: Alice Brock, Restaurant Owner Made Famous by a Song, Dies at 83
abstract: Arlo Guthrie’s antiwar staple “Alice’s Restaurant” was inspired by a Thanksgiving Day visit to her diner in western Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: Alice Brock, whose eatery in western Massachusetts was immortalized as the place where “you can get anything you want” in Arlo Guthrie’s 1967 antiwar song “Alice’s Restaurant,” died on Thursday in Wellfleet, Mass. — just a week before Thanksgiving, the holiday during which the rambling story at the center of the song takes place. She was 83.

headline: Sebastian Gorka to Return to White House as Adviser
abstract: In a statement, Donald J. Trump lauded the firebrand conservative commentator as a “tireless advocate” for his agenda. There was no mention that Mr. Gorka had been forced out of the Trump administration in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Gorka, the firebrand conservative commentator who worked in the White House briefly in President-elect Donald J. Trump’s first term, was named by Mr. Trump on Friday to a senior advisory position.

headline: Why the Rain Won’t End the Drought in the Northeast
abstract: Hundreds of brush fires and wildfires have sparked all over the New York City region. Hilary Howard, who covers climate change and the environment in the region, explains what’s happening.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of brush fires and wildfires have sparked all over the New York City region. Hilary Howard, who covers climate change and the environment in the region, explains what’s happening.

headline: Trump Picks Scott Turner, Little-Known Official From First Term, to Lead HUD
abstract: The housing agency plays a central role in addressing the growing national affordability crisis.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has chosen Scott Turner, a little-known former pro football player and motivational speaker, to lead the Department of Housing and Urban Development, an agency that plays a central role in addressing the growing national affordability crisis.

headline: Ex-N.Y.P.D. Officer Convicted of Sex Offenses Involving 4 Underage Boys
abstract: Christopher Terranova, a former officer from Staten Island, was accused of preying on teenage boys on Snapchat, including one whom he met when the child reported a robbery.
