lead_paragraph: A former New York City police officer was convicted on Friday of sex offenses involving four underage boys, including a robbery victim whom he befriended and then preyed on over Snapchat by sending him an explicit photo and asking for one in return.

headline: A Lesson From Poland: Reversing Populist Policies Is Tough
abstract: The country’s new leaders are trying to undo changes, like abortion restrictions and politicized courts, made by their hard-right predecessors. It “takes longer than you expect,” one minister said.
lead_paragraph: He promised salvation for a country “in ruins” — an end to immigration, a civil service stripped of entrenched left-wing opponents, a judiciary purged of meddlesome judges and a news media giving voice to the people instead of elites.

headline: Cash, Kidnappings and Luxury Resorts: A Formula for Power in Modi’s India
abstract: With a tactic known as “resort politics,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party has been accused of using brute force to take over Indian state governments.
lead_paragraph: The lawmakers had finished a routine assembly vote and were scattering into the Mumbai night.

headline: 55 Days Into Hunger Strike, Activist’s Mother Says She ‘Won’t Back Down’
abstract: Laila Soueif, the British-born mother of the Egyptian political prisoner Alaa Abd El Fattah, is demanding the U.K. do more to secure his release.
lead_paragraph: After a few days without food, the hunger stops. The body, while weak, “learns how to just function.” That is how Laila Soueif, an Egyptian mathematician and professor, describes her hunger strike, which reached 55 days on Saturday.

headline: Quote of the Day: Nothing Short of Perfection Will Do
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I could argue that I’m having more of an impact on people here than I could have anywhere else. But personally — personally — I want to go play for a national championship.”

headline: As Threat of Trump Tariffs Looms, Europe’s Leaders Seek Greater Unity
abstract: At a conference in Paris, corporate chiefs, finance ministers and top politicians called for a “Europe First” policy to counter Donald Trump’s protectionist agenda.
lead_paragraph: For months, European business leaders have watched as Donald J. Trump paved a path back to the White House by doubling down on an “America First” economic policy, putting protectionism and business-friendly tax and regulatory pledges high on the agenda.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 23, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 10 about late-night host Johnny Carson incorrectly quoted part of a line from a famous Johnny Carson quip. The joke goes, “Half the marriages end in divorce — and then there are the unhappy ones,” not “and then there are the happy ones.”

headline: Trump Chooses New York Doctor to Be Next U.S. Surgeon General
abstract: Dr. Janette Nesheiwat is a medical director for a chain of urgent care clinics. Her sister served as an adviser in the first Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Friday selected Dr. Janette Nesheiwat, a New York medical director with family ties to his first administration and a Fox News contributor, to be the next surgeon general of the United States.

headline: One Dead in U.S. Listeria Outbreak Tied to Ready-to-Eat Meat and Poultry
abstract: Officials have linked 11 listeria cases since October 2021 to items from Yu Shang Food, which is recalling more than 72,000 pounds of products.
lead_paragraph: A baby died and at least 10 other people in four states fell ill in an outbreak of listeria tied to ready-to-eat meat and poultry products sold by Yu Shang Food, federal health officials said on Friday, as the company recalled more than 72,000 pounds of items.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How a Pop Pianist Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Chloe Flower, who performed with Cardi B at the Grammy Awards, indulges in luxury shopping, a foot massage and three-hour dinners with loved ones on her “me” day.
lead_paragraph: Chloe Flower first came to New York City when she was 12. She was with her parents, and she had one question for them: “Why didn’t you bring me sooner?”

headline: Can the Gilgo Beach Suspect’s House Become a ‘Nice Starter Home’?
abstract: Asa Ellerup, who is married to Rex Heuermann, the defendant in the Gilgo Beach murders, stuck it out despite destructive searches and gawkers. Now she is selling and heading to South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Neighbors breathed a sigh of relief this week when an empty shipping container appeared outside the dilapidated red house in Massapequa Park that has become known as the home of the accused Long Island serial killer.

headline: Dining Sheds Changed the N.Y.C. Food Scene. Now Watch Them Disappear.
abstract: Street side sheds and shanties helped keep restaurants afloat during the worst of the coronavirus pandemic. Now, for better or worse, new city rules are forcing their removal.
lead_paragraph: Street side sheds and shanties helped keep restaurants afloat during the worst of the coronavirus pandemic. Now, for better or worse, new city rules are forcing their removal.

headline: F.B.I. Agents Investigate Use of Fake Donors in N.Y. Assembly Race
abstract: The inquiry follows a New York Times report questioning the validity of more than $162,000 in matching funds given to Dao Yin, a Democrat of Queens.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have opened a criminal investigation of Dao Yin, a recent New York State Assembly candidate suspected of using fake donors and forged signatures to artificially inflate his allotment of matching funds, according to several people familiar with the matter.

headline: Israeli Strike in the Heart of Beirut Kills at Least 20
abstract: Israel was targeting a senior Hezbollah commander, but failed to kill him, one Israeli official said. Hezbollah officials said none of the group’s leaders were at the attack site.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike on a residential building in central Beirut killed at least 20 people on Saturday, the Lebanese Health Ministry said, part of an intensifying Israeli military campaign that appears aimed at pressuring Hezbollah into a cease-fire deal.

headline: How to Focus Like Your Life Depends on It
abstract: To become more effective at any task, borrow from a Formula 1 driver’s mental tool kit.
lead_paragraph: Most of us don’t require F1-level focus to get through our days. But we all struggle with distraction — and the techniques that drivers use to optimize their performance can help anyone to be more intentional and effective in all sorts of situations. We asked McLaren Formula 1 team driver Oscar Piastri (that’s him, in the video above), along with a sports psychologist and an attention expert, for tricks to stay on track.

headline: An ‘Enhanced’ Version of the Olympics May Happen. Should It?
abstract: With a controversial plan to allow doping in a major athletic competition, Aron D’Souza hopes to usher in an era of “superhumans.” There are several hurdles left to clear.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning this fall, Aron D’Souza was at home in London expecting a long-anticipated delivery: a vintage set of the “Great Books of the Western World,” a collection with over 50 volumes of philosophy, history and literature published in the 1950s by Encyclopaedia Britannica, including “Faust,” Freud’s “On Narcissism” and “The Hippocratic Oath.”

headline: How Brunch Came to a Backyard Farm in Compton
abstract: It was once a vacant, weedy lot next to a school. Now, it provides fresh produce and a twice-monthly meal to customers.
lead_paragraph: On the first and third Sunday of every month, Alma Backyard Farms hosts brunch. Long, elegant folding tables are set up between raised beds packed with dinosaur kale, collards and beans. Butterflies weave around sage.

headline: Trump’s Trade Agenda Could Benefit Friends and Punish Rivals
abstract: Donald Trump has a record of pardoning favored companies from tariffs. Companies are once again lining up to try to influence him.
lead_paragraph: The sweeping tariffs that President-elect Donald J. Trump imposed in his first term on foreign metals, machinery, clothing and other products were intended to have maximum impact around the world. They sought to shutter foreign factories, rework international supply chains and force companies to make big investments in the United States.

headline: Want a Diamond? You’ll Need to Decide on Lab-Grown or Natural.
abstract: Consumer misconceptions about diamonds can make the process of engagement ring shopping even more distressing.
lead_paragraph: With Thanksgiving marking the unofficial start of engagement season — late November through Valentine’s Day is when marriage proposals are common — ring buying is top of mind for many couples considering marriage.

headline: They Investigated Pandemic Fraud, Then Earned Thousands
abstract: Some private citizens are hunting for potential cases of fraud tied to small-business loans. They have earned big payouts — in some cases, more than $1 million.
lead_paragraph: When J. Bryan Quesenberry first learned that the federal government was sending out hundreds of billions of dollars to help businesses survive during the Covid-19 pandemic, he thought: “There’s going to be fraud here. There just has to be.”

headline: Lucy Liu Thinks It’s Important to Make a Mess Sometimes
abstract: “That’s how creative things happen,” said the actress, one of the stars of the holiday film “Red One.”
lead_paragraph: Lucy Liu’s 9-year-old son, Rockwell, hasn’t seen his mother draw blood in “Charlie’s Angels” or “Shazam! Fury of the Gods” and certainly not in “Kill Bill, Vol. 1.”

headline: Stratford-Upon-Lake-Michigan: Royal Shakespeare Company Plays Chicago
abstract: With less touring, it’s been a while since all the world has been its stage, but the troupe is working with the Chicago Shakespeare Theater — where it has family ties.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Shakespeare Company, which keeps the plays of William Shakespeare alive in the town of his birth, was long a regular presence in the United States. It brought Ian McKellen to Brooklyn as King Lear, built a replica of its main theater in an Upper East Side drill hall and sent a stream of shows to Broadway.

headline: I’m Ending My Lease Early and Found the Landlord a New Tenant. Can He Refuse?
abstract: State housing laws favor tenant protection, so landlords want to make sure that a new tenant will meet the lease obligations.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m moving out of my rent-stabilized apartment in Brooklyn and I provided my landlord with a suitable replacement, a friend of a friend who needs a new place after ending a relationship. When I told my landlord that I needed to end my lease early and that I had a replacement for him, he responded that it would be fine as long as she worked with his broker. His broker is charging a large fee and asking for a guarantor that makes 80 times the rent. Is 80 times the rent typical? And why would she have to pay a broker’s fee here?

headline: The French Philosopher Whose Romantic Theory of Time Was All the Rage
abstract: Henri Bergson enjoyed a cult following on both sides of the Atlantic in the early 20th century. A new biography explains what the fuss was about.
lead_paragraph: In the second decade of the last century, The New York Times could not stop writing about Henri Bergson, whom it called “the favorite philosopher of the salons.” There was a gushing interview from Paris, in which the great man explained “his wonderful philosophy of the ‘vital impulse’ working in and through matter.” There were reviews of books by him and about him. A cable from Rome relayed the pope’s condemnation of his “poisonous” errors. A report from uptown counted over a thousand guests at a tea party in his honor at Columbia University. And when Bergson tried to slip quietly into the country in 1917, that, too, was headline news: “French Philosopher Comes on the Liner New York Unheralded.”

headline: Chasing the Perfect Photograph in Amish Country
abstract: In his mission to document the earth’s food supply, George Steinmetz recovers the human element in aerial photography — and in farming. Ahead of his new book, he brings our critic into the field.
lead_paragraph: In his mug shot, the photographer George Steinmetz doesn’t seem especially threatening. It captures some of the inquisitive humanity that Steinmetz, a tall and direct people’s person with a John Malkovich mien, conveys in life.

headline: The Surprising Impact of North Carolina’s New Voter ID Law
abstract: After a decade of battles over voter ID, the law that finally went into effect landed with a whimper, not a bang.
lead_paragraph: After more than a decade of court battles and legislative jousting over voting rules, North Carolina this month held its first general election under its new voter ID law.

headline: Hezbollah Believed to Be Using Copy of Israeli Missile Against Israel
abstract: The Lebanese militant group captured an advanced Israeli anti-tank missile in the 2006 war, and its ally, Iran, reverse-engineered it, Israeli officials say.
lead_paragraph: The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah has been using an advanced missile against Israel that was reverse-engineered from an Israeli weapon it captured in a past war, according to Israeli defense officials.

headline: She Faked a Religious Conversion to Escape Terrorists
abstract: After being abducted by an offshoot of Boko Haram in Nigeria six years ago, a Christian nurse describes her daring escape and how faith kept her alive.
lead_paragraph: For more than six years, Alice Loksha Ngaddah bided her time, waiting for an opportunity to escape her abductors.

headline: Election Forecasts Try to Go Beyond the Polls. Are They Helping?
abstract: The forecasts, like those from Decision Desk HQ, Nate Silver and 538, are now ubiquitous, but their accuracy is hard to measure.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Nate Silver’s election forecast model was so novel — and accurate — that it landed him on Time magazine’s list of the 100 most influential people the next year.

headline: The Supervillain Is the Hero Now
abstract: How Americans learned to root for the dark side — from the Joker and “Wicked” to Elon Musk.
lead_paragraph: On Election Day, Elon Musk posted a video on X, his social media platform, presenting himself as an avatar of “Dark MAGA.” A blizzard of pop-culture memes evoking anime, comic books and action movies, the two-minute supercut bristles with a familiar chaotic energy. Donald Trump, in his trademark blue suit and red tie, strides across the frame in broad daylight, while Musk, in a black cap and T-shirt, cuts a gleefully diabolical figure. To date, the video has garnered 91.4 million views.

headline: Can Disney Cut Into Netflix’s Stand-Up Comedy Dominance?
abstract: Under the Hulu banner, the company says it will offer quality over quantity while largely avoiding controversy. Many comedians are ready to give it a shot.
lead_paragraph: Spend some time in the comedy world and you will hear complaints about Netflix, which has established itself as the most important home for stand-up for nearly a decade.

headline: Hundreds More Nazca Lines Emerge in Peru’s Desert
abstract: With drones and A.I., researchers managed to double the number of mysterious geoglyphs in a matter of months.
lead_paragraph: Gouged into a barren stretch of pampa in southern Peru, the Nazca Lines are one of archaeology’s most perplexing mysteries. On the floor of the coastal desert, the shallow markings look like simple furrows. But from the air, hundreds of feet up, they morph into trapezoids, spirals and zigzags in some locations, and stylized hummingbirds and spiders in others. There is even a cat with the tail of a fish. Thousands of lines jump cliffs and traverse ravines without changing course; the longest is bullet-straight and extends for more than 15 miles.

headline: What Trump’s Cabinet Picks Tell Us About His Second Term
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump is filling key cabinet positions with controversial picks at a breakneck speed. Jonathan Swan, senior political correspondent at The Times, explains why these choices are significant, even if they don’t all make it into office.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump is filling key cabinet positions with controversial picks at a breakneck speed. Jonathan Swan, senior political correspondent at The Times, explains why these choices are significant, even if they don’t all make it into office.

headline: Republicans Ponder: What if the Trump Tax Cuts Cost Nothing?
abstract: Some in the party are considering alternative ways of assessing the federal budget as they prepare to extend temporary tax cuts passed in 2017.
lead_paragraph: What counts as a tax cut?

headline: Trump Promised to Halve Energy Costs in 18 Months. Experts Have Doubts.
abstract: A president has little control over global oil markets, economists say.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump repeatedly promised voters that he would cut energy and electricity prices in half within 18 months of taking office.

headline: I Tested the Latest FAFSA. It Works Fine. Don’t Celebrate Yet.
abstract: The rollout of the new student aid form last year was a debacle. This year’s beta testing has gone better. Next up: millions of users and a new administration.
lead_paragraph: Last year, in a fit of masochism, I tried to become the first person in the United States to fill out a FAFSA (short for Free Application for Federal Student Aid) form at the precise moment the Department of Education unveiled a long-delayed overhaul.

headline: On Blood-Soaked Ground, a ‘Prayer for the Future’ of a Divided Land
abstract: Two weeks after the election, a gathering in Gettysburg commemorated Lincoln’s address, 272 words that have come to epitomize what it means to be presidential.
lead_paragraph: The bugler’s call to assemble had sounded, wreaths had been laid, a choral society had sung and dignitaries had spoken, all on a blood-consecrated hill in the Pennsylvania town of Gettysburg. All to commemorate the 161st anniversary of the speech that came to epitomize what it meant to be presidential.

headline: A Long-Held Secret Is Now Public. Will It Alter Cormac McCarthy’s Legacy?
abstract: Revelations about a relationship between the author and a girl who was 16 when they met shocked readers, but not scholars of his work. Now there’s a debate about how much she influenced his writing.
lead_paragraph: This week, Vanity Fair published a bombshell article revealing that Cormac McCarthy, one of the country’s most celebrated and enigmatic novelists, had a relationship with a girl he met when he was 42 and she was 16, a foster child who felt so unsafe at home she often carried a gun and used the pool area at the motel where he was staying to shower.

headline: The Voice of Milhouse on Saying Goodbye to ‘The Simpsons’
abstract: After 35 years of voicing Bart’s unlucky but indefatigable best friend, Pamela Hayden is retiring. She still has high hopes for his future.
lead_paragraph: When you answer your phone to hear a grown woman shouting “Wazzzuuuuup?” in the voice of a 10-year-old boy, you can be pretty sure that you’re talking with Pamela Hayden. For some 35 years, Hayden has played many distinctive characters on “The Simpsons,” the long-running animated Fox sitcom, but none with more nerdy exuberance than Milhouse Van Houten, the hapless but good-hearted best friend of Bart Simpson.

headline: With Memes and in State Media, Many Russians Cheer on Putin’s Threats
abstract: While support for Vladimir V. Putin’s threats resounded in pro-war venues, some Russians reacted with worry, gallows humor and apathy to the suggestions of striking the West and using nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: The day after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia raised the stakes in tensions with the West, many Russians awoke on Friday feeling anxious that the prospect of nuclear war had come slightly closer.

headline: Trump Won More of New York’s Votes. Did He Win More of Its Love, Too?
abstract: The city tolerated Donald J. Trump, and then it loathed him. Now, some New Yorkers have begun to embrace him. The Kid from Queens couldn’t be happier.
lead_paragraph: Even though Donald J. Trump is cloistered in Florida and planning his return to Washington, it seems like he has been stuck in a New York state of mind.

headline: An Idaho County Will Publish Everyone’s Ballots to Combat Mistrust
abstract: After enduring a host of election conspiracy claims in recent years, Ada County believes it has found a way to restore confidence in the vote-counting system.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the 2020 election, as supporters of Donald J. Trump scoured the nation for any malfeasance that might explain his defeat, the county clerk’s office in Boise, Idaho, was inundated with queries.

headline: Kayaker Trapped on Australian River Has Leg Amputated in 20-Hour Rescue
abstract: The police in the state of Tasmania said all other efforts to help the man, a foreign tourist in his 60s, failed before the decision was made to amputate.
lead_paragraph: A kayaker’s leg was amputated on Saturday in a harrowing 20-hour effort to free him after he became trapped in rocks on a river in Australia, the police in the state of Tasmania said.

headline: K-Pop Trained Rosé to Be ‘a Perfect Girl.’ Now She’s Trying to Be Herself.
abstract: The Blackpink star strikes out on her own, away from the system that turned her into a global phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: South Korean pop, known as K-pop, is not just a type of music — it’s a culture, where bold style, perfectly choreographed dance moves and ebullient earworms that draw from pop, hip-hop and traditional Korean music attract a huge and particularly devoted global fan base. The genre’s stars, known as idols, are trained, often for years, by entertainment companies that then place the most promising trainees in groups, write and produce their music and obsessively manage their public images. It’s a system that works for the idols who make it big, but it has also drawn criticism for its grueling methods, which some call exploitative.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,254
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Nov. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 532
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Nov. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Alberta Breaks With the Canadian Pension Model
abstract: The provincial government abruptly purged the board and senior leaders of Alberta’s pension fund, defying a long-held principle that funds should be free of political interference.
lead_paragraph: Without any advance notice, the government of Alberta last week fired all 10 directors on the board of its pension fund, Alberta Investment Management Corporation, along with its chief executive and three of his most senior employees. Then, this week, it announced that Stephen Harper, the former Conservative prime minister, would serve as the fund’s chairman.

headline: Your Heart’s Desire
abstract: Understanding what’s “for you” or “not for you” is part of refining taste. But what if it’s also closing you off to pleasure and connection?
lead_paragraph: It’s “Glicked” weekend, if you’re up for it, an invitation to take in a double feature of two of the season’s most anticipated movies, both of which opened yesterday: “Wicked,” Jon M. Chu’s adaptation of the Broadway musical, starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande, and “Gladiator II,” Ridley Scott’s return to the Colosseum 24 years after his original epic.

headline: No Grandchildren in Their Lives
abstract: Readers respond to a front-page article about parents whose children don’t plan to have children of their own.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gift Ideas That Push Back the Darkness
abstract: Give a woman her life back, save a child’s life or help a child read, with my annual holiday giving guide.
lead_paragraph: This column is part of Times Opinion’s 2024 Giving Guide. Read more about the guide in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

headline: The Bizarro Normalcy of the Public Reaction to Trump’s Win
abstract: A second Trump administration is one where nobody’s quite sure what anyone else is really thinking.
lead_paragraph: One of the things that has been clear with Donald Trump’s win this time is how different it is: no shock wave jolting society. This is, according to polling, one of the presidential election outcomes most widely accepted as legitimate of the past 25 years. The reaction from some of those who didn’t vote for him seems more restrained, with a widespread interest in preservation of self amid potential chaos — a retreat from the news to focus on family, friends and peace of mind.

headline: Three Theories of the Trump Cabinet
abstract: Where will this particular cast of characters take us?
lead_paragraph: Before Donald Trump’s victory, making detailed predictions about how his second administration would govern seemed like a fool’s errand — there were too many multitudes within the Trumpian tent, too many promiscuous promises to voters, to say for sure what forms of Trumpism would end up expressed in a second four-year whirl.

headline: Trump: Protector of Women — or Predators?
abstract: If you want to see women flying high, go to the movies.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump proclaimed that he would be the protector of women.

headline: No One Was Worried About My Country’s Elections This Year. They Should Be.
abstract: An unexciting campaign mirrors young Uruguayans’ lack of enthusiasm for democracy.
lead_paragraph: In a year of landmark elections, my country’s presidential vote last month flew under the radar. And perhaps with good reason: Uruguay’s balloting was marked by unexciting candidates and their lackluster attempts to entice undecided voters to the polls. In the end, no candidate won a majority, leaving weary Uruguayans to brace for another round of unimpressive speeches leading up to a runoff on Sunday.

headline: Gladiator Movies Aren’t Telling the Real Story About Rome
abstract: Forget the movies. Roman ideals of masculinity went far beyond what gladiators could achieve.
lead_paragraph: For a modern audience, it’s tempting to valorize the Roman gladiator — strong, brave, fierce — as a masculine ideal. Indeed, ancient Rome has become for many young men an exemplar of a “lost” masculinity, as evidenced by the social media accounts and TikTok posts celebrating Roman culture. For that crowd, “Gladiator II,” the blockbuster movie that arrived on Friday, with its arena battles and bloody clashes between sword-wielding warriors (and occasional live sharks), will be a welcome moment to celebrate a Roman notion of manly individualism. There’s just one catch: To ancient Romans, gladiators were not ideals of masculinity, or of heroism.

headline: They Hate Each Other. They Love Each Other. We Can’t Look Away.
abstract: “Wicked” revels in the power of female frenemies.
lead_paragraph: When Glinda and Elphaba, the leads of the new movie adaptation of “Wicked,” clap eyes on each other, it’s loathe at first sight.

headline: Sectarian Violence Kills at Least 25 in Northwest Pakistan
abstract: The clashes overnight between Sunni and Shiite tribes in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province came a day after gunmen ambushed a convoy of vehicles in the area.
lead_paragraph: Violent clashes erupted overnight between Sunni and Shiite tribes in northwestern Pakistan, leaving at least 25 people dead and markets, homes and government properties in flames, officials and residents said on Saturday.

headline: 2 Books for Readers Who Don’t Care About Polite Company
abstract: A Japanese tale of “frustrated love and revenge,” and a visual history of bathrooms.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Biden’s Chief Economist Processes the Election With ‘Confusion, Guilt’
abstract: Jared Bernstein, the chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, was a leading architect of “Bidenomics.”
lead_paragraph: Since the election, Jared Bernstein, the chair of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, has often found himself in a down mood — dealing, he says, with “confusion, guilt” and “cognitive dissonance.”

headline: Stock for Sale by Cabinet Members
abstract: Trump’s picks for Treasury secretary and commerce secretary both lead Wall Street firms. Here’s what that could mean for their finances and businesses.
lead_paragraph: As President-elect Donald Trump takes an unconventional approach to stocking his cabinet, he’s also embracing one candidate pool that has plenty of precedent: Wall Street chief executives.

headline: Where You Should Donate This Holiday Season
abstract: Announcing the return of Opinion’s annual giving guide.
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning and on Saturdays.

headline: So Many Days Lost at the Doctor’s Office
abstract: Medical care can be wearying and time-consuming, especially for seniors. Researchers are beginning to quantify the burdens.
lead_paragraph: Deana Hendrickson sometimes feels daunted by the demands of the medical system. “Every body part has a doctor,” she lamented. “I hate it.”

headline: Hot Take: Pumpkin Pie Is Good
abstract: Especially Melissa Clark’s brandied pumpkin pie, a New York Times Cooking classic with five stars and over 2,000 reviews.
lead_paragraph: I’ll come right out and say it: I love pumpkin pie. I know this seasonal treat has its detractors, but it’s only because they’ve never had a good pumpkin pie. And I get it. A wan pumpkin pie — one without enough spiced oomph in its filling and a bland, stodgy crust — is just an aboveground pool of sugary squash mush.

headline: Food Poisoning Kills 23 Children as South Africa Declares Emergency
abstract: The South African government said that nearly 900 people, many children, had fallen sick since September.
lead_paragraph: The six young children had just shared  snacks bought from a corner store when they began convulsing. The children, all of them under 8, died moments later, adding more victims to a wave of food poisoning that the authorities say has killed nearly two dozen children in a few months.

headline: How Scott Bessent Went From Democratic Donor to Trump Treasury Secretary Pick
abstract: The hedge fund investor predicted last year that President-elect Donald J. Trump’s political fortunes were on the rise.
lead_paragraph: In the heat of the 2000 presidential campaign, Vice President Al Gore took a break from barnstorming battleground states to attend a fund-raiser for the Democratic National Committee in East Hampton, N.Y. Standing behind Mr. Gore onstage was Scott Bessent, a hedge fund manager and — at the time — a major donor to Democrats who co-hosted the event at his home.

headline: Blue Man Group to End New York Run After Three Decades Off Broadway
abstract: The troupe is also closing its Chicago company, but continues to perform in Berlin, Boston, Las Vegas and, soon, Orlando.
lead_paragraph: Blue Man Group, the wordless theatrical troupe of drum-beating, paint-splattering, bald blue performers, will end its run in New York on Feb. 2, more than three decades and 17,000 performances after it began.

headline: Down About the Election? There Is a Speech I Want You to Read.
abstract: Frederick Douglass knew what to do when faced with Jim Crow.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans who know of Frederick Douglass know that he lived to see the destruction of chattel slavery and the liberation of Black Americans from the despotism of human bondage. Less well known is the fact that Douglass would also live long enough to see the slave stand free, stand a brief moment in the sun, and move back again toward slavery, to paraphrase W.E.B. Du Bois in his book “Black Reconstruction.”

headline: What’s Behind Ukraine and Russia’s Missile Brinkmanship?
abstract: Tit-for-tat moves this week included the use of American-made ballistic missiles to strike inside Russia, and new nuclear threats from Moscow. Neither appear to have influenced the war on the ground.
lead_paragraph: The low-lying clouds over the city lit up for a split second, video footage showed, then streaks of dozens of glowing warheads plummeted out of the sky.

headline: Madeleine Riffaud, ‘the Girl Who Saved Paris,’ Dies at 100
abstract: Humiliated by a Nazi officer as a teenager, she joined the French Resistance. By the time she was 20, she had killed a German soldier, survived torture and captured a supply train.
lead_paragraph: Madeleine Riffaud, a French Resistance hero who survived three weeks of torture as a teenager and who went on to celebrate her 20th birthday by helping to capture 80 Nazis on an armored supply train, died on Nov. 6 at her home in Paris. She was 100.

headline: Israeli Strike Hits Residential Building in Central Beirut
abstract: At least 20 people were killed and dozens of others were wounded in the strike on Beirut’s Basta neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: At least 20 people were killed and dozens of others were wounded in the strike on Beirut’s Basta neighborhood.

headline: Scenes From the Storm That Drenched the West Coast
abstract: The storm, driven by the season’s first major atmospheric river, inundated the Pacific Northwest and Northern California, killing at least three people and causing widespread power outages.
lead_paragraph: A gusty, rain-soaked storm swept through the Pacific Northwest and Northern California this week, killing at least three people and knocking out power for hundreds of thousands of customers.

headline: 2-Year-Old Gorilla Dies After Being Struck by Hydraulic Door at Zoo
abstract: A Calgary Zoo staff member mistakenly activated a door that struck the western lowland gorilla named Eyare, a report found.
lead_paragraph: A 2-year-old gorilla died of traumatic injuries last week at the Calgary Zoo in Alberta, Canada, after being struck by a hydraulic door that a staff member mistakenly activated, according to the zoo.

headline: Shape Up or Ship Out
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners floats in with a precise Sunday construction.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Trump Picks Brooke Rollins, a Conservative Lawyer, to Lead Agriculture Dept.
abstract: Ms. Rollins is the chief executive of the America First Policy Institute, a think tank created to promote President-elect Donald J. Trump’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Saturday chose Brooke Rollins, his former White House domestic policy adviser, to helm the Agriculture Department, whose wide-ranging purview includes supporting farmers who grow the nation’s two biggest crops, corn and soybeans, and setting the nutrition standards in school cafeterias across the nation.

headline: Climate Talks End With a Bitter Fight and a Deal on Money
abstract: The financing plan, which calls for $300 billion per year in support for developing nations, was immediately assailed as inadequate by a string of delegates.
lead_paragraph: Negotiators at this year’s United Nations climate summit struck an agreement early on Sunday in Baku, Azerbaijan, to triple the flow of money to help developing countries adopt cleaner energy and cope with the effects of climate change. Under the deal, wealthy nations pledged to reach $300 billion per year in support by 2035, up from a current target of $100 billion.

headline: California Educator Is Charged With Molesting 8 Children
abstract: David Braff was first accused of misconduct years ago but has since held a series of school jobs. The authorities are investigating the possibility of additional victims.
lead_paragraph: A Los Angeles assistant principal was arrested on Friday and charged with molesting eight children between 2015 and 2019, while he was working as an elementary school counselor in Ventura County.

headline: Owners of Colorado Funeral Home Admit to Abusing Nearly 200 Corpses
abstract: Jon and Carie Hallford pleaded guilty to corpse abuse after dozens of decaying bodies were found at their funeral home.
lead_paragraph: A couple who owned a funeral home at two locations in Colorado pleaded guilty on Friday to multiple counts of corpse abuse, more than a year after 191 bodies were found decaying at their businesses in a horrific scene, the authorities said.

headline: Trump’s Choices for Health Agencies Suggest a Shake-Up Is Coming
abstract: The picks to oversee public health have all pushed back against Covid policies or supported ideas that are outside the medical mainstream.
lead_paragraph: A longtime leader of the anti-vaccine movement. A highly credentialed surgeon. A seven-term Florida congressman. A Fox News contributor with her own line of vitamins.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 24, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend on Page 10 about late-night host Johnny Carson incorrectly quoted part of a line from a famous Johnny Carson quip. The joke goes, “Half the marriages end in divorce — and then there are the unhappy ones,” not “and then there are the happy ones.”

headline: Fred R. Harris, Oklahoma Senator Who Ran for President, Dies at 94
abstract: After eight years in the Senate as a moderate Democrat, he took a leftward turn toward “new populism” in a failed shot at the presidency in 1976.
lead_paragraph: Fred R. Harris, a maverick Oklahoma Democrat who served eight years in the Senate and who lost a race for his party’s 1976 presidential nomination in a populist campaign that challenged politics as usual and proposed radical changes for America, died on Saturday in Albuquerque. He was 94.

headline: Tortured, Burned, Put to Death. Their Crime? ‘Sorcery.’
abstract: Tragedies in Papua New Guinea are often followed by accusations of sorcery and unspeakable acts of violence. That cycle has become more brutal in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The men came wielding bush knives. They wanted to avenge a baby girl, who had died the night before. They said she had been killed by a sorcerer’s black magic, and accused a woman who had encountered the baby that morning.

headline: A Corruption Case That Spilled Across Latin America Is Coming Undone
abstract: Operation Car Wash, which started in Brazil, revealed a bribery scheme that spanned at least 12 countries. Brazil’s Supreme Court has reversed much of its impact.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest corruption crackdowns in recent history is being quietly wiped away.

headline: What Two Acclaimed Female-Directed Movies Say About Indian Cinema
abstract: “Laapataa Ladies” and “All We Imagine as Light” have both captivated audiences at home. But only one was able to get India’s nod for the best foreign film Oscar.
lead_paragraph: One is a deft comedy about the misadventures of two young brides in rural India. The other is a delicate tale about the intersecting lives of three women in cosmopolitan Mumbai.

headline: Taking a Second Look at the Lives of Troubled Girls, a Decade Later
abstract: When they were teens, these girls were sent to a school for juvenile delinquents. Our journalists experienced the rare privilege of telling their stories twice.
lead_paragraph: I remember the first day that the photographer Ruth Fremson and I met the Lady Jaguars, a misfit basketball team of troubled teens in West Tennessee. It was winter, 13 years ago. The girls, ages 13 to 17, were tossed together because a juvenile-court judge sentenced them to a strict day school called Carroll Academy. They never came close to winning games.

headline: Quote of the Day: Bathing in Oil Might Seem Crude Near a Climate Summit, but Locals Swear by It
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “The resin itself is a bit toxic. But for skin problems, the resin really helps.”

headline: What Ever Happened to the Lady Jaguars?
abstract: When we met them a dozen years ago, they were teenagers in trouble, playing for a basketball team that always lost. Did they find a way to win at life?
lead_paragraph: Her name is Hannah. When I met her more than a decade ago, she was a wide-eyed and curious seventh grader with church-pew manners. She was chatty and clingy, a dreamer with a trusting heart. She played with dolls and sang in a choir. She wanted to be a veterinarian and live in a mansion.

headline: The Democrats Are in Trouble. This Man Can Save Them.
abstract: The theories of the 20th-century philosopher John Rawls can inspire a new way for Democrats to find relevance.
lead_paragraph: The election victory by Donald Trump and his Republican Party was a rebuke of a Democratic Party that has positioned itself as protector of a despised status quo, rendering it unable to connect with an electorate desperate for change. Defeating Mr. Trump in the future will require liberals, progressives and others on the left to articulate a positive vision that can capture the imagination of a broad majority of Americans.

headline: Taiwan Is Ready to Defend Democracy. Is Trump?
abstract: Many Americans voted for border security. Try living next to China.
lead_paragraph: I don’t envy American voters. Your presidential choices have an impact halfway across the planet. Your soldiers fight and die in other countries’ wars. I know you’re tired of feeling you have to fix the world’s problems. But like it or not, this unique privilege and responsibility comes with being a citizen of the greatest country in the world.

headline: New York City Hotel Rates Soar to Record Heights as Holiday Travel Nears
abstract: Hotels charged an average of $417 per night in September, the highest monthly rate ever for the city. “I don’t understand how normal people can go there,” one tourist said.
lead_paragraph: For a recent Friday night at a Hilton in Times Square: $537, including a daily $35 “destination charge.”

headline: Chinatown Vendor Tallies Neighborhood’s Decline in $1 Plastic Bracelets
abstract: A longtime vendor in Manhattan’s Chinatown is finding it harder to make a living as people shun his intricate crafts, haggle over cheap knickknacks and shift their spending online.
lead_paragraph: By the time Shaohua Yu erected his stand at around 10 a.m., Chinatown was already bustling. Tourists were wandering around the stalls along Canal Street, where Chinese peddlers and recent immigrants from Africa were selling the same fake Louis Vuitton and Gucci products. Behind Mr. Yu, the New Kam Man supermarket had just rolled up its steel curtain. A row of roasted ducks hung in the window facing him.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Trash Talk at Work? Uncool in Any Language.
abstract: One of my co-workers criticized another in Spanish. Should I tell them that they were understood?
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: ‘Every Few Pages Reflected Each Person’s Take on Their Experience ’
abstract: What “Law & Order” background actors think, a special summer and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: At Bible Study for the Homeless, a Search for Meaning
abstract: Religion is often overlooked as a factor in the lives of the needy, but those who gather at a center in Virginia say it helps sustain them.
lead_paragraph: Six mornings a week, a call for quiet stills a day center for homeless people in Northern Virginia, and those so inclined gather to thank God, read scripture and ponder its message for their tribulations.

headline: Former Obama Aide Enters the New York City Mayor’s Race
abstract: Michael Blake, a former state assemblyman and a veteran of the Obama administration, joins a crowded field of candidates running against Mayor Eric Adams.
lead_paragraph: Michael Blake, a former New York State assemblyman from the Bronx and a veteran of the Obama administration, is entering the crowded race to unseat Mayor Eric Adams.

headline: Have New York’s Football Teams Finally Hit Rock Bottom?
abstract: The Jets and Giants are both having seasons that fans would rather forget. But they took very different routes to get there.
lead_paragraph: Misery and gloom are haunting the Giants yet again this football season. But there is one consolation: At least they aren’t the Jets.

headline: An Israeli Rabbi Is Abducted and Killed in the U.A.E.
abstract: The Israeli authorities called the killing of Rabbi Zvi Kogan an act of terrorism. The Emirati government said it had arrested three people in connection with the murder.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli rabbi in the United Arab Emirates who had been missing since Thursday has been found murdered, Israeli and Emirati authorities announced on Sunday. Israeli officials called the death of the rabbi, Zvi Kogan, an act of terrorism, without providing any further details.

headline: Reading, With Extra Cheese: Remembering Pizza Hut’s ‘Book It!’
abstract: Reporting on the 40th anniversary of the popular pizza literacy program sent one writer on a mozzarella-scented memory trail.
lead_paragraph: It was late one night last spring, and I was Googling cultural phenomena that would mark milestone anniversaries in 2024, as a sleepless reporter does.

headline: In West Bank Raids, Palestinians See Echoes of Israel’s Gaza War
abstract: West Bank residents say Israeli forces are adopting tactics similar to the ones they are deploying in Gaza, including airstrikes and the use of Palestinians as human shields.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli soldiers grabbed his arms on each side, Nasir Damaj recalled, marching him through the streets to the blown-out shell of a mosque.

headline: Should You Still Learn to Code in an A.I. World?
abstract: Coding boot camps once looked like the golden ticket to an economically secure future. But as that promise fades, what should you do? Keep learning, until further notice.
lead_paragraph: When Florencio Rendon was laid off from his third construction job in three years, he said, “it was the straw that broke the camel’s back.”

headline: Shopping and Shame Share the Shelves in ‘American Bulk’
abstract: In an eye-opening collection, Emily Mester considers why she, and we, seek satisfaction by obsessively choosing, buying and rating the objects we desire.
lead_paragraph: We have reached peak feedback. The customer is not only always right, but always writing, rating. The bank, the phone company and the hospital want us to evaluate our experiences with them on a scale of 1 to 10. There are Yelp reviews of Planet Earth.

headline: A Survivor in Spain Filmed How the Water Flooded Her Town in Hours
abstract: Rosalía Arenas, a resident of Utiel, recorded on her phone for nearly five hours as deadly floods submerged her street. A boat eventually evacuated Ms. Arena and her 2-year-old child.
lead_paragraph: Rosalía Arenas, a resident of Utiel, recorded on her phone for nearly five hours as deadly floods submerged her street. A boat eventually evacuated Ms. Arena and her 2-year-old child.

headline: Raging Waters Were Headed Their Way. Why Did Nobody Tell Them?
abstract: Torrential rains in Valencia, in eastern Spain, caused flooding that killed more than 200 people. The deluge started inland. It took the authorities hours to warn those downstream.
lead_paragraph: Hours before a river of mud descended on towns around Valencia, trapping and killing hundreds of people, water started gushing through the small Spanish municipality of Utiel.

headline: The Icy, Terrifying, Pathological Human Need to Climb
abstract: In “The White Ladder,” the British writer Daniel Light explores the heroes, villains and dramas of early mountaineering.
lead_paragraph: In 1519, the Spanish conquistador Diego de Ordaz reached the summit of the stratovolcano Popocatépetl during an expedition in Mexico under Hernan Cortés.

headline: A Reggaeton Ode to Colombia Is a Hit, but It’s Not Music to Everyone’s Ears
abstract: A recent song’s explicit lyrics have prompted criticism that the music promotes harmful stereotypes about Colombia.
lead_paragraph: “A mamacita since she was 14,” the song says in Spanish, with a chorus that repeats: “And even though that little baby has an owner, she goes out whenever she wants.”

headline: ‘Wicked’ and ‘Gladiator II’ Jump-Start the Box Office, but at a Cost
abstract: Battling a 27 percent decline in domestic ticket sales compared with before the pandemic, studios left no marketing drum unthumped in releasing the movies.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood was back this weekend to where it desperately hungers to be — at the center of global culture.

headline: How Southwest Airlines Lost Its Groove
abstract: For decades, the company made money even as other airlines stumbled and went bankrupt. But the carrier has struggled to adapt to changes in air travel.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Southwest Airlines started flying out of Bellingham, Wash., a growing city near the Canadian border, aiming to do what it had done in dozens of smaller airports — sell lots of tickets to people who have few other travel options.

headline: Shopping for a Good Riding Boot?
abstract: Start here.
lead_paragraph: Riding boots are worn today as much for walking on city sidewalks as they are for hunting or the other horseback activities for which the footwear was originally made centuries ago. But with so many options out there, how does one choose?

headline: The Amsterdam Attacks and the Long Shadow of ‘Pogroms’
abstract: Many have used an old word to refer to recent events. Is it accurate?
lead_paragraph: Femke Halsema, the mayor of Amsterdam, may have touched off a diplomatic incident last week when she said on a Dutch television show that she regretted having used the word “pogrom” the day after attacks on Israelis in her city surrounding a soccer match.

headline: Immigrants Across U.S. Rush to Prepare for Trump Crackdown
abstract: Donald Trump’s promise to carry out mass deportations has driven fearful immigrants to seek protections and advice.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has vowed to slash immigration — both legal and illegal — and ramp up deportations on Day 1.

headline: ‘Shoot Me Up With Everything’
abstract: For a reporter who covers infectious diseases, vaccines are an indispensable news gathering tool.
lead_paragraph: Vaccines are an indispensable news gathering tool. They permit reporters to travel to areas where fatal or debilitating diseases are prevalent; exactly the places that warrant coverage by The New York Times.

headline: Trump Is Running His Transition Team on Secret Money
abstract: Breaking with past practice, President-elect Donald J. Trump has not agreed to disclose the donors paying for his planning effort or to limit their contributions.
lead_paragraph: Updated Nov. 27: Since this article was published, an aide to President-elect Donald J. Trump said that although Mr. Trump’s transition did not plan to sign an agreement with the General Services Administration, it would not accept donations from foreigners and would disclose donors’ names. The aide did not say when Mr. Trump would release those names or if he would limit the size of donations to $5,000, as previous president-elects have.

headline: Egypt Feuds With Travel Blogger, Issuing 1,100-Word Response to Complaints
abstract: When a blogger criticized Cairo’s airport, Egypt’s government fired back, citing security footage, threatening legal action and asking, “Is it reasonable for a passenger to visit two lounges before a single flight?”
lead_paragraph: Authoritarian governments are not known for taking kindly to criticism. And in Egypt, official skins can be especially thin: Deepening repression has muffled most dissent and sent tens of thousands of perceived political opponents to jail, including one for posting a doctored photo of the president with Mickey Mouse ears.

headline: ‘A God Who Continually Surprises Us’: A Q&A With a Theologian Who Changed His Mind About Gay Marriage
abstract: Can God be wrong?
lead_paragraph: I’ve spent my life in politics, but faith has been most central to shaping who I am. My conversations with people of faith have been among the most enriching of my life. Richard Hays, an ordained minister who is an emeritus professor at Duke Divinity School, is one of the world’s leading New Testament theologians. In 1996 he wrote “The Moral Vision of the New Testament,” in which he argued that gay and lesbian sexual relationships distort God’s created order and that churches should not bless same-sex unions. In his new book, “The Widening of God’s Mercy,” written with his son Christopher Hays, Richard Hays says he was wrong. I spoke to Richard Hays about his journey and what changed his mind. This conversation, which has been lightly edited, is the first of what I hope will be a series exploring the world of faith.

headline: Donald Trump Thinks He Won’t Have Enough Power
abstract: The once and future president’s constitutional gimmicks are embarrassingly transparent.
lead_paragraph: These are the times that try a constitutional conservative’s soul.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 533
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,255
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Nov. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: There’s a Simple Way to Stop Dangerous Wildfires. We Barely Use It.
abstract: We don’t use prescribed burns enough.
lead_paragraph: The Northeast didn’t see it coming, but suddenly we are putting out a lot of wildfires: The state of New York is in the midst of its most active wildfire season in more than a decade. A wildfire in southwestern Massachusetts grew to 1,000 acres this week, the second fire in the region to reach that size this month. New Jersey has suppressed 500 wildfires and counting this fall.

headline: Hezbollah Fires About 250 Projectiles Into Israel After Deadly Strike in Beirut
abstract: The waves of attacks on Sunday came amid diplomatic efforts to reach a cease-fire in the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah fired about 250 projectiles into Israel on Sunday, a day after an Israeli strike in the heart of the Lebanese capital killed more than 25 people.

headline: New Thanksgiving Classics
abstract: We’ve got a menu for your holiday.
lead_paragraph: The menus are being planned, grocery lists made, details finalized — it’s nearly go time for Thanksgiving, a time for epic feasting and the one day of the year on which even the most reluctant home cooks wander into the kitchen. Are you ready?

headline: I Starred in ‘Cabaret.’ We Need to Heed Its Warning.
abstract: Much has changed since the show debuted on Broadway in 1966, but it’s what hasn’t changed that should worry us.
lead_paragraph: This past week marked 58 years since the opening night for the Broadway premiere of “Cabaret” in 1966. At the time, the country was in deep turmoil. Overseas, the Vietnam War was escalating, and at home, our most regressive forces were counterpunching against the progress demanded by the civil rights movement. The composer John Kander, the lyricist Fred Ebb and the playwright Joe Masteroff wrote “Cabaret” in collaboration with the director Harold Prince as a response to the era. The parallels between the rise of fascism in 1930s Berlin as depicted in the show and the mounting tensions of the 1960s in America were both obvious and ominous.

headline: Connecticut Couple Charged in $1 Million Theft of Lululemon Goods
abstract: Investigators said the couple used trickery and misdirection to steal merchandise from Lululemon stores in at least five states.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut couple were charged with being part of an organized retail theft operation that is suspected of stealing about $1 million in Lululemon merchandise across several states, the authorities said.

headline: Former BP Chief Joins A.I. Data Center Developer
abstract: Bernard Looney will join Prometheus Hyperscale, a Wyoming start-up, to help it address the enormous energy needs of the artificial intelligence industry.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Looney, the former chief executive of BP, one of the world’s largest energy companies, said Sunday that he would become chairman of a data center start-up in the United States, a move that comes amid a ravenous appetite for electricity to power the boom in artificial intelligence.

headline: Fat, Flaky Mounds of Quick Bread, Golden Brown, With a Significant Crumb
abstract: My five-star all-purpose biscuit recipe, at the ready.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. This is going to be a long week, even if you love Thanksgiving unreservedly.

headline: Getting the Election Wrong, and Right
abstract: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks. Also: Blaming the Green Party for a Democratic loss in the Senate race in Pennsylvania; a sitcom cabinet.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Without Drama or Banana, Art Auctions Struggle
abstract: Beyond the headline-grabbing sales of the fall auction season, the market tries to soar beyond its two-year slump.
lead_paragraph: Despite auctioneers selling about 1,600 works of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art within the last week, the only serious moment of excitement came from a $6.2 million banana. The conceptual artwork, “Comedian” by Maurizio Cattelan, had a crowd of at least 300 jammed into the Sotheby’s salesroom to witness its absurd triumph — becoming the world’s most expensive fruit in a series of sales where several more traditional artworks failed to muster even a single bid.

headline: Chuck Woolery, Host of ‘Love Connection,’ Dies at 83
abstract: After a career that included stints on “Wheel of Fortune” and other popular game shows, he took a combative turn as a right-wing podcast host.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Woolery, who was the affable host of “Love Connection,” “Wheel of Fortune” and other television game shows and who later criticized liberal values and the Democratic Party as the co-host of a popular right-wing podcast, died on Saturday at his home in Horseshoe Bay, Texas. He was 83.

headline: Does the Conductor Klaus Mäkelä Deserve His Meteoric Rise?
abstract: The 28-year-old maestro, entrusted with two storied ensembles, visited Carnegie Hall with the superb Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: A raucously received performance of Mahler’s First Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Saturday was the latest exclamation point in the conductor Klaus Mäkelä’s meteoric rise. Mäkelä is just 28 and made his Carnegie debut a mere eight months ago with the Orchestre de Paris — one of the two very good ensembles he currently leads.

headline: 2 Dead After Civil Air Patrol Plane Crashes in Colorado Mountains
abstract: A Cessna plane crashed while conducting a training exercise, killing the pilot and an aerial photographer, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two people died and one was injured after a Civil Air Patrol plane crashed while conducting an aerial photography training exercise amid the rugged peaks of Larimer County, Colo., on Saturday, officials said.

headline: Rico Carty, Exceptional Hitter Who Was Stymied by Injuries, Dies at 85
abstract: A Dominican baseball star, he had a dazzling rookie year and became a pioneering designated hitter, but injuries and tuberculosis held him back.
lead_paragraph: Rico Carty, a Dominican baseball star whose early exceptional promise was thwarted by untimely injuries, died on Saturday. He was 85.

headline: What to Know About Brooke Rollins, Trump’s Choice for Agriculture Secretary
abstract: A Texas native, Ms. Rollins worked in the first Trump White House and has also led two influential conservative think tanks.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump rounded out his cabinet selections on Saturday, picking Brooke Rollins as his agriculture secretary.

headline: The World Seeks an End to Plastic Pollution at Talks in South Korea
abstract: Many nations hope to reduce the half a billion tons of plastic made each year. But pushback from plastic and oil producers, and Donald Trump’s election, could scuttle an agreement.
lead_paragraph: On the heels of contentious climate talks in Azerbaijan, negotiators from around the globe are descending on Busan, South Korea, this week with another formidable goal: the world’s first treaty designed to tackle plastic pollution’s explosive growth.

headline: Hezbollah Fires About 250 Projectiles Into Israel
abstract: Hezbollah’s attack came after Israel’s deadly strike on Beirut on Saturday. It was one of the largest mounted by the militant group against Israel since it started firing on the country last year in solidarity with Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah’s attack came after Israel’s deadly strike on Beirut on Saturday. It was one of the largest mounted by the militant group against Israel since it started firing on the country last year in solidarity with Hamas.

headline: Charles Dumont, Who Wrote Enduring Melodies for Édith Piaf, Dies at 95
abstract: His dozens of songs included “Non, Je Ne Regrette Rien,” a powerful anthem of redemptive love that became one of Piaf’s signature songs.
lead_paragraph: Charles Dumont, who wrote the music for “Non, Je Ne Regrette Rien,” the soaring song about sweeping away the past to find love anew that the hallowed but troubled singer Édith Piaf turned into an anthem of French culture, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Paris. He was 95.

headline: Tony Campolo, Preacher Who Challenged Religious Right, Dies at 89
abstract: A mesmerizing speaker, he urged his fellow evangelicals to turn away from politics in favor of the values of charity and love espoused by Jesus.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Tony Campolo, one of the most influential evangelical preachers of the past half century, who urged Christians to resist the strong political tug of the religious right and to affirm that their faith called them, first and foremost, to fight poverty and racism, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 89.

headline: Trump’s Cabinet: Many Ideologies Behind the Veil of ‘America First’
abstract: One faction of prospective nominees appears focused on revenge, another on calming markets and a third on relentlessly — perhaps hopelessly — cutting people and budgets.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s final flurry of cabinet picks and other appointments rounded out what his aides described as a unified, loyal, MAGA-driven administration. But scratch the surface and there are at least three distinct factions and a range of ideologies, barely suppressed to get through the rigors of the confirmation process.

headline: Dartmouth Sorority and 2 Fraternity Members Are Charged After Student’s Drowning
abstract: The 20-year-old student died this summer after attending an off-campus party. The fraternity members and sorority were charged with offenses related to providing alcohol to minors.
lead_paragraph: A Dartmouth College sorority and two fraternity members have been charged with underage alcohol offenses in the death of a 20-year-old student who drowned after attending an off-campus party this summer.

headline: Monday Briefing: U.N. Climate Talks End With a Deal
abstract: Plus, photographing the world’s food.
lead_paragraph: Negotiators at this year’s United Nations climate summit, known as COP29, struck an agreement early yesterday to help developing countries adopt cleaner energy and cope with the effects of climate change. Under the deal, wealthy nations pledged to reach $300 billion per year in support by 2035, up from a current target of $100 billion.

headline: Israel Conducts Widespread Strikes Near Beirut
abstract: As negotiators inch toward a cease-fire deal, the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon has intensified.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military late on Sunday conducted a heavy barrage of airstrikes on the southern outskirts of Beirut where Hezbollah holds sway, with fighter jets racing across the skies above the Lebanese capital and deafening explosions ringing out for miles.

headline: Nations at COP29 Climate Summit Agree to Annual $300 Billion Pledge
abstract: Delegates from developing countries described the deal’s financial target, $300 billion per year by 2035, as lacking the ambition needed to help their governments combat climate change.
lead_paragraph: Delegates from developing countries described the deal’s financial target, $300 billion per year by 2035, as lacking the ambition needed to help their governments combat climate change.

headline: Perches in a Coop
abstract: Dena R. Witkes makes her Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Washington Curtails Intel’s Chip Grant After Company Stumbles
abstract: The Biden administration is reducing its award to the chip maker, partly to account for a multibillion-dollar military contract.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration plans to reduce Intel’s preliminary $8.5 billion federal CHIPS grant, a move that follows the California-based company’s investment delays and broader business struggles.

headline: The Official Unofficial Record
abstract: How do you count almost 12 million votes if you’re not the government?
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 25, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Uruguay’s Center Left Reclaims Power in Presidential Election
abstract: After a campaign notable for the amiable tone from both sides, Yamandú Orsi was named the winner.
lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay — A onetime mayor and history teacher defeated the candidate of the conservative coalition that has governed Uruguay for the past five years to win his country’s presidency on Sunday.

headline: ‘Dune: Prophecy’ Season 1, Episode 2 Recap: The Agony
abstract: Valya has shown that she is clearly willing to sacrifice whatever, and whomever, it takes to accomplish her goal.
lead_paragraph: Desmond Hart is an anomaly. He is alive after a sandworm attack that should have left him in the belly of the beast. He knows of the Sisterhood’s secret plan to play puppet master with the universe’s rulers as their marionettes. He can burn people to death using only his mind, apparently from light years away. He can resist the Voice, with which Mother Superior Valya Harkonnen has subdued even other powerful members of her own Sisterhood.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Jets and Giants Take Different Routes Toward Rock Bottom
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 25, 2024
lead_paragraph: “I had a feeling this year might not go very well, and now it’s like I’m a NASCAR fan waiting to see the wreck.”

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Reaching a climate deal.
lead_paragraph: Negotiators at this year’s U.N. climate summit, known as COP29, struck an agreement early yesterday to help developing countries adopt cleaner energy and cope with the effects of climate change. Under the deal, wealthy nations pledged to reach $300 billion per year in support by 2035, increased from the current target of $100 billion.

headline: Don’t Let Donald Trump Drive You Into Internal Exile
abstract: Focusing on your own life and disengaging from politics can be appealing. But it is a abdication of responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Since Donald Trump’s victory, I have not been able to stop thinking about Vladimir Putin’s return to the Russian presidency in 2012 — another time in which an exhausted populace found itself unclear on what to do next.

headline: Your Thanksgiving Day Watching Lineup, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
abstract: Watch the Macy’s Day Parade, the dog show and football while the turkey is cooking, and catch up on true crime and two new shows.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re big on cooking, big on eating or big on avoiding Thanksgiving altogether, one of the best parts of the holiday is that there are endless options on TV throughout the day.

headline: DHL Cargo Plane Crashes Near Airport in Lithuania, Killing 1
abstract: The crash near Vilnius Airport sparked a fire in a residential area, officials said. One person on board was killed and three others were hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: A DHL cargo plane crashed in a residential area near Vilnius Airport in Lithuania, killing one person on board and setting a house ablaze, officials said.

headline: Word of the Day: saturnine
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word saturnine has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 29 in “For This Goth, Halloween Is Her Christmas” by Marisa Meltzer:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: As New York’s Migrant Crisis Eases, Trump’s Deportation Threat Looms
abstract: New York City’s migrant shelter population has been steadily falling, but President-elect Donald Trump’s immigration stance will bring new challenges.
lead_paragraph: After a two-year influx of asylum seekers, New York City leaders are cautiously optimistic that the migrant crisis has begun to subside.

headline: Ultranationalist Leads First Round of Romania’s Presidential Election
abstract: Calin Georgescu, who had been widely dismissed as a fringe candidate, won the most votes on Sunday with 22.9 percent. He will face a more centrist opponent in the second round on Dec. 8.
lead_paragraph: Romania, a NATO member and host to a missile defense facility built by the United States, has been thrown into political disarray by the surprise victory of a little-known ultranationalist in the first round of a presidential election held this weekend.

headline: ‘Everyone Thought We Were Going to Die’: Living With Flight Trauma
abstract: Extreme turbulence, a blown-out door, an engine on fire: For passengers and crew members who have experienced in-air emergencies, the pain endures.
lead_paragraph: Last January, Shandy Brewer boarded an Alaska Airlines flight from Portland, Ore., to Ontario, Calif., en route to her grandmother’s birthday celebration. She was seated in the 11th row, between her father and a stranger. Shortly after takeoff, Ms. Brewer and the other passengers heard a loud bang. She couldn’t see that 15 rows behind her one of the plane’s doors had blown off, exposing passengers to open air at 16,000 feet.

headline: How Healthy Is Turkey?
abstract: Give thanks for this bird — and its many nutritional benefits.
lead_paragraph: Americans gobble up more than 46 million turkeys on Thanksgiving, according to some estimates. But experts say that this love for the bird shouldn’t end when the holiday is over. Eating turkey regularly — whether it’s sliced in a deli sandwich or ground up in chili — can boost your health in more ways than one.

headline: Great Apes and Tiny Bears: Chasing Wild Thrills in Borneo
abstract: This Southeast Asian island, home to some of the world’s strangest and most iconic creatures, is a dream destination for a growing number of “mammal watchers.”
lead_paragraph: We lurched along an unpaved road in the night, walls of trees and knotted vines on either side. In the darkness lurked some of the world’s most unusual mammals, and I had come to Borneo to fulfill a lifelong dream to see them: catlike civets, scaled anteaters called pangolins and big-eyed colugos that spread their body flat as they glide from trunk to trunk.

headline: The Teeny, Tiny Tee Is Back (Again)
abstract: Some people are buying actual kids’ shirts, but this time, that relic of ’90s and Y2K fashion is available in many more sizes.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Caruso had never really bought into the idea of dressing for one’s body type. “It’s incredibly limiting,” she said, adding that the concept is really just code for wanting “to look thinner or taller or attempt to reinforce other Eurocentric beauty standards.”

headline: Should I Sit Through the Movie’s Closing Credits?
abstract: The film has ended, but the names of the many people who worked on it are rolling across the screen. Do you stick around?
lead_paragraph: Do you have a question for our culture writers and editors? Ask us here.

headline: Kyle Abraham Is Fully in His Feelings About Now
abstract: In “Dear Lord, Make Me Beautiful,” an evening-length dance, the choreographer considers what scares him but also what it might feel like to have burdens lifted.
lead_paragraph: In rehearsals, the choreographer Kyle Abraham is usually at the front of the room, directing and shaping his work. But on a recent afternoon at the Park Avenue Armory, he came running into the studio with childlike abandon — the opening of his latest dance.

headline: 10 Picture Books That Help Kids (and Adults) Celebrate Gratitude
abstract: Stories of giving and of appreciating everyday wonders will warm hearts and teach valuable lessons this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: “Practice gratitude.” It’s a simple instruction we see on tote bags, coffee mugs and yoga T-shirts. And just like yoga, we know that, when we do it, we will feel better. Yet it can often feel nearly impossible to maintain this habit. Is it any wonder why? Even in this season of abundance, there are plenty of bona fide reasons to cry, complain and kvetch! Just remember: Our kids are listening. Build back your gratitude muscle by sharing these 10 picture books with the little ones in your life. I promise you’ll be thankful that you did.

headline: Why Some of the Year’s Best Performances Are From Actresses Who Say Very Little
abstract: Films like “Conclave” and “Bird” provide a stark contrast to the recent succession of films about women finding their voices.
lead_paragraph: IN A TENSE moment midway through Edward Berger’s recent movie “Conclave,” a pulpy thriller about the process of selecting a new pope, Isabella Rossellini, playing a nun named Sister Agnes, enters a room full of cardinals from around the world. A series of uncovered secrets and shifting alliances have turned this initially serene council into a rat’s nest of backstabbing, grandstanding, explaining, interrupting men. After asking permission to speak, Sister Agnes discreetly delivers a piece of information that will upend the papal election and expose some of the most powerful figures in the Roman Catholic Church to public, career-ending humiliation. Her short speech concluded, she bobs at the waist ever so slightly, giving a tiny curtsy whose performance of feminine deference is a put-down in itself. For the rest of the film, Sister Agnes never says another word.

headline: Black and White Clothes That Are Surprisingly Festive
abstract: Monochromatic palettes, offbeat accessories and statement pieces bring a sense of occasion to men’s holiday fashion.

headline: What’s Wrong With White Bread?
abstract: After years of sourdough dominance, bakers are going back to basics.
lead_paragraph: ON A RECENT Tuesday, all the diners at the New York raw bar Penny, with its marble counter, cream-colored brickwork and ice boxes of escabeche mussels and fresh shrimp, had come seeking sophistication. So why was there so much white bread? Nearly every customer was eating the 39-year-old chef and owner Joshua Pinsky’s oven-warm loaf, served with butter and anchovies.

headline: In California’s Heartland, Some Latino Immigrants Back Trump’s Border Stance
abstract: They said they believed that Donald J. Trump’s attacks on undocumented immigrants were directed at recent asylum seekers rather than their own community members.
lead_paragraph: When José Pérez Gómez came from Mexico more than 25 years ago, he scraped together money by selling handmade furniture on the streets of Fresno, Calif. Eventually, he turned that hustle into a full-fledged brick-and-mortar business, which allowed him to raise a family and send two daughters to college.

headline: Inside the World of Competitive ‘Tablescaping’
abstract: These inventive, meticulous competitors can teach us something about setting the “perfect” table.
lead_paragraph: If you look to the Los Angeles County Fair’s annual tablescaping competition for a little place-setting inspiration, you may find, among other eccentricities, a giant handmade squid pressed against a floating submarine porthole, a fake urn for a fictitious dead cat, a dozen or so dolls and the endless glittering frills of tinsel.

headline: Can Tisch Put Her Stamp on the N.Y.P.D.?
abstract: Jessica Tisch, the sanitation commissioner, is moving to the Police Department. Will Eric Adams let her really be in charge?
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the issues facing Jessica Tisch as she moves from sanitation commissioner to police commissioner. We’ll also find out what the Columbia University football team did for the first time since John F. Kennedy was in the White House.

headline: An I.V.F. Mix-Up, a Shocking Discovery and an Unbearable Choice
abstract: Two couples in California discovered they were raising each other’s genetic children. Should they switch their girls?
lead_paragraph: In the days after Daphna Cardinale delivered her second child, she experienced a rare sense of calm and wonder. The feeling was a relief after so much worrying: She and her husband, Alexander, had tried for three years to conceive before turning to in vitro fertilization, and Daphna, once pregnant, had frequent and painful early contractions. But now, miraculously, here was their baby, their perfect baby, May, with black hair plastered on her head. (May is a nickname that her parents requested to protect her privacy.)

headline: I’ll Never Forget What Kennedy Did During Samoa’s Measles Outbreak
abstract: What he did during a measles epidemic in Samoa shouldn’t be forgotten.
