lead_paragraph: In November 2019, when an epidemic of measles was killing children and babies in Samoa, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — who in recent days became Donald Trump’s pick to lead the department of Health and Human Services — sent the prime minister of Samoa a four-page letter. In it, he suggested the measles vaccine itself may have caused the outbreak.

headline: How Universities Cracked Down on Pro-Palestinian Activism
abstract: Stricter rules and punishments over campus protests seem to be working. Universities have seen just under 950 protest events this semester, compared with 3,000 in the spring.
lead_paragraph: Colleges and universities have tightened rules around protests, locked campus gates and handed down stricter punishments after the disruptions of pro-Palestinian demonstrations and encampments last spring.

headline: A Nobel Laureate’s Journals Offer Much Color but Little Drama
abstract: Orhan Pamuk’s illustrated notebooks lead us to the great writer’s mind, then ask us to remain outside.
lead_paragraph: Is Orhan Pamuk’s “Memories of Distant Mountains: Illustrated Notebooks, 2009-2022” the most embarrassing book published in modern times by a recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature?

headline: The Comedy of Pain, and Korean Food
abstract: The comedian Youngmi Mayer is fearless on TikTok, about her Korean American identity and foodie culture. In a new memoir, she explains laughing while crying.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Youngmi Mayer didn’t mean to bring a cockroach into a downtown Manhattan food hall.

headline: Easing the Biodiversity Crisis One Flowerpot at a Time
abstract: Help for converting a garden, no matter how small, into a wildlife sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Giving Guide 2024. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

headline: Donald Trump Will Do Nothing to Bring Back Our Dying American Dream
abstract: Large negative movements in the finances of the young and the working class are going to make his second term much tougher sledding than his first.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump got lucky in his first term. When he arrived, inflation was low, unemployment was falling, and growth was steady. He applied a bit of juice via his large regressive tax cut, and the economy accelerated without triggering inflation. In retrospect, his term was a bit like a speeding car that got away with it.

headline: What Makes You Cry?
abstract: Humans are the only species that sheds emotional tears, but much about our tears remain an enigma. What kind of crier are you?
lead_paragraph: You’re watching a romantic comedy and the protagonist finally finds true love.You’re embarrassed by your teacher in front of the entire class.Your younger sibling wins the state athletics championship against all odds.Your pet dies.

headline: How Trump Could Upend Electric Car Sales
abstract: Fewer people will be able to afford electric cars and trucks if President-elect Donald J. Trump and Republicans in Congress eliminate a $7,500 federal tax credit.
lead_paragraph: Many car buyers have come to rely on a $7,500 federal tax credit on electric vehicles to soften the blow of their high prices. But those credits could disappear after President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office, leading to an almost immediate drop in sales of the cars and trucks.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Spanish-style home in Los Angeles, a four-bedroom house with a detached studio in the East Bay, and a Craftsman bungalow in Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: This recently renovated, three-bedroom, two-bathroom house sits in the hills of Los Angeles’s Mount Washington neighborhood, 15 minutes north of downtown. The adjoining lot is included as part of the sale, allowing for the addition of another structure.

headline: The Defeat of Kamala Harris Is Not the End of the Story
abstract: The woman-president thing is more than just a check mark on the feminist to-do list.
lead_paragraph: Just how long do you think it will be before we get a woman president?

headline: I’m a Food Editor. I Hate Thanksgiving Dinner.
abstract: True confessions from the New York Times Cooking desk.
lead_paragraph: Margaux Laskey, an associate editor at New York Times Cooking, has a surprising confession: She doesn’t like Thanksgiving dinner. After days of effort, she finds the final product bland and boring. “I love gratitude and thankfulness, but I’m grateful I don’t have to eat turkey if I don’t want to,” she says. In this episode, she shares ways to celebrate Thanksgiving — no cooking required.

headline: How Do I Balance Being Fashionable With Being Professional?
abstract: A reader asks how to dress for work without losing a sense of style. Our fashion critic offers insights on striking the right balance.
lead_paragraph: This is a misinterpretation of the situation, a sort of inane inverse of the adage that children should be seen and not heard. It suggests that adults should be heard but not seen, and in an increasingly visual world, that idea is a nonstarter.

headline: What if It Gets Really Bad? Four Columnists Debate Trump’s Approach to Power.
abstract: Trump’s 2016 presidential transition signaled how he would govern. What do his preparations for a second term tell us about America’s future?
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Jamelle Bouie, Ross Douthat, M. Gessen and Lydia Polgreen about Donald Trump’s preparations for a second term and what they signal about America’s future.

headline: How Democrats Lost Their Base and Their Message
abstract: Donald Trump’s populist pitch bumped Democrats off their traditional place in American politics.
lead_paragraph: It has long been clear that the rise of Donald J. Trump meant the end of the Republican Party as we once knew it.

headline: Trump’s Judicial Hero Would Have Hated His Recess Appointments Plan
abstract: Justice Antonin Scalia, a conservative giant, said attempts to circumvent the Senate’s responsibility to vet nominees were “ignoble” and “just made up.”
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has singled out one former member of the Supreme Court as his judicial north star: Justice Antonin Scalia, a giant of the conservative legal movement who died in 2016.

headline: An Emerald Taken From Brazil Decades Ago May Soon Be Returned
abstract: A U.S. ruling set in motion the gem’s repatriation to Brazil, where it was first unearthed more than 20 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Tales have been told for years about the famed 836-pound emerald believed to be worth up to $1 billion: that it survived a panther attack, that it survived the floods of Hurricane Katrina, that the gem may be cursed.

headline: Philippines President Slams Vice President’s Assassination Plot
abstract: Political turmoil has escalated after Vice President Sara Duterte claimed to have arranged for President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr.’s assassination if she is slain.
lead_paragraph: President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. of the Philippines said on Monday that he was taking seriously “deeply concerning” threats that had been made against him, days after his vice president said she had arranged for an assassin to kill Mr. Marcos if she were murdered.

headline: On the Outskirts of Beirut, a Crowd Watches the War, and Waits for Its End
abstract: Every night, dozens gather at the hillside to watch airstrikes rain down on the city’s southern suburbs. The ritual offers a window into the war — and proof that the once unimaginable is really happening.
lead_paragraph: The crowds gather every evening on a scenic hillside on the outskirts of Beirut. Young men, old couples and local journalists, all drawn by the unobstructed view of the Dahiya, the cluster of neighborhoods south of Beirut that has been pummeled by Israeli airstrikes over the past two months.

headline: Netanyahu Signals Openness to Cease-Fire With Hezbollah, Officials Say
abstract: The United States is pushing Israel to reach a deal with the Lebanese militia by Thanksgiving, even as key details remained unresolved, Israeli officials said.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has indicated he is open to a cease-fire in the yearlong conflict with Hezbollah, as U.S. officials pressured him to finalize a deal before Thanksgiving, according to two Israeli officials briefed on his thinking.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,256
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Nov. 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 534
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Nov. 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Trump Transition’s Secret Funding, and a Campus Crackdown
abstract: Plus, payouts for finding pandemic fraud.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: A Sudden Escalation in Ukraine Before Trump Takes Office
abstract: Long-range missiles, North Korean troops and starker threats from Russia — the war has entered a more volatile phase.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has promised a radically different approach to foreign policy from that of the Biden administration. In Ukraine, he has pledged to end the war in a day.

headline: Storm Bert Batters Britain, Leaving at Least 3 Dead
abstract: Torrential rain doused most of the country, stymying travel and leading to flooding, landslides, fallen trees and power outages.
lead_paragraph: Widespread travel disruption took place across Britain on Monday as a result of Storm Bert, which pounded the country with a deluge of rain and fierce winds over the weekend.

headline: A Climate Change
abstract: We explore Donald Trump’s climate agenda.
lead_paragraph: Some of Donald Trump’s first steps on climate change when he enters the White House will send a message that the federal government no longer cares about the issue. He will pull out of the Paris Agreement. Allies say he’ll strip the phrases “climate change,” “clean energy” and “environmental justice” from every agency website.

headline: The Bessent Bounce — Markets Cheer Trump’s Treasury Pick
abstract: Investors seemed to signal their approval for Scott Bessent as a safe choice to implement the president-elect’s economic agenda.
lead_paragraph: Stocks and bonds are rising on Monday, and the dollar is down. On the first trading day since Donald Trump chose the billionaire financier Scott Bessent as his pick for Treasury secretary, investors seem to be signaling they like the choice.

headline: Barbara Taylor Bradford, Whose Sagas Were Best Sellers, Dies at 91
abstract: Her own rags-to-riches story mirrored those of many of her resilient heroines, and her dozens of novels helped her amass a fortune of $300 million.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Taylor Bradford, one of the world’s best-selling novelists, who captivated readers for decades with chronicles of buried secrets, raging ambitions and strong women of humble origins rising to wealth and power, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

headline: Newsom Challenges Trump on Electric Vehicle Tax Credits
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom said California would fill the void for residents if the Trump administration killed a $7,500 E.V. tax credit.
lead_paragraph: California will step in and provide rebates to eligible residents who buy electric vehicles if President-elect Donald J. Trump ends the $7,500 federal E.V. tax credit, Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Monday.

headline: Can You Find The 13 Hidden Book Titles in This Text Puzzle?
abstract: This very short story hides the titles of 13 popular books published in the first decade of the 21st century. Dive in and see if you can find them all — and get an instant reading list at the end.
lead_paragraph: This very short story hides the titles of 13 popular books published in the first decade of the 21st century. Dive in and see if you can find them all — and get an instant reading list at the end.

headline: Regulator Sues Anti-Police Activist Who Spent Charity Funds on Himself
abstract: Brandon Anderson, who used his nonprofit’s accounts to rent mansions and buy luxury clothes, was featured in a New York Times story in August.
lead_paragraph: The District of Columbia’s attorney general on Monday sued an activist known for his calls to abolish the police, saying that he diverted $75,000 from a charity to pay for mansion rentals, a trip to Cancún and designer clothes.

headline: Macy’s Discovers Employee Hid Millions in Delivery Expenses
abstract: The department store chain said it had found the erroneous accounting entries while preparing its results for the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s said on Monday that an employee had “intentionally” misstated and hidden up to $154 million in delivery expenses over the past few years, forcing the retailer to delay a much-anticipated earnings report that Wall Street uses to gauge the strength of holiday shopping.

headline: Ex-Dancer Accuses Shen Yun of Forced Labor and Trafficking in Lawsuit
abstract: The former performer, who was recruited to join Shen Yun at age 13, said the prominent dance group coerced children into making money for it.
lead_paragraph: A former dancer for Shen Yun Performing Arts, the prominent music and dance company of the Falun Gong religious movement, filed a lawsuit on Monday accusing the group and its leaders of trafficking vulnerable children to work for little to no pay.

headline: Dating App Fatigue? In Vermont, Personal Ads Still Thrive.
abstract: Small weekly seeks readers looking for love.
lead_paragraph: Katie Flagg moved to Vermont when she was 18 to attend Middlebury College and fell in love at first sight — with the state. But after she graduated and moved to a farmhouse in the middle of rural Addison County, she had a sudden pang of doubt: Would she live there alone forever?

headline: Israeli Strikes Destroy Buildings Near Beirut
abstract: Israel hit buildings in the Dahiya area south of Beirut, Lebanon, as it continued a heavy exchange of fire with Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Israel hit buildings in the Dahiya area south of Beirut, Lebanon, as it continued a heavy exchange of fire with Hezbollah.

headline: U.K. Man Fighting for Ukraine Is Said to Be Captured in Russia
abstract: Russian state media reported that a British volunteer for the Ukrainian Army was captured amid fighting in the Kursk region.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces in the country’s Kursk region have captured a British man who volunteered for the Ukrainian Army, Russia’s state news agencies reported, in what would likely be the first case of a Westerner detained on Russian soil while fighting for Ukraine.

headline: If My Dying Daughter Could Face Her Mortality, Why Couldn’t the Rest of Us?
abstract: A bereaved mother’s case against our grief-phobic culture.
lead_paragraph: The first week of March 2022, I flew to Miami with my 13-year-old daughter, Orli; her 8-year-old sister, Hana; and my partner, Ian. We were, by all appearances, healthy. Robust, even.

headline: Steel Maker ThyssenKrupp to Slash 11,000 Jobs in Germany
abstract: The venerable steel producer, which has been struggling against high energy prices at home and growing competition from abroad, is the latest company in Europe to cut its work force.
lead_paragraph: ThyssenKrupp, the largest steel maker in Germany, said Monday that it would eliminate up to 11,000 jobs by 2030, a decision that comes as the country struggled to overcome economic weakness that has hindered growth for nearly two years.

headline: Can Wall Street Billionaires Deliver on Trump’s Blue-Collar Promise?
abstract: The president-elect has named wealthy financiers for key economic positions, raising questions about how much they will follow through on promises to help the working class.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump first ran for the White House in 2016, his closing campaign advertisement lamented the influence of Wall Street in Washington, flashing ominous images of big banks and the billionaire liberal philanthropist George Soros.

headline: Trump’s Middle East Envoy Has Prior Ties to Oil-Rich Nations There
abstract: Steve Witkoff’s involvement with two sovereign wealth funds as he bought and then sold Manhattan’s Park Lane Hotel demonstrates the potential conflicts his new role will present.
lead_paragraph: Steven Witkoff, the billionaire New York real estate executive whom President-elect Donald J. Trump has named as his special envoy to the Middle East, was in a jam.

headline: Cheese Dreams Live Up to Their Name
abstract: These two-bite, snacky sandwiches are made with loads of Cheddar cheese spiked with Worcestershire sauce and garlic powder for oomph.
lead_paragraph: And seemingly without warning, Thanksgiving is only three days away. I’m not going to stress you out with a checklist of things to do for the great feast (except for a little reminder to defrost your turkey if you haven’t already). Instead, I’m going to focus on getting you fed for all the other meals during this frantic week. Just because you’re cooking turkey on Thursday doesn’t mean you have to skip dinner tonight.

headline: ‘DNA Typewriters’ Can Record a Cell’s History
abstract: Labs around the world are trying to turn cells into autobiographers, tracking their own development from embryos to adults.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after conception, a fertilized egg divides, becoming two. Then each of those cells splits, becoming four, and on and on. Over time, those lineages of cells grow distinct, giving rise to all the different organs and tissues in the human body and comprising as many as 36 trillion cells.

headline: Democrats Rush to Regroup in the Southern Battlegrounds
abstract: With critical races in Georgia and North Carolina just two years away, the party is soul-searching on a time crunch.
lead_paragraph: For some Democrats in the South, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victories in Georgia and North Carolina this month crystallized a nagging fear that the inroads they had made in these presidential battlegrounds could be dismissed as a fluke.

headline: What’s Going on With All of These Food Recalls?
abstract: It might seem like there’s news about E. coli or listeria every week. Here’s what the data on food safety actually show.
lead_paragraph: There has been a barrage of bad news about food lately. Ten people died after eating Boar’s Head deli meat in a listeria outbreak that hospitalized dozens of others. One person has died and more than 100 people have been sickened in an E. coli outbreak linked to onions served on McDonald’s Quarter Pounders. This month, there has been a food recall nearly every day.

headline: Kitchens Are a Force for Social Change
abstract: Places that make and prepare food have a quietly revolutionary impact on the communities around them. In a new series from Headway, we train a lens on kitchens that are sparking change.
lead_paragraph: On the outskirts of Austin, Texas, a place called Community First! Village has become pivotal to the city’s plans for addressing homelessness in the city.

headline: Overcoming Obesity, With Diet and Physical Education
abstract: Responses to a news article about overweight Americans. Also: Cabinet picks accused of sexual abuse; transgender rights; boys’ feelings about the election.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The ‘Rocket Docket’ Judge Who Will Decide the Fate of Google’s Ad Technology
abstract: The ruling by a federal judge, Leonie Brinkema, in an antitrust case over Google’s advertising technology could add to the internet company’s woes.
lead_paragraph: During a trial in a Virginia courtroom in September over Google’s dominance in advertising technology, concepts and phrases like a “second-price auction," “demand-side platforms” and “header bidding” repeatedly came up.

headline: An A.I. Granny Is Phone Scammers’ Worst Nightmare
abstract: Daisy Harris, an A.I.-generated English granny, has been stymying scammers with meandering, time-wasting conversations. But can she actually make a dent in the flood of fraud?
lead_paragraph: Daisy Harris likes birds — there’s one outside her window. Her cat is named Fluffy, and she’d love to tell you about her knitting hobby. She likes tea and biscuits. And she just can’t seem to figure out this internet thing.

headline: In Haiti, a Grim Barometer: Even United Nations Workers Are Fleeing
abstract: A surge in gang violence over the past two weeks has led international aid organizations to rethink their staff levels in Haiti.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations helicopter has been buzzing nonstop for days over Haiti, as the U.N. starts to draw down its personnel in Port-au-Prince, evacuating 14 people at a time in chopper rides.

headline: How Much Thanksgiving Turkey Should I Buy Per Person?
abstract: Have enough — but not too much — for a feast.
lead_paragraph: On Thanksgiving, leftovers are natural and expected — even hotly anticipated. But striking that balance between extra and way too much can be difficult.

headline: Storm Bert Causes Flooding Across Britain and Ireland
abstract: Heavy weekend rain and strong winds brought in by Storm Bert caused widespread flooding and travel disruptions across Britain and Ireland, and killed at least three people in England and Wales.
lead_paragraph: Heavy weekend rain and strong winds brought in by Storm Bert caused widespread flooding and travel disruptions across Britain and Ireland, and killed at least three people in England and Wales.

headline: Kendrick Lamar Heads Back to His Comfort Zone on ‘GNX’
abstract: After a war of words with Drake that yielded one of the biggest hits of Lamar’s career, the Los Angeles rapper is eager to shift back on his sixth album.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, Kendrick Lamar steps into the present.

headline: New Mexico City to Pay $20 Million to Family of Woman Shot by Police
abstract: New Mexico has among the highest rates of killings by police officers in the U.S., and officials are trying to reduce the number of deadly encounters.
lead_paragraph: The city of Las Cruces, N.M., has agreed to pay $20 million to the family of a 45-year-old woman who was shot and killed by a city police officer, settling a lawsuit that highlighted the state’s persistently high rate of police killings.

headline: U.A.E. Arrests 3 Uzbeks Linked to Murder of Israeli Rabbi
abstract: Israeli authorities say the abduction and killing of Rabbi Zvi Kogan was an act of antisemitic terrorism, but investigators have not yet stated a motive.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates on Monday announced the arrests of three Uzbek nationals in connection with the kidnapping and murder of an Israeli-Moldovan rabbi, an attack that raised alarm over the safety of the small Jewish community in the country.

headline: Republicans Freak Out Over Trump’s Choice for Labor Secretary
abstract: The business wing of the party is appalled that he chose someone who supports workers’ rights.
lead_paragraph: It might be the most shocking news yet to come out of this roller-coaster of a transition: After weeks of choosing cabinet secretaries who seem determined to destroy the agencies they will lead, Donald Trump announced the choice of a secretary of labor whom many American workers actually like.

headline: Do You Use Online Betting Markets? Tell Us About It.
abstract: The New York Times is covering the rise of online betting markets. We want to hear about the experiences of people who use them, either for recreational purposes or as a source of income.
lead_paragraph: After a Supreme Court case in 2018 opened the door to legal sports gambling, millions of Americans began using sports betting platforms like DraftKings and FanDuel. During the election season, many also placed bets on political outcomes using platforms like PredictIt, Kalshi and Polymarket.

headline: Bishop T.D. Jakes Recovering From ‘Health Incident’ During Sunday Sermon
abstract: Bishop Jakes received immediate medical attention and is now “stable and under the care of medical professionals,” according to the Potter’s House, his megachurch.
lead_paragraph: Bishop T.D. Jakes, the Dallas-based megachurch pastor, was recovering after he experienced an unspecified “health incident” during his Sunday sermon, according to his church.

headline: Devoted Aide Who Keeps Good News Flowing Will Follow Trump to the White House
abstract: Natalie Harp, a 33-year-old former anchor on a right-wing cable show, is poised to become the gatekeeper for information to and from the president.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has always demanded loyalty from his aides, but few have answered the call quite like Natalie Harp.

headline: Thousands Defy Pakistan Crackdown to Rally for Imran Khan’s Release
abstract: Supporters of the ex-prime minister marched toward Islamabad, the capital. Clashes with the police left at least one officer dead, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of supporters of jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan defied a government lockdown and violent police opposition to march to the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan, on Monday evening and demand his release, the latest escalation of political tensions.

headline: The Nosy and Deadly 81-Year-Old With an 8-Year-Old Blackmailer
abstract: Our columnist on new thrillers by Christopher Bollen, M.W. Craven and Marie Tierney.
lead_paragraph: HAVOC (Harper, 242 pp., $30), a deliciously nasty tale of resentment and revenge, is set in a once-fashionable hotel in Luxor, Egypt, where 81-year-old Maggie Burkhardt has grandly taken up residence during the pandemic. Her insatiable need to meddle in the lives of others, often without their knowledge, has already forced her to make exits from 18 previous hotels over five years.

headline: ‘Liberated’ From Leadership, McConnell Is Ready to Pick His Own Fights
abstract: The longest-serving Senate leader is relinquishing his post in the next Congress and planning to use his influence in ways that could put him at odds with President-elect Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The last time President Donald J. Trump was in the White House, Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who was then the majority leader, played a crucial role in empowering him and pushing through his agenda.

headline: Biden Pardons Turkeys for the Last Time as President
abstract: Setting aside politics, the president used the lighthearted ceremony to thank the nation one more time for the opportunity to serve.
lead_paragraph: President Biden appeared for eight minutes on Monday to extend pardons to a pair of Thanksgiving turkeys, with a quick nod to the 77-year-old tradition and a brief moment of reflection to give thanks to the country.

headline: Jack Smith Seeks Dismissal of Two Federal Cases Against Trump
abstract: The special counsel effectively brought to a close the Justice Department efforts to hold Donald J. Trump accountable in the election and classified documents cases.
lead_paragraph: The special counsel Jack Smith asked two courts on Monday to effectively shut down the federal criminal cases he brought against President-elect Donald J. Trump last year, bowing to a Justice Department policy that says it is unconstitutional to pursue prosecutions against sitting presidents.

headline: U.S. Says Google Is an Ad Tech Monopolist, in Closing Arguments
abstract: The two sides made their final cases to a federal judge Monday in a trial over the tech giant’s dominance in technology that sells ads online.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the United States on Monday said that Google had created a monopoly with its services to place ads online, closing out an antitrust trial over the company’s dominance in advertising technology that could add to the Silicon Valley giant’s mounting woes.

headline: Judge Allows San Jose State Transgender Volleyball Player to Compete
abstract: A federal judge ruled that the player, who is at the center of a controversy over transgender athletes, can participate in a women’s volleyball conference tournament this week.
lead_paragraph: A transgender volleyball player at San Jose State University can continue to compete on the women’s team, a judge ruled Monday, despite complaints from other players who object to the participation of an athlete who is transgender.

headline: Thousands Demand Imran Khan’s Release in Major Pakistan Rally
abstract: The capital of Pakistan is under lockdown as thousands of supporters of jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan have marched towards Islamabad to demand his release.
lead_paragraph: The capital of Pakistan is under lockdown as thousands of supporters of jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan have marched towards Islamabad to demand his release.

headline: Paul Caponigro, Photographer in Love with Nature, Dies at 91
abstract: He photographed landscapes, deer, sunflowers and still lifes. “I knew that the forces of nature were a language,” he said. “Nature was really my teacher.”
lead_paragraph: In 1967, when the renowned landscape photographer Paul Caponigro was living in Dublin, he learned about a herd of white deer in nearby County Wicklow. Intrigued, he asked a man who worked on a large estate there if he could get his dog to chase the deer in and out of a forest.

headline: Who Needs Congress When You Have Cameo?
abstract: Matt Gaetz, who was Donald Trump’s former pick for attorney general, will wish you a happy birthday. For $500.
lead_paragraph: Recently out of politics? Have some time on your hands and want to make a few bucks?

headline: Nan Goldin Challenges Germany on What Artists Can Say About Israel
abstract: A speech by the artist at an exhibition of her work was followed by protests from her supporters and an uproar in the news media.
lead_paragraph: The artist and activist Nan Goldin makes no secret of her views about Israel and the wars in Gaza and Lebanon.

headline: Widespread Microsoft Outage Takes Email and Videoconferencing Offline
abstract: The software giant said it was working on a fix for the issue, which has affected the many companies that use Microsoft’s products. It later said it had fixed all affected services except Outlook on the web.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s customers were unable to gain access to their email or videoconferencing systems on Monday, as a wave of outages spread across the country after a faulty software update inside the company’s huge computer network.

headline: Yann Nury’s Twice Baked Potatoes With Caviar
abstract: The New York-based chef elevates the classic potato dish with crème fraîche instead of sour cream and a dollop of caviar on top.
lead_paragraph: The New York-based chef elevates the classic potato dish with crème fraîche instead of sour cream and a dollop of caviar on top.

headline: A Simple Baked Potato, With a Luxurious Twist
abstract: The French-born chef Yann Nury shares a festive take on a classic American comfort food.
lead_paragraph: Caviar purists suggest that the ideal way to enjoy a hit of the briny roe is atop something starchy and a little rich. A blini, plucked from a passing cocktail tray, will do. But so will the humble potato. The New York-based chef Yann Nury, 41, describes it, in fact, as “the ideal receptacle for a noble product.” And unlike a bite-size canapé, a caviar-adorned jacket potato is both luxurious and comforting.

headline: Vast Oceans of Water May Be Hiding Within Uranus and Neptune
abstract: A scientist simulated the contents of the ice giant worlds, and found that a fluid layer may explain each planet’s strange magnetic field.
lead_paragraph: We might finally understand what’s going on inside Uranus and Neptune, and the answer is pretty surprising: They may each contain an ocean of water.

headline: Squirting Cucumbers Shoot Their Seeds Like Botanical Bombardiers
abstract: Scientists say they’ve worked out how the plant can fire its seeds up to almost 40 feet.
lead_paragraph: The hairy, ground-hugging vines of the squirting cucumber Ecballium elaterium might seem like an ordinary weedy plant. But take a closer look at the plant, which grows in dry, barren areas in the Mediterranean, and you’ll find “an extraordinary thing,” said Chris Thorogood, a botanist at the University of Oxford Botanic Garden and Arboretum.

headline: The Certainty of Uncertainty
abstract: There’s no avoiding uncertainty in economics, so we need tools to deal with it
lead_paragraph: A century ago, Frank Knight wrote a book that put uncertainty in its rightful place at the heart of economics and entrepreneurship. I love that his last name was a homonym of “night,” when objects are hidden by darkness and uncertainty reigns.

headline: Biden Pardons the Last Turkeys of His Presidency
abstract: President Biden, granting clemency to a pair of turkeys in an annual White House ceremony, expressed gratitude for serving as commander in chief.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, granting clemency to a pair of turkeys in an annual White House ceremony, expressed gratitude for serving as commander in chief.

headline: Judge Delays Hearing on Menendez Brothers’ Bid for Early Release
abstract: A hearing scheduled for mid-December was pushed back to Jan. 30 so the judge and the new L.A. district attorney could have time to review filings in the case.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Los Angeles said on Monday that a hearing on whether to resentence the brothers Erik and Lyle Menendez would be pushed back until early next year to give the court and a newly elected district attorney more time to review the case.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Trump’s Criminal Cases Likely to Be Dismissed
abstract: Plus, a possible cease-fire deal in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel, asked a federal judge in Washington and a court in Atlanta yesterday to dismiss two indictments against President-elect Donald Trump: one accusing him of attempting to overturn the 2020 election and one accusing him of illegally holding classified documents.

headline: There Have Been Dozens of ‘Wicked’ Interviews. Why Did This One Go Viral?
abstract: When a journalist asked the actress Cynthia Erivo about fans “holding space” for the movie’s signature song, a meme was born.
lead_paragraph: The press tour for “Wicked” has been a long blur of pink and green outfits and a seemingly endless run of interviews with the film’s two stars, Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo.

headline: Netflix to Screen ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’ in Havana
abstract: The first two episodes will be shown at a film festival in Havana that was long championed by Gabriel García Márquez, the Colombian novelist who wrote the book.
lead_paragraph: Even after he won the Nobel Prize in Literature, Gabriel García Márquez sometimes described himself as a lover of film, and particularly Latin America film, at heart. At various points in his life he both studied and taught film, wrote screenplays and helped establish and lead the New Latin American Cinema Foundation in Cuba.

headline: Former Kentucky Sheriff Arraigned on Murder Charge in Judge Shooting
abstract: The former sheriff, Shawn Stines, was indicted last week after a local judge was shot to death in his chambers in September.
lead_paragraph: A former Kentucky sheriff was arraigned on a murder charge on Monday in the same county courthouse where he is accused of gunning down a judge in his chambers two months earlier.

headline: Jessica Tisch Is Sworn In as N.Y.P.D. Commissioner
abstract: Commissioner Tisch is the fourth person to hold the role during the Adams administration, and the department’s second-ever female leader.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Tisch was sworn in on Monday as the 48th commissioner of the Police Department as Mayor Eric Adams pushed back against criticism about a manager who has never walked a police beat leading a department of more than 34,000 officers.

headline: The Vice-Presidential Curse
abstract: Incumbent vice presidents running for president face unique challenges — and have a poor track record in elections.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Tonight, my colleague Ian Prasad Philbrick has a look at why it’s so difficult for sitting vice presidents to succeed their bosses. I’ll be back on Wednesday. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Here’s Where Weather May Disrupt Your Thanksgiving Travel
abstract: Millions of people are taking to the road and skies this week. Some may encounter dreary weather.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rain and snow across the country this week could disrupt the record number of travelers expected to be on the roads and in the skies for the Thanksgiving holiday.

headline: Special Counsel Moves to Dismiss Federal Cases Against Trump
abstract: Also, Israel is nearing a decision on a Lebanon cease-fire. Here's the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel who charged Donald Trump with 44 criminal counts across a pair of felony cases, asked two separate courts today to drop the charges against the president-elect. Within hours, one of the cases was dismissed.

headline: ‘Get Millie Black’ Is a Fresh Take on the Cop Drama
abstract: Created by the Booker Prize-winning author Marlon James, the HBO series puts a new spin on a lot of old crime show conventions.
lead_paragraph: “Get Millie Black,” beginning on Monday at 9 p.m., is another high-end HBO crime drama about a cop who does things her own way — against the rules, no matter what her angry boss says. She does so on account of her too-personal investment in this and all cases because of the way they remind her of her childhood. (Her lousy childhood, obviously.)

headline: When Your Workouts Turn Into a Work of Art
abstract: Using the maps from his daily runs, Duncan McCabe took the Strava art trend to new heights by creating an animated stickman that has become an online sensation.
lead_paragraph: Over the summer, when Duncan McCabe would tell his co-workers at his Toronto-area software company that he was heading out for a run, they would ask him whether he was training for a race.

headline: Trump Evaded Jack Smith and the Rule of Law
abstract: He will spend his presidential term with no fear of a verdict on his federal indictments.
lead_paragraph: The real verdict on Donald Trump will be issued by the American people.

headline: Driver Kills 3 Florida Deputies in a ‘Gut Punch’ to Palm Beach County
abstract: Three members of the motorcycle unit at the Palm Beach County Sheriff’s Office were struck by a driver on Thursday. Two died that day, and a third who had been in critical condition died on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials in Palm Beach County, Fla., were already planning a memorial for two members of the sheriff’s office who were killed in a crash last week when they learned on Monday that a third, who was in critical condition, had died.

headline: Florida Woman Who Fatally Shot Black Neighbor Gets 25 Years in Prison
abstract: Susan Lorincz, who shot Ajike Owens, was convicted of manslaughter. The case prompted national outrage.
lead_paragraph: A white woman in Florida who fatally shot a Black neighbor who confronted her amid a longstanding dispute over the neighbor’s children was sentenced on Monday to 25 years in prison.

headline: Biden White House Holds Up U.S. Contribution to Anti-Doping Agency
abstract: The administration is pressing the World Anti-Doping Agency to allow an outside audit after it failed to suspend Chinese swimmers for positive tests.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is holding up the annual U.S. payment to the World Anti-Doping Agency to press the organization to make changes in the wake of revelations that it chose not to discipline elite Chinese swimmers who tested positive for a banned drug, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Kohl’s Picks C.E.O. of Michaels to Help It Turn Around
abstract: Ashley Buchanan will be the third chief executive of the department store chain since 2018.
lead_paragraph: Kohl’s has hired Ashley Buchanan, chief executive of the crafts retailer Michaels, to be its next chief executive, the department store chain said on Monday. Mr. Buchanan, who has run Michaels since 2020, will start on Jan. 15.

headline: We’re Talking Thanksgiving With Martha Stewart, David Chang, Gayle King, Gwyneth Paltrow and More
abstract: We’ve gathered some of the biggest names in cooking and culture to share warm memories, hot takes and delicious recipes.
lead_paragraph: We’ve gathered some of the biggest names in cooking and culture to share warm memories, hot takes and delicious recipes.

headline: Crony Capitalism Is Coming to America
abstract: Business success may increasingly depend on connections, not competence.
lead_paragraph: It’s late 2025, and Donald Trump has done what he said he would do: impose high tariffs — taxes on imports — on goods coming from abroad, with extremely high tariffs on imports from China. These tariffs have had exactly the effect many economists predicted, although Trump insisted otherwise: higher prices for American buyers.

headline: End of Trump Cases Leaves Limits on Presidential Criminality Unclear
abstract: Donald J. Trump is set to regain office without clarity on the scope of presidential immunity and with a lingering cloud over whether outside special counsels can investigate high-level wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: The end of the two federal criminal cases against President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday left momentous, unsettled questions about constraints on criminal wrongdoing by presidents, from the scope of presidential immunity to whether the Justice Department may continue to appoint outside special counsels to investigate high-level wrongdoing.

headline: Trump Plans Tariffs on Mexico, Canada and China That Could Cripple Trade
abstract: The president-elect said that he would impose the across-the-board tariffs on Day 1 and that they would stay in place until Canada, Mexico and China halted the flow of drugs and migrants.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on President-elect Trump’s transition.

headline: At the Brooklyn Academy, Musical Journeys Through Minefields
abstract: The Silkroad Ensemble’s “American Railroad” and Alarm Will Sound’s “Sun Dogs” used music and images to engage with difficult topics.
lead_paragraph: The completion of the transcontinental railroad was a herculean achievement. In 1850, the United States had 10,000 miles of track; by 1900, trains carried people, goods and ideas from coast to coast over 215,000 miles of track. Recently, historians have begun to tally the human cost of this construction project, especially among the people who performed the dangerous and backbreaking labor and the Native tribes whose lands and livelihoods were slashed through by the tracks.

headline: There Is No Excuse for the Bullying of Sarah McBride
abstract: After a brutal election, Democrats need to get better at talking about trans issues.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine how terrifying it must be to be a trans person, or the parent of one, in America right now.

headline: Trial of Controversial Alzheimer’s Drug Halted After Disappointing Results
abstract: Cassava Sciences said that its drug did not significantly reduce cognitive decline in 1,900 people with mild to moderate Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Cassava Sciences, a small biotechnology company based in Austin, Texas, announced it would stop the advanced clinical trial for an experimental Alzheimer’s drug, ending a long-contested bid for regulatory approval.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 26, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about the ruling junta in Mali replacing the country’s prime minister misstated the military rank of the new prime minister, Abdoulaye Maiga. He is a general, not a colonel.

headline: Significant Stretches
abstract: Killian Olson makes his Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Israeli Strikes Threaten Lebanon’s Archaeological Treasures
abstract: The country is home to thousands of years’ worth of antiquities. Some have already been damaged or destroyed in the war, alarming the conservationists trying to protect them.
lead_paragraph: For Mohammad Kanso, the ancient Roman temples of Baalbek felt like home.

headline: Top Trump Aide Accused of Asking for Money to ‘Promote’ Potential Appointees
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump ordered the investigation by his legal team into Boris Epshteyn, a powerful figure in the transition. Mr. Epshteyn denies the allegations.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s legal team found evidence that a top adviser asked for retainer fees from potential appointees in order to promote them for jobs in the new administration, five people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

headline: Biden Administration to Lend $6 Billion for Rivian E.V. Factory
abstract: The financing for a factory in Georgia is part of a last-minute effort to establish climate policies before President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Monday that it would lend $6 billion to help Rivian build an electric car factory in Georgia, part of an effort to lock in Democratic climate policies before President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office.

headline: TikTok Influencer Arrested After Documenting Stolen Items, Police Say
abstract: Marlena Velez, 22, stole the items by scanning false bar codes in the self-checkout to make the items cheaper, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A Florida woman and TikTok influencer was arrested after she shoplifted about $500 worth of items from Target and posted about her shopping spree to her hundreds of thousands of social media followers, the authorities said.

headline: Quote of the Day: PULLOUTS BY U.N. DISMAY HAITIANS
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 26, 2024
lead_paragraph: “What about the ones who can’t leave?”

headline: The World’s Pioneering Tech Cop Is Making Her Exit
abstract: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s antitrust regulator, who put technology’s harms on the global agenda, reflected on a decade of taking on the biggest companies and what comes next.
lead_paragraph: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union antitrust enforcer who has been the world’s foremost critic of the tech industry, recently walked through her Brussels office wondering what to do with the stuff she had accumulated during a decade in that role, which ends late this month. At one point, she paused to lift a sculpture of a hand holding up its middle finger.

headline: China’s Police Are Preying on Small Firms in Search of Cash
abstract: With localities facing budget holes, the police are crossing provincial borders to collect fines and draining company treasuries. Businesses call it a shakedown.
lead_paragraph: In April 2023, police officers from a city in southern Guangdong Province traveled 600 miles north to Wuhan, detained 25 employees of a social media company and coerced its finance staff to transfer more than $41 million to accounts associated with the police.

headline: Angela Merkel Tells Us What She Really Thinks
abstract: In her memoir, the former German chancellor reflects on her political rise and defends her record as the outlook for her country turns grim.
lead_paragraph: “Never explain, never complain,” is a maxim supposedly espoused by the British royal family. As Angela Merkel writes in her exhaustive yet surprisingly fast-paced autobiography, “Freedom,” it also became a phrase that she would repeat to herself during her 16 years as German chancellor, from 2005 until she stepped down in December 2021.

headline: As Russia Advances in Ukraine, a Cop Has to Flee City After City
abstract: For Volodymyr Nikulin, being a wartime police officer means aiding evacuees, surviving a shrapnel wound and tackling looters. It also means quickly switching cities when one falls to the invaders.
lead_paragraph: The belongings of Volodymyr Nikulin, a Ukrainian police officer stationed near the country’s eastern front line, boil down to this: a shrapnel-riddled car, a small sack stuffed with sweaters and pants, and two plastic bags filled with basic food and medicine.

headline: A Misstep by Ireland’s Prime Minister Muddies Election Race
abstract: A fumbled meeting with a voter may dent Simon Harris’s popularity. But his coalition government’s main opposition, the nationalist party Sinn Fein, will likely remain locked out of power.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the Republic of Ireland looked like a rare Western democracy bent on defying the global trend of tossing out its government. The two centrist parties that have governed Ireland in a coalition since 2020, Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil, appeared to be on cruise control to lock up enough votes to stay in power.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Talks on a truce between Israel and Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is set to meet with his cabinet today to discuss a proposed cease-fire with Hezbollah, Israeli officials said. U.S. officials have pressured him to finalize the terms this week, and Netanyahu has indicated that he’s open to a deal, according to other Israeli officials briefed on his thinking.

headline: Rescuers Walk 14 Hours to Save Sole Survivor of Costa Rica Plane Crash
abstract: Rescue workers trekked overnight across a remote mountain forest carrying a woman who had survived a crash that killed five of the six people aboard.
lead_paragraph: Emergency workers in Costa Rica walked through a remote mountain forest on Tuesday carrying a woman who was in critical condition after she survived a plane crash that killed five of the six people aboard.

headline: Mr. Trump, Do You Realize How Much the World Has Changed Since You Were President?
abstract: Three giant, shifting tectonic plates will have profound implications for the new administration.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump left the White House nearly four years ago. Given his self-confidence, I suspect he is now thinking: “What could be so different? I’ve got this.”

headline: She Was the Most Powerful Woman in the World. And She Isn’t Ready to Say Sorry.
abstract: In her memoir, Angela Merkel doesn’t take the chance to make amends.
lead_paragraph: On page 273 of her memoir, Angela Merkel admits she made a mistake.

headline: Late Night Makes Its Last Jokes About Biden Pardoning Turkeys
abstract: Although Thanksgiving was still three days away, “the turkeys looked at Biden and said, ‘We better get this done,’” Jimmy Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: propaganda
abstract: This word has appeared in 678 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word propaganda has appeared in 678 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 29 in “How Russia, China and Iran Are Interfering in the Presidential Election” by Sheera Frenkel, Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers:

headline: Rocket Engine Fire Stalls Japan’s Ambitions to Launch Satellites
abstract: Japan is off to a shaky start in its efforts to break into the space rocket market dominated by Elon Musk’s SpaceX.
lead_paragraph: Japan halted an engine test for one of its flagship rockets after a fire broke out at the launch site on Tuesday, marking the latest setback in the country’s efforts to establish a foothold in the growing market for vehicles capable of launching satellites into orbit.

headline: Fire Engulfs Japan Rocket Test Site
abstract: Large plumes of smoke billowed from the launch site at Tanegashima Space Center, Japan, after a malfunction during an engine test.
lead_paragraph: Large plumes of smoke billowed from the launch site at Tanegashima Space Center, Japan, after a malfunction during an engine test.

headline: He Was One of New York’s Busiest Shoplifters. His Mother Was a Cop.
abstract: Drug addiction fueled David Andino’s need to steal. Every day, he hit the same Target in Manhattan. His mother, a retired police officer, hadn’t seen him in years.
lead_paragraph: The shoplifter knew the geography of the big gleaming Target store in TriBeCa as well as he knew his dingy little $20-a-week room uptown.

headline: On the Wings of War
abstract: Scientists study the flight of hummingbirds to design robots for drone warfare.
lead_paragraph: Hummingbirds zooming around the garden from flower to flower and sipping nectar probably don’t appear at first glance to be models for instruments of war.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: How to Watch the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: For the 98th time, Macy’s brings New Yorkers its annual parade. This year, there will be 22 floats, 17 character balloons and performances by the Temptations and T-Pain.
lead_paragraph: A flying turkey, loads of confetti and dazzling dancers. It’s time to kick off the holidays in New York City.

headline: 5 Ways to Fix New York City’s Housing Crisis
abstract: Here is what renters, landlords, developers and politicians say.
lead_paragraph: This is The Housing Crunch, a five-part series on New York City’s affordable housing crisis.

headline: They Attended Trump’s Trial. Now He’s Offering Them High-Profile Jobs.
abstract: A parade of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s allies showed their loyalty at his criminal trial in Manhattan. Many are now in line for key government jobs.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny spring day this year, two members of Congress and two former presidential candidates stepped out of the Manhattan courthouse where Donald J. Trump was being tried on criminal charges.

headline: ‘Glicked’
abstract: Can “Wicked” and “Gladiator II” recapture the magic of “Barbenheimer”?
lead_paragraph: “Wicked” and “Gladiator II” both opened on Friday. With its own catchy portmanteau, “Glicked,” some fans are trying to recapture the excitement from the movie event of last summer: the same-day opening of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer,” or “Barbenheimer.”

headline: Their Landlord Overcharged Them. Now Tenants Will Split $15 Million.
abstract: Dozens of New York City renters are receiving payoffs from Blackstone in a settlement of a case that accused the previous landlord of violating rent-stabilization rules.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Blackstone is paying some New York City renters more than $100,000 each to resolve claims that they had been overcharged for their rent-stabilized apartments, according to court papers and an announcement from a housing watchdog group on Tuesday.

headline: Pakistan Deploys Army in Its Capital as Protesters and Police Clash
abstract: Soldiers were ordered to defend government buildings with gunfire if needed, as supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan demanded his release from prison.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan deployed its army in the nation’s capital on Tuesday with orders to shoot protesters if necessary, as deadly clashes escalated between the police and supporters of former Prime Minister Imran Khan.

headline: China’s Huawei Takes Aim at Apple With Latest Smartphone
abstract: Last year, a chip breakthrough put Huawei on top of the Chinese smartphone market. Now it is rolling out its newest phone, the Mate 70 series.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the tech giant Huawei catapulted to the top of the smartphone market in China when it released the Mate 60 Pro, a phone that contained a tiny computer chip more advanced than any previously made by a Chinese company.

headline: Hong Kong’s Top Court Upholds Rights of Same-Sex Married Couples
abstract: Long-running legal battles culminated in a ruling that preserves public housing benefits and inheritance rights in the territory.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong’s top court ruled on Tuesday to uphold inheritance and public housing benefits for same-sex married couples, a decision that supporters hailed as an important step toward expanding gay rights in the territory.

headline: Is Creativity Dead?
abstract: Or is the algorithm just hiding it from you?
lead_paragraph: Or is the algorithm just hiding it from you?

headline: The Future Is Eerie in This Queens Townhouse
abstract: Two designers created a unique home that they hope makes visitors feel like they’re in an alternate world.
lead_paragraph: When Erica Sellers bought a townhouse in Ridgewood, Queens, with plans to renovate it, she simply wanted to build a new home for herself. But after she invited her friend Jeremy Silberberg to see it, the project grew into something much more ambitious.

headline: This Drinking Habit Is More Dangerous Than Bingeing
abstract: And it’s on the rise among middle-aged drinkers.
lead_paragraph: The holidays offer an excuse to gather with loved ones, let loose and indulge: Plates loaded with comfort foods. Unapologetic napping. All the pie.

headline: Colombia and Venezuela Have a Beef: Who Owns the, or Makes the Best, Arepa?
abstract: Both countries claim the cornbread as their own. But where does it really come from? And who makes it better?
lead_paragraph: A heated and longstanding rivalry simmers between neighbors Colombia and Venezuela — not over politics, migration or even soccer, but over the humble arepa.

headline: Taxing Farm Animals’ Farts and Burps? Denmark Gives It a Try.
abstract: Cows and pigs produce a large share of planet-warming methane. A new tax is part of a plan to clean that up.
lead_paragraph: Denmark, known for its inventive restaurants and elegant design studios, is about to become known for something more basic: the world’s first belch and manure tax.

headline: ‘Wicked’ and the Merchandising Juggernaut That Eclipses ‘Barbie’
abstract: The new movie’s tie-ins are the logical endpoint for a Broadway show that always intended to be huge.
lead_paragraph: It started with the dolls.

headline: Big, Bold ’80s-Esque Jewelry Is Back
abstract: The season’s most precious accessories come in bright colors, with plenty of sparkle and an abundance of gold.

headline: Emma Corrin and Maggie Nelson on the Strength in Vulnerability
abstract: The “Nosferatu” actor and the writer discuss solitude, self-editing and the playfulness of their work.
lead_paragraph: Emma Corrin first encountered Maggie Nelson’s work three summers ago, when the actor was in Brighton, England, filming 2022’s “My Policeman,” a British drama about postwar sexual repression. At the time, Corrin, now 28, was grappling with their gender identity, and a friend recommended “The Argonauts” (2015), Nelson’s memoir about queer desire and making a family with her partner, the artist Harry Dodge. The book appealed so deeply to Corrin that, when that production ended, they decided to remain at the flat they’d rented during filming to finish reading it.

headline: For These TikTok Dramas, It Is All About the Storytelling
abstract: Short-form series like “Bistro Huddy” and Paloma Diamond bring old-fashioned serials to the world of social media.
lead_paragraph: The most popular dish on the menu at Bistro Huddy is the Santa Fe Chicken. Unfortunately, you can’t order it, no matter how often the restaurant’s regular customers do. That’s because the brick-walled bistro isn’t a restaurant at all. Rather, it’s a green screen set up in the Los Angeles home of Drew Talbert and his wife, Andrea Kelley.

headline: The Air in Subway Stations Is Bad for You, Study Finds
abstract: An N.Y.U. researcher found that the No. 1 stations in Washington Heights are especially unhealthy. The M.T.A. doesn’t agree.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at a study that said air quality in subway stations is poor. And, with the migrant crisis easing, we’ll look at what President-elect Donald Trump’s threats to deport undocumented immigrants might mean for the city.

headline: $29 Flights, Half-Price Cruises: Whether It’s Black Friday or Travel Tuesday, Deals Abound
abstract: Our Frugal Traveler columnist waded through the sales, and found some of the best bargains she’s seen in years.
lead_paragraph: As a sales season, Black Friday long ago turned the weekend corner to extend to Cyber Monday. And it’s still growing as Travel Tuesday — this year falling on Dec. 3 — gains traction.

headline: Does the United States Have an Infertility Crisis?
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has pledged to investigate the issue. Here’s what we know — and what we don’t — about infertility in America.
lead_paragraph: It’s become a popular talking point among some of President-elect Trump’s most prominent supporters: America has an infertility problem.

headline: Modern Warfare Is Breeding Deadly Superbugs. Why?
abstract: Researchers are trying to understand why resistant pathogens are so prevalent in the war-torn nations of the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Last October, Christina Assi, a 28-year-old photojournalist for Agence France-Presse, took a selfie against the sunset and WhatsApped it to her mother. “Be careful,” her mother replied.

headline: Moths Were Destroying My Clothes. Tiny Parasitic Wasps Saved Them.
abstract: A “weird city version” of common countryside wisdom saved my favorite outfits.
lead_paragraph: Everything in life is a trade-off between money and time; when it comes to collecting vintage fashion, I put in the time. Catalogs from brands like Dries van Noten, Narciso Rodriguez and Prada, heavy as bibles, guide my search for cheap grails. I’ve often had the feeling that I’m rescuing these items from living with someone who wouldn’t appreciate them. Do they even care that Rodriguez finished his seams so elegantly that you can wear his dresses inside out? This level of care makes me feel calm in a careless world. During the pandemic, the brightly clashing florals of Van Noten’s 2008 Spring-Summer collection captured my heart — and bit by bit, via eBay and Etsy, my closet became a lush and jumbled garden. I’m not much of a nature person, but these were the sorts of pandemic plants I could tend to.

headline: Review: ‘We Are Your Robots,’ Still Tuning Up
abstract: In Ethan Lipton’s musings on A.I., Mozart has a place alongside humpback whales.
lead_paragraph: Are they not men? The members of the onstage combo in Ethan Lipton’s new show are, in fact, robots, despite looking like middle-aged male representatives of the human species. They may play tunes for the benefit of the audience members, but their main purpose, Lipton informs us, is to find out “what you want from your machines, so we can make your lives better.” (Lipton narrates the show and performs lead vocals.) The purpose of the evening, it appears, is for these sophisticated high-tech creatures in gray suits to undergo deep learning.

headline: Transforming Daniel Craig Into a Very Grimy William Burroughs
abstract: The clothes in Luca Guadagnino’s new film “Queer” are almost entirely from the 1950s. So don’t expect them to look spotless.
lead_paragraph: “Queer,” the director Luca Guadagnino’s new film, is a tale of misplaced affection. It is also a movie that will leave neat freaks clutching their Tide pens.

headline: The Best Way to Eat Thanksgiving Leftovers? Sauced and Tucked Into a Tortilla
abstract: Give that day-old turkey new life, and turn it into tender pavo al pastor or a hearty birria.
lead_paragraph: There are many reluctant turkey eaters out there. Deeming it bland or boring or both, they might begrudgingly eat it out of tradition or politeness. But when leftovers are being passed out at the end of the night, they’re nowhere to be found.

headline: I Ran Operation Warp Speed. I’m Concerned About Bird Flu.
abstract: Avian influenza might mutate to enable human-to-human transmission.
lead_paragraph: As Donald Trump gets ready to return to the White House on Jan. 20, he must be prepared to tackle one issue immediately: the possibility that the spreading avian flu might mutate to enable human-to-human transmission.

headline: Is Creativity Dead?
abstract: Or is the algorithm just hiding it from you?
lead_paragraph: As you scroll through the internet, you’ve probably noticed the same problem Kirby Ferguson has: “Everything looks the same, sounds the same, is the same.” In the Opinion Video above, the filmmaker argues that our culture often appears to be plagued by a dearth of creativity. But what if, beneath the surface of mainstream culture, there was a world of wild imagination waiting to be discovered — if only a powerful force would stop suppressing it?

headline: Nicholas Kristof: Consider Skipping Meat This Thanksgiving
abstract: The columnist points out the hypocrisy of loving your dog while eating bacon.
lead_paragraph: It’s Thanksgiving week, and the columnist Nicholas Kristof wants you to consider skipping the turkey. “I don’t want to wag my fingers at people and tell them, ‘Look, this is how you should eat,’ but I do think that there are really important ethical questions that we have to ponder and confront,” he says. In this episode, Kristof argues that Americans, who spend thousands of dollars each year caring for their dogs, should spare a thought for the pigs who live short lives in brutal conditions before ending up on breakfast plates.

headline: Breaking Up Google Would Be a Big Mistake
abstract: Such a move would help no one.
lead_paragraph: There’s no question that Google dominates the world of internet search. But in attempting to open up this critical industry to more competition, the government is pursuing a cure worse than the disease. If the government is successful at breaking up Google, history tells us that consumers and many enterprises tied to our vast and flourishing internet may ultimately pay a price.

headline: Would Bernie Have Won?
abstract: Faiz Shakir makes a case for the Democratic Party to embrace economic populism.
lead_paragraph: As the Democratic Party debates where to go after its 2024 drubbing, we’re going to spend the next two episodes of the show featuring two very different perspectives on the way forward.

headline: Our Mount Rushmore of Fictional Presidents
abstract: Jed Bartlett and other presidents of our youth.
lead_paragraph: After a “stranger than fiction” presidential race, the hosts take a deep dive into the messy movie and television plots that actually put this election to shame.

headline: FIFA President’s Bet on Club World Cup Meets Reality
abstract: Gianni Infantino has tied his legacy to the 32-team tournament, even inscribing his name on the trophy. Its success is far from guaranteed.
lead_paragraph: Next summer, the United States will play host to an event that may define the legacy of FIFA’s president, Gianni Infantino.

headline: Do You Have Any Special or Unusual Holiday Traditions?
abstract: Times readers shared their fun, unique and eccentric holiday rituals — like singing to the turkey with a sibling while it roasts outside. What are yours?
lead_paragraph: There are many classic holiday traditions: baking cookies, throwing footballs in the backyard, ice skating as a light snow falls, wearing ugly Christmas sweaters, lighting a menorah or a kinara, watching family movies together.

headline: A Great Idea for People With a Terrible Disease: Let’s Find a Cure Ourselves
abstract: A group of long Covid patients is financing research and making progress.
lead_paragraph: This column is part of Times Opinion’s 2024 Giving Guide. Read more about the guide in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

headline: Biden Cuts Intel’s Chip Award by More Than $600 Million
abstract: The Silicon Valley company will receive less money from the CHIPS Act after winning a $3 billion military contract and changing some of its investment commitments.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said Tuesday that it would award up to $7.86 billion in direct funding to Intel, with the U.S. chip giant set to receive at least $1 billion of that money before the end of the year.

headline: Transgender Activists Question the Movement’s Confrontational Approach
abstract: Facing diminishing public support, some activists say all-or-nothing tactics are not working. “We have to make it OK for someone to change their minds.”
lead_paragraph: To get on the wrong side of transgender activists is often to endure their unsparing criticism.

headline: Obesity Drugs Would Be Covered by Medicare and Medicaid Under Biden Proposal
abstract: The proposed rule could give millions of Americans access to the new drugs; it will also put pressure on the incoming Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration, in one of its last major policy directives, proposed on Tuesday that Medicare and Medicaid cover obesity medications, a costly and probably popular move that the Trump administration would need to endorse to become official.

headline: Fentanyl Rises Again, This Time as Trump’s Diplomatic Weapon Against China
abstract: The president-elect’s pledge to use tariffs to stem the flow of opioids from China could backfire if Beijing responds by ending counternarcotics cooperation.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threat on Monday to slap China with new tariffs is a bitterly recurring issue: the flow into the United States of the potent opioid fentanyl, created using chemicals made in China.

headline: After Trump’s Tariff Threat, Is a China Currency War Next?
abstract: While China could offset American tariffs by letting its currency fall, that might endanger Beijing’s recent efforts to stabilize the economy.
lead_paragraph: Beijing has a powerful tool for responding to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threatened new tariffs on Chinese goods: It could start a currency war, a step that poses formidable risks for China as well as the United States.

headline: Fury Unfolds in Pakistan
abstract: Scenes from the violent clashes between the security forces and protesters who are demanding the release of Imran Khan from prison.
lead_paragraph: Through Imran Khan’s evolution from global sports star to anti-corruption crusader and to prime minister of Pakistan — and then to outsider after his ouster in 2022 — his ability to mobilize huge street protests through social media has been a potent tool to pressure his opponents.

headline: 4 Found Dead and 7 Still Missing After Tourist Ship Sinks in Egypt
abstract: The vessel was hit by a large wave in a part of the Red Sea coast that is known for diving and snorkeling.
lead_paragraph: Rescuers found five survivors and four bodies on Tuesday from the wreck of a boat carrying tourists that sank amid high waves off the Red Sea coast of Egypt a day earlier, according to the Egyptian authorities. Search efforts were continuing for seven other missing passengers and crew, they said.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,257
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 535
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Trump’s Dramatic Tariff Plan, and a Cease-Fire Takes Shape in Lebanon
abstract: Plus, Matt Gaetz’s new gig.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Metamorphosis of Pete Hegseth
abstract: Three military deployments reshaped the views of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Defense Department.
lead_paragraph: Now that Matt Gaetz has withdrawn from consideration as attorney general, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s most controversial cabinet pick is his selection of Pete Hegseth as secretary of defense.

headline: Russia Says Ukraine Struck Inside its Territory with U.S.-Made Missiles, Again
abstract: On Tuesday, Ukraine also reported enduring an immense Russian air assault overnight that involved nearly 200 drones, as both sides intensified air attacks.
lead_paragraph: Russia said on Tuesday that Ukraine had struck its territory again with U.S.-supplied missiles, just as the Ukrainian Air Force reported that Russia had unleashed an immense air assault overnight that involved nearly 200 drones.

headline: Barack Obama’s Big Lesson
abstract: We cover an analysis of the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: It remains Barack Obama’s most underrated political skill: his appeal to working-class voters, including those who are white.

headline: 100 Notable Books of 2024
abstract: Here are the year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, chosen by the staff of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Here are the year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, chosen by the staff of The New York Times Book Review.

headline: Sign Up to Learn the 10 Best Books of 2024
abstract: On Dec. 3, we’ll announce our picks. Make sure you’re among the first to find out.
lead_paragraph: Good news, book lovers! We’ve arrived at our list of the 10 Best Books of 2024, and we can’t wait to share it with you.

headline: Trump’s Tariff Threat Roils Global Markets
abstract: The dollar gained and investors sold off stocks after the president-elect promised to levy new restrictions on the United States’ biggest trade partners.
lead_paragraph: Investors and policymakers are getting a dose of Trumponomics déjà vu this morning.

headline: Walmart, Once Eager to Promote Diversity, Pulls Back Amid Conservative Pressure
abstract: Among other things, the retailer will no longer use the term D.E.I.
lead_paragraph: In June of 2020, as protesters spilled into the streets after the murder of George Floyd, Walmart’s chief executive, Doug McMillon, promised action.

headline: Has Social Media Advice Affected Your Finances? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: If you have come across misleading personal finance advice online, tell us. We may include your experiences in an article.
lead_paragraph: Social media and other platforms have helped make information on financial literacy, investing and trading more accessible than ever. Many accounts share information that can help people manage their money. But others are sharing advice that regulators say can be misleading.

headline: New Drug Causes 20 Percent Weight Loss in Early Amgen Results
abstract: The drug, which is named MariTide and delivered in a monthly injection, is some time away from being sold.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical manufacturer Amgen announced on Tuesday that an experimental obesity drug helped patients lose up to 20 percent of their weight in a year. The drug, MariTide, is given by injection once a month, compared with once a week for other obesity drugs like Wegovy and Zepbound that are already on the market.

headline: Mexico’s President Raises Prospect of Retaliatory Tariffs on U.S. Goods
abstract: President Claudia Sheinbaum responded to President-elect Trump’s threat to impose high tariffs, saying such a move would inflict damage on both countries.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum, hit back on Tuesday morning at President-elect Trump’s vow to impose 25 percent tariffs on all products coming into the United States from Mexico, signaling that her country was prepared to respond with retaliatory tariffs of its own.

headline: The Rebellious Beauty of Nollywood’s Screen Sirens
abstract: The distinctive makeup of early-aughts Nigerian movies is coming back — and so is the daring attitude of the women who wore it.
lead_paragraph: In the early 2000s, the femme fatales of Nollywood were seldom seen without pencil-thin eyebrows, a thick, dark swipe of lip liner or a carefully placed, painted-on beauty mark. In Nigerian films like “Games Women Play” (2005), “Yankee Girls” (2008), “Mama, I Will Die for You” (2004) and “Love & Marriage” (2004), the rebellious city girls, wayward wives and conniving mothers-in-law are quickly identifiable by their flashy makeup, which often remixed early-aughts American trends. Although these movies have been popular among West African and diasporic viewers since their releases, their circulation over the years was relatively narrow, restricted to VHS, DVD and niche corners of YouTube. But now, nearly two decades later, a broader audience is discovering these films online and recreating their distinctive beauty looks for themselves — turning the “bad girls” of Nollywood’s recent past into their own modern heroes.

headline: Thanksgiving Eve Means Meatballs
abstract: Specifically, Kay Chun’s 5-ingredient, 20-minute pork and ricotta meatballs that call out for your favorite marinara and a pile of rigatoni.
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, the night before Thanksgiving was for meatballs — a huge pot of them in burbling marinara sauce, with spaghetti alongside. (One year my brother’s golden retriever managed to knock at least four pounds of meatballs in sauce off the counter and went to town on them, but that’s another story.) Retriever incidents aside, I’m still a believer in meatballs as a cozy but festive way to feed a group: Everyone loves a meatball, and they are pretty easy both to make and to plan a menu around.

headline: Breyten Breytenbach, Anti-Apartheid Writer in Exile, Dies at 85
abstract: He wrote poetry in Afrikaans and prose in English in his fight against South African racial oppression, an effort that landed him in jail for seven years.
lead_paragraph: Breyten Breytenbach, a dissident South African-born poet, memoirist and former political prisoner who was jailed on trumped-up charges for anti-apartheid actions in the 1970s, died on Sunday in Paris, his longtime place of residence as an expatriate critic of his homeland. He was 85.

headline: North Carolina’s Democratic Governor Vetoes a G.O.P. Power Grab
abstract: Republicans have a supermajority in the state’s legislature and may move to override Gov. Roy Cooper’s veto, which would set off a new fight over state power and hurricane aid.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina, a Democrat, on Tuesday vetoed a bill passed by the state’s Republican-controlled legislature that would strip his office of important powers and shift more authority to G.O.P. officials.

headline: One Housing Project Got Built. Another Didn’t. Why?
abstract: There’s a solution to New York City’s housing shortage: Build more homes. But that can get complicated. Mihir Zaveri, a New York Times reporter covering housing in the New York City region, explains why one project got built and another did not.
lead_paragraph: There’s a solution to New York City’s housing shortage: Build more homes. But that can get complicated. Mihir Zaveri, a New York Times reporter covering housing in the New York City region, explains why one project got built and another did not.

headline: Drake Accuses Universal Music of Boosting a Kendrick Lamar Song
abstract: The Canadian rapper filed legal papers on Monday in New York and Texas accusing his record label of promoting “Not Like Us” ahead of Drake’s tracks.
lead_paragraph: Drake’s war of words with Kendrick Lamar, through a vicious back-and-forth of diss tracks, generated some of the biggest headlines in rap this year.
