abstract: While there were limited signs of life in the area, most residents were hesitant to head back without greater certainty that the cease-fire with Hezbollah would hold.
lead_paragraph: A truck was transporting an Israeli tank returned from Lebanon. Residents were visiting their damaged homes near the border for the first time in a year. Israeli soldiers were bathing in a natural hot spring in the rain, in an area where sirens screamed the previous night.

headline: Rain Expected at Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade
abstract: Over half an inch of rain could accumulate throughout Thursday in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Spectators attending Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade on Thursday can expect light, steady rain throughout the event, according to the National Weather Service.

headline: Thousands Stream Homeward as Fragile Peace Begins in Lebanon
abstract: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah began on Wednesday, but much hardship and uncertainty lie ahead after a yearlong war that killed thousands and left widespread destruction in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of civilians began the journey back to their war-ravaged, mostly abandoned communities around Beirut and in southern Lebanon on Wednesday, as a U.S.-backed cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah took tenuous hold after more than 13 months of bloodshed.

headline: What We Know About the Cease-Fire in Lebanon
abstract: The truce began Wednesday, bringing a fragile peace to Israel and Lebanon. Israeli troops are to withdraw in phases  from southern Lebanon, and Lebanese military convoys headed south to protect the peace.
lead_paragraph: A cease-fire agreement to end the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon went into effect on Wednesday morning, bringing a fragile peace to an area that has seen more than a year of fighting.

headline: Robert Dixon, Last Surviving Buffalo Soldier, Dies at 103
abstract: A member of one of the U.S. Army’s all-Black regiments, formed after the Civil War, he trained West Point cadets in horsemanship during World War II.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Robert W. Dixon Sr., the last known survivor of the U.S. Army’s all-Black regiments known as Buffalo Soldiers, died on Nov. 15 near Albany, N.Y. He was 103.

headline: Thousands of Lebanese Head South as a Fragile Peace Begins
abstract: Also, Trump picked an envoy for Russia and Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Roads heading south of Beirut were packed with bumper-to-bumper traffic today as thousands of people returned to war-ravaged towns. The movement came as a cease-fire began to take effect between Israel and Hezbollah after more than 13 months of bloodshed.

headline: Schools in Gaza Bombed During Cease-Fire in Lebanon
abstract: Gazans searched through the rubble after an Israeli strike hit two schools serving as shelters for the displaced.
lead_paragraph: Gazans searched through the rubble after an Israeli strike hit two schools serving as shelters for the displaced.

headline: Sean Combs Is Denied Bail a Third Time
abstract: A federal judge ruled against the music mogul’s efforts to be released from jail while he awaits trial on sex trafficking and racketeering charges.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the embattled music mogul who has been charged with sex trafficking and racketeering, was denied bail again on Wednesday after a federal judge rejected his lawyers’ third attempt to challenge his detention.

headline: Lebanese and Israelis Return to Their Homes Following Cease-Fire
abstract: Ramez Hassan Boustany checked on his home in the southern suburbs of Beirut following the cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah. In northern Israel, Amichay Bitton surveyed the damage on his parents’ property.
lead_paragraph: Ramez Hassan Boustany checked on his home in the southern suburbs of Beirut following the cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hezbollah. In northern Israel, Amichay Bitton surveyed the damage on his parents’ property.

headline: Youth Pastor Charged With Nearly 200 Sex Crimes Going Back Decades
abstract: Many of the victims were the West Virginia pastor’s relatives, the police said, including five nieces who filed a complaint against him in 2004.
lead_paragraph: The state police in West Virginia are continuing to investigate a longtime youth pastor who has now been charged with nearly 200 counts of sexual abuse crimes involving children, many of them his relatives, dating back more than three decades.

headline: F.T.C. Launches Antitrust Investigation Into Microsoft
abstract: Regulators are demanding information from the company on its cloud computing, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity products.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has opened an investigation into whether Microsoft has violated antitrust law in multiple segments of its wide-ranging business, according to two people familiar with the inquiry, the latest salvo in a battle by the government to rein in the most powerful tech companies.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Detective Is Charged With Making ‘Ghost Guns’
abstract: Anthony Sciortino, a detective in Staten Island, was also charged with falsifying police records in what prosecutors said was a “brazen act of misconduct.”
lead_paragraph: A New York City police detective has been arrested and accused of amassing a small arsenal of unregistered firearms, prosecutors said.

headline: John Fetterman Wants Democrats to Stop Freaking Out
abstract: “Buckle up and pack a lunch, because it’s going to be four years of this,” the Democratic senator from Pennsylvania said.
lead_paragraph: Senator John Fetterman wasn’t in Washington for the first Trump administration. But he has a few ideas about how Democrats should handle the second.

headline: A Year of War Transformed Hezbollah
abstract: Israel has decimated Hezbollah’s senior leadership and military infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: Wars have a transformative impact on the parties that fight them. That was certainly the case the last time Israel and Hezbollah engaged in all-out conflict back in July 2006. Hezbollah emerged from that fight — which lasted just over a month — battered but defiant after standing up to the most powerful military in the Middle East. That experience, along with Iranian support, set Hezbollah up to make significant strides militarily and politically in the years that followed, transforming it into a transnational organization equipped with an estimated 150,000 rockets and missiles while also being represented by lawmakers in Lebanon’s Parliament.

headline: U.S. Border Agents Seize 3,000 Fake Gibson Guitars
abstract: They would have been worth nearly $18 million if they were genuine, making it the largest counterfeit instrument seizure in history, officials said.
lead_paragraph: At a glance, the Gibson guitars look like some of the most coveted six-stringed instruments in the world, including signature models played by Dave Grohl that sell for up to $10,000 and some that looked as if they had been autographed by Slash.

headline: ‘Queer’ Review: The Seductive, Damaged Charm of Daniel Craig
abstract: The star kills off his Bond to inhabit a dissolute American expat in Luca Guadagnino’s handsome adaptation of the William S. Burroughs novella.
lead_paragraph: When William Lee stalks through Mexico City in “Queer,” he often seems on high alert, though sometimes he’s just high. The louche protagonist in Luca Guadagnino’s soft-serve adaptation of the William S. Burroughs autobiographical novella, Lee is a smoker, drinker, heroin addict and epic storyteller. He’s a refugee from America who at times seems like a visitor from another dimension. Played with sensitivity and predatory heat by Daniel Craig, Lee has a feverish mind, eyes like searchlights and a mouth that’s quick to sneer. There are moments when he seems possessed, though it’s not often clear what’s taken hold of his soul.

headline: Jim Abrahams, 80, Dies; a Mastermind of ‘Airplane!’ and ‘Naked Gun’
abstract: Along with his fellow filmmakers David and Jerry Zucker, he revolutionized film comedy with a straight-faced, fast-paced style of parody.
lead_paragraph: Jim Abrahams, who with the brothers David and Jerry Zucker surely comprised one of the funniest trios of comedy writers in film history, layering on the yucks in classics like “Airplane!” and “The Naked Gun,” died on Tuesday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 80.

headline: How Will Trump’s Covid Contrarians Handle the Next Pandemic?
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s selections to run the nation’s health agencies are alarming infectious disease experts.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump had already succeeded in rattling the nation’s public health and biomedical establishment by the time he announced on Tuesday that he had picked Dr. Jay Bhattacharya to run the National Institutes of Health. But amid growing fears of a deadly bird flu pandemic, perhaps no one was more rattled than experts in infectious disease.

headline: Mexico’s President and Trump Describe a Positive Talk but Differ on Migration Details
abstract: The discussion between President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico and the president-elect came after Mr. Trump threatened tariffs unless Mexican authorities stopped migrants and drugs from coming across the border.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum, spoke to President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday afternoon, and both later characterized their discussion as positive while providing different descriptions of what Mexico is doing to stave off a potential tariff war.

headline: E.U. Vessels Surround Anchored Chinese Ship After Baltic Sea Cables Are Severed
abstract: Multiple countries are investigating and the authorities in Europe say they have not ruled out sabotage. But U.S. intelligence officials have assessed that the cables were not cut deliberately.
lead_paragraph: For more than a week, a Chinese commercial ship has apparently been forced to anchor in the Baltic Sea, surrounded and monitored by naval and coast guard vessels from European countries as the authorities attempt to unravel a maritime mystery.

headline: Ohio Governor Signs Bathroom Restrictions for Transgender Students
abstract: The state is one of at least a dozen states to set restrictions on bathrooms for transgender students at public schools.
lead_paragraph: Transgender students in Ohio, from kindergarten through college, will be prohibited from using bathrooms that align with their gender identity after Gov. Mike DeWine, a Republican, signed a bill on Wednesday imposing the restrictions. Ohio is among at least a dozen states in recent years to adopt laws setting restrictions on bathrooms for transgender students at public schools.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Meets With Trump at Mar-a-Lago
abstract: The president-elect has long been critical of Mr. Zuckerberg’s social media platforms, saying they censor conservative viewpoints.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg met on Wednesday with President-elect Donald J. Trump in a rare face-to-face encounter, the latest attempt by the Meta chief executive to establish a positive rapport with Mr. Trump.

headline: What the Cease-Fire Tells Us About Hezbollah
abstract: Hezbollah has entered a cease-fire with Israel. Ben Hubbard, an international correspondent for The New York Times, explains how 13 months of war left Hezbollah weakened, isolated and desperate for a way to stop the fighting in Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah has entered a cease-fire with Israel. Ben Hubbard, an international correspondent for The New York Times, explains how 13 months of war left Hezbollah weakened, isolated and desperate for a way to stop the fighting in Lebanon.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 28, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the Democratic Party’s efforts to regain momentum in Southern battleground states, misidentified the college at which Laken Riley was enrolled at the time of her death. She was attending Augusta University, not the University of Georgia.

headline: Syrian Rebel Groups Launch Largest Offensive in Years
abstract: Scores of people were killed after forces opposed to the government of President Bashar al-Assad overtook a Syrian military base, a monitoring group reported.
lead_paragraph: Syrian opposition forces have launched an offensive in a western Aleppo district that has killed at least 89 people and overtaken a Syrian military base, a monitoring group based in Britain reported on Wednesday.

headline: Pitcher for the Reds
abstract: Ricky J. Sirois piles on.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Appeals Court Again Blocks U.S. From Cutting Texas Border Wire Along Rio Grande
abstract: The injunction is the second time that the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has sided with Texas in a yearlong dispute over barbed wire around the city of Eagle Pass.
lead_paragraph: For the second time, a federal appeals court has limited the Biden administration’s authority to cut barbed wire that Texas authorities have erected along the country’s southern border to deter migrants from crossing into the United States.

headline: As Plastic Talks Continue, a Reminder of What We’re All Exposed To
abstract: As international talks continue this week, a dozen U.N. officials reveal scientists tracked their exposure to many chemicals found in plastics.
lead_paragraph: The wristbands look like those you might find at a souvenir shop: bendy loops of silicone, in the color of your choice. But scientists are increasingly using the bands to measure exposure to toxic chemicals present in the air around us and in everyday items we use, including personal care products.

headline: Quote of the Day: The Race to Build A Sun on Earth
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “The Wright brothers, with basically the tools of a bicycle repair shop, could put together the technology that could fly. You can’t quite do that with fusion.”

headline: London’s 850-Year-Old Smithfield Meat Market Is Set to Close
abstract: The historic site in Britain’s capital has been a market for centuries. The local authority voted this week to close it.
lead_paragraph: For 22 years, John Burt has cut and trimmed steaks, chops and roasts in a butcher shop across the street from Smithfield, the oldest meat market in London. In that time, he said, he has watched the market’s slow decline, from a carnivore’s bustling bazaar to a hulking relic of an earlier London.

headline: These Exams Mean Everything in India. Thieves See a Gold Mine.
abstract: In a country where government jobs are highly coveted, the tests that govern hiring are a lucrative target for criminal gangs.
lead_paragraph: The call arrived — it was go time. The medical doctor rushed to the airport, bound for a midnight operation hundreds of miles away in western India.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: The first day of a truce between Hezbollah and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of civilians began to return to war-ravaged communities around Beirut and in southern Lebanon yesterday, as a U.S.-backed cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah took tenuous hold after more than 13 months of bloodshed. About one-quarter of Lebanon’s more than five million people had been forced from their homes by the war.

headline: China Is on a Quest for the Holy Grail of Meat. Let’s Hope It Succeeds.
abstract: China’s push to develop alternative proteins is not a threat to America. It’s good for the planet.
lead_paragraph: In late September, 11 Republican members of Congress wrote to the directors of national intelligence and the Department of Agriculture’s Office of Homeland Security to warn of the latest threat emerging in China. They said China seeks to become the world leader in production of meat alternatives — part of a “targeted attempt to dominate global food supply chains” that could pose an urgent threat to the food security of the United States and its allies.

headline: This Maverick Thinker Is the Karl Marx of Our Time
abstract: Wolfgang Streeck has a convincing theory of what has gone wrong with globalization.
lead_paragraph: Who could have seen Donald Trump’s resounding victory coming? Ask the question of an American intellectual these days and you may meet with embittered silence. Ask a European intellectual and you will likely hear the name of Wolfgang Streeck, a German sociologist and theorist of capitalism.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Putrid Flowers
abstract: Can you prevent your spouse from growing a plant that (occasionally) smells like a rotting corpse?
lead_paragraph: Jilian writes: I have a voodoo lily bulb that I wish to grow in our home. It’s basically a miniature corpse flower: Every three to four years, it will bloom and smell like rotting meat for two days. It’s a wonder of nature, but my husband objects. I say being his life partner has obliged me to put up with a variety of bad smells, so he owes me.

headline: Seth Meyers Wishes You a Happy Frozen-Pizza Thanksgiving
abstract: Meyers tried out a few catchphrases for DiGiorno’s seasonal offering, while Jimmy Fallon suggested some last-minute Turkey Day substitutions.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: India’s Exam Leaks Underline the Nation’s Bigger Problem
abstract: The economy has failed to create enough good jobs, so a government post appeals to far more people than there are openings, fueling desperation.
lead_paragraph: India has been rocked by multiple scandals involving leaked exams this year, and the country’s government has scrambled to contain the fallout each time.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: The M.T.A.’s New Subway Boss Says He’s Here to Stay
abstract: For a decade, the M.T.A. has not retained a city transit president for longer than three years. Now a 27-year veteran of the authority is taking the job.
lead_paragraph: As a child, Demetrius Crichlow noticed that his father’s palms were often stained black with grease after long days as a train car repairman in New York City’s transit system.

headline: What to Know About a Possible Federal Takeover of Rikers Island
abstract: A judge found New York City in contempt of an agreement meant to improve jail conditions, setting the stage for a receivership.
lead_paragraph: New York City could lose control over its jails after a federal judge on Wednesday said that it had failed to improve conditions at the notoriously dangerous Rikers Island complex.

headline: This 22-Foot Turkey Roosts in a Region of Roadside Giants
abstract: Big Tom is a beloved landmark in his Minnesota hometown. Across the Midwest, small places take pride in having the largest of just about anything.
lead_paragraph: The most celebrated resident of Frazee, Minn., is 22 feet tall and is known to his friends simply as Big Tom. He lives alone just off Highway 10, past the metal barns but before the railroad tracks, where admirers show up seeking photos at all hours of the day.

headline: After Stowaway Found, Delta Investigates Flight From New York to Paris
abstract: A passenger went through security screening but avoided identity and boarding pass checks before flying out of the United States, a T.S.A. representative said.
lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines said it had opened an investigation after the pilot of a flight that landed in Paris on Wednesday announced that the police were boarding his plane because it was carrying an extra passenger.

headline: What I Wish Someone Had Told Me About Motherhood
abstract: The uncertainty before making a decision about having kids is the hardest part.
lead_paragraph: In the early months after my daughter was born, I thought it was surely the hormones surging through my body that made me, someone who had never been interested in babies, find my daughter’s every move endlessly fascinating. At some point the hormones would quiet, the fascination would diminish, and I would return to my prior self.

headline: Poems About Dead Relatives Irk Billy Collins
abstract: “If I come across ‘Dad’ or ‘Mommy,’ I’m out,” says the former U.S. poet laureate. “‘Grandma’ gets a pass.” His new collection is “Water, Water.”
lead_paragraph: Have you ever gotten into trouble for reading a book?

headline: The U.S. Is Building an Early Warning System to Detect Geoengineering
abstract: Balloon launches from around the world are part of a new kind of global alarm system: One that can detect if another country tries to dim the sun.
lead_paragraph: In a guarded compound at the foot of the Rockies, government scientists are working on a new kind of global alarm system: One that can detect if another country, or maybe just an adventurous billionaire, tries to dim the sun.

headline: Is That Turkey Still Good?
abstract: Here’s how to extend the life of your Thanksgiving leftovers — without getting sick.
lead_paragraph: Q: I enjoy Thanksgiving leftovers even more than the meal on the big day. How long are they safe to eat?

headline: Hamas Faces a Future Without Its Most Important Ally
abstract: Israel’s offensive against Hezbollah and the cease-fire to stop the fighting in Lebanon have left Hamas increasingly isolated.
lead_paragraph: Hamas has long believed that a wider war in the Middle East would help deliver the organization a victory in its war with Israel.

headline: Frequent Fliers Are Rethinking Loyalty Programs and Setting Themselves Free
abstract: Some travelers, frustrated with changing airline rewards programs, have stopped chasing status and adopted different strategies when booking flights and using credit cards.
lead_paragraph: When SuzAnn Brantner moved to Indiana from Los Angeles during the coronavirus pandemic, she had been a longtime Delta Air Lines frequent flier, achieving the highest loyalty status the airline offered: Diamond Medallion. The benefits included expedited security screenings, priority boarding and top preference for complimentary first-class upgrades.

headline: Trading the Formal Wedding Feast for a Food Truck
abstract: To encourage more partying — or save space and money — some couples are abandoning the sit-down dinner.
lead_paragraph: Sit-down meals, many of which are multicourse affairs with exhaustively planned seating arrangements, have long been a cornerstone of the wedding reception.

headline: Republicans Built an Ecosystem of Influencers. Some Democrats Want One, Too.
abstract: Democrats were badly outflanked online in the election, and progressive influencers are now trying to create networks to be a left-wing answer to Turning Point USA.
lead_paragraph: Zackory Kirk, an influencer based in Atlanta who goes by the name The Zactivist and has more than 220,000 followers on Instagram, TikTok and other platforms, has been churning out mostly progressive content for more than four years.

headline: Cher: A Visual Dictionary
abstract: The things that make Cher Cher.
lead_paragraph: It takes nothing away from her voice to say that Cher is a singer for whom the visuals matter. A lot.

headline: ‘Beatles ’64’ Review: They Wanted to Hold Their Hands
abstract: This documentary, directed by David Tedeschi, comes up with a solid compendium of the band’s arcana from their first trip to the United States, when fans went wild.
lead_paragraph: Few cultural events of the 20th century have withstood as much scrutiny as the Beatles’ first trip to the United States, but the documentary “Beatles ’64,” directed by David Tedeschi, a frequent collaborator of Martin Scorsese’s, comes up with a solid compendium of Beatlemania arcana.

headline: ‘Nutcrackers’ Review: Christmas With a Crank
abstract: Ben Stiller stars in a tonally bumpy comedy with genre roots in Hallmark territory.
lead_paragraph: If you tilt your head and squint, “Nutcrackers” resembles a Hallmark movie, though it certainly is not one. Michael (Ben Stiller), a big-city real estate guy, is on the verge of closing the deal of a lifetime when he’s called away from Chicago to rural Ohio. There, his estranged sister and her husband have died tragically, leaving behind four feral nephews to whom he is now technically guardian. He intends to stay just long enough to get them placed in foster homes, but mischief of all kinds ensues. Also, Christmas is in three weeks. You can see where this is going.

headline: ‘Reinas’ Review: Memories of Lima
abstract: The political turmoil of Peru in the 1990s serves as the backdrop for this intimate domestic drama about growing up and learning to let go.
lead_paragraph: To this day, political violence continues to be an issue in Peru, though the ‘80s and ’90s — when the Maoist guerrilla movement Shining Path waged bloody conflicts against the Peruvian government before being crushed by President Alberto Fujimori — are considered the country’s rock-bottom.

headline: ‘Sweethearts’ Review: Friends Without Benefits
abstract: Two college freshmen conspire to simultaneously dump their exes in Jordan Weiss’s unremarkable debut feature.
lead_paragraph: Bright, breezy and requiring little in the way of close attention, the teen rom-com “Sweethearts” is perfect for those who prefer their movies to be barely more than background noise. Otherwise, the lame plotting (by Dan Brier and Jordan Weiss, who also directs) and lack of jokes soon become painfully obvious.

headline: Expensive ZIP Codes Have Something in Common
abstract: It’s beaches and water (and sometimes snow), according to a study that analyzed median list prices in every state.
lead_paragraph: For years, celebrities and tech titans have flocked to Atherton, Calif., a suburb in the heart of Silicon Valley. Given the town’s ultrawealthy residents, it may come as no surprise that Atherton is where one finds the most expensive ZIP code in the United States based on home prices, according to a study by RealtyHop.

headline: 36 Hours in Honolulu
abstract: Explore lush forest trails, midcentury architecture and tropical flavors in Hawaii’s multicultural capital.
lead_paragraph: Explore lush forest trails, midcentury architecture and tropical flavors in Hawaii’s multicultural capital.

headline: For These Two ‘Nutcracker’ Princes, It’s Showtime
abstract: This season, two vivacious boys at the School of American Ballet make their princely debuts in New York City Ballet’s production of “The Nutcracker.”
lead_paragraph: The hellion of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” is a little boy named Fritz who is as naughty as they come. He fights with his sister, Marie; he convinces the boys at a Christmas Eve party to antagonize the girls. And who breaks the Nutcracker doll? Silly question. Wherever Fritz goes, trouble follows.

headline: Grandma Foods
abstract: The comforts of eating like an old person.
lead_paragraph: At times of upheaval, people turn to comfort food. In early Covid, for example, it was the processed foods of childhood — cans of Chef Boyardee or fistfuls of Goldfish crackers.

headline: Holiday Shopping, Up Close and Personal
abstract: The experience of interacting with small business owners at winter markets makes holiday shopping “a little bit more wholesome” for some visitors.
lead_paragraph: Even when Monica Martino was “broke and couldn’t afford anything,” she loved roaming the stalls at New York City’s holiday markets.

headline: Donald Trump Jr. Emerges as a Loyal Enforcer
abstract: His siblings have long retreated from the inner circle, but the president-elect’s eldest son has made a name for himself as the person who can best assess loyalty to the Trump political brand.
lead_paragraph: Ivanka and Jared left the White House behind for a life in Miami. Eric is running the family business. Tiffany got married. Barron is a budding strategist at NYU.

headline: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
abstract: A Shostakovich quartet survey, contemporary choral works and piano music written and performed by Marie Awadis are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: We are spoiled with great recordings of the Shostakovich string quartets, so you might wonder why we need yet another set. It wasn’t until I began listening to these recordings by the Barcelona-based Cuarteto Casals, though, that it dawned on me how similar the playing of most other groups is: biting and hard-edged, bows digging into the strings. Of course, this is part of the music. It’s difficult to imagine even the earliest of Shostakovich’s quartets without some grit in the sound.

headline: My Brother Is Doing the Trump Dance
abstract: Kevin sighs happily and sleeps easily, while I’m holding my breath.
lead_paragraph: I know that every year, some of you see this Thanksgiving column by my brother and think that it is actually I who is serving up this slab of red meat under the nom de plume of Kevin Dowd. I can assure you that Kevin is very real and, this year, very excited. So, caveat emptor: Here is Kevin’s column.

headline: One of Biden’s Closest Allies in Africa Is Ready to Court Trump
abstract: President João Lourenço of Angola has worked hard to strengthen his country’s partnership with the United States and says the recent election won’t derail that.
lead_paragraph: Since taking office seven years ago, President João Lourenço of Angola has cast aside Cold War allegiances and made an aggressive push to draw his southern African nation closer to the United States.

headline: Beans, Beans, Magical Beans
abstract: Could one tiny legume save the planet?
lead_paragraph: In a nation filled with meat lovers, how can we persuade Americans to stop eating animals and help save the planet? The food writer Bee Wilson believes the answer lies with food preferences — specifically, changing them. “It is possible to learn to love new foods, and it’s something transformative and actually joyous,” she says. In this episode, she makes the case for changing your taste for beans, a humble legume that is packed with extraordinary flavor.

headline: Peter Doig Finds the Soul and Menace of a Modernist Gem
abstract: The artist organizes a show of seldom-seen paintings at Gagosian to cast a fresh eye on Balthus’s enigmatic 1933 tableau, “The Street.”

headline: Pajamas Worth a Passport Stamp
abstract: Pajama sets from small European labels have for some become stylish souvenirs that signal their discerning taste.
lead_paragraph: At a time when an abundance of superfake handbags and clothing dupes has made it easier than ever to buy versions of items once considered hard to get, those who value provenance have found a new way to flaunt it: pajamas.

headline: For a Food Writer, Thanksgiving Is a Spot in the Super Bowl Every Year
abstract: Some professionals in the food writing business are spent before Turkey Day arrives. Others feel they can finally cook for themselves.
lead_paragraph: You could say Thanksgiving has been my Super Bowl since I was around 13 years old.

headline: After Five Generations, a Family Gave Back the Treasures in Its Closet
abstract: The descendants of a 19th-century federal official decided to return a prized collection of heirlooms to a descendant of a Lakota leader, Chief Spotted Tail.
lead_paragraph: The beaten-up suitcase had been in the Newell family for more than a century, passed from dusty closet to dusty closet and pulled out every now and then for guests.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in North Bellmore, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Sherman, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, three-bath brick house built in 2016 with an entry foyer, a wood-burning fireplace, a den, a formal dining room, an eat-in kitchen with imported Italian Carrara marble countertops and double sinks and dishwashers, an en suite primary bedroom with a gas fireplace and a balcony, a laundry room, a swimming pool, a hot tub, a covered patio and an attached garage, on 0.21 acres. Judith Marino, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-353-6223; danielgale.com

headline: Psychedelic Traces Found on Mug From Ancient Egypt
abstract: Egyptians may have used hallucinogenic substances as part of a fertility rite, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: Something in the printout caught Branko van Oppen de Ruiter’s eye. He was at home in the Netherlands, working remotely for his new employer, the Tampa Museum of Art, which had named him a curator of Greek and Roman exhibits. The coronavirus had delayed his move to Florida, so he did what he could studying the museum’s collections from afar.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in Chelsea, on the Upper East Side and on the Grand Concourse.
lead_paragraph: A studio apartment with exposed brick, a galley kitchen, a mirrored dining nook, ample closets and built-in shelving, on the second floor of a six-story, cat-friendly prewar building with a virtual intercom, a live-in super and basement storage cages. Ben Jacobs, Jessica Chestler and Benjamin Goldman, Douglas Elliman, 917-887-3922; elliman.com

headline: A Fossil Gets Its Name From a Revived Indigenous Language
abstract: After scientists found an extinct burrowing amphibian on Eastern Shoshone land, members of the tribe gave it a name in their language.
lead_paragraph: At age 6, Reba Teran lost the ability to speak her language. Like many Indigenous students in the 20th century, she attended schools where any language other than English was forbidden.

headline: The Great Gags From ‘Airplane!’ and More
abstract: With the death of Jim Abrahams, one third of the Zucker-Abrahams-Zucker writing and directing trio, a look at some of the funniest moments from their key films.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost hard to believe that at one point Leslie Nielsen was thought of as a serious actor who was an odd choice to play a comic role like the deadpan doctor in the disaster movie spoof “Airplane!”

headline: Celebrating the Art Movement That Wasn’t
abstract: “Harmony & Dissonance” at the Guggenheim Museum is a  mood-lifting, masterpiece-studded show that offers an in-depth look at Orphism, which is famous for being unknown.
lead_paragraph: Orphism has always seemed less like an art movement than a spinoff of cubism that flourished and fizzled in short order. Founded in Paris with the supposed goal of infusing the dun-hued planes of cubism with rapturous color, it failed to produce a manifesto or so much as a single scandal. Although the movement was named by Guillaume Apollinaire, the omnipresent poet and critic — he selected the moniker in tribute to Orpheus, the Greek god of music — it had none of the adhesive power of his other art labels, which include cubism and Surrealism.

headline: Did the World Need a Hot Santa? It Got One Anyway.
abstract: A new series of ads from Target features Kris K., a “weirdly hot” version of the beloved character, continuing a trend of spicing up holiday favorites.
lead_paragraph: In a new Target commercial, a female shopper is expressing shock to someone on the phone over the low price of turkeys when a handsome store employee in a bright red sweater with a popped collar tells her that the deals are, in fact, real.

headline: With Trump Returning and Hezbollah Weakened, Iran Strikes a Conciliatory Tone
abstract: As Iran faces domestic and foreign challenges, its bellicose rhetoric on the United States and Israel has given way to signs that it wants less confrontation.
lead_paragraph: In mid-November, Iran dispatched a top official to Beirut to urge Hezbollah to accept a cease-fire with Israel. Around the same time, Iran’s U.N. ambassador met with Elon Musk, an overture to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inner circle. And on Friday, it will hold talks in Geneva with European countries on a range of issues, including its nuclear program.

headline: She Was the Queen of 90 Million Nightstands
abstract: Barbara Taylor Bradford was a profound part of her readers’ lives.
lead_paragraph: The news that the novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford died on Sunday, at the age of 91, brought me right back to the library my family frequented when I was a kid, where her fat, pastel-colored paperbacks preened from the carousels to the right of the entrance. That’s where the most popular, most commercial books hung out, separated from the quiet dignity of the rest of the place. It was there that my mother would find me come checkout time, surrounded first by tween smut from Sweet Valley High, then by rapes and murders from Mary Higgins Clark, and then by tales of riches, betrayals and come-from-behind triumphs from Barbara Taylor Bradford.

headline: In Brooklyn With $800,000 and Designs on a One-Bedroom. Which Option Was the Right Fit?
abstract: Forced out of their two-bedroom rental by a new landlord, a young couple looked to downsize in Park Slope or Clinton Hill. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: Forced out of their two-bedroom rental by a new landlord, a young couple looked to downsize in Park Slope or Clinton Hill. Here’s what they found.

headline: A Top Chinese Commander Is Suspended Under Suspicion of Corruption
abstract: The case of Adm. Miao Hua suggests the persistence of graft at high levels of the military, despite the efforts by Xi Jinping to stamp out corruption.
lead_paragraph: A senior member of China’s military elite has been suspended from office, under suspicion of “serious violations of discipline,” the Chinese government revealed on Thursday, months after two of the country’s former defense ministers were officially denounced for graft and disloyalty to the Communist Party and its top leader, Xi Jinping.

headline: ‘A Lack of Respect’: Chinese Women Mobilize Against Subpar Sanitary Pads
abstract: An online campaign has prompted major pad manufacturers to apologize. Regulators said they would consider women’s criticisms when writing new standards.
lead_paragraph: When Sabrina Wang, a Chinese university student, saw an online post that claimed that manufacturers of sanitary pads had been cheating women, selling them pads that were significantly shorter than advertised, she decided to measure her own. She was shocked to find that all three brands she had at home were shorter than labeled, by as much as 17 percent.

headline: In the Kitchen With Ina Garten
abstract: Michael Barbaro, host of “The Daily,” visited the legendary cook at her home in East Hampton, N.Y., for a Thanksgiving meal.
lead_paragraph: Michael Barbaro, host of “The Daily,” visited the legendary cook at her home in East Hampton, N.Y., for a Thanksgiving meal.

headline: Thanksgiving With Ina Garten
abstract: The Barefoot Contessa shared simple tips on the art of hosting for this special episode of “The Daily.”
lead_paragraph: Leading up to Thanksgiving, we took a trip to the home of Ina Garten, the iconic cookbook author and TV star. For one glorious afternoon, she gave us a master class on the art of hosting. She answered our questions big and small — seating arrangements, whether to have bread at the table, what to do with that difficult relative, how to zest correctly. Plus, she walked us through two of her go-to holiday recipes, which turned out to be simpler than we expected. Listen to the episode below, and explore some of her recipes.

headline: Lebanon Cease-Fire Appears to Hold Despite Israeli Strike
abstract: Israel said it had targeted militants headed to a rocket facility, but neither Israel nor Hezbollah seemed keen to immediately return to full-scale fighting.
lead_paragraph: The uneasy truce between Israel and the militant group Hezbollah largely held through its second day in Lebanon on Thursday, although Israel conducted an airstrike that it said targeted militants violating terms of the cease-fire deal.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 537
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Nov. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,259
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Nov. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Russia Launches Huge Bombardment of Ukraine and Signals More to Come
abstract: Ukraine said the attacks targeted energy infrastructure. President Vladimir V. Putin said they were retaliation for Kyiv’s use of long-range American missiles.
lead_paragraph: Russia attacked Ukrainian energy infrastructure with missiles and drones on Thursday, in what President Vladimir V. Putin said was retaliation for Kyiv’s hitting Russian territory with long-range American missiles.

headline: A Holiday Tradition
abstract: We’re covering Thanksgiving arguments past.
lead_paragraph: Things have gotten so bad, we are told, that the Thanksgiving table is now a battlefield. Advice columnists, psychologists, therapists, podcasters and philosophers counsel us how to avoid or defuse arguments about politics.

headline: Books About Everyone, for Everyone
abstract: First Book’s work is an antidote to book bans. It makes diverse books more accessible to students, teachers and libraries.
lead_paragraph: Book banning is on the rise in the United States. A growing number of communities are trying to take reading choices out of the hands of children and families by declaring some books off limits. At least 220 public school districts imposed bans last school year on more than 4,200 books, according to PEN America. The targets of those bans are often books that feature people of color or people who are not heterosexual or books that deal with difficult subjects like sexual violence and substance abuse.

headline: Australia Has Barred Everyone Under 16 From Social Media. Will It Work?
abstract: The law sets a minimum age for users of platforms like TikTok, Instagram and X. How the restriction will be enforced online remains an open question.
lead_paragraph: Australia has imposed a sweeping ban on social media for children under 16, one of the world’s most comprehensive measures aimed at safeguarding young people from potential hazards online. But many details were still unclear, such as how it will be enforced and what platforms will be covered.

headline: How Australia Will (or Won’t) Keep Children Off Social Media
abstract: Critics say big questions remain not only about how the new law will be enforced, but also about whether the ban will really protect young people.
lead_paragraph: Australia has passed a law to prevent children under 16 from creating accounts on social media platforms.

headline: San Jose State’s Opponent Boycotts Game Over Transgender Player. Again.
abstract: The women’s volleyball team at the center of a national debate over gender and sports advanced to the conference championship after Boise State refused to play.
lead_paragraph: The San Jose State University Spartans women’s volleyball team, which is at the center of a national debate over the inclusion of transgender women in women’s sports, advanced to its conference championship on Saturday without having played a single game in the tournament.

headline: Crowds Turn Out for Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade Despite Rain
abstract: About two dozen protesters briefly disrupted the procession near 55th Street and were taken into custody, the police said.
lead_paragraph: They stood in inches-deep puddles on street corners, heedless of soaked feet. They huddled under garbage-bags-turned-raincoats, and sodden umbrellas — but everyone was smiling.

headline: Her Wrestling Empire Was Said to Harm Children. Trump Chose Her for Education.
abstract: Linda McMahon, whose résumé mainly rests on running World Wrestling Entertainment, has faced questions for years over whether she is suitable for important education posts.
lead_paragraph: Appointees to the State Board of Education usually sail through the confirmation process in Connecticut’s House of Representatives, but a 2009 choice, Linda E. McMahon, drew intense pushback.

headline: Maps Pinpoint Where Democrats Lost Ground Since 2020 in 11 Big Cities
abstract: A Times analysis shows where Kamala Harris got fewer votes compared with Joe Biden and which voting blocs drove each city’s red shift.
lead_paragraph: A Times analysis shows where Kamala Harris got fewer votes compared with Joe Biden and which voting blocs drove each city’s red shift.

headline: Kendrick Lamar’s Never-Ending Battles
abstract: The Los Angeles rapper returns with his (surprise) sixth album, itching to escape his Drake drama, but still benefiting from it.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Kendrick Lamar released his sixth album, “GNX,” with no advance notice, unless you count the heavy anticipation that has been hovering around him since the apex of his battle with Drake earlier this year. A squabble over hip-hop ethics became a cultural touchstone, leaving Lamar with a No. 1 hit and Drake with spiritual and professional bruises.

headline: Who Might Be the Next Chair of the Democratic Party?
abstract: The current leader of the Democratic National Committee, Jaime Harrison, won’t seek re-election. His successor will need to revive a distressed party.
lead_paragraph: As the Democratic Party reels from devastating losses — in the presidential contest, the race to control the Senate and its bid to regain control of the House — its national committee is searching for a new chair. Whoever lands that critical role will be charged with shepherding the party out of the woods and into a new era.

headline: How a Women’s College Volleyball Team Became the Center of the Transgender Athlete Debate
abstract: Not since the swimmer Lia Thomas has a college athlete or team put the fiercely contested issue of transgender rights in sports under such a bright spotlight.
lead_paragraph: On the court, they seem like any other college women’s volleyball team. At a recent game, the players moved around the court in staccato rhythm, setting and spiking the ball, springing into the air like pogo sticks to block attacking shots, all in their blue and gold uniforms of the San Jose State University Spartans.

headline: How to Cook Today
abstract: Quick-fire answers to common turkey questions, and a cranberry grilled cheese to keep you going. You’ve got this.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I have a lot of Thanksgiving rules. One of them is no appetizers.

headline: Restoring Faith in Public Health Messaging
abstract: Responses to an essay about how health authorities could better communicate with the public. Also: Trump donors; teaching students; the Pink House; hate groups.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Yunchan Lim, a Piano Star at 20, Casts Light on Chopin
abstract: Performing with the New York Philharmonic and Kazuki Yamada, Lim played Chopin’s F minor Concerto with imperturbable calm and eloquence.
lead_paragraph: David Geffen Hall is very nearly sold out for the New York Philharmonic’s performances this Friday, Saturday and Sunday. So jump, if you can, at the vanishing chance to hear Yunchan Lim play Chopin’s Piano Concerto in F minor.

headline: What a Deadly Offensive in Syria Means for a Stalled Civil War
abstract: Rebel groups have launched the largest offensive in years against government forces in the northwest.
lead_paragraph: Syrian opposition fighters have made their most significant advance in years against government forces, heating up a civil war that had long been at a stalemate.

headline: Ukraine Faces Power Outages as Russia Targets Energy Infrastructure
abstract: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin said the attacks were a response to Ukraine’s hitting Russian territory with U.S.-made long-range missiles last week.
lead_paragraph: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin said the attacks were a response to Ukraine’s hitting Russian territory with U.S.-made long-range missiles last week.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Otherworldly high school romances anchor two of our recommended books this week, both of which feature lonely boys who are besotted with and mystified by the objects of their affection. In Haruki Murakami’s “The City and Its Uncertain Walls,” the beloved is a girl from a walled-in dream city, where she works at the library; in Charles Burns’s graphic novel “Final Cut,” she is the alien-generated replica of the narrator’s fetching friend. Young love!

headline: Veggie Recipe Matchmaker, Part 1
abstract: “Together we have the dietary restrictions from hell.” “I said I’d bring a ‘tasty salad’ but I have zero ideas for making that happen.” Let’s get it.
lead_paragraph: It’s Thanksgiving. It’s Recipe Matchmaker. We’re going long today to 1) cover as many requests as possible and 2) give you an excuse to take a few extra minutes for yourself among all of the holiday hoopla. Grateful for you! Let’s get it.

headline: Two South Asian Neighbors, Once Friendly, Are Now at Bitter Odds
abstract: India and Bangladesh have traded angry accusations about Bangladesh’s Hindu minority.
lead_paragraph: Months of simmering tension between India and Bangladesh erupted into the open this week, as the once-friendly neighbors exchanged angry accusations after the arrest of a Hindu priest in Bangladesh on charges of sedition.

headline: British Fan of ‘Homeland’ Series Is Convicted of Spying for Iran
abstract: Daniel Khalife also pleaded guilty to an escape from a London jail, strapped underneath a truck with a sling made of trousers, that embarrassed the British authorities.
lead_paragraph: After he escaped from a London jail last year, strapped by a sling made from trousers to the underside of a food-delivery truck, Daniel Khalife spent three days on the run, evading a nationwide manhunt launched by Britain’s embarrassed authorities.

headline: Romania Court Orders a Recount After Surprise Election Result
abstract: A top court issued the ruling just days after an ultranationalist outsider unexpectedly won the most votes in the first round of presidential elections held Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Political turmoil deepened in Romania on Thursday after the country’s top court called for a recount of all the ballots cast in the first round of a presidential election, just days after a little-known ultranationalist won the most votes.

headline: Footprints Suggest Different Human Relatives Lived Alongside One Another
abstract: A discovery in northern Kenya hints that two extinct species that were our ancient relatives shared the same habitat and possibly interacted.
lead_paragraph: A million and a half years ago, amid giant storks and the ancestors of antelopes, two extinct relatives of humans walked along the same muddy lakeshore in what is today northern Kenya, new research suggests.

headline: Yiddish Is a Supposedly Dying Language That’s Thrillingly Alive
abstract: Yiddish, the heart of some communities, is always fascinating.
lead_paragraph: If I tell you that there are languages other than English that someone in America could live a whole life in, which would come to mind? Spanish, maybe? Chinese? Both are spoken in (among many other settings) tight-knit communities that are continually refreshed by new immigration. Pondering a little further, you might think of rural Amish communities that speak dialects of German.

headline: Snow and Rain Disrupt Holiday Travel as Storm Moves Across the Northeast
abstract: More than a foot of snow could accumulate in northern New England, hampering drivers in a record-breaking year for Thanksgiving travel.
lead_paragraph: A snowstorm in the Northeast dumped more than six inches of snow in some areas by Thursday afternoon, while several feet of lake-effect snow were expected in areas along the Great Lakes over the weekend, making Thanksgiving travel dangerous for drivers.

headline: Biden Makes a Final Nantucket Visit as President
abstract: The president made his usual stops, expressing gratitude for progress toward peace in the Middle East and urging Americans to stay hopeful.
lead_paragraph: The president and the first lady made their customary Thanksgiving rounds in Massachusetts on Thursday morning, delivering pumpkin pies to police officers, firefighters and medics on Nantucket and calling members of the armed services, continuing a family tradition they have followed since 1975.

headline: Defense Secretary Takes Control of Plea Deals in War Crimes Cases
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III stripped his appointee of plea deal authority in a memo on Monday, which the Pentagon has not yet made public.
lead_paragraph: After months of wrangling over the legitimacy of a plea deal in the Sept. 11 case, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has stripped a senior official running the war crimes court of her authority to reach settlements in any cases at Guantánamo Bay.

headline: Hiker Survives 50 Days in Canadian Wilderness
abstract: Sam Benastick was found after weeks missing in British Columbia’s frigid Redfern-Keily Provincial Park, and after the official search was called off. The police had feared “this would not be the outcome,” a spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: After 50 days surviving in the remote, frigid wilderness of Canada’s northern Rocky Mountains, a missing hiker was found alive this week, the Canadian authorities announced on Wednesday.

headline: Everyone’s Going to the Book Bar
abstract: A glass of wine, a snack and a new book is about as good as it gets.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I was a voracious reader. I loved to crack open a book first thing in the morning and last thing at night. In second grade, I got in trouble for surreptitiously devouring “The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe” under my desk during other lessons because I couldn’t stand that my class was reading it one chapter at a time.

headline: ‘The Agency’ Is a Slick and Pleasing Spy Drama
abstract: Based on the French show “The Bureau,” the new Showtime series stars Michael Fassbender as a spy who must readjust to life after living undercover.
lead_paragraph: Pity the C.I.A. agents deploying their enhanced interrogation techniques, beating hostages and meddling; truly it is they who suffer. It’s hard work being a spy — but the hardest work of all is loving yourself.

headline: ‘Nobody Won’: Residents of a Lebanese City Return to Rubble and Sorrow
abstract: Tens of thousands of people who had fled the city of Baalbek returned to bombed-out restaurants, flattened apartment buildings and many of the dead still buried under the rubble.
lead_paragraph: Hammers clanged against brick and metal as the residents of Baalbek set to work repairing their homes, desperate to restart their lives again.

headline: Friday Briefing: Day 2 of Lebanon’s Cease-fire
abstract: Plus, the gangs stealing hiring exams in India.
lead_paragraph: The uneasy truce between Israel and Hezbollah largely held through its second day in Lebanon yesterday, though Israel conducted an airstrike that it said targeted militants violating terms of the cease-fire deal.

headline: Trump Team’s Rejection of a Transition Deal Adds a Wrinkle to Its Transparency Pledges
abstract: The president-elect’s team said it would disclose its donors’ names and not take donations from foreigners, but it isn’t legally bound to adhere to those promises.
lead_paragraph: The refusal by President-elect Donald J. Trump’s team to sign a transition agreement with the General Services Administration means that, despite the team’s pledges to abide by several transparency customs of presidential handovers, it isn’t legally bound to follow through on its promises.

headline: Peggy Caserta, Who Wrote a Tell-All About Janis Joplin, Dies at 84
abstract: Her Haight-Ashbury clothing store was ground zero for the counterculture. But she was best known for a tawdry book — which she later disavowed — published after Ms. Joplin’s death.
lead_paragraph: Peggy Caserta, whose funky Haight-Ashbury clothing boutique was a magnet for young bohemians and musicians, and who exploited her relationship with Janis Joplin in a much-panned 1973 memoir that she later disavowed, died on Nov. 21 at her home in Tillamook, Ore. She was 84.

headline: The Moral Challenge of Trumpism
abstract: Trumpism represents an alternative value system. The people I regard as upright and admirable MAGA regards as morally disgraceful.
lead_paragraph: I admire Mitt Romney. He is, by all accounts, an outstanding husband and father. He built a successful investment firm by supporting successful young businesses like Staples. He served the public as head of the 2002 Winter Olympics and as a governor. As a senator, he had the courage to vote to convict Donald Trump twice, in the two separate impeachment trials, when few other Republicans did.

headline: Canada Accuses Google of Creating an Ad Tech Monopoly
abstract: The case largely echoes an antitrust action in the United States and seeks to force Google to sell off sections of its online ad business.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s competition authority on Thursday accused Google of abusing its tools for buying and selling online advertising to create a monopoly, and filed a complaint seeking to force the company to sell two of its main advertising technology services.

headline: Why Mexico Is Eliminating Independent Watchdog Agencies
abstract: A vote in the country’s Senate has cleared the way to abolish seven independent organizations that provided oversight on issues such as public information and price fixing.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s Senate on Thursday night passed a sweeping proposal to dissolve several government-financed yet independent watchdog organizations, a move the president and her supporters said would help reduce corruption and waste. Critics have called it a step backward for transparency and regulation.

headline: Art Collector Who Bought a $6 Million Banana Offers to Buy 100,000 More
abstract: The vendor who sold the banana received only a quarter for the fruit. The buyer of the conceptual work has offered his stand a bigger payday, but logistical problems may be in the way.
lead_paragraph: A week after a Chinese cryptocurrency entrepreneur bought an artwork composed of a fresh banana stuck to a wall with duct tape for $6.2 million at auction, the man, Justin Sun, announced a grand gesture on X. He said he planned on purchasing 100,000 bananas — or $25,000 worth of the produce — from the Manhattan stand where the original fruit was sold for 25 cents.

headline: Down for a Ski Trip
abstract: Willa Angel Chen Miller makes her New York Times Crossword debut, in a collaboration with Matthew Stock.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: This Beloved Ginger Ale Is Made With a Dozen Ingredients
abstract: Plus: a California hot spring retreat, an exhibition of Dorothea Rockburne’s artwork and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: The Danish brand Vipp was founded in 1939 with a single design: a waste bin. In the decades since, its product line has expanded to include a full furniture range, lighting and home accessories. In 2014, Vipp opened its first guesthouse, a contemporary prefab cabin near Lake Immeln, in southern Sweden. It now runs nine vacation rentals in Europe and, as of today, is taking reservations for its first in North America, a five-bedroom home in Todos Santos on the Pacific Coast of Mexico’s Baja California peninsula. Sofie Christensen Egelund, the third generation co-owner of Vipp, was introduced to the region by the Mexico City-based architect Pablo Pérez Palacios, who’s behind the property’s design. The 3,800-square-foot home has a rooftop pool and open interiors that highlight natural materials: The walls are made of rammed earth, while window shutters are woven from branches of the local Palo de Arco tree. Furnishings include some of Vipp’s own pieces as well as the brand’s signature kitchen, a modular system with minimalist hardware. Pérez Palacios sees the final space as “an ongoing dialogue between Mexican and Danish design sensibilities.” From $2,500 a night, vipp.com.

headline: Quote of the Day: Georgia Winemakers, Long Tied to Russia, Drift Toward West
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We are not simply selling wine, we are selling our culture.”

headline: Four Decades Later, a Yearbook Prediction Comes to Fruition
abstract: Andrew Gottlieb had a crush on his good friend Steuart Osha. When they reconnected years later, things finally turned romantic.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, Andrew Gottlieb penned a note so long that it covered two pages of Elizabeth Alexandra Steuart Osha’s high school yearbook. In it, he matter-of-factly stated that they would one day get married. Four decades later his prediction came true.

headline: A Union That Was Meant to Be
abstract: The parents of Dr. Hilary Gallin and Joshua Brodie were trying to set them up for months. Little did they know, the couple had already connected.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Hilary Gallin and Joshua Robert Brodie connected on Bumble in January 2023, they quickly realized their parents had been trying to set them up on a date for months.

headline: A Breakup Was Just the Beginning of Their Story
abstract: When Amaiya Davis and Matthew Wynter’s relationship ended abruptly, Ms. Davis blamed it on a cosmic shift, but she never lost hope. “I think part of me always knew we would get back together,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Amaiya Briani Davis thinks she was in the grips of the woolly astrological stage known as “Saturn return” in the spring of 2018. “It’s this period before you turn 30 when a lot of change happens,” she said.

headline: Black Friday Used to Be Fun. Now, Many Shoppers Would Rather Sleep In.
abstract: Lining up early outside stores and hunting for deals was once part of a gratifying Black Friday. It no longer feels that way.
lead_paragraph: For Max Frazier, shopping on Black Friday used to be one of his favorite annual traditions.

headline: It All Started With an Unexpected Hug and a Selfie
abstract: Jeffrey Ballou and Rasheedah Thomas unintentionally memorialized what would become one of the most significant days of their lives.
lead_paragraph: One of Rasheedah Iman Thomas’s most treasured photos is an impromptu selfie she took with a stranger who was a fellow guest at a friend’s birthday party in May 2018.

headline: Killer Whales Hunt and Feast on the Largest Fish On Earth
abstract: Whale sharks are gentle, filter-feeding giants, but orcas in Mexican waters were documented attacking the animals and devouring their livers.
lead_paragraph: Off Baja California in Mexico, a killer whale named after an Aztec emperor is leading his pod on routine takedowns of the largest fish in the sea: whale sharks.

headline: A Dublin Neighborhood at the Sharp End of Ireland’s Election Issues
abstract: In a northeast neighborhood of the capital city, deprivation and affluence exist side-by-side, and many voters feel frustrated by the status quo.
lead_paragraph: On the lamp posts in northeast Dublin, campaign posters are stacked one on top of the next, the faces of prominent politicians and newcomers competing for attention ahead of Ireland’s general election on Friday.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The cease-fire between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: After months of fighter jets and rockets in the skies and explosions erupting on the ground, quiet reigned over much of Lebanon and northern Israel yesterday.

headline: Chinese Court Sentences Journalist to 7 Years in Prison for Espionage
abstract: Dong Yuyu, who has written articles critical of the Communist Party, was arrested in 2022 while having lunch with a Japanese diplomat.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese court sentenced a high-ranking editor and columnist for a major Communist Party newspaper to seven years in prison on espionage charges on Friday. His family said it was punishment for past writings that were critical of the government, as well as a warning to Chinese citizens against engaging with foreigners.

headline: Four Opinion Writers on ‘Wicked’: ‘Women Deserve Rage. We Have a Lot to Be Angry About.’
abstract: A big-budget holiday film with a strong antifascist message? “Wicked” is not what we expected.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Maureen Dowd, Tressie McMillan Cottom and Lydia Polgreen about the new movie “Wicked.”

headline: My Traumatized Dog and I Had Trust Issues
abstract: We needed a steady presence in our lives. Enter Kevin.
lead_paragraph: One morning, leaving for work, I stepped outside the gate of my apartment building and heard a rustle of activity to my left. I turned to see a tiny dog trotting toward me on the sidewalk, looking nervously back at a knot of people who were following and calling out.

headline: How China Became the World’s Largest Car Exporter
abstract: Tariffs from the United States and other countries are unlikely to stop China’s auto export dominance.
lead_paragraph: Tariffs from the United States and other countries are unlikely to stop China’s auto export dominance.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

headline: The Great Opera Tradition Died With Puccini
abstract: A century after his death, the composer of “La Bohème,” “Tosca” and “Madama Butterfly” still dominates the repertoire like no one since.
lead_paragraph: There’s a knock at the door.

headline: Will Hochul’s Political Concerns Put New York’s Climate Goals at Risk?
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul is contending with pressures from environmental advocates and President-elect Donald Trump as she charts a path forward.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, New York passed a sweeping law that promised to drastically reduce emissions and make New York an example for the nation.

headline: Goodbye, Chain Drugstores. Hello, Golf Simulators.
abstract: New York’s retail landscape is changing. But it’s not cheese shops or butchers that are taking over those vacant neighborhood storefronts.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year or so, the commercial real estate industry has made it very easy for me to satisfy an urge I am not sure I will ever have. Within a six- or seven-minute walk from my apartment in Brooklyn, it is now possible to get to two indoor golf simulators — places where the purpose is to successfully whack a ball into a 10-ft screen that delivers digital replicas of famous golf courses and a soul-crushing lineup of metrics about the reach, speed and accuracy of any particular swing.

headline: Can a Court’s ‘Last Resort’ Fix New York City’s Jails?
abstract: A federal judge is likely to employ a rarely used remedy to try to fix longstanding problems in the city’s jails. But it’s not foolproof.
lead_paragraph: Conditions in Alabama’s prison system had been so miserable, for so long, in 1976 that a federal judge took the unusual step of appointing an outside authority to fix them.

headline: The Many Faces of NEETs
abstract: The acronym for young people “not in education, employment or training” has been all over the internet lately. But like Gen Z-ers themselves, the term can be misunderstood.
lead_paragraph: When they aren’t roasting millennials’ outfits or scrolling on TikTok, how are Gen Z-ers spending their time?

headline: Ukraine’s River of Anguish
abstract: Amphibious operations across the Dnipro River at Kherson illustrated the suffering and endurance of Ukrainian forces. A team of Times journalists observed the perilous movements.
lead_paragraph: Late at night, half a dozen Ukrainian infantrymen leaned over a map spread on wooden pallets inside a building. Within an hour they would embark on one of the most dangerous deployments of the war, a nighttime operation across the Dnipro River.

headline: U.S. Zoos Gave a Fortune to Protect Pandas. That’s Not How China Spent It.
abstract: A Times investigation found that zoos knew conservation money went toward apartment buildings and roads. But they wanted to keep displaying pandas, so nobody looked too closely.
lead_paragraph: For decades, American zoos have raised tens of millions of dollars from donors and sent the money to China for the right to host and display pandas. Under U.S. law, those funds were required to be spent protecting pandas in the wild.

headline: An Elegy for Crystal Cove A7, Our Family’s Piece of Paradise
abstract: A one-bedroom vacation condo on St. Thomas was heaven for a writer when she was growing up. But what did the place mean after her parents were gone?
lead_paragraph: The setting for some of my most treasured childhood memories is a one-bedroom condo that stood 75 feet from a white sand beach, overlooking the absurdly blue Caribbean. To my sister and me, it was heaven, with Murphy beds — the coolest gizmos ever — folding down at night and disappearing each day.

headline: Ms. Rachel’s Improbable Journey From Toddler Whisperer to Holiday Toy Story
abstract: Rachel Accurso might be this era’s Mister Rogers, if he had been on YouTube, TikTok and Instagram. Toy companies and publishers all want a piece of the action.
lead_paragraph: About a year and a half ago, Laura Henderson, a toy company executive and 38-year-old mother in Toronto, was at the tail end of maternity leave with her second child. She was bleary-eyed and overwhelmed, as mothers juggling an infant and toddler tend to be, when she started scrolling TikTok and stumbled upon the children’s personality known as Ms. Rachel.

headline: An Apocalyptic Novel Throws Stones at the Glass House of ‘King Lear’
abstract: Julia Armfield’s “Private Rites” is a contemporary reimagining of the Shakespearean tragedy, set in a flooded London.
lead_paragraph: “Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! Rage! Blow!/You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout/Till you have drench’d our steeples,” Shakespeare’s King Lear shouts into the storm after he is spurned by two of his three daughters. Taking his desperate cry as its inspiration, Julia Armfield’s captivating novel “Private Rites” imagines a present city resembling London where storms haven’t just drenched steeples; they’ve drowned entire churches. Amid incessant rain, “narrowing gaps between floodplains,” unstable electrical grids and homes “whose foundations are coming apart,” an architect named Stephen Carmichael is celebrated in lavish coffee-table books for his ingenious, cantilevered structures built in “hillside enclaves … where it is still possible to stroll or drive a car,” hovering above the poor and the rising water levels. Following his death, his three queer adult daughters are left to grapple with his legacy, his divisive will and his “easy cruelty.”

headline: How Online Shoppers Are Trying to Foil ‘Porch Pirates’
abstract: Some people race to grab their packages before thieves can nab them. Others move to buildings with dedicated mailrooms.
lead_paragraph: Good news: Your package has been delivered.

headline: The Price of Being Cool? A Quarter-Billion Dollars.
abstract: The WSA building, a 31-story New York office tower with mysterious financing, has become an improbable hub for artists, designers and influencers.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the canyons of New York’s financial district, there is an office tower that matches the cultural moment, for better and for worse. It might be the first “It” building.

headline: The Heirs of a Despised Draft Dodger Want His Wright Brothers Plane Back
abstract: The Franklin Institute has said a wealthy scion, long vilified for refusing to serve during World War I, gave them a treasured Wright-built plane. His family is challenging that account.
lead_paragraph: The Franklin Institute, a Philadelphia museum dedicated to the study of science, has long said one of its most impressive holdings — a plane built in 1911 by the Wright brothers — was a gift from a man named Grover C. Bergdoll.

headline: Transcendent (and Occasionally Filthy) New Romance Novels
abstract: Our columnist on some recent favorites.
lead_paragraph: Category romances — those slim titles issued every month from themed imprints — are the high-end sports cars of the book world. Impractical luxuries, they’re designed for a single purpose: to go vroom very fast. They’re not always subtle, but when they succeed, they’re absolutely exhilarating.

headline: Margo Martindale Pours It On in ‘The Sticky’
abstract: The esteemed character actress has spent decades enlivening films and series in just a few scenes or episodes. In this new Amazon heist comedy, she is first on the call sheet.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you need a woman who can slit someone’s throat, who can poison someone’s whiskey, who can smash her son’s fingers with a hammer, who can commit armed robbery with precision and glee. Perhaps you are responsible for “The Sticky,” a new Amazon heist comedy, premiering on Dec. 6, and you require an actress who can reliably crash most of a maple tree through the glass doors of a provincial office building.

headline: How the Bonne Maman Advent Calendar Became a Hot Commodity
abstract: More than a year of research and development plus word-of-mouth has kept the French jam company’s calendars in shopping carts.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s the inspired flavors like pear with cocoa nibs or pineapple and yuzu, the affordability ($45) or the cute little jars that can be repurposed to hold spices or jewelry. But out of the many covetable food-based Advent calendars, those from a 53-year-old jam company are the hottest commodity.

headline: Holiday Shopping Season Separates Winning Retailers From Losers
abstract: Consumers are seeking deals and being choosier about their spending in the crucial final weeks of the year, executives say.
lead_paragraph: Shoppers are heading into the Black Friday weekend unsure how wide to open their wallets, retailers say, with many still feeling the squeeze of inflation and also worried that tariffs could make things even more expensive if they wait too long to buy.

headline: Kennedy’s Inheritance: How Addiction and Trauma Shaped a Turbulent Life
abstract: Donald Trump’s pick to be health secretary, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has reached a pinnacle of power after a life of fame and addictions and a career intertwined with conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: In September 1983, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. fell ill on a flight to Rapid City, S.D. The pilot radioed ahead for medics. By dint of his famous name, Mr. Kennedy, then 29 and fresh out of law school, was taken to a V.I.P. room at the airport, where investigators found heroin in his luggage.

headline: Trump May Find Things to Like About Biden’s ‘Horrible’ Foreign Policy
abstract: The world is braced for disruption from the president-elect, but he may find more common ground with President Biden than many assume.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump comes to office with a view of America’s place in the world that is dramatically different from his predecessor’s.

headline: Casting the Cabinet
abstract: The Trump cabinet is mostly complete — at least until the official nomination and confirmation process — and it is quite a picture.
lead_paragraph: People who are casually following the recent announcements from President-elect Donald J. Trump about how he intends to staff the upper ranks of the executive branch could be forgiven for thinking they were reading about a beauty contest, not political appointments. If, during his first administration, Mr. Trump boasted of his generals from “central casting,” now, it seems, he has applied the same principle to the whole shebang.

headline: When Zoos Pay for Endangered Species: Our Correspondent Explains the Risks
abstract: We tracked $86 million in U.S. money that was supposed to go toward panda conservation in China.
lead_paragraph: Pandas are a vulnerable species. American zoos are allowed to fly them in from China and display them to tourists on one condition: They have to prove to federal regulators that they are helping pandas in the wild.

headline: She Was Scratching Her Arms Raw. Would Anything Stop This Itch?
abstract: The attacks came out of nowhere and brought life to a miserable standstill. And she had the scars to prove it.
lead_paragraph: The 62-year-old woman shifted in her seat. The flight to Honolulu was full, the mood a little giddy. The unbroken ocean and sky filled the window. She and her daughter were four hours into the trip from Los Angeles to the wedding of a close family friend; it was going to be a great week. Then, she caught herself scratching lightly at a place on her forearm, just below the crease of her elbow. She lifted her arm to look at the spot. Nothing there. Immediately she was filled with dread.

headline: Death of Cyclist in Paris Lays Bare Divide in Mayor’s War Against Cars
abstract: Paul Varry was run over on a city street in what prosecutors suspect was a deliberate act of road rage, as bikers and drivers choose sides.
lead_paragraph: It sent a shock through Paris, a city striving to transform itself into one of the great cycling metropolises in the world: a bicycle rider, crushed under the wheels of an SUV in a bike lane just a few yards from La Madeleine, the landmark neoclassical church, in what prosecutors suspect was a deliberate act of road rage.

headline: How to Visit Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris
abstract: After a fire shuttered the beloved Gothic landmark for five years, visitor demand is expected to be high once the doors reopen Dec. 8. Here’s how to plan your visit and what to expect.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 8, the doors of Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris are scheduled to reopen to the public after a fire engulfed the beloved structure five years ago.

headline: Will the Markets Check Trump’s Power?
abstract: The president-elect cares about financial markets, our columnist says. That gives investors a restraint on his decisions, even if it’s a tenuous one.
lead_paragraph: The president-elect follows the markets closely. He bragged frequently about how well stocks performed in his first term in office, and said they had boomed this year in anticipation of his return to the White House.

headline: The Churchill of Staten Island
abstract: On the 150th anniversary of Winston Churchill’s birth, Luke Boyd, a Churchill impersonator who lives on Staten Island, will get up at 11 a.m.: “When Sir Winston would have.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll find out how a Winston Churchill impersonator plans to spend Churchill’s 150th birthday. We’ll also meet the new head of New York City Transit, the division of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that runs the subways and buses.

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in Paris
abstract: A one-bedroom with a showcase ceiling in Marais, a lofted three-bedroom apartment on Avenue Frochot, and a three-bedroom unit in the 10th Arrondissement.
lead_paragraph: This one-bedroom, two-bath apartment with thick wood beams crisscrossing the living room ceiling is on the top two floors of a 17th-century building in central Paris.
